It was late--not till Strether had spent an hour upstairs with him (Strether)--that this subject consented to betake himself to doubtful rest. Dinner and the subsequent stroll by moonlight--a dream, on Strether's part, of romantic effects rather prosaically merged in a mere missing of thicker coats--had measurably intervened, and this midnight conference was the result of Waymarsh's having -LRB-when they were free, as he (Strether) put it, of their fashionable friend-RRB- found the smoking-room not quite what he (Strether) wanted, and yet bed what he (Strether) wanted less. His (Strether) most frequent form of words was that he (Strether) knew himself, and they were applied on this occasion to his (Strether) certainty of not sleeping. He (Strether) knew himself well enough to know that he (Strether) should have a night of prowling unless he (Strether) should succeed, as a preliminary, in getting prodigiously tired. If the effort directed to this end involved till a late hour the presence of Strether--consisted, that is, in the detention of the latter for full discourse--there was yet an impression of minor discipline involved for our friend in the picture Waymarsh made as he (friend) sat in trousers and shirt on the edge of his (friend) couch. With his (friend) long legs extended and his (friend) large back much bent, he (friend) nursed alternately, for an almost incredible time, his (friend) elbows and his (friend) beard. He (friend) struck his (friend) visitor as extremely, as almost wilfully uncomfortable; yet what had this been for Strether, from that first glimpse of him (Strether) disconcerted in the porch of the hotel, but the predominant notes. The discomfort was in a manner contagious, as well as also in a manner inconsequent and unfounded; the visitor felt that unless he (visitor) should get used to it--or unless Waymarsh himself should--it would constitute a menace for his (visitor) own prepared, his (visitor) own already confirmed, consciousness of the agreeable. On their first going up together to the room Strether had selected for him (Strether) Waymarsh had looked it over in silence and with a sigh that represented for his (Strether) companion, if not the habit of disapprobation, at least the despair of felicity; and this look had recurred to Strether as the key of much he (Strether) had since observed.

``Europe,'' (he)
he (Strether) had begun to gather from these things, had up to now rather failed of its message to him (Strether); he (Strether) hadn't got into tune with it and had at the end of three months almost renounced any such expectation.

He (Strether) really appeared at present to insist on that by just perching there with the gas in his (Strether) eyes. This of itself somehow conveyed the futility of single rectifications in a multiform failure. He (Strether) had a large handsome head and a large sallow seamed face--a striking significant physiognomic total, the upper range of which, the great political brow, the thick loose hair, the dark fuliginous eyes, recalled even to a generation whose standard had dreadfully deviated the impressive image, familiar by engravings and busts, of some great national worthy of the earlier part of the mid-century. He (Strether) was of the personal type--and it was an element in the power and promise that in their early time Strether had found in him (Strether)--of the American statesman, the statesman trained in

``Congressional halls,'' (the statesman)
of an elder day. The legend had been in later years that as the lower part of his (Strether) face, which was weak, and slightly crooked, spoiled the likeness, this was the real reason for the growth of his (Strether) beard, which might have seemed to spoil it for those not in the secret. He (Strether) shook his (Strether) mane; he (Strether) fixed, with his (Strether) admirable eyes, his (Strether) auditor or his (Strether) observer; he (Strether) wore no glasses and had a way, partly formidable, yet also partly encouraging, as from a representative to a constituent, of looking very hard at those who approached him (representative). He (representative) met you as if you had knocked and he (representative) had bidden you enter. Strether, who hadn't seen him (Strether) for so long an interval, apprehended him (Strether) now with a freshness of taste, and had perhaps never done him (Strether) such ideal justice. The head was bigger, the eyes finer, than they need have been for the career; but that only meant, after all, that the career was itself expressive. What it expressed at midnight in the gas-glaring bedroom at Chester was that the subject of it had, at the end of years, barely escaped, by flight in time, a general nervous collapse. But this very proof of the full life, as the full life was understood at Milrose, would have made to Strether's imagination an element in which Waymarsh could have floated easily had he (Strether) only consented to float. Alas nothing so little resembled floating as the rigour with which, on the edge of his (Strether) bed, he (Strether) hugged his (Strether) posture of prolonged impermanence. It suggested to his (Strether) comrade something that always, when kept up, worried him (Strether)--a person established in a railway-coach with a forward inclination. It represented the angle at which poor Waymarsh was to sit through the ordeal of Europe.

Thanks to the stress of occupation, the strain of professions, the absorption and embarrassment of each, they had not, at home, during years before this sudden brief and almost bewildering reign of comparative ease, found so much as a day for a meeting; a fact that was in some degree an explanation of the sharpness with which most of his (Strether) friend's features stood out to Strether. Those he (Strether) had lost sight of since the early time came back to him (Strether); others that it was never possible to forget struck him (Strether) now as sitting, clustered and expectant, like a somewhat defiant family-group, on the doorstep of their residence. The room was narrow for its length, and the occupant of the bed thrust so far a pair of slippered feet that the visitor had almost to step over them in his (visitor) recurrent rebounds from his (visitor) chair to fidget back and forth. There were marks the friends made on things to talk about, and on things not to, and one of the latter in particular fell like the tap of chalk on the blackboard. Married at thirty, Waymarsh had not lived with his (visitor) wife for fifteen years, and it came up vividly between them in the glare of the gas that Strether wasn't to ask about her (Waymarsh). He (Strether) knew they were still separate and that she (Waymarsh) lived at hotels, travelled in Europe, painted her (Waymarsh) face and wrote her (Waymarsh) husband abusive letters, of not one of which, to a certainty, that sufferer spared himself the perusal; but he (sufferer) respected without difficulty the cold twilight that had settled on this side of his (sufferer) companion's life. It was a province in which mystery reigned and as to which Waymarsh had never spoken the informing word. Strether, who wanted to do him (Strether) the highest justice wherever he (Strether) COULD do it, singularly admired him (Strether) for the dignity of this reserve, and even counted it as one of the grounds--grounds all handled and numbered--for ranking him (Strether), in the range of their acquaintance, as a success. He (acquaintance) WAS a success, Waymarsh, in spite of overwork, or prostration, of sensible shrinkage, of his (acquaintance) wife's letters and of his (acquaintance) not liking Europe. Strether would have reckoned his (Strether) own career less futile had he (Strether) been able to put into it anything so handsome as so much fine silence. One might one's self easily have left Mrs. Waymarsh; and one would assuredly have paid one's tribute to the ideal in covering with that attitude the derision of having been left by her (Waymarsh). Her (Waymarsh) husband had held his (husband) tongue and had made a large income; and these were in especial the achievements as to which Strether envied him (Strether). Our friend had had indeed on his (friend) side too a subject for silence, which he (friend) fully appreciated; but it was a matter of a different sort, and the figure of the income he (friend) had arrived at had never been high enough to look any one in the face.

``I don't know as I quite see what you require it for. You don't appear sick to speak of.'' (unknown)
It was of Europe Waymarsh thus finally spoke.

``Well,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
said Strether, who fell as much as possible into step,
``I guess I don't FEEL sick now that I've started. But I had pretty well run down before I did start.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Waymarsh raised his (Strether) melancholy look.

``Ain't you about up to your usual average?'' (friend)

It was not quite pointedly sceptical, but it seemed somehow a plea for the purest veracity, and it thereby affected our friend as the very voice of Milrose. He (friend) had long since made a mental distinction--though never in truth daring to betray it--between the voice of Milrose and the voice even of Woollett. It was the former he (friend) felt, that was most in the real tradition. There had been occasions in his (friend) past when the sound of it had reduced him (friend) to temporary confusion, and the present, for some reason, suddenly became such another. It was nevertheless no light matter that the very effect of his (friend) confusion should be to make him (friend) again prevaricate.

``That description hardly does justice to a man to whom it has done such a lot of good to see YOU.'' (Waymarsh/Mrs. Waymarsh)

Waymarsh fixed on his (friend) washing-stand the silent detached stare with which Milrose in person, as it were, might have marked the unexpectedness of a compliment from Woollett, and Strether for his (Strether) part, felt once more like Woollett in person.

``I mean,'' (friend)
his (Strether) friend presently continued,
``that your appearance isn't as bad as I've seen it: it compares favourably with what it was when I last noticed it.'' (friend)
On this appearance Waymarsh's eyes yet failed to rest; it was almost as if they obeyed an instinct of propriety, and the effect was still stronger when, always considering the basin and jug, he (Strether) added:
``You've filled out some since then.'' (he)

``I'm afraid I have,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether laughed:
``one does fill out some with all one takes in, and I've taken in, I dare say, more than I've natural room for. I was dog-tired when I sailed.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
It had the oddest sound of cheerfulness.

``I was dog-tired,'' (companion)
his (Strether) companion returned,
``when I arrived, and it's this wild hunt for rest that takes all the life out of me. The fact is, Strether--and it's a comfort to have you here at last to say it to; though I don't know, after all, that I've really waited; I've told it to people I've met in the cars--the fact is, such a country as this ain't my KIND of country anyway. There ain't a country I've seen over here that DOES seem my kind. Oh I don't say but what there are plenty of pretty places and remarkable old things; but the trouble is that I don't seem to feel anywhere in tune. That's one of the reasons why I suppose I've gained so little. I haven't had the first sign of that lift I was led to expect.'' (companion)
With this he (Strether) broke out more earnestly.
``Look here--I want to go back.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

His (Strether) eyes were all attached to Strether's now, for he (Strether) was one of the men who fully face you when they talk of themselves. This enabled his (Strether) friend to look at him (Strether) hard and immediately to appear to the highest advantage in his (Strether) eyes by doing so.

``That's a genial thing to say to a fellow who has come out on purpose to meet you!'' (Waymarsh/Mrs. Waymarsh)

Nothing could have been finer, on this, than Waymarsh's sombre glow.

``HAVE you come out on purpose?'' (unknown)

``Well--very largely.'' (unknown)

``I thought from the way you wrote there was something back of it.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether hesitated.

``Back of my desire to be with you?'' (unknown)

``Back of your prostration.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether, with a smile made more dim by a certain consciousness, shook his (Strether) head.

``There are all the causes of it!'' (unknown)

``And no particular cause that seemed most to drive you?'' (friend)

Our friend could at last conscientiously answer.

``Yes. One. There IS a matter that has had much to do with my coming out.'' (Waymarsh/Mrs. Waymarsh)

Waymarsh waited a little.

``Too private to mention?'' (unknown)

``No, not too private--for YOU. Only rather complicated.'' (unknown)

``Well,'' (Waymarsh/Mrs. Waymarsh)
said Waymarsh, who had waited again,
``I MAY lose my mind over here, but I don't know as I've done so yet.'' (Waymarsh/Mrs. Waymarsh)

``Oh you shall have the whole thing. But not tonight.'' (Waymarsh/Mrs. Waymarsh)

Waymarsh seemed to sit stiffer and to hold his (Strether) elbows tighter.

``Why not--if I can't sleep?'' (unknown)

``Because, my dear man, I CAN!'' (unknown)

``Then where's your prostration?'' (unknown)

``Just in that--that I can put in eight hours.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
And Strether brought it out that if Waymarsh didn't
``gain'' (Waymarsh/Mrs. Waymarsh)
it was because he (Strether) didn't go to bed: the result of which was, in its order, that, to do the latter justice, he (Strether) permitted his (Strether) friend to insist on his (Strether) really getting settled. Strether, with a kind coercive hand for it, assisted him (Strether) to this consummation, and again found his (Strether) own part in their relation auspiciously enlarged by the smaller touches of lowering the lamp and seeing to a sufficiency of blanket. It somehow ministered for him (Strether) to indulgence to feel Waymarsh, who looked unnaturally big and black in bed, as much tucked in as a patient in a hospital and, with his (patient) covering up to his (patient) chin, as much simplified by it He (patient) hovered in vague pity, to be brief, while his (patient) companion challenged him (patient) out of the bedclothes.
``Is she (I) really after you? Is that what's behind?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether felt an uneasiness at the direction taken by his (Strether) companion's insight, but he (Strether) played a little at uncertainty.

``Behind my coming out?'' (unknown)

``Behind your prostration or whatever. It's generally felt, you know, that she (I) follows you up pretty close.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether's candour was never very far off.

``Oh it has occurred to you that I'm literally running away from Mrs. Newsome?'' (unknown)

``Well, I haven't KNOWN but what you are. You're a very attractive man, Strether. You've seen for yourself,'' (Waymarsh/Mrs. Waymarsh)
said Waymarsh
``what that lady downstairs makes of it. Unless indeed,'' (Waymarsh/Mrs. Waymarsh)
he (Strether) rambled on with an effect between the ironic and the anxious,
``it's you who are after HER. IS Mrs. Newsome OVER here?'' (he)
He (Strether) spoke as with a droll dread of her (Waymarsh).

It made his (Strether) friend--though rather dimly--smile.

``Dear no she (Newsome)'s safe, thank goodness--as I think I more and more feel--at home. She (Newsome) thought of coming, but she (Newsome) gave it up. I've come in a manner instead of her (Newsome); and come to that extent--for you're right in your inference--on her (Newsome) business. So you see there IS plenty of connexion.'' (Waymarsh/Mrs. Waymarsh)

Waymarsh continued to see at least all there was.

``Involving accordingly the particular one I've referred to?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether took another turn about the room, giving a twitch to his (Strether) companion's blanket and finally gaining the door. His (Strether) feeling was that of a nurse who had earned personal rest by having made everything straight.

``Involving more things than I can think of breaking ground on now. But don't be afraid--you shall have them from me: you'll probably find yourself having quite as much of them as you can do with. I shall--if we keep together--very much depend on your impression of some of them.'' (Waymarsh/Mrs. Waymarsh)

Waymarsh's acknowledgement of this tribute was characteristically indirect.

``You mean to say you don't believe we WILL keep together?'' (unknown)

``I only glance at the danger,'' (Strether)
Strether paternally said,
``because when I hear you wail to go back I seem to see you open up such possibilities of folly.'' (Strether)

Waymarsh took it--silent a little--like a large snubbed child

``What are you going to do with me?'' (a child)

It was the very question Strether himself had put to Miss Gostrey, and he (Strether) wondered if he (Strether) had sounded like that. But HE (Strether) at least could be more definite.

``I'm going to take you right down to London.'' (unknown)

``Oh I've been down to London!'' (unknown)
Waymarsh more softly moaned.
``I've no use, Strether, for anything down there.'' (unknown)

``Well,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
said Strether, good-humouredly,
``I guess you've some use for me.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

``So I've got to go?'' (unknown)

``Oh you've got to go further yet.'' (unknown)

``Well,'' (Waymarsh/Mrs. Waymarsh)
Waymarsh sighed,
``do your damnedest! Only you WILL tell me before you lead me on all the way--?'' (Waymarsh/Mrs. Waymarsh)

Our friend had again so lost himself, both for amusement and for contrition, in the wonder of whether he (Strether) had made, in his (Strether) own challenge that afternoon, such another figure, that he (Strether) for an instant missed the thread.

``Tell you--?'' (unknown)

``Why what you've got on hand.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether hesitated.

``Why it's such a matter as that even if I positively wanted I shouldn't be able to keep it from you.'' (Waymarsh/Mrs. Waymarsh)

Waymarsh gloomily gazed.

``What does that mean then but that your trip is just FOR her (me)?'' (unknown)

``For Mrs. Newsome? Oh it certainly is, as I say. Very much.'' (unknown)

``Then why do you also say it's for me?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether, in impatience, violently played with his (Strether) latch.

``It's simple enough. It's for both of you.'' (Waymarsh/Mrs. Waymarsh)

Waymarsh at last turned over with a groan.

``Well, I won't marry you!'' (unknown)

``Neither, when it comes to that--!'' (the visitor)
But the visitor had already laughed and escaped.

III

He (visitor) had told Miss Gostrey he (visitor) should probably take, for departure with Waymarsh, some afternoon train, and it thereupon in the morning appeared that this lady had made her (lady) own plan for an earlier one. She (lady) had breakfasted when Strether came into the coffee-room; but, Waymarsh not having yet emerged, he (Strether) was in time to recall her (Waymarsh) to the terms of their understanding and to pronounce her (Waymarsh) discretion overdone. She (Waymarsh) was surely not to break away at the very moment she (Waymarsh) had created a want. He (Strether) had met her (Waymarsh) as she (Waymarsh) rose from her (Waymarsh) little table in a window, where, with the morning papers beside her (Waymarsh), she (Waymarsh) reminded him (Strether), as he (Strether) let her (Waymarsh) know, of Major Pendennis breakfasting at his (Strether) club--a compliment of which she (Waymarsh) professed a deep appreciation; and he (Strether) detained her (Waymarsh) as pleadingly as if he (Strether) had already--and notably under pressure of the visions of the night--learned to be unable to do without her (Waymarsh). She (Waymarsh) must teach him (Strether) at all events, before she (Waymarsh) went, to order breakfast as breakfast was ordered in Europe, and she (Waymarsh) must especially sustain him (Strether) in the problem of ordering for Waymarsh. The latter had laid upon his (Strether) friend, by desperate sounds through the door of his (Strether) room, dreadful divined responsibilities in respect to beefsteak and oranges--responsibilities which Miss Gostrey took over with an alertness of action that matched her (Gostrey) quick intelligence. She (Gostrey) had before this weaned the expatriated from traditions compared with which the matutinal beefsteak was but the creature of an hour, and it was not for her (Gostrey), with some of her (Gostrey) memories, to falter in the path though she (Gostrey) freely enough declared, on reflexion, that there was always in such cases a choice of opposed policies.

``There are times when to give them their head, you know--!'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

They had gone to wait together in the garden for the dressing of the meal, and Strether found her (Gostrey) more suggestive than ever

``Well, what?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

``Is to bring about for them such a complexity of relations-unless indeed we call it a simplicity!--that the situation HAS to wind itself up. They want to go back.'' (unknown)

``And you want them to go!'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether gaily concluded.

``I always want them to go, and I send them as fast as I can.'' (unknown)

``Oh I know--you take them to Liverpool.'' (unknown)

``Any port will serve in a storm. I'm--with all my other functions--an agent for repatriation. I want to re-people our stricken country. What will become of it else? I want to discourage others.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

The ordered English garden, in the freshness of the day, was delightful to Strether, who liked the sound, under his (Strether) feet, of the tight fine gravel, packed with the chronic damp, and who had the idlest eye for the deep smoothness of turf and the clean curves of paths.

``Other people?'' (unknown)

``Other countries. Other people--yes. I want to encourage our own.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether wondered.

``Not to come? Why then do you `meet' them--since it doesn't appear to be to stop them?'' (unknown)

``Oh that they shouldn't come is as yet too much to ask. What I attend to is that they come quickly and return still more so. I meet them to help it to be over as soon as possible, and though I don't stop them I've my way of putting them through. That's my little system; and, if you want to know,'' (Maria/Maria Gostrey)
said Maria Gostrey,
``it's my real secret, my innermost mission and use. I only seem, you see, to beguile and approve; but I've thought it all out and I'm working all the while underground. I can't perhaps quite give you my formula, but I think that practically I succeed. I send you back spent. So you stay back. Passed through my hands--'' (Maria/Maria Gostrey)

``We don't turn up again?'' (she)
The further she (Gostrey) went the further he (Strether) always saw himself able to follow.
``I don't want your formula--I feel quite enough, as I hinted yesterday, your abysses. Spent!'' (he)
he (Strether) echoed.
``If that's how you're arranging so subtly to send me I thank you for the warning.'' (guests)

For a minute, amid the pleasantness--poetry in tariffed items, but all the more, for guests already convicted, a challenge to consumption--they smiled at each other in confirmed fellowship.

``Do you call it subtly? It's a plain poor tale. Besides, you're a special case.'' (unknown)

``Oh special cases--that's weak!'' (She)
She (Gostrey) was weak enough, further still, to defer her (Gostrey) journey and agree to accompany the gentlemen on their own, might a separate carriage mark her (Gostrey) independence; though it was in spite of this to befall after luncheon that she (Gostrey) went off alone and that, with a tryst taken for a day of her (Gostrey) company in London, they lingered another night. She (Gostrey) had, during the morning--spent in a way that he (they) was to remember later on as the very climax of his (they) foretaste, as warm with presentiments, with what he (they) would have called collapses--had all sorts of things out with Strether; and among them the fact that though there was never a moment of her (Gostrey) life when she (Gostrey) wasn't
``due'' (she)
somewhere, there was yet scarce a perfidy to others of which she (Gostrey) wasn't capable for his (Strether) sake. She (Gostrey) explained moreover that wherever she (Gostrey) happened to be she (Gostrey) found a dropped thread to pick up, a ragged edge to repair, some familiar appetite in ambush, jumping out as she (Gostrey) approached, yet appeasable with a temporary biscuit. It became, on her (Gostrey) taking the risk of the deviation imposed on him (Strether) by her (Gostrey) insidious arrangement of his (Strether) morning meal, a point of honour for her (Gostrey) not to fail with Waymarsh of the larger success too; and her (Gostrey) subsequent boast to Strether was that she (Gostrey) had made their friend fare--and quite without his (Strether) knowing what was the matter--as Major Pendennis would have fared at the Megatherium. She (Gostrey) had made him (Strether) breakfast like a gentleman, and it was nothing, she (Gostrey) forcibly asserted, to what she (Gostrey) would yet make him (Strether) do. She (Gostrey) made him (Strether) participate in the slow reiterated ramble with which, for Strether, the new day amply filled itself; and it was by her (Gostrey) art that he (Strether) somehow had the air, on the ramparts and in the Rows, of carrying a point of his (Strether) own.

The three strolled and stared and gossiped, or at least the two did; the case really yielding for their comrade, if analysed, but the element of stricken silence. This element indeed affected Strether as charged with audible rumblings, but he (Strether) was conscious of the care of taking it explicitly as a sign of pleasant peace. He (Strether) wouldn't appeal too much, for that provoked stiffness; yet he (Strether) wouldn't be too freely tacit, for that suggested giving up. Waymarsh himself adhered to an ambiguous dumbness that might have represented either the growth of a perception or the despair of one; and at times and in places--where the low-browed galleries were darkest, the opposite gables queerest, the solicitations of every kind densest--the others caught him (Strether) fixing hard some object of minor interest, fixing even at moments nothing discernible, as if he (Strether) were indulging it with a truce. When he (Strether) met Strether's eye on such occasions he (Strether) looked guilty and furtive, fell the next minute into some attitude of retractation. Our friend couldn't show him (friend) the right things for fear of provoking some total renouncement, and was tempted even to show him (friend) the wrong in order to make him (friend) differ with triumph. There were moments when he (friend) himself felt shy of professing the full sweetness of the taste of leisure, and there were others when he (friend) found himself feeling as if his (friend) passages of interchange with the lady at his (friend) side might fall upon the third member of their party very much as Mr. Burchell, at Dr. Primrose's fireside, was influenced by the high flights of the visitors from London. The smallest things so arrested and amused him (Primrose) that he (Primrose) repeatedly almost apologised--brought up afresh in explanation his (Primrose) plea of a previous grind. He (Primrose) was aware at the same time that his (Primrose) grind had been as nothing to Waymarsh's, and he (Primrose) repeatedly confessed that, to cover his (Primrose) frivolity, he (Primrose) was doing his (Primrose) best for his (Primrose) previous virtue. Do what he (Primrose) might, in any case, his (Primrose) previous virtue was still there, and it seemed fairly to stare at him (Primrose) out of the windows of shops that were not as the shops of Woollett, fairly to make him (Primrose) want things that he (Primrose) shouldn't know what to do with. It was by the oddest, the least admissible of laws demoralising him (Primrose) now; and the way it boldly took was to make him (Primrose) want more wants. These first walks in Europe were in fact a kind of finely lurid intimation of what one might find at the end of that process. Had he (Primrose) come back after long years, in something already so like the evening of life, only to be exposed to it? It was at all events over the shop-windows that he (Primrose) made, with Waymarsh, most free; though it would have been easier had not the latter most sensibly yielded to the appeal of the merely useful trades. He (Primrose) pierced with his (Primrose) sombre detachment the plate-glass of ironmongers and saddlers, while Strether flaunted an affinity with the dealers in stamped letter-paper and in smart neckties. Strether was in fact recurrently shameless in the presence of the tailors, though it was just over the heads of the tailors that his (Strether) countryman most loftily looked. This gave Miss Gostrey a grasped opportunity to back up Waymarsh at his (Strether) expense. The weary lawyer--it was unmistakeable--had a conception of dress; but that, in view of some of the features of the effect produced, was just what made the danger of insistence on it. Strether wondered if he (Strether) by this time thought Miss Gostrey less fashionable or Lambert Strether more so; and it appeared probable that most of the remarks exchanged between this latter pair about passers, figures, faces, personal types, exemplified in their degree the disposition to talk as

``society'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
talked.

Was what was happening to himself then, was what already HAD happened, really that a woman of fashion was floating him (Strether) into society and that an old friend deserted on the brink was watching the force of the current? When the woman of fashion permitted Strether--as she (woman) permitted him (Strether) at the most--the purchase of a pair of gloves, the terms she (woman) made about it, the prohibition of neckties and other items till she (woman) should be able to guide him (Strether) through the Burlington Arcade, were such as to fall upon a sensitive ear as a challenge to just imputations. Miss Gostrey was such a woman of fashion as could make without a symptom of vulgar blinking an appointment for the Burlington Arcade. Mere discriminations about a pair of gloves could thus at any rate represent--always for such sensitive ears as were in question--possibilities of something that Strether could make a mark against only as the peril of apparent wantonness. He (Strether) had quite the consciousness of his (Strether) new friend, for their companion, that he (Strether) might have had of a Jesuit in petticoats, a representative of the recruiting interests of the Catholic Church. The Catholic Church, for Waymarsh-that was to say the enemy, the monster of bulging eyes and far-reaching quivering groping tentacles--was exactly society, exactly the multiplication of shibboleths, exactly the discrimination of types and tones, exactly the wicked old Rows of Chester, rank with feudalism; exactly in short Europe.

There was light for observation, however, in an incident that occurred just before they turned back to luncheon. Waymarsh had been for a quarter of an hour exceptionally mute and distant, and something, or other--Strether was never to make out exactly what--proved, as it were, too much for him (Strether) after his (Strether) comrades had stood for three minutes taking in, while they leaned on an old balustrade that guarded the edge of the Row, a particularly crooked and huddled street-view.

``He (it) thinks us sophisticated, he (it) thinks us worldly, he (it) thinks us wicked, he (it) thinks us all sorts of queer things,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether reflected; for wondrous were the vague quantities our friend had within a couple of short days acquired the habit of conveniently and conclusively lumping together. There seemed moreover a direct connexion between some such inference and a sudden grim dash taken by Waymarsh to the opposite side. This movement was startlingly sudden, and his (Strether) companions at first supposed him (Strether) to have espied, to be pursuing, the glimpse of an acquaintance. They next made out, however, that an open door had instantly received him (Strether), and they then recognised him (Strether) as engulfed in the establishment of a jeweller, behind whose glittering front he (jeweller) was lost to view. The fact had somehow the note of a demonstration, and it left each of the others to show a face almost of fear. But Miss Gostrey broke into a laugh.
``What's the matter with him (it)?'' (unknown)

``Well,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
said Strether,
``he (it) can't stand it.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

``But can't stand what?'' (unknown)

``Anything. Europe.'' (unknown)

``Then how will that jeweller help him (jeweller)?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether seemed to make it out, from their position, between the interstices of arrayed watches, of close-hung dangling gewgaws.

``You'll see.'' (unknown)

``Ah that's just what--if he (jeweller) buys anything--I'm afraid of: that I shall see something rather dreadful.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether studied the finer appearances.

``He (jeweller) may buy everything.'' (unknown)

``Then don't you think we ought to follow him (jeweller)?'' (unknown)

``Not for worlds. Besides we can't. We're paralysed. We exchange a long scared look, we publicly tremble. The thing is, you see, we ``realise.

'' He (Strether) has struck for freedom.'' (She)

She (Gostrey) wondered but she (Gostrey) laughed.

``Ah what a price to pay! And I was preparing some for him (jeweller) so cheap.'' (unknown)

``No, no,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether went on, frankly amused now;
``don't call it that: the kind of freedom you deal in is dear.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Then as to justify himself:
``Am I not in MY way trying it? It's this.'' (unknown)

``Being here, you mean, with me?'' (unknown)

``Yes, and talking to you as I do. I've known you a few hours, and I've known HIM all my life; so that if the ease I thus take with you about him (jeweller) isn't magnificent'' (him)
--and the thought of it held him (Strether) a moment--
``why it's rather base.'' (him)

``It's magnificent!'' (Miss Gostrey)
said Miss Gostrey to make an end of it.
``And you should hear,'' (she)
she (Gostrey) added,
``the ease I take--and I above all intend to take--with Mr. Waymarsh.'' (she)

Strether thought.

``About ME? Ah that's no equivalent. The equivalent would be Waymarsh's himself serving me up--his (Waymarsh) remorseless analysis of me. And he (Waymarsh)'ll never do that'' (he)
--he (Strether) was sadly clear.
``He (Waymarsh)'ll never remorselessly analyse me.'' (He)
He (Strether) quite held her (Gostrey) with the authority of this.
``He (Waymarsh)'ll never say a word to you about me.'' (She)

She (Gostrey) took it in; she (Gostrey) did it justice; yet after an instant her (Gostrey) reason, her (Gostrey) restless irony, disposed of it.

``Of course he (Waymarsh) won't. For what do you take people, that they're able to say words about anything, able remorselessly to analyse? There are not many like you and me. It will be only because he (Waymarsh)'s too stupid.'' (friend)

It stirred in her (Gostrey) friend a sceptical echo which was at the same time the protest of the faith of years.

``Waymarsh stupid?'' (unknown)

``Compared with you.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether had still his (Strether) eyes on the jeweller's front, and he (Strether) waited a moment to answer.

``He (Waymarsh)'s a success of a kind that I haven't approached.'' (unknown)

``Do you mean he (Waymarsh) has made money?'' (unknown)

``He (Waymarsh) makes it--to my belief. And I,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
said Strether,
``though with a back quite as bent, have never made anything. I'm a perfectly equipped failure.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

He (Strether) feared an instant she (Gostrey)'d ask him (Strether) if he (Strether) meant he (Strether) was poor; and he (Strether) was glad she (Gostrey) didn't, for he (Strether) really didn't know to what the truth on this unpleasant point mightn't have prompted her (Gostrey). She (Gostrey) only, however, confirmed his (Strether) assertion.

``Thank goodness you're a failure--it's why I so distinguish you! Anything else to-day is too hideous. Look about you--look at the successes. Would you BE one, on your honour? Look, moreover,'' (she)
she (Gostrey) continued,
``at me.'' (she)

For a little accordingly their eyes met.

``I see,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether returned.
``You too are out of it.'' (unknown)

``The superiority you discern in me,'' (she)
she (Gostrey) concurred,
``announces my futility. If you knew,'' (she)
she (Gostrey) sighed,
``the dreams of my youth! But our realities are what has brought us together. We're beaten brothers in arms.'' (she)

He (Strether) smiled at her (Gostrey) kindly enough, but he (Strether) shook his (Strether) head.

``It doesn't alter the fact that you're expensive. You've cost me already--!'' (he)

But he (Strether) had hung fire.

``Cost you what?'' (unknown)

``Well, my past--in one great lump. But no matter,'' (he)
he (Strether) laughed:
``I'll pay with my last penny.'' (he)

Her (Gostrey) attention had unfortunately now been engaged by their comrade's return, for Waymarsh met their view as he (Strether) came out of his (Strether) shop.

``I hope he (us) hasn't paid,'' (she)
she (Waymarsh) said,
``with HIS (us) last; though I'm convinced he (us) has been splendid, and has been so for you.'' (she)

``Ah no--not that!'' (unknown)

``Then for me?'' (unknown)

``Quite as little.'' (Waymarsh/Mrs. Waymarsh)
Waymarsh was by this time near enough to show signs his (Strether) friend could read, though he (Strether) seemed to look almost carefully at nothing in particular.

``Then for himself?'' (unknown)

``For nobody. For nothing. For freedom.'' (unknown)

``But what has freedom to do with it?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether's answer was indirect.

``To be as good as you and me. But different.'' (She)

She (Waymarsh) had had time to take in their companion's face; and with it, as such things were easy for her (Waymarsh), she (Waymarsh) took in all.

``Different--yes. But better!'' (Waymarsh/Mrs. Waymarsh)

If Waymarsh was sombre he (companion) was also indeed almost sublime. He (companion) told them nothing, left his (companion) absence unexplained, and though they were convinced he (companion) had made some extraordinary purchase they were never to learn its nature. He (companion) only glowered grandly at the tops of the old gables.

``It's the sacred rage,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether had had further time to say; and this sacred rage was to become between them, for convenient comprehension, the description of one of his (Strether) periodical necessities. It was Strether who eventually contended that it did make him (Strether) better than they. But by that time Miss Gostrey was convinced that she (Gostrey) didn't want to be better than Strether.

Book Second

I

Those occasions on which Strether was, in association with the exile from Milrose, to see the sacred rage glimmer through would doubtless have their due periodicity; but our friend had meanwhile to find names for many other matters. On no evening of his (friend) life perhaps, as he (friend) reflected, had he (friend) had to supply so many as on the third of his (friend) short stay in London; an evening spent by Miss Gostrey's side at one of the theatres, to which he (friend) had found himself transported, without his (friend) own hand raised, on the mere expression of a conscientious wonder. She (Gostrey) knew her (Gostrey) theatre, she (Gostrey) knew her (Gostrey) play, as she (Gostrey) had triumphantly known, three days running, everything else, and the moment filled to the brim, for her (Gostrey) companion, that apprehension of the interesting which, whether or no the interesting happened to filter through his (companion) guide, strained now to its limits his (companion) brief opportunity. Waymarsh hadn't come with them; he (companion) had seen plays enough, he (companion) signified, before Strether had joined him (Strether)--an affirmation that had its full force when his (Strether) friend ascertained by questions that he (Strether) had seen two and a circus. Questions as to what he (Strether) had seen had on him (Strether) indeed an effect only less favourable than questions as to what he (Strether) hadn't. He (Strether) liked the former to be discriminated; but how could it be done, Strether asked of their constant counsellor, without discriminating the latter?

Miss Gostrey had dined with him (Strether) at his (Strether) hotel, face to face over a small table on which the lighted candles had rose-coloured shades; and the rose-coloured shades and the small table and the soft fragrance of the lady--had anything to his (Strether) mere sense ever been so soft?--were so many touches in he (Strether) scarce knew what positive high picture. He (Strether) had been to the theatre, even to the opera, in Boston, with Mrs. Newsome, more than once acting as her (Newsome) only escort; but there had been no little confronted dinner, no pink lights, no whiff of vague sweetness, as a preliminary: one of the results of which was that at present, mildly rueful, though with a sharpish accent, he (Strether) actually asked himself WHY there hadn't. There was much the same difference in his (Strether) impression of the noticed state of his (Strether) companion, whose dress was

``cut down,'' (companion)
as he (Strether) believed the term to be, in respect to shoulders and bosom, in a manner quite other than Mrs. Newsome's, and who wore round her (Newsome) throat a broad red velvet band with an antique jewel--he (Strether) was rather complacently sure it was antique--attached to it in front. Mrs. Newsome's dress was never in any degree
``cut down,'' (Mrs. Newsome)
and she (Newsome) never wore round her (Newsome) throat a broad red velvet band: if she (Newsome) had, moreover, would it ever have served so to carry on and complicate, as he (Strether) now almost felt, his (Strether) vision?

It would have been absurd of him (Strether) to trace into ramifications the effect of the ribbon from which Miss Gostrey's trinket depended, had he (Strether) not for the hour, at the best, been so given over to uncontrolled perceptions. What was it but an uncontrolled perception that his (Strether) friend's velvet band somehow added, in her (Gostrey) appearance, to the value of every other item--to that of her (Gostrey) smile and of the way she (Gostrey) carried her (Gostrey) head, to that of her (Gostrey) complexion, of her (Gostrey) lips, her (Gostrey) teeth, her (Gostrey) eyes, her (Gostrey) hair? What, certainly, had a man conscious of a man's work in the world to do with red velvet bands? He (man) wouldn't for anything have so exposed himself as to tell Miss Gostrey how much he (man) liked hers, yet he (man) HAD none the less not only caught himself in the act--frivolous, no doubt, idiotic, and above all unexpected--of liking it: he (man) had in addition taken it as a starting-point for fresh backward, fresh forward, fresh lateral flights. The manner in which Mrs. Newsome's throat WAS encircled suddenly represented for him (man), in an alien order, almost as many things as the manner in which Miss Gostrey's was. Mrs. Newsome wore, at operatic hours, a black silk dress--very handsome, he (man) knew it was

``handsome'' (he)
--and an ornament that his (man) memory was able further to identify as a ruche. He (man) had his (man) association indeed with the ruche, but it was rather imperfectly romantic. He (man) had once said to the wearer--and it was as
``free'' (He)
a remark as he (man) had ever made to her (Newsome)--that she (Newsome) looked, with her (Newsome) ruff and other matters, like Queen Elizabeth; and it had after this in truth been his (man) fancy that, as a consequence of that tenderness and an acceptance of the idea, the form of this special tribute to the
``frill'' (Queen Elizabeth)
had grown slightly more marked. The connexion, as he (man) sat there and let his (man) imagination roam, was to strike him (man) as vaguely pathetic; but there it all was, and pathetic was doubtless in the conditions the best thing it could possibly be. It had assuredly existed at any rate; for it seemed now to come over him (man) that no gentleman of his (gentleman) age at Woollett could ever, to a lady of Mrs. Newsome's, which was not much less than his (gentleman), have embarked on such a simile.

All sorts of things in fact now seemed to come over him (gentleman), comparatively few of which his (gentleman) chronicler can hope for space to mention. It came over him (gentleman) for instance that Miss Gostrey looked perhaps like Mary Stuart: Lambert Strether had a candour of fancy which could rest for an instant gratified in such an antithesis. It came over him (Strether) that never before--no, literally never--had a lady dined with him (Strether) at a public place before going to the play. The publicity of the place was just, in the matter, for Strether, the rare strange thing; it affected him (Strether) almost as the achievement of privacy might have affected a man of a different experience. He (man) had married, in the far-away years, so young as to have missed the time natural in Boston for taking girls to the Museum; and it was absolutely true of hint that--even after the close of the period of conscious detachment occupying the centre of his (man) life, the grey middle desert of the two deaths, that of his (man) wife and that, ten years later, of his (man) boy--he (man) had never taken any one anywhere. It came over him (man) in especial--though the monition had, as happened, already sounded, fitfully gleamed, in other forms--that the business he (man) had come out on hadn't yet been so brought home to him (man) as by the sight of the people about him (man). She (wife) gave him (man) the impression, his (man) friend, at first, more straight than he (man) got it for himself--gave it simply by saying with off-hand illumination:

``Oh yes, they're types!'' (he)
--but after he (man) had taken it he (man) made to the full his (man) own use of it; both while he (man) kept silence for the four acts and while he (man) talked in the intervals. It was an evening, it was a world of types, and this was a connexion above all in which the figures and faces in the stalls were interchangeable with those on the stage.

He (man) felt as if the play itself penetrated him (man) with the naked elbow of his (man) neighbour, a great stripped handsome red-haired lady who conversed with a gentleman on her (lady) other side in stray dissyllables which had for his (gentleman) ear, in the oddest way in the world, so much sound that he (gentleman) wondered they hadn't more sense; and he (gentleman) recognised by the same law, beyond the footlights, what he (gentleman) was pleased to take for the very flush of English life. He (gentleman) had distracted drops in which he (gentleman) couldn't have said if it were actors or auditors who were most true, and the upshot of which, each time, was the consciousness of new contacts. However he (gentleman) viewed his (gentleman) job it was

``types'' (he)
he (gentleman) should have to tackle. Those before him (gentleman) and around him (gentleman) were not as the types of Woollett, where, for that matter, it had begun to seem to him (gentleman) that there must only have been the male and the female. These made two exactly, even with the individual varieties. Here, on the other hand, apart from the personal and the sexual range--which might be greater or less--a series of strong stamps had been applied, as it were, from without; stamps that his (male) observation played with as, before a glass case on a table, it might have passed from medal to medal and from copper to gold. It befell that in the drama precisely there was a bad woman in a yellow frock who made a pleasant weak good-looking young man in perpetual evening dress do the most dreadful things. Strether felt himself on the whole not afraid of the yellow frock, but he (Strether) was vaguely anxious over a certain kindness into which he (Strether) found himself drifting for its victim. He (Strether) hadn't come out, he (Strether) reminded himself, to be too kind, or indeed to be kind at all, to Chadwick Newsome. Would Chad also be in perpetual evening dress? He (Chad) somehow rather hoped it--it seemed so to add to THIS young man's general amenability; though he (man) wondered too if, to fight him (man) with his (man) own weapons, he (man) himself -LRB-a thought almost startling-RRB- would have likewise to be. This young man furthermore would have been much more easy to handle--at least for HIM--than appeared probable in respect to Chad.

It came up for him (Chad) with Miss Gostrey that there were things of which she (Gostrey) would really perhaps after all have heard, and she (Gostrey) admitted when a little pressed that she (Gostrey) was never quite sure of what she (Gostrey) heard as distinguished from things such as, on occasions like the present, she (Gostrey) only extravagantly guessed.

``I seem with this freedom, you see, to have guessed Mr. Chad. He (Chad)'s a young man on whose head high hopes are placed at Woollett; a young man a wicked woman has got hold of and whom his (man) family over there have sent you out to rescue. You've accepted the mission of separating him (man) from the wicked woman. Are you quite sure she (woman)'s very bad for him (man)?'' (him)

Something in his (Chad) manner showed it as quite pulling him (Chad) up.

``Of course we are. Wouldn't YOU be?'' (unknown)

``Oh I don't know. One never does--does one?--beforehand. One can only judge on the facts. Yours are quite new to me; I'm really not in the least, as you see, in possession of them: so it will be awfully interesting to have them from you. If you're satisfied, that's all that's required. I mean if you're sure you ARE sure: sure it won't do.'' (unknown)

``That he (One) should lead such a life? Rather!'' (unknown)

``Oh but I don't know, you see, about his (One) life; you've not told me about his (One) life. She (I) may be charming--his (One) life!'' (unknown)

``Charming?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
--Strether stared before him (Strether).
``She (I)'s base, venal-out of the streets.'' (unknown)

``I see. And HE (One)--?'' (unknown)

``Chad, wretched boy?'' (unknown)

``Of what type and temper is he (Chad)?'' (she)
she (Gostrey) went on as Strether had lapsed.

``Well--the obstinate.'' (he)
It was as if for a moment he (Strether) had been going to say more and had then controlled himself.

That was scarce what she (Gostrey) wished.

``Do you like him (Chad)?'' (he)

This time he (Strether) was prompt.

``No. How CAN I?'' (unknown)

``Do you mean because of your being so saddled with him (Chad)?'' (unknown)

``I'm thinking of his (Chad) mother,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
said Strether after a moment.
``He (Chad) has darkened her (mother) admirable life.'' (He)
He (Strether) spoke with austerity.
``He (Chad) has worried her (mother) half to death.'' (unknown)

``Oh that's of course odious.'' (She)
She (Gostrey) had a pause as if for renewed emphasis of this truth, but it ended on another note.
``Is her (mother) life very admirable?'' (unknown)

``Extraordinarily.'' (Miss Gostrey)

There was so much in the tone that Miss Gostrey had to devote another pause to the appreciation of it.

``And has he (Chad) only HER? I don't mean the bad woman in Paris,'' (she)
she (Gostrey) quickly added--
``for I assure you I shouldn't even at the best be disposed to allow him (Chad) more than one. But has he (Chad) only his (Chad) mother?'' (she)

``He (Chad) has also a sister, older than himself and married; and they're both remarkably fine women.'' (unknown)

``Very handsome, you mean?'' (he)

This promptitude--almost, as he (Strether) might have thought, this precipitation, gave him (Strether) a brief drop; but he (Strether) came up again.

``Mrs. Newsome, I think, is handsome, though she (Newsome)'s not of course, with a son of twenty-eight and a daughter of thirty, in her (daughter) very first youth. She (daughter) married, however, extremely young.'' (unknown)

``And is wonderful,'' (Miss Gostrey)
Miss Gostrey asked,
``for her (daughter) age?'' (Miss Gostrey)

Strether seemed to feel with a certain disquiet the pressure of it.

``I don't say she (daughter)'s wonderful. Or rather,'' (he)
he (Strether) went on the next moment,
``I do say it. It's exactly what she (daughter) IS--wonderful. But I wasn't thinking of her (daughter) appearance,'' (he)
he (Strether) explained--
``striking as that doubtless is. I was thinking--well, of many other things.'' (he)
He (Strether) seemed to look at these as if to mention some of them; then took, pulling himself up, another turn.
``About Mrs. Pocock people may differ.'' (unknown)

``Is that the daughter's name--`Pocock'?'' (unknown)

``That's the daughter's name,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether sturdily confessed.

``And people may differ, you mean, about HER beauty?'' (unknown)

``About everything.'' (unknown)

``But YOU admire her (daughter)?'' (He)

He (Strether) gave his (Strether) friend a glance as to show how he (Strether) could bear this

``I'm perhaps a little afraid of her (daughter).'' (he)

``Oh,'' (Miss Gostrey)
said Miss Gostrey,
``I see her (daughter) from here! You may say then I see very fast and very far, but I've already shown you I do. The young man and the two ladies,'' (Miss Gostrey)
she (Gostrey) went on,
``are at any rate all the family?'' (she)

``Quite all. His (man) father has been dead ten years, and there's no brother, nor any other sister. They'd do,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
said Strether,
``anything in the world for him (brother).'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

``And you'd do anything in the world for THEM?'' (He)

He (Strether) shifted again; she (Gostrey) had made it perhaps just a shade too affirmative for his (Strether) nerves.

``Oh I don't know!'' (unknown)

``You'd do at any rate this, and the `anything' they'd do is represented by their MAKING you do it.'' (unknown)

``Ah they couldn't have come--either of them. They're very busy people and Mrs. Newsome in particular has a large full life. She (Newsome)'s moreover highly nervous--and not at all strong.'' (unknown)

``You mean she (Newsome)'s an American invalid?'' (He)

He (Strether) carefully distinguished.

``There's nothing she (Newsome) likes less than to be called one, but she (Newsome) would consent to be one of those things, I think,'' (he)
he (Strether) laughed,
``if it were the only way to be the other.'' (he)

``Consent to be an American in order to be an invalid?'' (unknown)

``No,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
said Strether,
``the other way round. She (Newsome)'s at any rate delicate sensitive high-strung. She (Newsome) puts so much of herself into everything--'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Ah Maria knew these things!

``That she (Newsome) has nothing left for anything else? Of course she (Newsome) hasn't. To whom do you say it? High-strung? Don't I spend my life, for them, jamming down the pedal? I see moreover how it has told on you.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether took this more lightly.

``Oh I jam down the pedal too!'' (unknown)

``Well,'' (she)
she (Maria) lucidly returned,
``we must from this moment bear on it together with all our might.'' (she)
And she (Maria) forged ahead.
``Have they money?'' (him)

But it was as if, while her (Maria) energetic image still held him (Strether), her (Maria) enquiry fell short.

``Mrs. Newsome,'' (he)
he (Strether) wished further to explain,
``hasn't moreover your courage on the question of contact. If she (Newsome) had come it would have been to see the person herself.'' (he)

``The woman? Ah but that's courage.'' (unknown)

``No--it's exaltation, which is a very different thing. Courage,'' (he)
he (Strether), however, accommodatingly threw out,
``is what YOU have.'' (he)

She (Maria) shook her (Maria) head.

``You say that only to patch me up--to cover the nudity of my want of exaltation. I've neither the one nor the other. I've mere battered indifference. I see that what you mean,'' (Miss Gostrey)
Miss Gostrey pursued,
``is that if your friend HAD come she (woman) would take great views, and the great views, to put it simply, would be too much for her (woman).'' (Miss Gostrey)

Strether looked amused at her (Gostrey) notion of the simple, but he (Strether) adopted her (Gostrey) formula.

``Everything's too much for her (woman).'' (unknown)

``Ah then such a service as this of yours--'' (unknown)

``Is more for her (woman) than anything else? Yes--far more. But so long as it isn't too much for ME--!'' (unknown)

``Her (woman) condition doesn't matter? Surely not; we leave her (woman) condition out; we take it, that is, for granted. I see it, her (woman) condition, as behind and beneath you; yet at the same time I see it as bearing you up.'' (unknown)

``Oh it does bear me up!'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether laughed.

``Well then as yours bears ME nothing more's needed.'' (she)
With which she (Gostrey) put again her (Gostrey) question.
``Has Mrs. Newsome money?'' (he)

This time he (Strether) heeded.

``Oh plenty. That's the root of the evil. There's money, to very large amounts, in the concern. Chad has had the free use of a great deal. But if he (Chad)'ll pull himself together and come home, all the same, he (Chad)'ll find his (Chad) account in it.'' (She)

She (Gostrey) had listened with all her (Gostrey) interest.

``And I hope to goodness you'll find yours!'' (unknown)

``He (Chad)'ll take up his (Chad) definite material reward,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
said Strether without acknowledgement of this.
``He (Chad)'s at the parting of the ways. He (Chad) can come into the business now--he (Chad) can't come later.'' (unknown)

``Is there a business?'' (unknown)

``Lord, yes--a big brave bouncing business. A roaring trade.'' (unknown)

``A great shop?'' (unknown)

``Yes--a workshop; a great production, a great industry. The concern's a manufacture--and a manufacture that, if it's only properly looked after, may well be on the way to become a monopoly. It's a little thing they make--make better, it appears, than other people can, or than other people, at any rate, do. Mr. Newsome, being a man of ideas, at least in that particular line,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether explained,
``put them on it with great effect, and gave the place altogether, in his (Newsome) time, an immense lift.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

``It's a place in itself?'' (unknown)

``Well, quite a number of buildings; almost a little industrial colony. But above all it's a thing. The article produced.'' (unknown)

``And what IS the article produced?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether looked about him (Strether) as in slight reluctance to say; then the curtain, which he (Strether) saw about to rise, came to his (Strether) aid.

``I'll tell you next time.'' (he)
But when the next time came he (Strether) only said he (Strether)'d tell her (Gostrey) later on--after they should have left the theatre; for she (Gostrey) had immediately reverted to their topic, and even for himself the picture of the stage was now overlaid with another image. His (Strether) postponements, however, made her (Gostrey) wonder--wonder if the article referred to were anything bad. And she (Gostrey) explained that she (Gostrey) meant improper or ridiculous or wrong. But Strether, so far as that went, could satisfy her (Gostrey).
``Unmentionable? Oh no, we constantly talk of it; we are quite familiar and brazen about it. Only, as a small, trivial, rather ridiculous object of the commonest domestic use, it's just wanting in-what shall I say? Well, dignity, or the least approach to distinction. Right here therefore, with everything about us so grand--!'' (he)
In short he (Strether) shrank.

``It's a false note?'' (unknown)

``Sadly. It's vulgar.'' (unknown)

``But surely not vulgarer than this.'' (she)
Then on his (Strether) wondering as she (Gostrey) herself had done:
``Than everything about us.'' (she)
She (Gostrey) seemed a trifle irritated.
``What do you take this for?'' (unknown)

``Why for--comparatively--divine!'' (unknown)

``This dreadful London theatre? It's impossible, if you really want to know.'' (unknown)

``Oh then,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
laughed Strether, ``I DON
``T really want to know!'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

It made between them a pause, which she (Gostrey), however, still fascinated by the mystery of the production at Woollett, presently broke.

''`Rather ridiculous'? Clothes-pins? Saleratus? Shoe-polish?'' (she)

It brought him (Strether) round. ``No--you don't even ``burn.

'' I don't think, you know, you'll guess it.'' (unknown)

``How then can I judge how vulgar it is?'' (unknown)

``You'll judge when I do tell you'' (he)
--and he (Strether) persuaded her (Gostrey) to patience. But it may even now frankly be mentioned that he (Strether) in the sequel never WAS to tell her (Gostrey). He (Strether) actually never did so, and it moreover oddly occurred that by the law, within her (Gostrey), of the incalculable, her (Gostrey) desire for the information dropped and her (Gostrey) attitude to the question converted itself into a positive cultivation of ignorance. In ignorance she (Gostrey) could humour her (Gostrey) fancy, and that proved a useful freedom. She (Gostrey) could treat the little nameless object as indeed unnameable--she (Gostrey) could make their abstention enormously definite. There might indeed have been for Strether the portent of this in what she (Gostrey) next said.

``Is it perhaps then because it's so bad--because your industry as you call it, IS so vulgar--that Mr. Chad won't come back? Does he (Chad) feel the taint? Is he (Chad) staying away not to be mixed up in it?'' (unknown)

``Oh,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether laughed,
``it wouldn't appear--would it?--that he (Chad) feels `taints'! He (Chad)'s glad enough of the money from it, and the money's his (Chad) whole basis. There's appreciation in that--I mean as to the allowance his (Chad) mother has hitherto made him (Chad). She (mother) has of course the resource of cutting this allowance off; but even then he (Chad) has unfortunately, and on no small scale, his (Chad) independent supply--money left him (Chad) by his (Chad) grandfather, her (mother) own father.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

``Wouldn't the fact you mention then,'' (Miss Gostrey)
Miss Gostrey asked,
``make it just more easy for him (Chad) to be particular? Isn't he (Chad) conceivable as fastidious about the source--the apparent and public source--of his (Chad) income?'' (Miss Gostrey)

Strether was able quite good-humouredly to entertain the proposition.

``The source of his (Chad) grandfather's wealth--and thereby of his (Chad) own share in it--was not particularly noble.'' (unknown)

``And what source was it?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether cast about.

``Well--practices.'' (unknown)

``In business? Infamies? He (Chad) was an old swindler?'' (unknown)

``Oh,'' (he)
he (Strether) said with more emphasis than spirit,
``I shan't describe HIM nor narrate his (Chad) exploits.'' (he)

``Lord, what abysses! And the late Mr. Newsome then?'' (unknown)

``Well, what about him (Newsome)?'' (unknown)

``Was he (Newsome) like the grandfather?'' (unknown)

``No--he (grandfather) was on the other side of the house. And he (grandfather) was different.'' (Miss Gostrey)

Miss Gostrey kept it up.

``Better?'' (friend)

Her (Gostrey) friend for a moment hung fire.

``No.'' (unknown)

Her (Gostrey) comment on his (friend) hesitation was scarce the less marked for being mute.

``Thank you. NOW don't you see,'' (she)
she (Gostrey) went on,
``why the boy doesn't come home? He (boy)'s drowning his (boy) shame.'' (she)

``His (boy) shame? What shame?'' (unknown)

``What shame? Comment donc? THE shame.'' (unknown)

``But where and when,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether asked, ``is
``THE shame'--where is any shame--to-day? The men I speak of--they did as every one does; and -LRB-besides being ancient history-RRB- it was all a matter of appreciation.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

She (Gostrey) showed how she (Gostrey) understood.

``Mrs. Newsome has appreciated?'' (unknown)

``Ah I can't speak for HER!'' (unknown)

``In the midst of such doings--and, as I understand you, profiting by them, she (Newsome) at least has remained exquisite?'' (unknown)

``Oh I can't talk of her (Newsome)!'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether said.

``I thought she (Newsome) was just what you COULD talk of. You DON

``T trust me,'' (unknown)
Miss Gostrey after a moment declared.

It had its effect.

``Well, her (Newsome) money is spent, her (Newsome) life conceived and carried on with a large beneficence--'' (unknown)

``That's a kind of expiation of wrongs? Gracious,'' (she)
she (Gostrey) added before he (Strether) could speak,
``how intensely you make me see her (Newsome)!'' (he)

``If you see her (Newsome),'' (Strether)
Strether dropped,
``it's all that's necessary.'' (Strether)

She (Gostrey) really seemed to have her (Gostrey).

``I feel that. She (Newsome) IS, in spite of everything, handsome.'' (him)

This at least enlivened him (Strether).

``What do you mean by everything?'' (unknown)

``Well, I mean YOU.'' (she)
With which she (Gostrey) had one of her (Gostrey) swift changes of ground.
``You say the concern needs looking after; but doesn't Mrs. Newsome look after it?'' (unknown)

``So far as possible. She (Newsome)'s wonderfully able, but it's not her (Newsome) affair, and her (Newsome) life's a good deal overcharged. She (Newsome) has many, many things.'' (unknown)

``And you also?'' (unknown)

``Oh yes--I've many too, if you will.'' (unknown)

``I see. But what I mean is,'' (Miss Gostrey)
Miss Gostrey amended,
``do you also look after the business?'' (Miss Gostrey)

``Oh no, I don't touch the business.'' (unknown)

``Only everything else?'' (unknown)

``Well, yes--some things.'' (unknown)

``As for instance--?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether obligingly thought.

``Well, the Review.'' (unknown)

``The Review?--you have a Review?'' (unknown)

``Certainly. Woollett has a Review--which Mrs. Newsome, for the most part, magnificently pays for and which I, not at all magnificently, edit. My name's on the cover,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether pursued,
``and I'm really rather disappointed and hurt that you seem never to have heard of it.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

She (Gostrey) neglected for a moment this grievance.

``And what kind of a Review is it?'' (unknown)

His (Strether) serenity was now completely restored.

``Well, it's green.'' (unknown)

``Do you mean in political colour as they say here--in thought?'' (unknown)

``No; I mean the cover's green--of the most lovely shade.'' (unknown)

``And with Mrs. Newsome's name on it too?'' (He)

He (Strether) waited a little.

``Oh as for that you must judge if she (Newsome) peeps out. She (Newsome)'s behind the whole thing; but she (Newsome)'s of a delicacy and a discretion--!'' (Miss Gostrey)

Miss Gostrey took it all.

``I'm sure. She (Newsome) WOULD be. I don't underrate her (Newsome). She (Newsome) must be rather a swell.'' (unknown)

``Oh yes, she (Newsome)'s rather a swell!'' (unknown)

``A Woollett swell--bon! I like the idea of a Woollett swell. And you must be rather one too, to be so mixed up with her (Newsome).'' (unknown)

``Ah no,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
said Strether,
``that's not the way it works.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

But she (Gostrey) had already taken him (Strether) up.

``The way it works--you needn't tell me!--is of course that you efface yourself.'' (unknown)

``With my name on the cover?'' (he)
he (Strether) lucidly objected.

``Ah but you don't put it on for yourself.'' (unknown)

``I beg your pardon--that's exactly what I do put it on for. It's exactly the thing that I'm reduced to doing for myself. It seems to rescue a little, you see, from the wreck of hopes and ambitions, the refuse-heap of disappointments and failures, my one presentable little scrap of an identity.'' (she)

On this she (Gostrey) looked at him (Strether) as to say many things, but what she (Gostrey) at last simply said was:

``She (me) likes to see it there. You're the bigger swell of the two,'' (she)
she (Gostrey) immediately continued,
``because you think you're not one. She (me) thinks she (me) IS one. However,'' (she)
Miss Gostrey added,
``she (me) thinks you're one too. You're at all events the biggest she (me) can get hold of.'' (Miss Gostrey)
She (Gostrey) embroidered, she (Gostrey) abounded.
``I don't say it to interfere between you, but on the day she (me) gets hold of a bigger one--!'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether had thrown back his (Strether) head as in silent mirth over something that struck him (Strether) in her (Gostrey) audacity or felicity, and her (Gostrey) flight meanwhile was already higher.
``Therefore close with her (me)--!'' (unknown)

``Close with her (me)?'' (he)
he (Strether) asked as she (Gostrey) seemed to hang poised.

``Before you lose your chance.'' (unknown)

Their eyes met over it.

``What do you mean by closing?'' (unknown)

``And what do I mean by your chance? I'll tell you when you tell me all the things YOU don't. Is it her (me) GREATEST fad?'' (she)
she (Gostrey) briskly pursued.

``The Review?'' (He)
He (Strether) seemed to wonder how he (Strether) could best describe it. This resulted however but in a sketch.
``It's her (me) tribute to the ideal.'' (unknown)

``I see. You go in for tremendous things.'' (unknown)

``We go in for the unpopular side--that is so far as we dare.'' (unknown)

``And how far DO you dare?'' (unknown)

``Well, she (me) very far. I much less. I don't begin to have her (me) faith. She (me) provides,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
said Strether,
``three fourths of that. And she (me) provides, as I've confided to you, ALL the money.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

It evoked somehow a vision of gold that held for a little Miss Gostrey's eyes, and she (Gostrey) looked as if she (Gostrey) heard the bright dollars shovelled in.

``I hope then you make a good thing--'' (he)

``I NEVER made a good thing!'' (he)
he (Strether) at once returned.

She (Gostrey) just waited.

``Don't you call it a good thing to be loved?'' (unknown)

``Oh we're not loved. We're not even hated. We're only just sweetly ignored.'' (She)

She (Gostrey) had another pause.

``You don't trust me!'' (she)
she (Gostrey) once more repeated.

``Don't I when I lift the last veil?--tell you the very secret of the prison-house?'' (she)

Again she (Gostrey) met his (Strether) eyes, but to the result that after an instant her (Gostrey) own turned away with impatience.

``You don't sell? Oh I'm glad of THAT!'' (he)
After which however, and before he (Strether) could protest, she (Gostrey) was off again.
``She (we)'s just a MORAL swell.'' (He)

He (Strether) accepted gaily enough the definition.

``Yes--I really think that describes her (we).'' (friend)

But it had for his (Strether) friend the oddest connexion.

``How does she (we) do her (we) hair?'' (He)

He (Strether) laughed out.

``Beautifully!'' (unknown)

``Ah that doesn't tell me. However, it doesn't matter--I know. It's tremendously neat--a real reproach; quite remarkably thick and without, as yet, a single strand of white. There!'' (He)

He (Strether) blushed for her (Gostrey) realism, but gaped at her (Gostrey) truth.

``You're the very deuce.'' (unknown)

``What else SHOULD I be? It was as the very deuce I pounced on you. But don't let it trouble you, for everything but the very deuce--at our age--is a bore and a delusion, and even he (I) himself, after all, but half a joy.'' (she)
With which, on a single sweep of her (Gostrey) wing, she (Gostrey) resumed.
``You assist her (it) to expiate--which is rather hard when you've yourself not sinned.'' (unknown)

``It's she (it) who hasn't sinned,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether replied.
``I've sinned the most.'' (unknown)

``Ah,'' (Miss Gostrey)
Miss Gostrey cynically laughed,
``what a picture of HER! Have you robbed the widow and the orphan?'' (Miss Gostrey)

``I've sinned enough,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
said Strether.

``Enough for whom? Enough for what?'' (unknown)

``Well, to be where I am.'' (unknown)

``Thank you!'' (a gentleman)
They were disturbed at this moment by the passage between their knees and the back of the seats before them of a gentleman who had been absent during a part of the performance and who now returned for the close; but the interruption left Miss Gostrey time, before the subsequent hush, to express as a sharp finality her (Gostrey) sense of the moral of all their talk.
``I knew you had something up your sleeve!'' (unknown)
This finality, however, left them in its turn, at the end of the play, as disposed to hang back as if they had still much to say; so that they easily agreed to let every one go before them--they found an interest in waiting. They made out from the lobby that the night had turned to rain; yet Miss Gostrey let her (Gostrey) friend know that he (friend) wasn't to see her (Gostrey) home. He (friend) was simply to put her (Gostrey), by herself, into a four-wheeler; she (Gostrey) liked so in London, of wet nights after wild pleasures, thinking things over, on the return, in lonely four-wheelers. This was her (Gostrey) great time, she (Gostrey) intimated, for pulling herself together. The delays caused by the weather, the struggle for vehicles at the door, gave them occasion to subside on a divan at the back of the vestibule and just beyond the reach of the fresh damp gusts from the street. Here Strether's comrade resumed that free handling of the subject to which his (Strether) own imagination of it already owed so much.
``Does your young friend in Paris like you?'' (him)

It had almost, after the interval, startled him (Strether).

``Oh I hope not! Why SHOULD he (friend)?'' (unknown)

``Why shouldn't he (friend)?'' (Miss Gostrey)
Miss Gostrey asked.
``That you're coming down on him (friend) need have nothing to do with it.'' (unknown)

``You see more in it,'' (he)
he (Strether) presently returned,
``than I.'' (he)

``Of course I see you in it.'' (he)

``Well then you see more in `me'!'' (unknown)

``Than you see in yourself? Very likely. That's always one's right. What I was thinking of,'' (she)
she (Gostrey) explained,
``is the possible particular effect on him (friend) of his (friend) milieu.'' (she)

``Oh his (friend) milieu--!'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether really felt he (Strether) could imagine it better now than three hours before.

``Do you mean it can only have been so lowering?'' (unknown)

``Why that's my very starting-point.'' (unknown)

``Yes, but you start so far back. What do his (friend) letters say?'' (unknown)

``Nothing. He (friend) practically ignores us--or spares us. He (friend) doesn't write.'' (unknown)

``I see. But there are all the same,'' (she)
she (Gostrey) went on,
``two quite distinct things that--given the wonderful place he (friend)'s in--may have happened to him (friend). One is that he (friend) may have got brutalised. The other is that he (friend) may have got refined.'' (she)

Strether stared--this WAS a novelty.

``Refined?'' (unknown)

``Oh,'' (she)
she (Gostrey) said quietly,
``there ARE refinements.'' (she)

The way of it made him (Strether), after looking at her (Gostrey), break into a laugh.

``YOU have them!'' (unknown)

``As one of the signs,'' (she)
she (Gostrey) continued in the same tone,
``they constitute perhaps the worst.'' (she)

He (Strether) thought it over and his (Strether) gravity returned.

``Is it a refinement not to answer his (friend) mother's letters?'' (She)

She (Gostrey) appeared to have a scruple, but she (Gostrey) brought it out.

``Oh I should say the greatest of all.'' (unknown)

``Well,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
said Strether,
``I'M quite content to let it, as one of the signs, pass for the worst that I know he (friend) believes he (friend) can do what he (friend) likes with me.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

This appeared to strike her (Gostrey).

``How do you know it?'' (unknown)

``Oh I'm sure of it. I feel it in my bones.'' (unknown)

``Feel he (friend) CAN do it?'' (unknown)

``Feel that he (friend) believes he (friend) can. It may come to the same thing!'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether laughed.

She (Gostrey) wouldn't, however, have this.

``Nothing for you will ever come to the same thing as anything else.'' (she)
And she (Gostrey) understood what she (Gostrey) meant, it seemed, sufficiently to go straight on.
``You say that if he (friend) does break he (friend)'ll come in for things at home?'' (unknown)

``Quite positively. He (friend)'ll come in for a particular chance--a chance that any properly constituted young man would jump at. The business has so developed that an opening scarcely apparent three years ago, but which his (man) father's will took account of as in certain conditions possible and which, under that will, attaches to Chad's availing himself of it a large contingent advantage--this opening, the conditions having come about, now simply awaits him (Chad). His (Chad) mother has kept it for him (Chad), holding out against strong pressure, till the last possible moment. It requires, naturally, as it carries with it a handsome ``part,

'' a large share in profits, his (Strether) being on the spot and making a big effort for a big result. That's what I mean by his (Strether) chance. If he (Strether) misses it he (Strether) comes in, as you say, for nothing. And to see that he (Strether) doesn't miss it is, in a word, what I've come out for.'' (She)

She (Gostrey) let it all sink in.

``What you've come out for then is simply to render him (Chad) an immense service.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Well, poor Strether was willing to take it so.

``Ah if you like.'' (unknown)

``He (Chad) stands, as they say, if you succeed with him (Chad), to gain--'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

``Oh a lot of advantages.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether had them clearly at his (Strether) fingers' ends.

``By which you mean of course a lot of money.'' (unknown)

``Well, not only. I'm acting with a sense for him (Chad) of other things too. Consideration and comfort and security--the general safety of being anchored by a strong chain. He (Chad) wants, as I see him (Chad), to be protected. Protected I mean from life.'' (unknown)

``Ah voila!'' (unknown)
--her (Gostrey) thought fitted with a click.
``From life. What you REALLY want to get him (Chad) home for is to marry him (Chad).'' (unknown)

``Well, that's about the size of it.'' (unknown)

``Of course,'' (she)
she (Gostrey) said,
``it's rudimentary. But to any one in particular?'' (she)

He (Strether) smiled at this, looking a little more conscious.

``You get everything out.'' (unknown)

For a moment again their eyes met.

``You put everything in!'' (He)

He (Strether) acknowledged the tribute by telling her (Gostrey).

``To Mamie Pocock.'' (She)

She (Gostrey) wondered; then gravely, even exquisitely, as if to make the oddity also fit:

``His (Chad) own niece?'' (She)

``Oh you must yourself find a name for the relation. His (Chad) brother-in-law's sister. Mrs. Jim's sister-in-law.'' (unknown)

It seemed to have on Miss Gostrey a certain hardening effect.

``And who in the world's Mrs. Jim?'' (unknown)
