``Chad's sister--who was Sarah Newsome. She (Sarah)'s married--didn't I mention it?--to Jim Pocock.'' (unknown)

``Ah yes,'' (she)
she (Gostrey) tacitly replied; but he (Strether) had mentioned things--! Then, however, with all the sound it could have,
``Who in the world's Jim Pocock?'' (she)
she (Gostrey) asked.

``Why Sally's husband. That's the only way we distinguish people at Woollett,'' (he)
he (Strether) good-humoredly explained.

``And is it a great distinction--being Sally's husband?'' (He)

He (Strether) considered.

``I think there can be scarcely a greater--unless it may become one, in the future, to be Chad's wife.'' (unknown)

``Then how do they distinguish YOU?'' (unknown)

``They DON

``T--except, as I've told you, by the green cover.'' (she)

Once more their eyes met on it, and she (Gostrey) held him (Strether) an instant.

``The green cover won't--nor will ANY cover--avail you with ME. You're of a depth of duplicity!'' (she)
Still, she (Gostrey) could in her (Gostrey) own large grasp of the real condone it.
``Is Mamie a great parti?'' (unknown)

``Oh the greatest we have--our prettiest brightest girl.'' (Miss Gostrey)

Miss Gostrey seemed to fix the poor child.

``I know what they CAN be. And with money?'' (unknown)

``Not perhaps with a great deal of that--but with so much of everything else that we don't miss it. We DON``T miss money much, you know,'' Strether added,

``in general, in America, in pretty girls.'' (unknown)

``No,'' (she)
she (Gostrey) conceded;
``but I know also what you do sometimes miss. And do you,'' (she)
she (Gostrey) asked,
``yourself admire her (girl)?'' (she)

It was a question, he (Strether) indicated, that there might be several ways of taking; but he (Strether) decided after an instant for the humorous.

``Haven't I sufficiently showed you how I admire ANY pretty girl?'' (she)

Her (Gostrey) interest in his (Strether) problem was by this time such that it scarce left her (Gostrey) freedom, and she (Gostrey) kept close to the facts.

``I supposed that at Woollett you wanted them--what shall I call it?--blameless. I mean your young men for your pretty girls.'' (unknown)

``So did I!'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether confessed.
``But you strike there a curious fact--the fact that Woollett too accommodates itself to the spirit of the age and the increasing mildness of manners. Everything changes, and I hold that our situation precisely marks a date. We SHOULD prefer them blameless, but we have to make the best of them as we find them. Since the spirit of the age and the increasing mildness send them so much more to Paris--'' (unknown)

``You've to take them back as they come. When they DO come. Bon!'' (she)
Once more she (Gostrey) embraced it all, but she (Gostrey) had a moment of thought.
``Poor Chad!'' (unknown)

``Ah,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
said Strether cheerfully
``Mamie will save him (Chad)!'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

She (Gostrey) was looking away, still in her (Gostrey) vision, and she (Gostrey) spoke with impatience and almost as if he (Strether) hadn't understood her (Gostrey).

``YOU'LL save him (Chad). That's who'll save him (Chad).'' (unknown)

``Oh but with Mamie's aid. Unless indeed you mean,'' (he)
he (Strether) added,
``that I shall effect so much more with yours!'' (he)

It made her (Gostrey) at last again look at him (Strether).

``You'll do more--as you're so much better--than all of us put together.'' (unknown)

``I think I'm only better since I've known YOU!'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether bravely returned.

The depletion of the place, the shrinkage of the crowd and now comparatively quiet withdrawal of its last elements had already brought them nearer the door and put them in relation with a messenger of whom he (Strether) bespoke Miss Gostrey's cab. But this left them a few minutes more, which she (Gostrey) was clearly in no mood not to use.

``You've spoken to me of what--by your success--Mr. Chad stands to gain. But you've not spoken to me of what you do.'' (unknown)

``Oh I've nothing more to gain,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
said Strether very simply.

She (Gostrey) took it as even quite too simple.

``You mean you've got it all `down'? You've been paid in advance?'' (unknown)

``Ah don't talk about payment!'' (he)
he (Strether) groaned.

Something in the tone of it pulled her (Gostrey) up, but as their messenger still delayed she (Gostrey) had another chance and she (Gostrey) put it in another way.

``What--by failure--do you stand to lose?'' (He)

He (Strether) still, however, wouldn't have it.

``Nothing!'' (he)
he (Strether) exclaimed, and on the messenger's at this instant reappearing he (Strether) was able to sink the subject in their responsive advance. When, a few steps up the street, under a lamp, he (Strether) had put her (Gostrey) into her (Gostrey) four-wheeler and she (Gostrey) had asked him (Strether) if the man had called for him (man) no second conveyance, he (man) replied before the door was closed.
``You won't take me with you?'' (unknown)

``Not for the world.'' (unknown)

``Then I shall walk.'' (unknown)

``In the rain?'' (unknown)

``I like the rain,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
said Strether.
``Good-night!'' (She)

She (Gostrey) kept him (Strether) a moment, while his (Strether) hand was on the door, by not answering; after which she (Gostrey) answered by repeating her (Gostrey) question.

``What do you stand to lose?'' (him)

Why the question now affected him (Strether) as other he (Strether) couldn't have said; he (Strether) could only this time meet it otherwise.

``Everything.'' (unknown)

``So I thought. Then you shall succeed. And to that end I'm yours--'' (he)

``Ah, dear lady!'' (he)
he (Strether) kindly breathed.

``Till death!'' (Maria/Maria Gostrey)
said Maria Gostrey.
``Good-night.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

II

Strether called, his (Strether) second morning in Paris, on the bankers of the Rue Scribe to whom his (Scribe) letter of credit was addressed, and he (Scribe) made this visit attended by Waymarsh, in whose company he (Scribe) had crossed from London two days before. They had hastened to the Rue Scribe on the morrow of their arrival, but Strether had not then found the letters the hope of which prompted this errand. He (Strether) had had as yet none at all; hadn't expected them in London, but had counted on several in Paris, and, disconcerted now, had presently strolled back to the Boulevard with a sense of injury that he (Strether) felt himself taking for as good a start as any other. It would serve, this spur to his (Strether) spirit, he (Strether) reflected, as, pausing at the top of the street, he (Strether) looked up and down the great foreign avenue, it would serve to begin business with. His (Strether) idea was to begin business immediately, and it did much for him (Strether) the rest of his (Strether) day that the beginning of business awaited him (Strether). He (Strether) did little else till night but ask himself what he (Strether) should do if he (Strether) hadn't fortunately had so much to do; but he (Strether) put himself the question in many different situations and connexions. What carried him (Strether) hither and yon was an admirable theory that nothing he (Strether) could do wouldn't be in some manner related to what he (Strether) fundamentally had on hand, or WOULD be--should he (Strether) happen to have a scruple--wasted for it. He (Strether) did happen to have a scruple--a scruple about taking no definite step till he (Strether) should get letters; but this reasoning carried it off. A single day to feel his (Strether) feet--he (Strether) had felt them as yet only at Chester and in London--was he (Strether) could consider, none too much; and having, as he (Strether) had often privately expressed it, Paris to reckon with, he (Strether) threw these hours of freshness consciously into the reckoning. They made it continually greater, but that was what it had best be if it was to be anything at all, and he (Strether) gave himself up till far into the evening, at the theatre and on the return, after the theatre, along the bright congested Boulevard, to feeling it grow. Waymarsh had accompanied him (Strether) this time to the play, and the two men had walked together, as a first stage, from the Gymnase to the Cafe Riche, into the crowded

``terrace'' (the men)
of which establishment--the night, or rather the morning, for midnight had struck, being bland and populous--they had wedged themselves for refreshment. Waymarsh, as a result of some discussion with his (Strether) friend, had made a marked virtue of his (Strether) having now let himself go; and there had been elements of impression in their half-hour over their watered beer-glasses that gave him (Strether) his (Strether) occasion for conveying that he (Strether) held this compromise with his (Strether) stiffer self to have become extreme. He (Strether) conveyed it--for it was still, after all, his (Strether) stiffer self who gloomed out of the glare of the terrace--in solemn silence; and there was indeed a great deal of critical silence, every way, between the companions, even till they gained the Place de l``Opera, as to the character of their nocturnal progress.

This morning there WERE letters--letters which had reached London, apparently all together, the day of Strether's journey, and had taken their time to follow him (Strether); so that, after a controlled impulse to go into them in the reception-room of the bank, which, reminding him (Strether) of the post-office at Woollett, affected him (Strether) as the abutment of some transatlantic bridge, he (Strether) slipped them into the pocket of his (Strether) loose grey overcoat with a sense of the felicity of carrying them off. Waymarsh, who had had letters yesterday, had had them again to-day, and Waymarsh suggested in this particular no controlled impulses. The last one he (Strether) was at all events likely to be observed to struggle with was clearly that of bringing to a premature close any visit to the Rue Scribe. Strether had left him (Strether) there yesterday; he (Strether) wanted to see the papers, and he (Strether) had spent, by what his (Strether) friend could make out, a succession of hours with the papers. He (Strether) spoke of the establishment, with emphasis, as a post of superior observation; just as he (Strether) spoke generally of his (Strether) actual damnable doom as a device for hiding from him (Strether) what was going on. Europe was best described, to his (Strether) mind, as an elaborate engine for dissociating the confined American from that indispensable knowledge, and was accordingly only rendered bearable by these occasional stations of relief, traps for the arrest of wandering western airs. Strether, on his (Strether) side, set himself to walk again--he (Strether) had his (Strether) relief in his (Strether) pocket; and indeed, much as he (Strether) had desired his (Strether) budget, the growth of restlessness might have been marked in him (Strether) from the moment he (Strether) had assured himself of the superscription of most of the missives it contained. This restlessness became therefore his (Strether) temporary law; he (Strether) knew he (Strether) should recognise as soon as see it the best place of all for settling down with his (Strether) chief correspondent. He (Strether) had for the next hour an accidental air of looking for it in the windows of shops; he (Strether) came down the Rue de la Paix in the sun and, passing across the Tuileries and the river, indulged more than once--as if on finding himself determined--in a sudden pause before the book-stalls of the opposite quay. In the garden of the Tuileries he (Strether) had lingered, on two or three spots, to look; it was as if the wonderful Paris spring had stayed him (Strether) as he (Strether) roamed. The prompt Paris morning struck its cheerful notes--in a soft breeze and a sprinkled smell, in the light flit, over the garden-floor, of bareheaded girls with the buckled strap of oblong boxes, in the type of ancient thrifty persons basking betimes where terrace-walls were warm, in the blue-frocked brass-labelled officialism of humble rakers and scrapers, in the deep references of a straight-pacing priest or the sharp ones of a white-gaitered red-legged soldier. He (soldier) watched little brisk figures, figures whose movement was as the tick of the great Paris clock, take their smooth diagonal from point to point; the air had a taste as of something mixed with art, something that presented nature as a white-capped master-chef. The palace was gone, Strether remembered the palace; and when he (Strether) gazed into the irremediable void of its site the historic sense in him (Strether) might have been freely at play--the play under which in Paris indeed it so often winces like a touched nerve. He (Strether) filled out spaces with dim symbols of scenes; he (Strether) caught the gleam of white statues at the base of which, with his (Strether) letters out, he (Strether) could tilt back a straw-bottomed chair. But his (Strether) drift was, for reasons, to the other side, and it floated him (Strether) unspent up the Rue de Seine and as far as the Luxembourg. In the Luxembourg Gardens he (Strether) pulled up; here at last he (Strether) found his (Strether) nook, and here, on a penny chair from which terraces, alleys, vistas, fountains, little trees in green tubs, little women in white caps and shrill little girls at play all sunnily

``composed'' (girls)
together, he (Strether) passed an hour in which the cup of his (Strether) impressions seemed truly to overflow. But a week had elapsed since he (Strether) quitted the ship, and there were more things in his (Strether) mind than so few days could account for. More than once, during the time, he (Strether) had regarded himself as admonished; but the admonition this morning was formidably sharp. It took as it hadn't done yet the form of a question--the question of what he (Strether) was doing with such an extraordinary sense of escape. This sense was sharpest after he (Strether) had read his (Strether) letters, but that was also precisely why the question pressed. Four of the letters were from Mrs. Newsome and none of them short; she (Newsome) had lost no time, had followed on his (Strether) heels while he (Strether) moved, so expressing herself that he (Strether) now could measure the probable frequency with which he (Strether) should hear. They would arrive, it would seem, her (Newsome) communications, at the rate of several a week; he (Strether) should be able to count, it might even prove, on more than one by each mail. If he (Strether) had begun yesterday with a small grievance he (Strether) had therefore an opportunity to begin to-day with its opposite. He (Strether) read the letters successively and slowly, putting others back into his (Strether) pocket but keeping these for a long time afterwards gathered in his (Strether) lap. He (Strether) held them there, lost in thought, as if to prolong the presence of what they gave him (Strether); or as if at the least to assure them their part in the constitution of some lucidity. His (Strether) friend wrote admirably, and her (Strether) tone was even more in her (Strether) style than in her (Strether) voice--he (Strether) might almost, for the hour, have had to come this distance to get its full carrying quality; yet the plentitude of his (Strether) consciousness of difference consorted perfectly with the deepened intensity of the connexion. It was the difference, the difference of being just where he (Strether) was and AS he (Strether) was, that formed the escape--this difference was so much greater than he (Strether) had dreamed it would be; and what he (Strether) finally sat there turning over was the strange logic of his (Strether) finding himself so free. He (Strether) felt it in a manner his (Strether) duty to think out his (Strether) state, to approve the process, and when he (Strether) came in fact to trace the steps and add up the items they sufficiently accounted for the sum. He (Strether) had never expected--that was the truth of it--again to find himself young, and all the years and other things it had taken to make him (Strether) so were exactly his (Strether) present arithmetic. He (Strether) had to make sure of them to put his (Strether) scruple to rest.

It all sprang at bottom from the beauty of Mrs. Newsome's desire that he (Strether) should be worried with nothing that was not of the essence of his (Strether) task; by insisting that he (Strether) should thoroughly intermit and break she (Newsome) had so provided for his (Strether) freedom that she (Newsome) would, as it were, have only herself to thank. Strether could not at this point indeed have completed his (Strether) thought by the image of what she (Newsome) might have to thank herself FOR: the image, at best, of his (Strether) own likeness-poor Lambert Strether washed up on the sunny strand by the waves of a single day, poor Lambert Strether thankful for breathing-time and stiffening himself while he (Strether) gasped. There he (Strether) was, and with nothing in his (Strether) aspect or his (Strether) posture to scandalise: it was only true that if he (Strether) had seen Mrs. Newsome coming he (Strether) would instinctively have jumped up to walk away a little. He (Strether) would have come round and back to her (Newsome) bravely, but he (Strether) would have had first to pull himself together. She (Newsome) abounded in news of the situation at home, proved to him (Strether) how perfectly she (Newsome) was arranging for his (Strether) absence, told him (Strether) who would take up this and who take up that exactly where he (Strether) had left it, gave him (Strether) in fact chapter and verse for the moral that nothing would suffer. It filled for him (Strether), this tone of hers, all the air; yet it struck him (Strether) at the same time as the hum of vain things. This latter effect was what he (Strether) tried to justify--and with the success that, grave though the appearance, he (Strether) at last lighted on a form that was happy. He (Strether) arrived at it by the inevitable recognition of his (Strether) having been a fortnight before one of the weariest of men. If ever a man had come off tired Lambert Strether was that man; and hadn't it been distinctly on the ground of his (Strether) fatigue that his (Strether) wonderful friend at home had so felt for him (Strether) and so contrived? It seemed to him (Strether) somehow at these instants that, could he (Strether) only maintain with sufficient firmness his (Strether) grasp of that truth, it might become in a manner his (Strether) compass and his (Strether) helm. What he (Strether) wanted most was some idea that would simplify, and nothing would do this so much as the fact that he (Strether) was done for and finished. If it had been in such a light that he (Strether) had just detected in his (Strether) cup the dregs of youth, that was a mere flaw of the surface of his (Strether) scheme. He (Strether) was so distinctly fagged-out that it must serve precisely as his (Strether) convenience, and if he (Strether) could but consistently be good for little enough he (Strether) might do everything he (Strether) wanted.

Everything he (Strether) wanted was comprised moreover in a single boon--the common unattainable art of taking things as they came. He (Strether) appeared to himself to have given his (Strether) best years to an active appreciation of the way they didn't come; but perhaps--as they would seemingly here be things quite other--this long ache might at last drop to rest. He (Strether) could easily see that from the moment he (Strether) should accept the notion of his (Strether) foredoomed collapse the last thing he (Strether) would lack would be reasons and memories. Oh if he (Strether) SHOULD do the sum no slate would hold the figures! The fact that he (Strether) had failed, as he (Strether) considered, in everything, in each relation and in half a dozen trades, as he (Strether) liked luxuriously to put it, might have made, might still make, for an empty present; but it stood solidly for a crowded past. It had not been, so much achievement missed, a light yoke nor a short load. It was at present as if the backward picture had hung there, the long crooked course, grey in the shadow of his (Strether) solitude. It had been a dreadful cheerful sociable solitude, a solitude of life or choice, of community; but though there had been people enough all round it there had been but three or four persons IN it. Waymarsh was one of these, and the fact struck him (Strether) just now as marking the record. Mrs. Newsome was another, and Miss Gostrey had of a sudden shown signs of becoming a third. Beyond, behind them was the pale figure of his (Strether) real youth, which held against its breast the two presences paler than itself--the young wife he (Strether) had early lost and the young son he (Strether) had stupidly sacrificed. He (Strether) had again and again made out for himself that he (Strether) might have kept his (Strether) little boy, his (Strether) little dull boy who had died at school of rapid diphtheria, if he (Strether) had not in those years so insanely given himself to merely missing the mother. It was the soreness of his (Strether) remorse that the child had in all likelihood not really been dull--had been dull, as he (Strether) had been banished and neglected, mainly because the father had been unwittingly selfish. This was doubtless but the secret habit of sorrow, which had slowly given way to time; yet there remained an ache sharp enough to make the spirit, at the sight now and again of some fair young man just growing up, wince with the thought of an opportunity lost. Had ever a man, he (man) had finally fallen into the way of asking himself, lost so much and even done so much for so little? There had been particular reasons why all yesterday, beyond other days, he (man) should have had in one ear this cold enquiry. His (man) name on the green cover, where he (man) had put it for Mrs. Newsome, expressed him (man) doubtless just enough to make the world--the world as distinguished, both for more and for less, from Woollett--ask who he (man) was. He (man) had incurred the ridicule of having to have his (man) explanation explained. He (man) was Lambert Strether because he (man) was on the cover, whereas it should have been, for anything like glory, that he (man) was on the cover because he (man) was Lambert Strether. He (man) would have done anything for Mrs. Newsome, have been still more ridiculous--as he (man) might, for that matter, have occasion to be yet; which came to saying that this acceptance of fate was all he (man) had to show at fifty-five.

He (man) judged the quantity as small because it WAS small, and all the more egregiously since it couldn't, as he (man) saw the case, so much as thinkably have been larger. He (man) hadn't had the gift of making the most of what he (man) tried, and if he (man) had tried and tried again--no one but himself knew how often--it appeared to have been that he (man) might demonstrate what else, in default of that, COULD be made. Old ghosts of experiments came back to him (man), old drudgeries and delusions, and disgusts, old recoveries with their relapses, old fevers with their chills, broken moments of good faith, others of still better doubt; adventures, for the most part, of the sort qualified as lessons. The special spring that had constantly played for him (man) the day before was the recognition--frequent enough to surprise him (man)--of the promises to himself that he (man) had after his (man) other visit never kept. The reminiscence to-day most quickened for him (man) was that of the vow taken in the course of the pilgrimage that, newly-married, with the War just over, and helplessly young in spite of it, he (man) had recklessly made with the creature who was so much younger still. It had been a bold dash, for which they had taken money set apart for necessities, but kept sacred at the moment in a hundred ways, and in none more so than by this private pledge of his (man) own to treat the occasion as a relation formed with the higher culture and see that, as they said at Woollett, it should bear a good harvest. He (man) had believed, sailing home again, that he (man) had gained something great, and his (man) theory--with an elaborate innocent plan of reading, digesting, coming back even, every few years--had then been to preserve, cherish and extend it. As such plans as these had come to nothing, however, in respect to acquisitions still more precious, it was doubtless little enough of a marvel that he (man) should have lost account of that handful of seed. Buried for long years in dark corners at any rate these few germs had sprouted again under forty-eight hours of Paris. The process of yesterday had really been the process of feeling the general stirred life of connexions long since individually dropped. Strether had become acquainted even on this ground with short gusts of speculation--sudden flights of fancy in Louvre galleries, hungry gazes through clear plates behind which lemon-coloured volumes were as fresh as fruit on the tree.

There were instants at which he (Strether) could ask whether, since there had been fundamentally so little question of his (Strether) keeping anything, the fate after all decreed for him (Strether) hadn't been only to BE kept. Kept for something, in that event, that he (Strether) didn't pretend, didn't possibly dare as yet to divine; something that made him (Strether) hover and wonder and laugh and sigh, made him (Strether) advance and retreat, feeling half ashamed of his (Strether) impulse to plunge and more than half afraid of his (Strether) impulse to wait. He (Strether) remembered for instance how he (Strether) had gone back in the sixties with lemon-coloured volumes in general on the brain as well as with a dozen--selected for his (Strether) wife too--in his (Strether) trunk; and nothing had at the moment shown more confidence than this invocation of the finer taste. They were still somewhere at home, the dozen--stale and soiled and never sent to the binder; but what had become of the sharp initiation they represented? They represented now the mere sallow paint on the door of the temple of taste that he (Strether) had dreamed of raising up--a structure he (Strether) had practically never carried further. Strether's present highest flights were perhaps those in which this particular lapse figured to him (Strether) as a symbol, a symbol of his (Strether) long grind and his (Strether) want of odd moments, his (Strether) want moreover of money, of opportunity, of positive dignity. That the memory of the vow of his (Strether) youth should, in order to throb again, have had to wait for this last, as he (Strether) felt it, of all his (Strether) accidents--that was surely proof enough of how his (Strether) conscience had been encumbered. If any further proof were needed it would have been to be found in the fact that, as he (Strether) perfectly now saw, he (Strether) had ceased even to measure his (Strether) meagreness, a meagreness that sprawled, in this retrospect, vague and comprehensive, stretching back like some unmapped Hinterland from a rough coast-settlement. His (Strether) conscience had been amusing itself for the forty-eight hours by forbidding him (Strether) the purchase of a book; he (Strether) held off from that, held off from everything; from the moment he (Strether) didn't yet call on Chad he (Chad) wouldn't for the world have taken any other step. On this evidence, however, of the way they actually affected him (Chad) he (Chad) glared at the lemon-coloured covers in confession of the subconsciousness that, all the same, in the great desert of the years, he (Chad) must have had of them. The green covers at home comprised, by the law of their purpose, no tribute to letters; it was of a mere rich kernel of economics, politics, ethics that, glazed and, as Mrs. Newsome maintained rather against HIS (Chad) view, pre-eminently pleasant to touch, they formed the specious shell. Without therefore any needed instinctive knowledge of what was coming out, in Paris, on the bright highway, he (Chad) struck himself at present as having more than once flushed with a suspicion: he (Chad) couldn't otherwise at present be feeling so many fears confirmed. There were

``movements'' (he)
he (Chad) was too late for: weren't they, with the fun of them, already spent? There were sequences he (Chad) had missed and great gaps in the procession: he (Chad) might have been watching it all recede in a golden cloud of dust. If the playhouse wasn't closed his (Chad) seat had at least fallen to somebody else. He (Chad) had had an uneasy feeling the night before that if he (Chad) was at the theatre at all--though he (Chad) indeed justified the theatre, in the specific sense, and with a grotesqueness to which his (Chad) imagination did all honour, as something he (Chad) owed poor Waymarsh--he (Chad) should have been there with, and as might have been said, FOR Chad.

This suggested the question of whether he (Chad) could properly have taken him (Chad) to such a play, and what effect--it was a point that suddenly rose--his (Chad) peculiar responsibility might be held in general to have on his (Chad) choice of entertainment. It had literally been present to him (Chad) at the Gymnase--where one was held moreover comparatively safe--that having his (Chad) young friend at his (Chad) side would have been an odd feature of the work of redemption; and this quite in spite of the fact that the picture presented might well, confronted with Chad's own private stage, have seemed the pattern of propriety. He (Chad) clearly hadn't come out in the name of propriety but to visit unattended equivocal performances; yet still less had he (Chad) done so to undermine his (Chad) authority by sharing them with the graceless youth. Was he (Chad) to renounce all amusement for the sweet sake of that authority? and WOULD such renouncement give him (Chad) for Chad a moral glamour? The little problem bristled the more by reason of poor Strether's fairly open sense of the irony of things. Were there then sides on which his (Strether) predicament threatened to look rather droll to him (Strether)? Should he (Strether) have to pretend to believe--either to himself or the wretched boy--that there was anything that could make the latter worse? Wasn't some such pretence on the other hand involved in the assumption of possible processes that would make him (Strether) better? His (Strether) greatest uneasiness seemed to peep at him (Strether) out of the imminent impression that almost any acceptance of Paris might give one's authority away. It hung before him (Strether) this morning, the vast bright Babylon, like some huge iridescent object, a jewel brilliant and hard, in which parts were not to be discriminated nor differences comfortably marked. It twinkled and trembled and melted together, and what seemed all surface one moment seemed all depth the next. It was a place of which, unmistakeably, Chad was fond; wherefore if he (Chad), Strether, should like it too much, what on earth, with such a bond, would become of either of them? It all depended of course--which was a gleam of light--on how the

``too much'' (friend)
was measured; though indeed our friend fairly felt, while he (friend) prolonged the meditation I describe, that for himself even already a certain measure had been reached. It will have been sufficiently seen that he (friend) was not a man to neglect any good chance for reflexion. Was it at all possible for instance to like Paris enough without liking it too much? He (friend) luckily however hadn't promised Mrs. Newsome not to like it at all. He (friend) was ready to recognise at this stage that such an engagement WOULD have tied his (friend) hands. The Luxembourg Gardens were incontestably just so adorable at this hour by reason--in addition to their intrinsic charm--of his (friend) not having taken it. The only engagement he (friend) had taken, when he (friend) looked the thing in the face, was to do what he (friend) reasonably could.

It upset him (friend) a little none the less and after a while to find himself at last remembering on what current of association he (friend) had been floated so far. Old imaginations of the Latin Quarter had played their part for him (friend), and he (friend) had duly recalled its having been with this scene of rather ominous legend that, like so many young men in fiction as well as in fact, Chad had begun. He (Chad) was now quite out of it, with his (Chad)

``home,'' (He)
as Strether figured the place, in the Boulevard Malesherbes; which was perhaps why, repairing, not to fail of justice either, to the elder neighbourhood, our friend had felt he (friend) could allow for the element of the usual, the immemorial, without courting perturbation. He (friend) was not at least in danger of seeing the youth and the particular Person flaunt by together; and yet he (friend) was in the very air of which--just to feel what the early natural note must have been--he (friend) wished most to take counsel. It became at once vivid to him (friend) that he (friend) had originally had, for a few days, an almost envious vision of the boy's romantic privilege. Melancholy Murger, with Francine and Musette and Rodolphe, at home, in the company of the tattered, one--if he (boy) not in his (boy) single self two or three--of the unbound, the paper-covered dozen on the shelf; and when Chad had written, five years ago, after a sojourn then already prolonged to six months, that he (Chad) had decided to go in for economy and the real thing, Strether's fancy had quite fondly accompanied him (Strether) in this migration, which was to convey him (Strether), as they somewhat confusedly learned at Woollett, across the bridges and up the Montagne Sainte-Genevieve. This was the region--Chad had been quite distinct about it--in which the best French, and many other things, were to be learned at least cost, and in which all sorts of clever fellows, compatriots there for a purpose, formed an awfully pleasant set. The clever fellows, the friendly countrymen were mainly young painters, sculptors, architects, medical students; but they were, Chad sagely opined, a much more profitable lot to be with--even on the footing of not being quite one of them--than the
``terrible toughs'' (Chad/Chad Newsome/Newsome)
-LRB-Strether remembered the edifying discrimination-RRB- of the American bars and banks roundabout the Opera. Chad had thrown out, in the communications following this one--for at that time he (Chad) did once in a while communicate--that several members of a band of earnest workers under one of the great artists had taken him (Chad) right in, making him (Chad) dine every night, almost for nothing, at their place, and even pressing him (Chad) not to neglect the hypothesis of there being as much
``in him (Strether)'' (him)
as in any of them. There had been literally a moment at which it appeared there might be something in him (Chad); there had been at any rate a moment at which he (Chad) had written that he (Chad) didn't know but what a month or two more might see him (Chad) enrolled in some atelier. The season had been one at which Mrs. Newsome was moved to gratitude for small mercies; it had broken on them all as a blessing that their absentee HAD perhaps a conscience--that he (Chad) was sated in fine with idleness, was ambitious of variety. The exhibition was doubtless as yet not brilliant, but Strether himself, even by that time much enlisted and immersed, had determined, on the part of the two ladies, a temperate approval and in fact, as he (Strether) now recollected, a certain austere enthusiasm.

But the very next thing that happened had been a dark drop of the curtain. The son and brother had not browsed long on the Montagne Sainte-Genevieve--his (son) effective little use of the name of which, like his (son) allusion to the best French, appeared to have been but one of the notes of his (son) rough cunning. The light refreshment of these vain appearances had not accordingly carried any of them very far. On the other hand it had gained Chad time; it had given him (Chad) a chance, unchecked, to strike his (Chad) roots, had paved the way for initiations more direct and more deep. It was Strether's belief that he (Strether) had been comparatively innocent before this first migration, and even that the first effects of the migration would not have been, without some particular bad accident, to have been deplored. There had been three months--he (Strether) had sufficiently figured it out--in which Chad had wanted to try. He (Chad) HAD tried, though not very hard--he (Chad) had had his (Chad) little hour of good faith. The weakness of this principle in him (Chad) was that almost any accident attestedly bad enough was stronger. Such had at any rate markedly been the case for the precipitation of a special series of impressions. They had proved, successively, these impressions--all of Musette and Francine, but Musette and Francine vulgarised by the larger evolution of the type--irresistibly sharp: he (Chad) had

``taken up,'' (he)
by what was at the time to be shrinkingly gathered, as it was scantly mentioned, with one ferociously
``interested'' (he)
little person after another. Strether had read somewhere of a Latin motto, a description of the hours, observed on a clock by a traveller in Spain; and he (traveller) had been led to apply it in thought to Chad's number one, number two, number three. Omnes vulnerant, ultima necat--they had all morally wounded, the last had morally killed. The last had been longest in possession--in possession, that is, of whatever was left of the poor boy's finer mortality. And it hadn't been she (traveller), it had been one of her (traveller) early predecessors, who had determined the second migration, the expensive return and relapse, the exchange again, as was fairly to be presumed, of the vaunted best French for some special variety of the worst.

He (boy) pulled himself then at last together for his (boy) own progress back; not with the feeling that he (boy) had taken his (boy) walk in vain. He (boy) prolonged it a little, in the immediate neighbourhood, after he (boy) had quitted his (boy) chair; and the upshot of the whole morning for him (boy) was that his (boy) campaign had begun. He (boy) had wanted to put himself in relation, and he (boy) would be hanged if he (boy) were NOT in relation. He (boy) was that at no moment so much as while, under the old arches of the Odeon, he (boy) lingered before the charming open-air array of literature classic and casual. He (boy) found the effect of tone and tint, in the long charged tables and shelves, delicate and appetising; the impression--substituting one kind of low-priced consommation for another--might have been that of one of the pleasant cafes that overlapped, under an awning, to the pavement; but he (boy) edged along, grazing the tables, with his (boy) hands firmly behind him (boy). He (boy) wasn't there to dip, to consume--he (boy) was there to reconstruct. He (boy) wasn't there for his (boy) own profit--not, that is, the direct; he (boy) was there on some chance of feeling the brush of the wing of the stray spirit of youth. He (boy) felt it in fact, he (boy) had it beside him (boy); the old arcade indeed, as his (boy) inner sense listened, gave out the faint sound, as from far off, of the wild waving of wings. They were folded now over the breasts of buried generations; but a flutter or two lived again in the turned page of shock-headed slouch-hatted loiterers whose young intensity of type, in the direction of pale acuteness, deepened his (boy) vision, and even his (boy) appreciation, of racial differences, and whose manipulation of the uncut volume was too often, however, but a listening at closed doors. He (boy) reconstructed a possible groping Chad of three or four years before, a Chad who had, after all, simply--for that was the only way to see it--been too vulgar for his (Chad) privilege. Surely it WAS a privilege to have been young and happy just there. Well, the best thing Strether knew of him (Strether) was that he (Strether) had had such a dream.

But his (Strether) own actual business half an hour later was with a third floor on the Boulevard Malesherbes--so much as that was definite; and the fact of the enjoyment by the third-floor windows of a continuous balcony, to which he (Strether) was helped by this knowledge, had perhaps something to do with his (Strether) lingering for five minutes on the opposite side of the street. There were points as to which he (Strether) had quite made up his (Strether) mind, and one of these bore precisely on the wisdom of the abruptness to which events had finally committed him (Strether), a policy that he (Strether) was pleased to find not at all shaken as he (Strether) now looked at his (Strether) watch and wondered. He (Strether) HAD announced himself--six months before; had written out at least that Chad wasn't to be surprised should he (Chad) see him (Chad) some day turn up. Chad had thereupon, in a few words of rather carefully colourless answer, offered him (Chad) a general welcome; and Strether, ruefully reflecting that he (Strether) might have understood the warning as a hint to hospitality, a bid for an invitation, had fallen back upon silence as the corrective most to his (Strether) own taste. He (Strether) had asked Mrs. Newsome moreover not to announce him (Strether) again; he (Strether) had so distinct an opinion on his (Strether) attacking his (Strether) job, should he (Strether) attack it at all, in his (Strether) own way. Not the least of this lady's high merits for him (Strether) was that he (Strether) could absolutely rest on her (lady) word. She (lady) was the only woman he (Strether) had known, even at Woollett, as to whom his (Strether) conviction was positive that to lie was beyond her (lady) art. Sarah Pocock, for instance, her (Pocock) own daughter, though with social ideals, as they said, in some respects different--Sarah who WAS, in her (Sarah) way, aesthetic, had never refused to human commerce that mitigation of rigour; there were occasions when he (Strether) had distinctly seen her (Sarah) apply it. Since, accordingly, at all events, he (Strether) had had it from Mrs. Newsome that she (Newsome) had, at whatever cost to her (Newsome) more strenuous view, conformed, in the matter of preparing Chad, wholly to his (Chad) restrictions, he (Chad) now looked up at the fine continuous balcony with a safe sense that if the case had been bungled the mistake was at least his (Chad) property. Was there perhaps just a suspicion of that in his (Chad) present pause on the edge of the Boulevard and well in the pleasant light?

Many things came over him (Chad) here, and one of them was that he (Chad) should doubtless presently know whether he (Chad) had been shallow or sharp. Another was that the balcony in question didn't somehow show as a convenience easy to surrender. Poor Strether had at this very moment to recognise the truth that wherever one paused in Paris the imagination reacted before one could stop it. This perpetual reaction put a price, if one would, on pauses; but it piled up consequences till there was scarce room to pick one's steps among them. What call had he (Strether), at such a juncture, for example, to like Chad's very house? High broad clear--he (Chad) was expert enough to make out in a moment that it was admirably built--it fairly embarrassed our friend by the quality that, as he (friend) would have said, it

``sprang'' (he)
on him (friend). He (friend) had struck off the fancy that it might, as a preliminary, be of service to him (friend) to be seen, by a happy accident, from the third-story windows, which took all the March sun, but of what service was it to find himself making out after a moment that the quality
``sprung,'' (him)
the quality produced by measure and balance, the fine relation of part to part and space to space, was probably--aided by the presence of ornament as positive as it was discreet, and by the complexion of the stone, a cold fair grey, warmed and polished a little by life--neither more nor less than a case of distinction, such a case as he (himself) could only feel unexpectedly as a sort of delivered challenge? Meanwhile, however, the chance he (himself) had allowed for--the chance of being seen in time from the balcony--had become a fact. Two or three of the windows stood open to the violet air; and, before Strether had cut the knot by crossing, a young man had come out and looked about him (man), had lighted a cigarette and tossed the match over, and then, resting on the rail, had given himself up to watching the life below while he (man) smoked. His (man) arrival contributed, in its order, to keeping Strether in position; the result of which in turn was that Strether soon felt himself noticed. The young man began to look at him (man) as in acknowledgement of his (man) being himself in observation.

This was interesting so far as it went, but the interest was affected by the young man's not being Chad. Strether wondered at first if he (Strether) were perhaps Chad altered, and then saw that this was asking too much of alteration. The young man was light bright and alert--with an air too pleasant to have been arrived at by patching. Strether had conceived Chad as patched, but not beyond recognition. He (Strether) was in presence, he (Strether) felt, of amendments enough as they stood; it was a sufficient amendment that the gentleman up there should be Chad's friend. He (Chad) was young too then, the gentleman up there--he (Chad) was very young; young enough apparently to be amused at an elderly watcher, to be curious even to see what the elderly watcher would do on finding himself watched. There was youth in that, there was youth in the surrender to the balcony, there was youth for Strether at this moment in everything but his (Strether) own business; and Chad's thus pronounced association with youth had given the next instant an extraordinary quick lift to the issue. The balcony, the distinguished front, testified suddenly, for Strether's fancy, to something that was up and up; they placed the whole case materially, and as by an admirable image, on a level that he (Strether) found himself at the end of another moment rejoicing to think he (Strether) might reach. The young man looked at him (man) still, he (man) looked at the young man; and the issue, by a rapid process, was that this knowledge of a perched privacy appeared to him (man) the last of luxuries. To him (man) too the perched privacy was open, and he (man) saw it now but in one light--that of the only domicile, the only fireside, in the great ironic city, on which he (man) had the shadow of a claim. Miss Gostrey had a fireside; she (Gostrey) had told him (man) of it, and it was something that doubtless awaited him (man); but Miss Gostrey hadn't yet arrived--she (Gostrey) mightn't arrive for days; and the sole attenuation of his (man) excluded state was his (man) vision of the small, the admittedly secondary hotel in the bye-street from the Rue de la Paix, in which her (Gostrey) solicitude for his (man) purse had placed him (man), which affected him (man) somehow as all indoor chill, glass-roofed court and slippery staircase, and which, by the same token, expressed the presence of Waymarsh even at times when Waymarsh might have been certain to be round at the bank. It came to pass before he (man) moved that Waymarsh, and Waymarsh alone, Waymarsh not only undiluted but positively strengthened, struck him (man) as the present alternative to the young man in the balcony. When he (man) did move it was fairly to escape that alternative. Taking his (man) way over the street at last and passing through the porte-cochere of the house was like consciously leaving Waymarsh out. However, he (man) would tell him (man) all about it.

Book Third

I

Strether told Waymarsh all about it that very evening, on their dining together at the hotel; which needn't have happened, he (Strether) was all the while aware, hadn't he (Strether) chosen to sacrifice to this occasion a rarer opportunity. The mention to his (Strether) companion of the sacrifice was moreover exactly what introduced his (Strether) recital--or, as he (Strether) would have called it with more confidence in his (Strether) interlocutor, his (Strether) confession. His (Strether) confession was that he (Strether) had been captured and that one of the features of the affair had just failed to be his (Strether) engaging himself on the spot to dinner. As by such a freedom Waymarsh would have lost him (Strether) he (Strether) had obeyed his (Strether) scruple; and he (Strether) had likewise obeyed another scruple--which bore on the question of his (Strether) himself bringing a guest.

Waymarsh looked gravely ardent, over the finished soup, at this array of scruples; Strether hadn't yet got quite used to being so unprepared for the consequences of the impression he (Strether) produced. It was comparatively easy to explain, however, that he (Strether) hadn't felt sure his (Strether) guest would please. The person was a young man whose acquaintance he (man) had made but that afternoon in the course of rather a hindered enquiry for another person--an enquiry his (man) new friend had just prevented in fact from being vain.

``Oh,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
said Strether,
``I've all sorts of things to tell you!'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
--and he (Strether) put it in a way that was a virtual hint to Waymarsh to help him (Strether) to enjoy the telling. He (Strether) waited for his (Strether) fish, he (Strether) drank of his (Strether) wine, he (Strether) wiped his (Strether) long moustache, he (Strether) leaned back in his (Strether) chair, he (Strether) took in the two English ladies who had just creaked past them and whom he (Strether) would even have articulately greeted if they hadn't rather chilled the impulse; so that all he (Strether) could do was--by way of doing something--to say
``Merci, Francois!'' (he)
out quite loud when his (Strether) fish was brought. Everything was there that he (Strether) wanted, everything that could make the moment an occasion, that would do beautifully--everything but what Waymarsh might give. The little waxed salle-a-manger was sallow and sociable; Francois, dancing over it, all smiles, was a man and a brother; the high-shouldered patronne, with her (Waymarsh) high-held, much-rubbed hands, seemed always assenting exuberantly to something unsaid; the Paris evening in short was, for Strether, in the very taste of the soup, in the goodness, as he (Strether) was innocently pleased to think it, of the wine, in the pleasant coarse texture of the napkin and the crunch of the thick-crusted bread. These all were things congruous with his (Strether) confession, and his (Strether) confession was that he (Strether) HAD--it would come out properly just there if Waymarsh would only take it properly--agreed to breakfast out, at twelve literally, the next day. He (Strether) didn't quite know where; the delicacy of the case came straight up in the remembrance of his (Strether) new friend's
``We'll see; I'll take you somewhere!'' (friend)
--for it had required little more than that, after all, to let him (Strether) right in. He (Strether) was affected after a minute, face to face with his (Strether) actual comrade, by the impulse to overcolour. There had already been things in respect to which he (Strether) knew himself tempted by this perversity. If Waymarsh thought them bad he (Strether) should at least have his (Strether) reason for his (Strether) discomfort; so Strether showed them as worse. Still, he (Strether) was now, in his (Strether) way, sincerely perplexed.

Chad had been absent from the Boulevard Malesherbes--was absent from Paris altogether; he (Chad) had learned that from the concierge, but had nevertheless gone up, and gone up--there were no two ways about it--from an uncontrollable, a really, if one would, depraved curiosity. The concierge had mentioned to him (Chad) that a friend of the tenant of the troisieme was for the time in possession; and this had been Strether's pretext for a further enquiry, an experiment carried on, under Chad's roof, without his (Chad) knowledge.

``I found his (Francois) friend in fact there keeping the place warm, as he (Francois) called it, for him (Francois); Chad himself being, as appears, in the south. He (Chad) went a month ago to Cannes and though his (Chad) return begins to be looked for it can't be for some days. I might, you see, perfectly have waited a week; might have beaten a retreat as soon as I got this essential knowledge. But I beat no retreat; I did the opposite; I stayed, I dawdled, I trifled; above all I looked round. I saw, in fine; and--I don't know what to call it--I sniffed. It's a detail, but it's as if there were something--something very good--TO sniff.'' (Waymarsh/Mrs. Waymarsh)

Waymarsh's face had shown his (Chad) friend an attention apparently so remote that the latter was slightly surprised to find it at this point abreast with him (Chad).

``Do you mean a smell? What of?'' (unknown)

``A charming scent. But I don't know.'' (Waymarsh/Mrs. Waymarsh)

Waymarsh gave an inferential grunt.

``Does he (It) live there with a woman?'' (unknown)

``I don't know.'' (Waymarsh/Mrs. Waymarsh)

Waymarsh waited an instant for more, then resumed.

``Has he (It) taken her (woman) off with him (It)?'' (unknown)

``And will he (It) bring her (woman) back?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
--Strether fell into the enquiry. But he (Strether) wound it up as before.
``I don't know.'' (he)

The way he (Strether) wound it up, accompanied as this was with another drop back, another degustation of the Leoville, another wipe of his (Strether) moustache and another good word for Francois, seemed to produce in his (Strether) companion a slight irritation.

``Then what the devil DO you know?'' (unknown)

``Well,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
said Strether almost gaily,
``I guess I don't know anything!'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
His (Strether) gaiety might have been a tribute to the fact that the state he (Strether) had been reduced to did for him (Strether) again what had been done by his (Strether) talk of the matter with Miss Gostrey at the London theatre. It was somehow enlarging; and the air of that amplitude was now doubtless more or less--and all for Waymarsh to feel--in his (Strether) further response.
``That's what I found out from the young man.'' (unknown)

``But I thought you said you found out nothing.'' (unknown)

``Nothing but that--that I don't know anything.'' (unknown)

``And what good does that do you?'' (unknown)

``It's just,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
said Strether,
``what I've come to you to help me to discover. I mean anything about anything over here. I FELT that, up there. It regularly rose before me in its might. The young man moreover--Chad's friend--as good as told me so.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

``As good as told you you know nothing about anything?'' (Waymarsh/Mrs. Waymarsh)
Waymarsh appeared to look at some one who might have as good as told HIM.
``How old is he (Chad)?'' (unknown)

``Well, I guess not thirty.'' (unknown)

``Yet you had to take that from him (Chad)?'' (unknown)

``Oh I took a good deal more--since, as I tell you, I took an invitation to dejeuner.'' (unknown)

``And are you GOING to that unholy meal?'' (unknown)

``If you'll come with me. He (Chad) wants you too, you know. I told him (Chad) about you. He (Chad) gave me his (Chad) card,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether pursued,
``and his (Chad) name's rather funny. It's John Little Bilham, and he (John) says his (John) two surnames are, on account of his (John) being small, inevitably used together.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

``Well,'' (Waymarsh/Mrs. Waymarsh)
Waymarsh asked with due detachment from these details,
``what's he (John) doing up there?'' (Waymarsh/Mrs. Waymarsh)

``His (John) account of himself is that he (John)'s `only a little artist-man.'' (me)
That seemed to me perfectly to describe him (Strether). But he (Strether)'s yet in the phase of study; this, you know, is the great art-school--to pass a certain number of years in which he (Strether) came over. And he (Strether)'s a great friend of Chad's, and occupying Chad's rooms just now because they're so pleasant. HE (Chad)
``S very pleasant and curious too,'' (HE)
Strether added--
``though he (John)'s not from Boston.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Waymarsh looked already rather sick of him (Strether).

``Where is he (John) from?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether thought. ``I don't know that, either. But he (John)'s ``notoriously,

'' as he (Strether) put it himself, not from Boston.'' (unknown)

``Well,'' (unknown)
Waymarsh moralised from dry depths,
``every one can't notoriously be from Boston. Why,'' (he)
he (Strether) continued,
``is he (John) curious?'' (he)

``Perhaps just for THAT--for one thing! But really,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether added,
``for everything. When you meet him (John) you'll see.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

``Oh I don't want to meet him (John),'' (Waymarsh/Mrs. Waymarsh)
Waymarsh impatiently growled.
``Why don't he (John) go home?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether hesitated.

``Well, because he (John) likes it over here.'' (Waymarsh/Mrs. Waymarsh)

This appeared in particular more than Waymarsh could bear.

``He (John) ought then to be ashamed of himself, and, as you admit that you think so too, why drag him (John) in?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether's reply again took time.

``Perhaps I do think so myself--though I don't quite yet admit it. I'm not a bit sure--it's again one of the things I want to find out. I liked him (John), and CAN you like people--? But no matter.'' (He)
He (Strether) pulled himself up.
``There's no doubt I want you to come down on me and squash me.'' (Waymarsh/Mrs. Waymarsh)

Waymarsh helped himself to the next course, which, however proving not the dish he (Strether) had just noted as supplied to the English ladies, had the effect of causing his (Strether) imagination temporarily to wander. But it presently broke out at a softer spot.

``Have they got a handsome place up there?'' (unknown)

``Oh a charming place; full of beautiful and valuable things. I never saw such a place'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
--and Strether's thought went back to it.
``For a little artist-man--!'' (He)
He (Strether) could in fact scarce express it.

But his (Strether) companion, who appeared now to have a view, insisted.

``Well?'' (unknown)

``Well, life can hold nothing better. Besides, they're things of which he (John)'s in charge.'' (unknown)

``So that he (John) does doorkeeper for your precious pair? Can life,'' (Waymarsh/Mrs. Waymarsh)
Waymarsh enquired,
``hold nothing better than THAT?'' (Waymarsh/Mrs. Waymarsh)
Then as Strether, silent, seemed even yet to wonder,
``Doesn't he (John) know what SHE is?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
he (Strether) went on.

``I don't know. I didn't ask him (John). I couldn't. It was impossible. You wouldn't either. Besides I didn't want to. No more would you.'' (Strether)
Strether in short explained it at a stroke.
``You can't make out over here what people do know.'' (unknown)

``Then what did you come over for?'' (unknown)

``Well, I suppose exactly to see for myself--without their aid.'' (unknown)

``Then what do you want mine for?'' (unknown)

``Oh,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether laughed,
``you're not one of THEM! I do know what you know.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

As, however, this last assertion caused Waymarsh again to look at him (Strether) hard--such being the latter's doubt of its implications--he (Strether) felt his (Strether) justification lame. Which was still more the case when Waymarsh presently said:

``Look here, Strether. Quit this.'' (Waymarsh/Mrs. Waymarsh)

Our friend smiled with a doubt of his (friend) own.

``Do you mean my tone?'' (unknown)

``No--damn your tone. I mean your nosing round. Quit the whole job. Let them stew in their juice. You're being used for a thing you ain't fit for. People don't take a fine-tooth comb to groom a horse.'' (unknown)

``Am I a fine-tooth comb?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether laughed.
``It's something I never called myself!'' (unknown)

``It's what you are, all the same. You ain't so young as you were, but you've kept your teeth.'' (He)

He (Strether) acknowledged his (Strether) friend's humour.

``Take care I don't get them into YOU! You'd like them, my friends at home, Waymarsh,'' (he)
he (Strether) declared;
``you'd really particularly like them. And I know'' (he)
--it was slightly irrelevant, but he (Strether) gave it sudden and singular force--
``I know they'd like you!'' (he)

``Oh don't work them off on ME!'' (Waymarsh/Mrs. Waymarsh)
Waymarsh groaned.

Yet Strether still lingered with his (Strether) hands in his (Strether) pockets.

``It's really quite as indispensable as I say that Chad should be got back.'' (unknown)

``Indispensable to whom? To you?'' (unknown)

``Yes,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether presently said.

``Because if you get him (Chad) you also get Mrs. Newsome?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether faced it.

``Yes.'' (unknown)

``And if you don't get him (Chad) you don't get her (Newsome)?'' (he)

It might be merciless, but he (Strether) continued not to flinch.

``I think it might have some effect on our personal understanding. Chad's of real importance--or can easily become so if he (Chad) will--to the business.'' (unknown)

``And the business is of real importance to his (Chad) mother's husband?'' (unknown)

``Well, I naturally want what my future wife wants. And the thing will be much better if we have our own man in it.'' (unknown)

``If you have your own man in it, in other words,'' (Waymarsh/Mrs. Waymarsh)
Waymarsh said,
``you'll marry--you personally--more money. She (wife)'s already rich, as I understand you, but she (wife)'ll be richer still if the business can be made to boom on certain lines that you've laid down.'' (Waymarsh/Mrs. Waymarsh)

``I haven't laid them down,'' (Strether)
Strether promptly returned.
``Mr. Newsome--who knew extraordinarily well what he (Newsome) was about--laid them down ten years ago.'' (Waymarsh/Mrs. Waymarsh)

Oh well, Waymarsh seemed to indicate with a shake of his (Strether) mane, THAT didn't matter!

``You're fierce for the boom anyway.'' (friend)

His (Strether) friend weighed a moment in silence the justice of the charge.

``I can scarcely be called fierce, I think, when I so freely take my chance of the possibility, the danger, of being influenced in a sense counter to Mrs. Newsome's own feelings.'' (Waymarsh/Mrs. Waymarsh)

Waymarsh gave this proposition a long hard look.

``I see. You're afraid yourself of being squared. But you're a humbug,'' (he)
he (Strether) added,
``all the same.'' (he)

``Oh!'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether quickly protested.

``Yes, you ask me for protection--which makes you very interesting; and then you won't take it. You say you want to be squashed--'' (unknown)

``Ah but not so easily! Don't you see,'' (Strether)
Strether demanded
``where my interest, as already shown you, lies? It lies in my not being squared. If I'm squared where's my marriage? If I miss my errand I miss that; and if I miss that I miss everything--I'm nowhere.'' (Strether)

Waymarsh--but all relentlessly--took this in.

``What do I care where you are if you're spoiled?'' (unknown)

Their eyes met on it an instant.

``Thank you awfully,'' (Strether)
Strether at last said.
``But don't you think HER judgement of that--?'' (unknown)

``Ought to content me? No.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

It kept them again face to face, and the end of this was that Strether again laughed.

``You do her (my) injustice. You really MUST know her (my). Good-night.'' (He)

He (Strether) breakfasted with Mr. Bilham on the morrow, and, as inconsequently befell, with Waymarsh massively of the party. The latter announced, at the eleventh hour and much to his (Strether) friend's surprise, that, damn it, he (Strether) would as soon join him (Strether) as do anything else; on which they proceeded together, strolling in a state of detachment practically luxurious for them to the Boulevard Malesherbes, a couple engaged that day with the sharp spell of Paris as confessedly, it might have been seen, as any couple among the daily thousands so compromised. They walked, wandered, wondered and, a little, lost themselves; Strether hadn't had for years so rich a consciousness of time--a bag of gold into which he (Strether) constantly dipped for a handful. It was present to him (Strether) that when the little business with Mr. Bilham should be over he (Bilham) would still have shining hours to use absolutely as he (Bilham) liked. There was no great pulse of haste yet in this process of saving Chad; nor was that effect a bit more marked as he (Chad) sat, half an hour later, with his (Chad) legs under Chad's mahogany, with Mr. Bilham on one side, with a friend of Mr. Bilham's on the other, with Waymarsh stupendously opposite, and with the great hum of Paris coming up in softness, vagueness-for Strether himself indeed already positive sweetness--through the sunny windows toward which, the day before, his (Strether) curiosity had raised its wings from below. The feeling strongest with him (Strether) at that moment had borne fruit almost faster than he (Strether) could taste it, and Strether literally felt at the present hour that there was a precipitation in his (Strether) fate. He (Strether) had known nothing and nobody as he (Strether) stood in the street; but hadn't his (Strether) view now taken a bound in the direction of every one and of every thing?

``What's he (You) up to, what's he (You) up to?'' (Bilham/Mr. Bilham)
--something like that was at the back of his (Strether) head all the while in respect to little Bilham; but meanwhile, till he (Bilham) should make out, every one and every thing were as good as represented for him (Bilham) by the combination of his (Bilham) host and the lady on his (Bilham) left. The lady on his (Bilham) left, the lady thus promptly and ingeniously invited to
``meet'' (the lady)
Mr. Strether and Mr. Waymarsh--it was the way she (lady) herself expressed her (lady) case--was a very marked person, a person who had much to do with our friend's asking himself if the occasion weren't in its essence the most baited, the most gilded of traps. Baited it could properly be called when the repast was of so wise a savour, and gilded surrounding objects seemed inevitably to need to be when Miss Barrace--which was the lady's name--looked at them with convex Parisian eyes and through a glass with a remarkably long tortoise-shell handle. Why Miss Barrace, mature meagre erect and eminently gay, highly adorned, perfectly familiar, freely contradictions and reminding him (friend) of some last-century portrait of a clever head without powder--why Miss Barrace should have been in particular the note of a
``trap'' (him)
Strether couldn't on the spot have explained; he (friend) blinked in the light of a conviction that he (friend) should know later on, and know well--as it came over him (friend), for that matter, with force, that he (friend) should need to. He (friend) wondered what he (friend) was to think exactly of either of his (friend) new friends; since the young man, Chad's intimate and deputy, had, in thus constituting the scene, practised so much more subtly than he (Chad) had been prepared for, and since in especial Miss Barrace, surrounded clearly by every consideration, hadn't scrupled to figure as a familiar object. It was interesting to him (Chad) to feel that he (Chad) was in the presence of new measures, other standards, a different scale of relations, and that evidently here were a happy pair who didn't think of things at all as he (Chad) and Waymarsh thought. Nothing was less to have been calculated in the business than that it should now be for him (Chad) as if he (Chad) and Waymarsh were comparatively quite at one.

The latter was magnificent--this at least was an assurance privately given him (Chad) by Miss Barrace.

``Oh your friend's a type, the grand old American--what shall one call it? The Hebrew prophet, Ezekiel, Jeremiah, who used when I was a little girl in the Rue Montaigne to come to see my father and who was usually the American Minister to the Tuileries or some other court. I haven't seen one these ever so many years; the sight of it warms my poor old chilled heart; this specimen is wonderful; in the right quarter, you know, he (Minister)'ll have a succes fou.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether hadn't failed to ask what the right quarter might be, much as he (Strether) required his (Strether) presence of mind to meet such a change in their scheme.
``Oh the artist-quarter and that kind of thing; HERE already, for instance, as you see.'' (He)
He (Strether) had been on the point of echoing
''`Here'?--is THIS the artist-quarter?'' (He)
but she (Waymarsh) had already disposed of the question with a wave of all her (Waymarsh) tortoise-shell and an easy
``Bring him (Minister) to ME!'' (she)
He (Strether) knew on the spot how little he (Strether) should be able to bring him (Strether), for the very air was by this time, to his (Strether) sense, thick and hot with poor Waymarsh's judgement of it. He (Strether) was in the trap still more than his (Strether) companion and, unlike his (Strether) companion, not making the best of it; which was precisely what doubtless gave him (Strether) his (Strether) admirable sombre glow. Little did Miss Barrace know that what was behind it was his (Strether) grave estimate of her (Waymarsh) own laxity. The general assumption with which our two friends had arrived had been that of finding Mr. Bilham ready to conduct them to one or other of those resorts of the earnest, the aesthetic fraternity which were shown among the sights of Paris. In this character it would have justified them in a proper insistence on discharging their score. Waymarsh's only proviso at the last had been that nobody should pay for him (character); but he (character) found himself, as the occasion developed, paid for on a scale as to which Strether privately made out that he (Strether) already nursed retribution. Strether was conscious across the table of what worked in him (Strether), conscious when they passed back to the small salon to which, the previous evening, he (Strether) himself had made so rich a reference; conscious most of all as they stepped out to the balcony in which one would have had to be an ogre not to recognise the perfect place for easy aftertastes. These things were enhanced for Miss Barrace by a succession of excellent cigarettes--acknowledged, acclaimed, as a part of the wonderful supply left behind him (ogre) by Chad--in an almost equal absorption of which Strether found himself blindly, almost wildly pushing forward. He (Strether) might perish by the sword as well as by famine, and he (Strether) knew that his (Strether) having abetted the lady by an excess that was rare with him (Strether) would count for little in the sum--as Waymarsh might so easily add it up--of her (Waymarsh) licence. Waymarsh had smoked of old, smoked hugely; but Waymarsh did nothing now, and that gave him (Strether) his (Strether) advantage over people who took things up lightly just when others had laid them heavily down. Strether had never smoked, and he (Strether) felt as if he (Strether) flaunted at his (Strether) friend that this had been only because of a reason. The reason, it now began to appear even to himself, was that he (Strether) had never had a lady to smoke with.

It was this lady's being there at all, however, that was the strange free thing; perhaps, since she (lady) WAS there, her (lady) smoking was the least of her (lady) freedoms. If Strether had been sure at each juncture of what--with Bilham in especial--she (lady) talked about, he (Bilham) might have traced others and winced at them and felt Waymarsh wince; but he (Bilham) was in fact so often at sea that his (Bilham) sense of the range of reference was merely general and that he (Bilham) on several different occasions guessed and interpreted only to doubt. He (Bilham) wondered what they meant, but there were things he (Bilham) scarce thought they could be supposed to mean, and

``Oh no--not THAT!'' (he)
was at the end of most of his (Bilham) ventures. This was the very beginning with him (Bilham) of a condition as to which, later on, it will be seen, he (Bilham) found cause to pull himself up; and he (Bilham) was to remember the moment duly as the first step in a process. The central fact of the place was neither more nor less, when analysed--and a pressure superficial sufficed--than the fundamental impropriety of Chad's situation, round about which they thus seemed cynically clustered. Accordingly, since they took it for granted, they took for granted all that was in connexion with it taken for granted at Woollett--matters as to which, verily, he (Chad) had been reduced with Mrs. Newsome to the last intensity of silence. That was the consequence of their being too bad to be talked about, and was the accompaniment, by the same token, of a deep conception of their badness. It befell therefore that when poor Strether put it to himself that their badness was ultimately, or perhaps even insolently, what such a scene as the one before him (Strether) was, so to speak, built upon, he (Strether) could scarce shirk the dilemma of reading a roundabout echo of them into almost anything that came up. This, he (Strether) was well aware, was a dreadful necessity; but such was the stern logic, he (Strether) could only gather, of a relation to the irregular life.

It was the way the irregular life sat upon Bilham and Miss Barrace that was the insidious, the delicate marvel. He (Bilham) was eager to concede that their relation to it was all indirect, for anything else in him (Bilham) would have shown the grossness of bad manners; but the indirectness was none the less consonant--THAT was striking-with a grateful enjoyment of everything that was Chad's. They spoke of him (Chad) repeatedly, invoking his (Chad) good name and good nature, and the worst confusion of mind for Strether was that all their mention of him (Strether) was of a kind to do him (Strether) honour. They commended his (Strether) munificence and approved his (Strether) taste, and in doing so sat down, as it seemed to Strether, in the very soil out of which these things flowered. Our friend's final predicament was that he (friend) himself was sitting down, for the time, WITH them, and there was a supreme moment at which, compared with his (friend) collapse, Waymarsh's erectness affected him (friend) as really high. One thing was certain--he (friend) saw he (friend) must make up his (friend) mind. He (friend) must approach Chad, must wait for him (Chad), deal with him (Chad), master him (Chad), but he (Chad) mustn't dispossess himself of the faculty of seeing things as they were. He (Chad) must bring him (Chad) to HIM--not go himself, as it were, so much of the way. He (Chad) must at any rate be clearer as to what--should he (Chad) continue to do that for convenience--he (Chad) was still condoning. It was on the detail of this quantity--and what could the fact be but mystifying?-that Bilham and Miss Barrace threw so little light. So there they were.

II

When Miss Gostrey arrived, at the end of a week, she (Gostrey) made him (Bilham) a sign; he (Bilham) went immediately to see her (Gostrey), and it wasn't till then that he (Bilham) could again close his (Bilham) grasp on the idea of a corrective. This idea however was luckily all before him (Bilham) again from the moment he (Bilham) crossed the threshold of the little entresol of the Quartier Marboeuf into which she (Gostrey) had gathered, as she (Gostrey) said, picking them up in a thousand flights and funny little passionate pounces, the makings of a final nest. He (Bilham) recognised in an instant that there really, there only, he (Bilham) should find the boon with the vision of which he (Bilham) had first mounted Chad's stairs. He (Bilham) might have been a little scared at the picture of how much more, in this place, he (Bilham) should know himself

``in'' (he)
hadn't his (Bilham) friend been on the spot to measure the amount to his (Bilham) appetite. Her (Gostrey) compact and crowded little chambers, almost dusky, as they at first struck him (Bilham), with accumulations, represented a supreme general adjustment to opportunities and conditions. Wherever he (Bilham) looked he (Bilham) saw an old ivory or an old brocade, and he (Bilham) scarce knew where to sit for fear of a misappliance. The life of the occupant struck him (occupant) of a sudden as more charged with possession even than Chad's or than Miss Barrace's; wide as his (Chad) glimpse had lately become of the empire of
``things,'' (Chad)
what was before him (Chad) still enlarged it; the lust of the eyes and the pride of life had indeed thus their temple. It was the innermost nook of the shrine--as brown as a pirate's cave. In the brownness were glints of gold; patches of purple were in the gloom; objects all that caught, through the muslin, with their high rarity, the light of the low windows. Nothing was clear about them but that they were precious, and they brushed his (pirate) ignorance with their contempt as a flower, in a liberty taken with him (pirate), might have been whisked under his (pirate) nose. But after a full look at his (pirate) hostess he (pirate) knew none the less what most concerned him (pirate). The circle in which they stood together was warm with life, and every question between them would live there as nowhere else. A question came up as soon as they had spoken, for his (pirate) answer, with a laugh, was quickly:
``Well, they've got hold of me!'' (unknown)
Much of their talk on this first occasion was his (pirate) development of that truth. He (pirate) was extraordinarily glad to see her (hostess), expressing to her (hostess) frankly what she (hostess) most showed him (pirate), that one might live for years without a blessing unsuspected, but that to know it at last for no more than three days was to need it or miss it for ever. She (hostess) was the blessing that had now become his (pirate) need, and what could prove it better than that without her (hostess) he (pirate) had lost himself?

``What do you mean?'' (she)
she (hostess) asked with an absence of alarm that, correcting him (pirate) as if he (pirate) had mistaken the
``period'' (he)
of one of her (hostess) pieces, gave him (pirate) afresh a sense of her (hostess) easy movement through the maze he (pirate) had but begun to tread.
``What in the name of all the Pococks have you managed to do?'' (unknown)

``Why exactly the wrong thing. I've made a frantic friend of little Bilham.'' (unknown)

``Ah that sort of thing was of the essence of your case and to have been allowed for from the first.'' (she)
And it was only after this that, quite as a minor matter, she (hostess) asked who in the world little Bilham might be.
