When she (hostess) learned that he (Bilham) was a friend of Chad's and living for the time in Chad's rooms in Chad's absence, quite as if acting in Chad's spirit and serving Chad's cause, she (hostess) showed, however, more interest.
``Should you mind my seeing him (Bilham)? Only once, you know,'' (she)
she (hostess) added.

``Oh the oftener the better: he (Bilham)'s amusing--he (Bilham)'s original.'' (unknown)

``He (Bilham) doesn't shock you?'' (Miss Gostrey)
Miss Gostrey threw out.

``Never in the world! We escape that with a perfection--! I feel it to be largely, no doubt, because I don't half-understand him (Bilham); but our modus vivendi isn't spoiled even by that. You must dine with me to meet him (Bilham),'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether went on.
``Then you'll see.'' (unknown)

``Are you giving dinners?'' (unknown)

``Yes--there I am. That's what I mean.'' (unknown)

All her (Gostrey) kindness wondered.

``That you're spending too much money?'' (unknown)

``Dear no--they seem to cost so little. But that I do it to THEM. I ought to hold off.'' (She)

She (Gostrey) thought again--she (Gostrey) laughed.

``The money you must be spending to think it cheap! But I must be out of it--to the naked eye.'' (He)

He (Strether) looked for a moment as if she (Gostrey) were really failing him (Strether).

``Then you won't meet them?'' (she)
It was almost as if she (Gostrey) had developed an unexpected personal prudence.

She (Gostrey) hesitated.

``Who are they--first?'' (unknown)

``Why little Bilham to begin with.'' (He)
He (Strether) kept back for the moment Miss Barrace.
``And Chad--when he (Chad) comes--you must absolutely see.'' (unknown)

``When then does he (Chad) come?'' (unknown)

``When Bilham has had time to write him (Bilham), and hear from him (Bilham) about me. Bilham, however,'' (he)
he (Strether) pursued,
``will report favourably--favourably for Chad. That will make him (Chad) not afraid to come. I want you the more therefore, you see, for my bluff.'' (he)

``Oh you'll do yourself for your bluff.'' (She)
She (Gostrey) was perfectly easy.
``At the rate you've gone I'm quiet.'' (unknown)

``Ah but I haven't,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
said Strether,
``made one protest.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

She (Gostrey) turned it over.

``Haven't you been seeing what there's to protest about?'' (He)

He (Strether) let her (Gostrey), with this, however ruefully, have the whole truth.

``I haven't yet found a single thing.'' (unknown)

``Isn't there any one WITH him (Chad) then?'' (unknown)

``Of the sort I came out about?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether took a moment.
``How do I know? And what do I care?'' (unknown)

``Oh oh!'' (unknown)
--and her (Gostrey) laughter spread. He (Strether) was struck in fact by the effect on her (Gostrey) of his (Strether) joke. He (Strether) saw now how he (Strether) meant it as a joke. SHE saw, however, still other things, though in an instant she (Gostrey) had hidden them.
``You've got at no facts at all?'' (He)

He (Strether) tried to muster them.

``Well, he (Chad) has a lovely home.'' (unknown)

``Ah that, in Paris,'' (she)
she (Gostrey) quickly returned,
``proves nothing. That is rather it DISproves nothing. They may very well, you see, the people your mission is concerned with, have done it FOR him (Chad).'' (she)

``Exactly. And it was on the scene of their doings then that Waymarsh and I sat guzzling.'' (unknown)

``Oh if you forbore to guzzle here on scenes of doings,'' (she)
she (Gostrey) replied,
``you might easily die of starvation.'' (she)
With which she (Gostrey) smiled at him (Strether).
``You've worse before you.'' (unknown)

``Ah I've EVERYTHING before me. But on our hypothesis, you know, they must be wonderful.'' (unknown)

``They ARE!'' (unknown)
said Miss Gostrey.
``You're not therefore, you see,'' (she)
she (Gostrey) added,
``wholly without facts. They've BEEN, in effect, wonderful.'' (she)

To have got at something comparatively definite appeared at last a little to help--a wave by which moreover, the next moment, recollection was washed.

``My young man does admit furthermore that they're our friend's great interest.'' (unknown)

``Is that the expression he (friend) uses?'' (unknown)

Strether more exactly recalled.

``No--not quite.'' (unknown)

``Something more vivid? Less?'' (He)

He (Strether) had bent, with neared glasses, over a group of articles on a small stand; and at this he (Strether) came up. ``It was a mere allusion, but, on the lookout as I was, it struck me.

``Awful, you know, as Chad is'--those were Bilham's words.'' (unknown)

''`Awful, you know'--? Oh!'' (Bilham/Mr. Bilham)
--and Miss Gostrey turned them over. She (Gostrey) seemed, however, satisfied.
``Well, what more do you want?'' (He)

He (Strether) glanced once more at a bibelot or two, and everything sent him (Strether) back.

``But it is all the same as if they wished to let me have it between the eyes.'' (She)

She (Gostrey) wondered.

``Quoi donc?'' (unknown)

``Why what I speak of. The amenity. They can stun you with that as well as with anything else.'' (unknown)

``Oh,'' (she)
she (Gostrey) answered,
``you'll come round! I must see them each,'' (she)
she (Gostrey) went on,
``for myself. I mean Mr. Bilham and Mr. Newsome--Mr. Bilham naturally first. Once only--once for each; that will do. But face to face--for half an hour. What's Mr. Chad,'' (she)
she (Gostrey) immediately pursued,
``doing at Cannes? Decent men don't go to Cannes with the--well, with the kind of ladies you mean.'' (she)

``Don't they?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether asked with an interest in decent men that amused her (Gostrey).

``No, elsewhere, but not to Cannes. Cannes is different. Cannes is better. Cannes is best. I mean it's all people you know--when you do know them. And if HE (Chad) does, why that's different too. He (Chad) must have gone alone. She (I) can't be with him (Chad).'' (unknown)

``I haven't,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether confessed in his (Strether) weakness,
``the least idea.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
There seemed much in what she (Gostrey) said, but he (Strether) was able after a little to help her (Gostrey) to a nearer impression. The meeting with little Bilham took place, by easy arrangement, in the great gallery of the Louvre; and when, standing with his (Bilham) fellow visitor before one of the splendid Titians--the overwhelming portrait of the young man with the strangely-shaped glove and the blue-grey eyes--he (man) turned to see the third member of their party advance from the end of the waxed and gilded vista, he (man) had a sense of having at last taken hold. He (man) had agreed with Miss Gostrey--it dated even from Chester--for a morning at the Louvre, and he (man) had embraced independently the same idea as thrown out by little Bilham, whom he (Bilham) had already accompanied to the museum of the Luxembourg. The fusion of these schemes presented no difficulty, and it was to strike him (Bilham) again that in little Bilham's company contrarieties in general dropped.

``Oh he (Chad)'s all right--he (Chad)'s one of US!'' (Miss Gostrey)
Miss Gostrey, after the first exchange, soon found a chance to murmur to her (Gostrey) companion; and Strether, as they proceeded and paused and while a quick unanimity between the two appeared to have phrased itself in half a dozen remarks--Strether knew that he (Strether) knew almost immediately what she (Gostrey) meant, and took it as still another sign that he (Strether) had got his (Strether) job in hand. This was the more grateful to him (Strether) that he (Strether) could think of the intelligence now serving him (Strether) as an acquisition positively new. He (Strether) wouldn't have known even the day before what she (Gostrey) meant--that is if she (Gostrey) meant, what he (Strether) assumed, that they were intense Americans together. He (Strether) had just worked round--and with a sharper turn of the screw than any yet--to the conception of an American intense as little Bilham was intense. The young man was his (Bilham) first specimen; the specimen had profoundly perplexed him (Bilham); at present however there was light. It was by little Bilham's amazing serenity that he (Bilham) had at first been affected, but he (Bilham) had inevitably, in his (Bilham) circumspection, felt it as the trail of the serpent, the corruption, as he (Bilham) might conveniently have said, of Europe; whereas the promptness with which it came up for Miss Gostrey but as a special little form of the oldest thing they knew justified it at once to his (Bilham) own vision as well. He (Bilham) wanted to be able to like his (Bilham) specimen with a clear good conscience, and this fully permitted it. What had muddled him (Bilham) was precisely the small artist-man's way--it was so complete--of being more American than anybody. But it now for the time put Strether vastly at his (Strether) ease to have this view of a new way.

The amiable youth then looked out, as it had first struck Strether, at a world in respect to which he (Strether) hadn't a prejudice. The one our friend most instantly missed was the usual one in favour of an occupation accepted. Little Bilham had an occupation, but it was only an occupation declined; and it was by his (Bilham) general exemption from alarm, anxiety or remorse on this score that the impression of his (Bilham) serenity was made. He (Bilham) had come out to Paris to paint--to fathom, that is, at large, that mystery; but study had been fatal to him (Bilham) so far as anything COULD be fatal, and his (Bilham) productive power faltered in proportion as his (Bilham) knowledge grew. Strether had gathered from him (Strether) that at the moment of his (Strether) finding him (Strether) in Chad's rooms he (Strether) hadn't saved from his (Strether) shipwreck a scrap of anything but his (Strether) beautiful intelligence and his (Strether) confirmed habit of Paris. He (Strether) referred to these things with an equal fond familiarity, and it was sufficiently clear that, as an outfit, they still served him (Strether). They were charming to Strether through the hour spent at the Louvre, where indeed they figured for him (Strether) as an unseparated part of the charged iridescent air, the glamour of the name, the splendour of the space, the colour of the masters. Yet they were present too wherever the young man led, and the day after the visit to the Louvre they hung, in a different walk, about the steps of our party. He (man) had invited his (man) companions to cross the river with him (man), offering to show them his (man) own poor place; and his (man) own poor place, which was very poor, gave to his (man) idiosyncrasies, for Strether--the small sublime indifference and independences that had struck the latter as fresh--an odd and engaging dignity. He (man) lived at the end of an alley that went out of an old short cobbled street, a street that went in turn out of a new long smooth avenue--street and avenue and alley having, however, in common a sort of social shabbiness; and he (man) introduced them to the rather cold and blank little studio which he (man) had lent to a comrade for the term of his (man) elegant absence. The comrade was another ingenuous compatriot, to whom he (comrade) had wired that tea was to await them

``regardless,'' (he)
and this reckless repast, and the second ingenuous compatriot, and the faraway makeshift life, with its jokes and its gaps, its delicate daubs and its three or four chairs, its overflow of taste and conviction and its lack of nearly all else--these things wove round the occasion a spell to which our hero unreservedly surrendered.

He (hero) liked the ingenuous compatriots--for two or three others soon gathered; he (hero) liked the delicate daubs and the free discriminations--involving references indeed, involving enthusiasms and execrations that made him (hero), as they said, sit up; he (hero) liked above all the legend of good-humoured poverty, of mutual accommodation fairly raised to the romantic, that he (hero) soon read into the scene. The ingenuous compatriots showed a candour, he (hero) thought, surpassing even the candour of Woollett; they were red-haired and long-legged, they were quaint and queer and dear and droll; they made the place resound with the vernacular, which he (hero) had never known so marked as when figuring for the chosen language, he (hero) must suppose, of contemporary art. They twanged with a vengeance the aesthetic lyre--they drew from it wonderful airs. This aspect of their life had an admirable innocence; and he (hero) looked on occasion at Maria Gostrey to see to what extent that element reached her (Maria). She (Maria) gave him (hero) however for the hour, as she (Maria) had given him (hero) the previous day, no further sign than to show how she (Maria) dealt with boys; meeting them with the air of old Parisian practice that she (Maria) had for every one, for everything, in turn. Wonderful about the delicate daubs, masterful about the way to make tea, trustful about the legs of chairs and familiarly reminiscent of those, in the other time, the named, the numbered or the caricatured, who had flourished or failed, disappeared or arrived, she (Maria) had accepted with the best grace her (Maria) second course of little Bilham, and had said to Strether, the previous afternoon on his (Strether) leaving them, that, since her (Maria) impression was to be renewed, she (Maria) would reserve judgement till after the new evidence.

The new evidence was to come, as it proved, in a day or two. He (Strether) soon had from Maria a message to the effect that an excellent box at the Francais had been lent her (Maria) for the following night; it seeming on such occasions not the least of her (Maria) merits that she (Maria) was subject to such approaches. The sense of how she (Maria) was always paying for something in advance was equalled on Strether's part only by the sense of how she (Maria) was always being paid; all of which made for his (Strether) consciousness, in the larger air, of a lively bustling traffic, the exchange of such values as were not for him (Strether) to handle. She (Maria) hated, he (Strether) knew, at the French play, anything but a box--just as she (Maria) hated at the English anything but a stall; and a box was what he (Strether) was already in this phase girding himself to press upon her (Maria). But she (Maria) had for that matter her (Maria) community with little Bilham: she (Maria) too always, on the great issues, showed as having known in time. It made her (Maria) constantly beforehand with him (Bilham) and gave him (Bilham) mainly the chance to ask himself how on the day of their settlement their account would stand. He (Bilham) endeavoured even now to keep it a little straight by arranging that if he (Bilham) accepted her (Maria) invitation she (Maria) should dine with him (Bilham) first; but the upshot of this scruple was that at eight o'clock on the morrow he (Bilham) awaited her (Maria) with Waymarsh under the pillared portico. She (Maria) hadn't dined with him (Bilham), and it was characteristic of their relation that she (Maria) had made him (Bilham) embrace her (Maria) refusal without in the least understanding it. She (Maria) ever caused her (Maria) rearrangements to affect him (Bilham) as her (Maria) tenderest touches. It was on that principle for instance that, giving him (Bilham) the opportunity to be amiable again to little Bilham, she (Maria) had suggested his (Bilham) offering the young man a seat in their box. Strether had dispatched for this purpose a small blue missive to the Boulevard Malesherbes, but up to the moment of their passing into the theatre he (Strether) had received no response to his (Strether) message. He (Strether) held, however, even after they had been for some time conveniently seated, that their friend, who knew his (friend) way about, would come in at his (friend) own right moment. His (friend) temporary absence moreover seemed, as never yet, to make the right moment for Miss Gostrey. Strether had been waiting till tonight to get back from her (Strether) in some mirrored form her (Strether) impressions and conclusions. She (Strether) had elected, as they said, to see little Bilham once; but now she (Strether) had seen him (Bilham) twice and had nevertheless not said more than a word.

Waymarsh meanwhile sat opposite him (Bilham) with their hostess between; and Miss Gostrey spoke of herself as an instructor of youth introducing her (Gostrey) little charges to a work that was one of the glories of literature. The glory was happily unobjectionable, and the little charges were candid; for herself she (Gostrey) had travelled that road and she (Gostrey) merely waited on their innocence. But she (Gostrey) referred in due time to their absent friend, whom it was clear they should have to give up.

``He (Chad) either won't have got your note,'' (she)
she (Gostrey) said,
``or you won't have got his (Chad): he (Chad) has had some kind of hindrance, and, of course, for that matter, you know, a man never writes about coming to a box.'' (she)
She (Gostrey) spoke as if, with her (Gostrey) look, it might have been Waymarsh who had written to the youth, and the latter's face showed a mixture of austerity and anguish. She (Waymarsh) went on however as if to meet this.
``He (man)'s far and away, you know, the best of them.'' (unknown)

``The best of whom, ma'am?'' (unknown)

``Why of all the long procession--the boys, the girls, or the old men and old women as they sometimes really are; the hope, as one may say, of our country. They've all passed, year after year; but there has been no one in particular I've ever wanted to stop. I feel--don't YOU?--that I want to stop little Bilham; he (Bilham)'s so exactly right as he (Bilham) is.'' (She)
She (Waymarsh) continued to talk to Waymarsh.
``He (Bilham)'s too delightful. If he (Bilham)'ll only not spoil it! But they always WILL; they always do; they always have.'' (unknown)

``I don't think Waymarsh knows,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether said after a moment,
``quite what it's open to Bilham to spoil.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

``It can't be a good American,'' (Waymarsh/Mrs. Waymarsh)
Waymarsh lucidly enough replied;
``for it didn't strike me the young man had developed much in THAT shape.'' (Waymarsh/Mrs. Waymarsh)

``Ah,'' (Miss Gostrey)
Miss Gostrey sighed,
``the name of the good American is as easily given as taken away! What IS it, to begin with, to BE one, and what's the extraordinary hurry? Surely nothing that's so pressing was ever so little defined. It's such an order, really, that before we cook you the dish we must at least have your receipt. Besides the poor chicks have time! What I've seen so often spoiled,'' (Miss Gostrey)
she (Gostrey) pursued,
``is the happy attitude itself, the state of faith and--what shall I call it?--the sense of beauty. You're right about him (You)'' (she)
--she (Gostrey) now took in Strether;
``little Bilham has them to a charm, we must keep little Bilham along.'' (Strether)
Then she (Gostrey) was all again for Waymarsh.
``The others have all wanted so dreadfully to do something, and they've gone and done it in too many cases indeed. It leaves them never the same afterwards; the charm's always somehow broken. Now HE (Bilham), I think, you know, really won't. He (Bilham) won't do the least dreadful little thing. We shall continue to enjoy him (Bilham) just as he (Bilham) is. No--he (Bilham)'s quite beautiful. He (Bilham) sees everything. He (Bilham) isn't a bit ashamed. He (Bilham) has every scrap of the courage of it that one could ask. Only think what he (Bilham) MIGHT do. One wants really--for fear of some accident--to keep him (Bilham) in view. At this very moment perhaps what mayn't he (Bilham) be up to? I've had my disappointments--the poor things are never really safe; or only at least when you have them under your eye. One can never completely trust them. One's uneasy, and I think that's why I most miss him (Bilham) now.'' (She)

She (Waymarsh) had wound up with a laugh of enjoyment over her (Waymarsh) embroidery of her (Waymarsh) idea--an enjoyment that her (Waymarsh) face communicated to Strether, who almost wished none the less at this moment that she (Waymarsh) would let poor Waymarsh alone. HE (Strether) knew more or less what she (Waymarsh) meant; but the fact wasn't a reason for her (Waymarsh) not pretending to Waymarsh that he (Strether) didn't. It was craven of him (Strether) perhaps, but he (Strether) would, for the high amenity of the occasion, have liked Waymarsh not to be so sure of his (Strether) wit. Her (Waymarsh) recognition of it gave him (Strether) away and, before she (Waymarsh) had done with him (Strether) or with that article, would give him (Strether) worse. What was he (Strether), all the same, to do? He (Strether) looked across the box at his (Strether) friend; their eyes met; something queer and stiff, something that bore on the situation but that it was better not to touch, passed in silence between them. Well, the effect of it for Strether was an abrupt reaction, a final impatience of his (Strether) own tendency to temporise. Where was that taking him (Strether) anyway? It was one of the quiet instants that sometimes settle more matters than the outbreaks dear to the historic muse. The only qualification of the quietness was the synthetic

``Oh hang it!'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
into which Strether's share of the silence soundlessly flowered. It represented, this mute ejaculation, a final impulse to burn his (Strether) ships. These ships, to the historic muse, may seem of course mere cockles, but when he (Strether) presently spoke to Miss Gostrey it was with the sense at least of applying the torch.
``Is it then a conspiracy?'' (unknown)

``Between the two young men? Well, I don't pretend to be a seer or a prophetess,'' (she)
she (Strether) presently replied;
``but if I'm simply a woman of sense he (seer)'s working for you to-night. I don't quite know how--but it's in my bones.'' (she)
And she (Strether) looked at him (Strether) at last as if, little material as she (Strether) yet gave him (Strether), he (Strether)'d really understand. ``For an opinion THAT
``S my opinion. He (seer) makes you out too well not to.'' (unknown)

``Not to work for me to-night?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether wondered.
``Then I hope he (seer) isn't doing anything very bad.'' (unknown)

``They've got you,'' (she)
she (Strether) portentously answered.

``Do you mean he (seer) IS--?'' (unknown)

``They've got you,'' (she)
she (Strether) merely repeated. Though she (Strether) disclaimed the prophetic vision she (Strether) was at this instant the nearest approach he (Strether) had ever met to the priestess of the oracle. The light was in her (Strether) eyes.
``You must face it now.'' (He)

He (Strether) faced it on the spot.

``They HAD arranged--?'' (unknown)

``Every move in the game. And they've been arranging ever since. He (seer) has had every day his (seer) little telegram from Cannes.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

It made Strether open his (Strether) eyes.

``Do you KNOW that?'' (unknown)

``I do better. I see it. This was, before I met him (seer), what I wondered whether I WAS to see. But as soon as I met him (seer) I ceased to wonder, and our second meeting made me sure. I took him (seer) all in. He (seer) was acting--he (seer) is still--on his (seer) daily instructions.'' (unknown)

``So that Chad has done the whole thing?'' (unknown)

``Oh no--not the whole. WE

``VE done some of it. You and I and `Europe.''' (unknown)

``Europe--yes,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether mused.

``Dear old Paris,'' (she)
she (Strether) seemed to explain. But there was more, and, with one of her (Strether) turns, she (Strether) risked it.
``And dear old Waymarsh. You,'' (she)
she (Strether) declared,
``have been a good bit of it.'' (she)

He (Strether) sat massive.

``A good bit of what, ma'am?'' (unknown)

``Why of the wonderful consciousness of our friend here. You've helped too in your way to float him (friend) to where he (friend) is.'' (unknown)

``And where the devil IS he (devil)?'' (She)

She (Strether) passed it on with a laugh.

``Where the devil, Strether, are you?'' (He)

He (Strether) spoke as if he (Strether) had just been thinking it out.

``Well, quite already in Chad's hands, it would seem.'' (he)
And he (Strether) had had with this another thought.
``Will that be--just all through Bilham--the way he (Bilham)'s going to work it? It would be, for him (Bilham), you know, an idea. And Chad with an idea--!'' (unknown)

``Well?'' (she)
she (Strether) asked while the image held him (Strether).

``Well, is Chad--what shall I say?--monstrous?'' (unknown)

``Oh as much as you like! But the idea you speak of,'' (she)
she (Strether) said,
``won't have been his (Chad) best. He (Chad)'ll have a better. It won't be all through little Bilham that he (Bilham)'ll work it.'' (she)

This already sounded almost like a hope destroyed.

``Through whom else then?'' (unknown)

``That's what we shall see!'' (she)
But quite as she (Strether) spoke she (Strether) turned, and Strether turned; for the door of the box had opened, with the click of the ouvreuse, from the lobby, and a gentleman, a stranger to them, had come in with a quick step. The door closed behind him (gentleman), and, though their faces showed him (gentleman) his (gentleman) mistake, his (gentleman) air, which was striking, was all good confidence. The curtain had just again arisen, and, in the hush of the general attention, Strether's challenge was tacit, as was also the greeting, with a quickly deprecating hand and smile, of the unannounced visitor. He (visitor) discreetly signed that he (visitor) would wait, would stand, and these things and his (visitor) face, one look from which she (gentleman) had caught, had suddenly worked for Miss Gostrey. She (gentleman) fitted to them all an answer for Strether's last question. The solid stranger was simply the answer--as she (gentleman) now, turning to her (gentleman) friend, indicated. She (gentleman) brought it straight out for him (friend)--it presented the intruder.
``Why, through this gentleman!'' (The gentleman)
The gentleman indeed, at the same time, though sounding for Strether a very short name, did practically as much to explain. Strether gasped the name back--then only had he (Strether) seen Miss Gostrey had said more than she (Gostrey) knew. They were in presence of Chad himself.

Our friend was to go over it afterwards again and again--he (friend) was going over it much of the time that they were together, and they were together constantly for three or four days: the note had been so strongly struck during that first half-hour that everything happening since was comparatively a minor development. The fact was that his (friend) perception of the young man's identity--so absolutely checked for a minute--had been quite one of the sensations that count in life; he (friend) certainly had never known one that had acted, as he (friend) might have said, with more of a crowded rush. And the rush though both vague and multitudinous, had lasted a long time, protected, as it were, yet at the same time aggravated, by the circumstance of its coinciding with a stretch of decorous silence. They couldn't talk without disturbing the spectators in the part of the balcony just below them; and it, for that matter, came to Strether--being a thing of the sort that did come to him (friend)--that these were the accidents of a high civilisation; the imposed tribute to propriety, the frequent exposure to conditions, usually brilliant, in which relief has to await its time. Relief was never quite near at hand for kings, queens, comedians and other such people, and though you might be yourself not exactly one of those, you could yet, in leading the life of high pressure, guess a little how they sometimes felt. It was truly the life of high pressure that Strether had seemed to feel himself lead while he (Strether) sat there, close to Chad, during the long tension of the act. He (Chad) was in presence of a fact that occupied his (Chad) whole mind, that occupied for the half-hour his (Chad) senses themselves all together; but he (Chad) couldn't without inconvenience show anything--which moreover might count really as luck. What he (Chad) might have shown, had he (Chad) shown at all, was exactly the kind of emotion--the emotion of bewilderment--that he (Chad) had proposed to himself from the first, whatever should occur, to show least. The phenomenon that had suddenly sat down there with him (Chad) was a phenomenon of change so complete that his (Chad) imagination, which had worked so beforehand, felt itself, in the connexion, without margin or allowance. It had faced every contingency but that Chad should not BE Chad, and this was what it now had to face with a mere strained smile and an uncomfortable flush.

He (Chad) asked himself if, by any chance, before he (Chad) should have in some way to commit himself, he (Chad) might feel his (Chad) mind settled to the new vision, might habituate it, so to speak, to the remarkable truth. But oh it was too remarkable, the truth; for what could be more remarkable than this sharp rupture of an identity? You could deal with a man as himself--you couldn't deal with him (man) as somebody else. It was a small source of peace moreover to be reduced to wondering how little he (man) might know in such an event what a sum he (man) was setting you. He (man) couldn't absolutely not know, for you couldn't absolutely not let him (man). It was a CASE then simply, a strong case, as people nowadays called such things,'' a case of transformation unsurpassed, and the hope was but in the general law that strong cases were liable to control from without. Perhaps he (man), Strether himself, was the only person after all aware of it. Even Miss Gostrey, with all her (Gostrey) science, wouldn't be, would she (Gostrey)?--and he (Strether) had never seen any one less aware of anything than Waymarsh as he (Strether) glowered at Chad. The social sightlessness of his (Chad) old friend's survey marked for him (Chad) afresh, and almost in an humiliating way, the inevitable limits of direct aid from this source. He (Chad) was not certain, however, of not drawing a shade of compensation from the privilege, as yet untasted, of knowing more about something in particular than Miss Gostrey did. His (Chad) situation too was a case, for that matter, and he (Chad) was now so interested, quite so privately agog, about it, that he (Chad) had already an eye to the fun it would be to open up to her (Gostrey) afterwards. He (Chad) derived during his (Chad) half-hour no assistance from her (Gostrey), and just this fact of her (Gostrey) not meeting his (Chad) eyes played a little, it must be confessed, into his (Chad) predicament.

He (Chad) had introduced Chad, in the first minutes, under his (Chad) breath, and there was never the primness in her (Gostrey) of the person unacquainted; but she (Gostrey) had none the less betrayed at first no vision but of the stage, where she (Gostrey) occasionally found a pretext for an appreciative moment that she (Gostrey) invited Waymarsh to share. The latter's faculty of participation had never had, all round, such an assault to meet; the pressure on him (Chad) being the sharper for this chosen attitude in her (Gostrey), as Strether judged it, of isolating, for their natural intercourse, Chad and himself. This intercourse was meanwhile restricted to a frank friendly look from the young man, something markedly like a smile, but falling far short of a grin, and to the vivacity of Strether's private speculation as to whether HE (Strether) carried himself like a fool. He (Strether) didn't quite see how he (Strether) could so feel as one without somehow showing as one. The worst of that question moreover was that he (Strether) knew it as a symptom the sense of which annoyed him (Strether).

``If I'm going to be odiously conscious of how I may strike the fellow,'' (he)
he (Strether) reflected,
``it was so little what I came out for that I may as well stop before I begin.'' (he)
This sage consideration too, distinctly, seemed to leave untouched the fact that he (Strether) WAS going to be conscious. He (Strether) was conscious of everything but of what would have served him (Strether).

He (Strether) was to know afterwards, in the watches of the night, that nothing would have been more open to him (Strether) than after a minute or two to propose to Chad to seek with him (Chad) the refuge of the lobby. He (Chad) hadn't only not proposed it, but had lacked even the presence of mind to see it as possible. He (Chad) had stuck there like a schoolboy wishing not to miss a minute of the show; though for that portion of the show then presented he (Chad) hadn't had an instant's real attention. He (Chad) couldn't when the curtain fell have given the slightest account of what had happened. He (Chad) had therefore, further, not at that moment acknowledged the amenity added by this acceptance of his (Chad) awkwardness to Chad's general patience. Hadn't he (Chad) none the less known at the very time--known it stupidly and without reaction--that the boy was accepting something? He (boy) was modestly benevolent, the boy--that was at least what he (boy) had been capable of the superiority of making out his (boy) chance to be; and one had one's self literally not had the gumption to get in ahead of him (boy). If we should go into all that occupied our friend in the watches of the night we should have to mend our pen; but an instance or two may mark for us the vividness with which he (friend) could remember. He (friend) remembered the two absurdities that, if his (friend) presence of mind HAD failed, were the things that had had most to do with it. He (friend) had never in his (friend) life seen a young man come into a box at ten o'clock at night, and would, if challenged on the question in advance, have scarce been ready to pronounce as to different ways of doing so. But it was in spite of this definite to him (friend) that Chad had had a way that was wonderful: a fact carrying with it an implication that, as one might imagine it, he (Chad) knew, he (Chad) had learned, how.

Here already then were abounding results; he (Chad) had on the spot and without the least trouble of intention taught Strether that even in so small a thing as that there were different ways. He (Strether) had done in the same line still more than this; had by a mere shake or two of the head made his (Strether) old friend observe that the change in him (Strether) was perhaps more than anything else, for the eye, a matter of the marked streaks of grey, extraordinary at his (Strether) age, in his (Strether) thick black hair; as well as that this new feature was curiously becoming to him (Strether), did something for him (Strether), as characterisation, also even--of all things in the world--as refinement, that had been a good deal wanted. Strether felt, however, he (Strether) would have had to confess, that it wouldn't have been easy just now, on this and other counts, in the presence of what had been supplied, to be quite clear as to what had been missed. A reflexion a candid critic might have made of old, for instance, was that it would have been happier for the son to look more like the mother; but this was a reflexion that at present would never occur. The ground had quite fallen away from it, yet no resemblance whatever to the mother had supervened. It would have been hard for a young man's face and air to disconnect themselves more completely than Chad's at this juncture from any discerned, from any imaginable aspect of a New England female parent. That of course was no more than had been on the cards; but it produced in Strether none the less one of those frequent phenomena of mental reference with which all judgement in him (Chad) was actually beset.

Again and again as the days passed he (Chad) had had a sense of the pertinence of communicating quickly with Woollett--communicating with a quickness with which telegraphy alone would rhyme; the fruit really of a fine fancy in him (Chad) for keeping things straight, for the happy forestalment of error. No one could explain better when needful, nor put more conscience into an account or a report; which burden of conscience is perhaps exactly the reason why his (Chad) heart always sank when the clouds of explanation gathered. His (Chad) highest ingenuity was in keeping the sky of life clear of them. Whether or no he (Chad) had a grand idea of the lucid, he (Chad) held that nothing ever was in fact--for any one else--explained. One went through the vain motions, but it was mostly a waste of life. A personal relation was a relation only so long as people either perfectly understood or, better still, didn't care if they didn't. From the moment they cared if they didn't it was living by the sweat of one's brow; and the sweat of one's brow was just what one might buy one's self off from by keeping the ground free of the wild weed of delusion. It easily grew too fast, and the Atlantic cable now alone could race with it. That agency would each day have testified for him (people) to something that was not what Woollett had argued. He (people) was not at this moment absolutely sure that the effect of the morrow's--or rather of the night's--appreciation of the crisis wouldn't be to determine some brief missive.

``Have at last seen him (fellow), but oh dear!'' (him)
--some temporary relief of that sort seemed to hover before him (people). It hovered somehow as preparing them all--yet preparing them for what? If he (people) might do so more luminously and cheaply he (people) would tick out in four words:
``Awfully old--grey hair.'' (he)
To this particular item in Chad's appearance he (Chad) constantly, during their mute half-hour, reverted; as if so very much more than he (Chad) could have said had been involved in it. The most he (Chad) could have said would have been:
``If he (fellow)'s going to make me feel young--!'' (he)
which indeed, however, carried with it quite enough. If Strether was to feel young, that is, it would be because Chad was to feel old; and an aged and hoary sinner had been no part of the scheme.

The question of Chadwick's true time of life was, doubtless, what came up quickest after the adjournment of the two, when the play was over, to a cafe in the Avenue de l``Opera. Miss Gostrey had in due course been perfect for such a step; she (Gostrey) had known exactly what they wanted--to go straight somewhere and talk; and Strether had even felt she (Gostrey) had known what he (Strether) wished to say and that he (Strether) was arranging immediately to begin. She (Gostrey) hadn't pretended this, as she (Gostrey) HAD pretended on the other hand, to have divined Waymarsh's wish to extend to her (Waymarsh) an independent protection homeward; but Strether nevertheless found how, after he (Strether) had Chad opposite to him (Chad) at a small table in the brilliant halls that his (Chad) companion straightway selected, sharply and easily discriminated from others, it was quite, to his (Chad) mind, as if she (Waymarsh) heard him (Chad) speak; as if, sitting up, a mile away, in the little apartment he (Chad) knew, she (Waymarsh) would listen hard enough to catch. He (Chad) found too that he (Chad) liked that idea, and he (Chad) wished that, by the same token, Mrs. Newsome might have caught as well. For what had above all been determined in him (Chad) as a necessity of the first order was not to lose another hour, nor a fraction of one; was to advance, to overwhelm, with a rush. This was how he (Chad) would anticipate--by a night-attack, as might be--any forced maturity that a crammed consciousness of Paris was likely to take upon itself to assert on behalf of the boy. He (boy) knew to the full, on what he (boy) had just extracted from Miss Gostrey, Chad's marks of alertness; but they were a reason the more for not dawdling. If he (Chad) was himself moreover to be treated as young he (Chad) wouldn't at all events be so treated before he (Chad) should have struck out at least once. His (Chad) arms might be pinioned afterwards, but it would have been left on record that he (Chad) was fifty. The importance of this he (Chad) had indeed begun to feel before they left the theatre; it had become a wild unrest, urging him (Chad) to seize his (Chad) chance. He (Chad) could scarcely wait for it as they went; he (Chad) was on the verge of the indecency of bringing up the question in the street; he (Chad) fairly caught himself going on--so he (Chad) afterwards invidiously named it--as if there would be for him (Chad) no second chance should the present be lost. Not till, on the purple divan before the perfunctory bock, he (Chad) had brought out the words themselves, was he (Chad) sure, for that matter, that the present would be saved.

Book Fourth

I

``I've come, you know, to make you break with everything, neither more nor less, and take you straight home; so you'll be so good as immediately and favourably to consider it!'' (I)
--Strether, face to face with Chad after the play, had sounded these words almost breathlessly, and with an effect at first positively disconcerting to himself alone. For Chad's receptive attitude was that of a person who had been gracefully quiet while the messenger at last reaching him (Chad) has run a mile through the dust. During some seconds after he (Chad) had spoken Strether felt as if HE (Strether) had made some such exertion; he (Strether) was not even certain that the perspiration wasn't on his (Strether) brow. It was the kind of consciousness for which he (Strether) had to thank the look that, while the strain lasted, the young man's eyes gave him (man). They reflected--and the deuce of the thing was that they reflected really with a sort of shyness of kindness--his (man) momentarily disordered state; which fact brought on in its turn for our friend the dawn of a fear that Chad might simply
``take it out'' (Chad/Chad Newsome/Newsome)
--take everything out--in being sorry for him (Chad). Such a fear, any fear, was unpleasant. But everything was unpleasant; it was odd how everything had suddenly turned so. This however was no reason for letting the least thing go. Strether had the next minute proceeded as roundly as if with an advantage to follow up.
``Of course I'm a busybody, if you want to fight the case to the death; but after all mainly in the sense of having known you and having given you such attention as you kindly permitted when you were in jackets and knickerbockers. Yes--it was knickerbockers, I'm busybody enough to remember that; and that you had, for your age--I speak of the first far-away time--tremendously stout legs. Well, we want you to break. Your mother's heart's passionately set upon it, but she (mother) has above and beyond that excellent arguments and reasons. I've not put them into her (mother) head--I needn't remind you how little she (mother)'s a person who needs that. But they exist--you must take it from me as a friend both of hers and yours--for myself as well. I didn't invent them, I didn't originally work them out; but I understand them, I think I can explain them--by which I mean make you actively do them justice; and that's why you see me here. You had better know the worst at once. It's a question of an immediate rupture and an immediate return. I've been conceited enough to dream I can sugar that pill. I take at any rate the greatest interest in the question. I took it already before I left home, and I don't mind telling you that, altered as you are, I take it still more now that I've seen you. You're older and--I don't know what to call it!--more of a handful; but you're by so much the more, I seem to make out, to our purpose.'' (unknown)

``Do I strike you as improved?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether was to recall that Chad had at this point enquired.

He (Chad) was likewise to recall--and it had to count for some time as his (Chad) greatest comfort--that it had been

``given'' (He)
him (Chad), as they said at Woollett, to reply with some presence of mind:
``I haven't the least idea.'' (him)
He (Chad) was really for a while to like thinking he (Chad) had been positively hard. On the point of conceding that Chad had improved in appearance, but that to the question of appearance the remark must be confined, he (Chad) checked even that compromise and left his (Chad) reservation bare. Not only his (Chad) moral, but also, as it were, his (Chad) aesthetic sense had a little to pay for this, Chad being unmistakeably--and wasn't it a matter of the confounded grey hair again?--handsomer than he (Chad) had ever promised. That however fell in perfectly with what Strether had said. They had no desire to keep down his (Strether) proper expansion, and he (Strether) wouldn't be less to their purpose for not looking, as he (Strether) had too often done of old, only bold and wild. There was indeed a signal particular in which he (Strether) would distinctly be more so. Strether didn't, as he (Strether) talked, absolutely follow himself; he (Strether) only knew he (Strether) was clutching his (Strether) thread and that he (Strether) held it from moment to moment a little tighter; his (Strether) mere uninterruptedness during the few minutes helped him (Strether) to do that. He (Strether) had frequently for a month, turned over what he (Strether) should say on this very occasion, and he (Strether) seemed at last to have said nothing he (Strether) had thought of--everything was so totally different.

But in spite of all he (Strether) had put the flag at the window. This was what he (Strether) had done, and there was a minute during which he (Strether) affected himself as having shaken it hard, flapped it with a mighty flutter, straight in front of his (Strether) companion's nose. It gave him (Strether) really almost the sense of having already acted his (Strether) part. The momentary relief--as if from the knowledge that nothing of THAT at least could be undone--sprang from a particular cause, the cause that had flashed into operation, in Miss Gostrey's box, with direct apprehension, with amazed recognition, and that had been concerned since then in every throb of his (Strether) consciousness. What it came to was that with an absolutely new quantity to deal with one simply couldn't know. The new quantity was represented by the fact that Chad had been made over. That was all; whatever it was it was everything. Strether had never seen the thing so done before--it was perhaps a speciality of Paris. If one had been present at the process one might little by little have mastered the result; but he (Strether) was face to face, as matters stood, with the finished business. It had freely been noted for him (Strether) that he (Strether) might be received as a dog among skittles, but that was on the basis of the old quantity. He (Strether) had originally thought of lines and tones as things to be taken, but these possibilities had now quite melted away. There was no computing at all what the young man before him (man) would think or feel or say on any subject whatever. This intelligence Strether had afterwards, to account for his (Strether) nervousness, reconstituted as he (Strether) might, just as he (Strether) had also reconstituted the promptness with which Chad had corrected his (Chad) uncertainty. An extraordinarily short time had been required for the correction, and there had ceased to be anything negative in his (Chad) companion's face and air as soon as it was made.

``Your engagement to my mother has become then what they call here a fait accompli?'' (unknown)
--it had consisted, the determinant touch, in nothing more than that.

Well, that was enough, Strether had felt while his (Strether) answer hung fire. He (Strether) had felt at the same time, however, that nothing could less become him (Strether) than that it should hang fire too long.

``Yes,'' (he)
he (Strether) said brightly,
``it was on the happy settlement of the question that I started. You see therefore to what tune I'm in your family. Moreover,'' (he)
he (Strether) added,
``I've been supposing you'd suppose it.'' (he)

``Oh I've been supposing it for a long time, and what you tell me helps me to understand that you should want to do something. To do something, I mean,'' (Chad)
said Chad,
``to commemorate an event so--what do they call it?--so auspicious. I see you make out, and not unnaturally,'' (Chad)
he (Chad) continued,
``that bringing me home in triumph as a sort of wedding-present to Mother would commemorate it better than anything else. You want to make a bonfire in fact,'' (he)
he (Chad) laughed,
``and you pitch me on. Thank you, thank you!'' (he)
he (Chad) laughed again.

He (Chad) was altogether easy about it, and this made Strether now see how at bottom, and in spite of the shade of shyness that really cost him (Strether) nothing, he (Strether) had from the first moment been easy about everything. The shade of shyness was mere good taste. People with manners formed could apparently have, as one of their best cards, the shade of shyness too. He (Strether) had leaned a little forward to speak; his (Strether) elbows were on the table; and the inscrutable new face that he (Strether) had got somewhere and somehow was brought by the movement nearer to his (Strether) critics There was a fascination for that critic in its not being, this ripe physiognomy, the face that, under observation at least, he (Strether) had originally carried away from Woollett. Strether found a certain freedom on his (Strether) own side in defining it as that of a man of the world--a formula that indeed seemed to come now in some degree to his (Strether) relief; that of a man to whom things had happened and were variously known. In gleams, in glances, the past did perhaps peep out of it; but such lights were faint and instantly merged. Chad was brown and thick and strong, and of old Chad had been rough. Was all the difference therefore that he (Chad) was actually smooth? Possibly; for that he (Chad) WAS smooth was as marked as in the taste of a sauce or in the rub of a hand. The effect of it was general--it had retouched his (Chad) features, drawn them with a cleaner line. It had cleared his (Chad) eyes and settled his (Chad) colour and polished his (Chad) fine square teeth--the main ornament of his (Chad) face; and at the same time that it had given him (Chad) a form and a surface, almost a design, it had toned his (Chad) voice, established his (Chad) accent, encouraged his (Chad) smile to more play and his (Chad) other motions to less. He (Chad) had formerly, with a great deal of action, expressed very little; and he (Chad) now expressed whatever was necessary with almost none at all. It was as if in short he (Chad) had really, copious perhaps but shapeless, been put into a firm mould and turned successfully out. The phenomenon--Strether kept eyeing it as a phenomenon, an eminent case--was marked enough to be touched by the finger. He (Strether) finally put his (Strether) hand across the table and laid it on Chad's arm.

``If you'll promise me--here on the spot and giving me your word of honour--to break straight off, you'll make the future the real right thing for all of us alike. You'll ease off the strain of this decent but none the less acute suspense in which I've for so many days been waiting for you, and let me turn in to rest. I shall leave you with my blessing and go to bed in peace.'' (Chad/Chad Newsome/Newsome)

Chad again fell back at this and, his (Chad) hands pocketed, settled himself a little; in which posture he (Chad) looked, though he (Chad) rather anxiously smiled, only the more earnest. Then Strether seemed to see that he (Strether) was really nervous, and he (Strether) took that as what he (Strether) would have called a wholesome sign. The only mark of it hitherto had been his (Strether) more than once taking off and putting on his (Strether) wide-brimmed crush hat. He (Strether) had at this moment made the motion again to remove it, then had only pushed it back, so that it hung informally on his (Strether) strong young grizzled crop. It was a touch that gave the note of the familiar--the intimate and the belated--to their quiet colloquy; and it was indeed by some such trivial aid that Strether became aware at the same moment of something else. The observation was at any rate determined in him (Strether) by some light too fine to distinguish from so many others, but it was none the less sharply determined. Chad looked unmistakeably during these instants--well, as Strether put it to himself, all he (Strether) was worth. Our friend had a sudden apprehension of what that would on certain sides be. He (Strether) saw him (Strether) in a flash as the young man marked out by women; and for a concentrated minute the dignity, the comparative austerity, as he (Strether) funnily fancied it, of this character affected him (Strether) almost with awe. There was an experience on his (Strether) interlocutor's part that looked out at him (Strether) from under the displaced hat, and that looked out moreover by a force of its own, the deep fact of its quantity and quality, and not through Chad's intending bravado or swagger. That was then the way men marked out by women WERE--and also the men by whom the women were doubtless in turn sufficiently distinguished. It affected Strether for thirty seconds as a relevant truth, a truth which, however, the next minute, had fallen into its relation.

``Can't you imagine there being some questions,'' (Chad)
Chad asked,
``that a fellow--however much impressed by your charming way of stating things--would like to put to you first?'' (Chad)

``Oh yes--easily. I'm here to answer everything. I think I can even tell you things, of the greatest interest to you, that you won't know enough to ask me. We'll take as many days to it as you like. But I want,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether wound up,
``to go to bed now.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

``Really?'' (Chad/Chad Newsome/Newsome)

Chad had spoken in such surprise that he (Chad) was amused.

``Can't you believe it?--with what you put me through?'' (The man)

The young man seemed to consider.

``Oh I haven't put you through much--yet.'' (unknown)

``Do you mean there's so much more to come?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether laughed.
``All the more reason then that I should gird myself.'' (he)
And as if to mark what he (Strether) felt he (Strether) could by this time count on he (Strether) was already on his (Strether) feet.

Chad, still seated, stayed him (Chad), with a hand against him (Chad), as he (Chad) passed between their table and the next.

``Oh we shall get on!'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

The tone was, as who should say, everything Strether could have desired; and quite as good the expression of face with which the speaker had looked up at him (speaker) and kindly held him (speaker). All these things lacked was their not showing quite so much as the fruit of experience. Yes, experience was what Chad did play on him (Chad), if he (Chad) didn't play any grossness of defiance. Of course experience was in a manner defiance; but it wasn't, at any rate--rather indeed quite the contrary!--grossness; which was so much gained. He (Chad) fairly grew older, Strether thought, while he (Strether) himself so reasoned. Then with his (Strether) mature pat of his (Strether) visitor's arm he (Strether) also got up; and there had been enough of it all by this time to make the visitor feel that something WAS settled. Wasn't it settled that he (visitor) had at least the testimony of Chad's own belief in a settlement? Strether found himself treating Chad's profession that they would get on as a sufficient basis for going to bed. He (Strether) hadn't nevertheless after this gone to bed directly; for when they had again passed out together into the mild bright night a check had virtually sprung from nothing more than a small circumstance which might have acted only as confirming quiescence. There were people, expressive sound, projected light, still abroad, and after they had taken in for a moment, through everything, the great clear architectural street, they turned off in tacit union to the quarter of Strether's hotel.

``Of course,'' (Chad)
Chad here abruptly began,
``of course Mother's making things out with you about me has been natural--and of course also you've had a good deal to go upon. Still, you must have filled out.'' (Chad)

He (Chad) had stopped, leaving his (Chad) friend to wonder a little what point he (Chad) wished to make; and this it was that enabled Strether meanwhile to make one.

``Oh we've never pretended to go into detail. We weren't in the least bound to THAT. It was `filling out' enough to miss you as we did.'' (Chad)

But Chad rather oddly insisted, though under the high lamp at their corner, where they paused, he (Chad) had at first looked as if touched by Strether's allusion to the long sense, at home, of his (Strether) absence.

``What I mean is you must have imagined.'' (unknown)

``Imagined what?'' (unknown)

``Well--horrors.'' (Strether horrors)

It affected Strether: horrors were so little--superficially at least--in this robust and reasoning image. But he (Strether) was none the less there to be veracious.

``Yes, I dare say we HAVE imagined horrors. But where's the harm if we haven't been wrong?'' (Chad/Chad Newsome/Newsome)

Chad raised his (Chad) face to the lamp, and it was one of the moments at which he (Chad) had, in his (Chad) extraordinary way, most his (Chad) air of designedly showing himself. It was as if at these instants he (Chad) just presented himself, his (Chad) identity so rounded off, his (Chad) palpable presence and his (Chad) massive young manhood, as such a link in the chain as might practically amount to a kind of demonstration. It was as if--and how but anomalously?--he (Chad) couldn't after all help thinking sufficiently well of these things to let them go for what they were worth. What could there be in this for Strether but the hint of some self-respect, some sense of power, oddly perverted; something latent and beyond access, ominous and perhaps enviable? The intimation had the next thing, in a flash, taken on a name--a name on which our friend seized as he (friend) asked himself if he (friend) weren't perhaps really dealing with an irreducible young Pagan. This description--he (friend) quite jumped at it--had a sound that gratified his (friend) mental ear, so that of a sudden he (friend) had already adopted it. Pagan--yes, that was, wasn't it? what Chad WOULD logically be. It was what he (Chad) must be. It was what he (Chad) was. The idea was a clue and, instead of darkening the prospect, projected a certain clearness. Strether made out in this quick ray that a Pagan was perhaps, at the pass they had come to, the thing most wanted at Woollett. They'd be able to do with one--a good one; he (Strether)'d find an opening--yes; and Strether's imagination even now prefigured and accompanied the first appearance there of the rousing personage. He (Strether) had only the slight discomfort of feeling, as the young man turned away from the lamp, that his (man) thought had in the momentary silence possibly been guessed.

``Well, I've no doubt,'' (Chad)
said Chad,
``you've come near enough. The details, as you say, don't matter. It HAS been generally the case that I've let myself go. But I'm coming round--I'm not so bad now.'' (Chad)
With which they walked on again to Strether's hotel.

``Do you mean,'' (unknown)
the latter asked as they approached the door,
``that there isn't any woman with you now?'' (unknown)

``But pray what has that to do with it?'' (unknown)

``Why it's the whole question.'' (unknown)

``Of my going home?'' (Chad/Chad Newsome/Newsome)
Chad was clearly surprised.
``Oh not much! Do you think that when I want to go any one will have any power--'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

``To keep you'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
--Strether took him (Strether) straight up--``from carrying out your wish? Well, our idea has been that somebody has hitherto--or a good many persons perhaps--kept you pretty well from ``wanting.
'' That's what--if you're in anybody's hands--may again happen. You don't answer my question'' (he)
--he (Strether) kept it up;
``but if you aren't in anybody's hands so much the better. There's nothing then but what makes for your going.'' (he)

Chad turned this over.

``I don't answer your question?'' (He)
He (Chad) spoke quite without resenting it. ``Well, such questions have always a rather exaggerated side. One doesn't know quite what you mean by being in women's ``hands.
'' It's all so vague. One is when one isn't. One isn't when one is. And then one can't quite give people away.'' (He)
He (Chad) seemed kindly to explain.
``I've NEVER got stuck--so very hard; and, as against anything at any time really better, I don't think I've ever been afraid.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
There was something in it that held Strether to wonder, and this gave him (Strether) time to go on. He (Strether) broke out as with a more helpful thought.
``Don't you know how I like Paris itself?'' (friend)

The upshot was indeed to make our friend marvel. ``Oh if THAT

``S all that's the matter with you--!'' (unknown)
It was HE (friend) who almost showed resentment.

Chad's smile of a truth more than met it.

``But isn't that enough?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether hesitated, but it came out.

``Not enough for your mother!'' (Chad/Chad Newsome/Newsome)
Spoken, however, it sounded a trifle odd--the effect of which was that Chad broke into a laugh. Strether, at this, succumbed as well, though with extreme brevity.
``Permit us to have still our theory. But if you ARE so free and so strong you're inexcusable. I'll write in the morning,'' (he)
he (Strether) added with decision.
``I'll say I've got you.'' (Chad)

This appeared to open for Chad a new interest.

``How often do you write?'' (unknown)

``Oh perpetually.'' (unknown)

``And at great length?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether had become a little impatient.

``I hope it's not found too great.'' (unknown)

``Oh I'm sure not. And you hear as often?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Again Strether paused.

``As often as I deserve.'' (unknown)

``Mother writes,'' (Chad)
said Chad,
``a lovely letter.'' (Chad)

Strether, before the closed porte-cochere, fixed him (Chad) a moment.

``It's more, my boy, than YOU do! But our suppositions don't matter,'' (he)
he (Chad) added,
``if you're actually not entangled.'' (he)

Chad's pride seemed none the less a little touched.

``I never WAS that--let me insist. I always had my own way.'' (he)
With which he (Chad) pursued:
``And I have it at present.'' (he)

``Then what are you here for? What has kept you,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether asked,
``if you HAVE been able to leave?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

It made Chad, after a stare, throw himself back.

``Do you think one's kept only by women?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
His (Chad) surprise and his (Chad) verbal emphasis rang out so clear in the still street that Strether winced till he (Strether) remembered the safety of their English speech.
``Is that,'' (the man)
the young man demanded,
``what they think at Woollett?'' (the man)
At the good faith in the question Strether had changed colour, feeling that, as he (Strether) would have said, he (Strether) had put his (Strether) foot in it. He (Strether) had appeared stupidly to misrepresent what they thought at Woollett; but before he (Strether) had time to rectify Chad again was upon him (Chad).
``I must say then you show a low mind!'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

It so fell in, unhappily for Strether, with that reflexion of his (Strether) own prompted in him (Strether) by the pleasant air of the Boulevard Malesherbes, that its disconcerting force was rather unfairly great. It was a dig that, administered by himself--and administered even to poor Mrs. Newsome--was no more than salutary; but administered by Chad--and quite logically--it came nearer drawing blood. They HADn't a low mind--nor any approach to one; yet incontestably they had worked, and with a certain smugness, on a basis that might be turned against them. Chad had at any rate pulled his (Chad) visitor up; he (Chad) had even pulled up his (Chad) admirable mother; he (Chad) had absolutely, by a turn of the wrist and a jerk of the far-flung noose, pulled up, in a bunch, Woollett browsing in its pride. There was no doubt Woollett HAD insisted on his (Chad) coarseness; and what he (Chad) at present stood there for in the sleeping street was, by his (Chad) manner of striking the other note, to make of such insistence a preoccupation compromising to the insisters. It was exactly as if they had imputed to him (Chad) a vulgarity that he (Chad) had by a mere gesture caused to fall from him (Chad). The devil of the case was that Strether felt it, by the same stroke, as falling straight upon himself. He (Strether) had been wondering a minute ago if the boy weren't a Pagan, and he (boy) found himself wondering now if he (boy) weren't by chance a gentleman. It didn't in the least, on the spot, spring up helpfully for him (boy) that a person couldn't at the same time be both. There was nothing at this moment in the air to challenge the combination; there was everything to give it on the contrary something of a flourish. It struck Strether into the bargain as doing something to meet the most difficult of the questions; though perhaps indeed only by substituting another. Wouldn't it be precisely by having learned to be a gentleman that he (gentleman) had mastered the consequent trick of looking so well that one could scarce speak to him (gentleman) straight? But what in the world was the clue to such a prime producing cause? There were too many clues then that Strether still lacked, and these clues to clues were among them. What it accordingly amounted to for him (Strether) was that he (Strether) had to take full in the face a fresh attribution of ignorance. He (Strether) had grown used by this time to reminders, especially from his (Strether) own lips, of what he (Strether) didn't know; but he (Strether) had borne them because in the first place they were private and because in the second they practically conveyed a tribute. He (Strether) didn't know what was bad, and--as others didn't know how little he (Strether) knew it--he (Strether) could put up with his (Strether) state. But if he (Strether) didn't know, in so important a particular, what was good, Chad at least was now aware he (Chad) didn't; and that, for some reason, affected our friend as curiously public. It was in fact an exposed condition that the young man left him (man) in long enough for him (man) to feel its chill--till he (man) saw fit, in a word, generously again to cover him (man). This last was in truth what Chad quite gracefully did. But he (Chad) did it as with a simple thought that met the whole of the case.

``Oh I'm all right!'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
It was what Strether had rather bewilderedly to go to bed on.

II

It really looked true moreover from the way Chad was to behave after this. He (Chad) was full of attentions to his (Chad) mother's ambassador; in spite of which, all the while, the latter's other relations rather remarkably contrived to assert themselves. Strether's sittings pen in hand with Mrs. Newsome up in his (Strether) own room were broken, yet they were richer; and they were more than ever interspersed with the hours in which he (Strether) reported himself, in a different fashion, but with scarce less earnestness and fulness, to Maria Gostrey. Now that, as he (Strether) would have expressed it, he (Strether) had really something to talk about he (Strether) found himself, in respect to any oddity that might reside for him (Strether) in the double connexion, at once more aware and more indifferent. He (Strether) had been fine to Mrs. Newsome about his (Strether) useful friend, but it had begun to haunt his (Strether) imagination that Chad, taking up again for her (Newsome) benefit a pen too long disused, might possibly be finer. It wouldn't at all do, he (Strether) saw, that anything should come up for him (Strether) at Chad's hand but what specifically was to have come; the greatest divergence from which would be precisely the element of any lubrication of their intercourse by levity It was accordingly to forestall such an accident that he (Chad) frankly put before the young man the several facts, just as they had occurred, of his (man) funny alliance. He (man) spoke of these facts, pleasantly and obligingly, as

``the whole story,'' (He)
and felt that he (man) might qualify the alliance as funny if he (man) remained sufficiently grave about it. He (man) flattered himself that he (man) even exaggerated the wild freedom of his (man) original encounter with the wonderful lady; he (man) was scrupulously definite about the absurd conditions in which they had made acquaintance--their having picked each other up almost in the street; and he (man) had -LRB-finest inspiration of all!-RRB- a conception of carrying the war into the enemy's country by showing surprise at the enemy's ignorance.

He (man) had always had a notion that this last was the grand style of fighting; the greater therefore the reason for it, as he (man) couldn't remember that he (man) had ever before fought in the grand style. Every one, according to this, knew Miss Gostrey: how came it Chad didn't know her (man)? The difficulty, the impossibility, was really to escape it; Strether put on him (Strether), by what he (Strether) took for granted, the burden of proof of the contrary. This tone was so far successful as that Chad quite appeared to recognise her (man) as a person whose fame had reached him (Chad), but against his (Chad) acquaintance with whom much mischance had worked. He (Chad) made the point at the same time that his (Chad) social relations, such as they could be called, were perhaps not to the extent Strether supposed with the rising flood of their compatriots. He (Chad) hinted at his (Chad) having more and more given way to a different principle of selection; the moral of which seemed to be that he (Chad) went about little in the

``colony.'' (he)
For the moment certainly he (Chad) had quite another interest. It was deep, what he (Chad) understood, and Strether, for himself, could only so observe it. He (Strether) couldn't see as yet how deep. Might he (Strether) not all too soon! For there was really too much of their question that Chad had already committed himself to liking. He (Chad) liked, to begin with, his (Chad) prospective stepfather; which was distinctly what had not been on the cards. His (Chad) hating him (Chad) was the untowardness for which Strether had been best prepared; he (Strether) hadn't expected the boy's actual form to give him (Strether) more to do than his (Strether) imputed. It gave him (Strether) more through suggesting that he (Strether) must somehow make up to himself for not being sure he (Strether) was sufficiently disagreeable. That had really been present to him (Strether) as his (Strether) only way to be sure he (Strether) was sufficiently thorough. The point was that if Chad's tolerance of his (Chad) thoroughness were insincere, were but the best of devices for gaining time, it none the less did treat everything as tacitly concluded.

That seemed at the end of ten days the upshot of the abundant, the recurrent talk through which Strether poured into him (Strether) all it concerned him (Strether) to know, put him (Strether) in full possession of facts and figures. Never cutting these colloquies short by a minute, Chad behaved, looked and spoke as if he (Chad) were rather heavily, perhaps even a trifle gloomily, but none the less fundamentally and comfortably free. He (Chad) made no crude profession of eagerness to yield, but he (Chad) asked the most intelligent questions, probed, at moments, abruptly, even deeper than his (Chad) friend's layer of information, justified by these touches the native estimate of his (Chad) latent stuff, and had in every way the air of trying to live, reflectively, into the square bright picture. He (Chad) walked up and down in front of this production, sociably took Strether's arm at the points at which he (Strether) stopped, surveyed it repeatedly from the right and from the left, inclined a critical head to either quarter, and, while he (Strether) puffed a still more critical cigarette, animadverted to his (Strether) companion on this passage and that. Strether sought relief--there were hours when he (Strether) required it--in repeating himself; it was in truth not to be blinked that Chad had a way. The main question as yet was of what it was a way TO. It made vulgar questions no more easy; but that was unimportant when all questions save those of his (Chad) own asking had dropped. That he (Chad) was free was answer enough, and it wasn't quite ridiculous that this freedom should end by presenting itself as what was difficult to move. His (Chad) changed state, his (Chad) lovely home, his (Chad) beautiful things, his (Chad) easy talk, his (Chad) very appetite for Strether, insatiable and, when all was said, flattering--what were such marked matters all but the notes of his (Strether) freedom? He (Strether) had the effect of making a sacrifice of it just in these handsome forms to his (Strether) visitor; which was mainly the reason the visitor was privately, for the time, a little out of countenance. Strether was at this period again and again thrown back on a felt need to remodel somehow his (Strether) plan. He (Strether) fairly caught himself shooting rueful glances, shy looks of pursuit, toward the embodied influence, the definite adversary, who had by a stroke of her (himself) own failed him (adversary) and on a fond theory of whose palpable presence he (adversary) had, under Mrs. Newsome's inspiration, altogether proceeded. He (adversary) had once or twice, in secret, literally expressed the irritated wish that SHE would come out and find her (Newsome).

He (adversary) couldn't quite yet force it upon Woollett that such a career, such a perverted young life, showed after all a certain plausible side, DID in the case before them flaunt something like an impunity for the social man; but he (man) could at least treat himself to the statement that would prepare him (man) for the sharpest echo. This echo--as distinct over there in the dry thin air as some shrill

``heading'' (him)
above a column of print--seemed to reach him (man) even as he (man) wrote.
``He (I) says there's no woman,'' (he)
he (man) could hear Mrs. Newsome report, in capitals almost of newspaper size, to Mrs. Pocock; and he (man) could focus in Mrs. Pocock the response of the reader of the journal. He (man) could see in the younger lady's face the earnestness of her (lady) attention and catch the full scepticism of her (lady) but slightly delayed
``What is there then?'' (the lady)
Just so he (man) could again as little miss the mother's clear decision:
``There's plenty of disposition, no doubt, to pretend there isn't.'' (the mother)
Strether had, after posting his (Strether) letter, the whole scene out; and it was a scene during which, coming and going, as befell, he (Strether) kept his (Strether) eye not least upon the daughter. He (Strether) had his (Strether) fine sense of the conviction Mrs. Pocock would take occasion to reaffirm--a conviction bearing, as he (Strether) had from the first deeply divined it to bear, on Mr. Strether's essential inaptitude. She (Pocock) had looked him (Strether) in his (Strether) conscious eyes even before he (Strether) sailed, and that she (Pocock) didn't believe HE (Strether) would find the woman had been written in her (woman) book. Hadn't she (woman) at the best but a scant faith in his (Strether) ability to find women? It wasn't even as if he (Strether) had found her (woman) mother--so much more, to her (woman) discrimination, had her (woman) mother performed the finding. Her (woman) mother had, in a case her (woman) private judgement of which remained educative of Mrs. Pocock's critical sense, found the man. The man owed his (man) unchallenged state, in general, to the fact that Mrs. Newsome's discoveries were accepted at Woollett; but he (man) knew in his (man) bones, our friend did, how almost irresistibly Mrs. Pocock would now be moved to show what she (Pocock) thought of his (man) own. Give HER a free hand, would be the moral, and the woman would soon be found.

His (man) impression of Miss Gostrey after her (Gostrey) introduction to Chad was meanwhile an impression of a person almost unnaturally on her (Gostrey) guard. He (guard) struck himself as at first unable to extract from her (Gostrey) what he (guard) wished; though indeed OF what he (guard) wished at this special juncture he (guard) would doubtless have contrived to make but a crude statement. It sifted and settled nothing to put to her (Gostrey), tout betement, as she (Gostrey) often said,

``Do you like him (I), eh?'' (she)
--thanks to his (guard) feeling it actually the least of his (guard) needs to heap up the evidence in the young man's favour. He (guard) repeatedly knocked at her (Gostrey) door to let her (Gostrey) have it afresh that Chad's case--whatever else of minor interest it might yield--was first and foremost a miracle almost monstrous. It was the alteration of the entire man, and was so signal an instance that nothing else, for the intelligent observer, could--COULD it?--signify.
``It's a plot,'' (he)
he (man) declared--
``there's more in it than meets the eye.'' (he)
He (man) gave the rein to his (man) fancy.
``It's a plant!'' (her)

His (man) fancy seemed to please her (Gostrey).

``Whose then?'' (unknown)

``Well, the party responsible is, I suppose, the fate that waits for one, the dark doom that rides. What I mean is that with such elements one can't count. I've but my poor individual, my modest human means. It isn't playing the game to turn on the uncanny. All one's energy goes to facing it, to tracking it. One wants, confound it, don't you see?'' (he)
he (man) confessed with a queer face--
``one wants to enjoy anything so rare. Call it then life'' (queer)
--he (man) puzzled it out--
``call it poor dear old life simply that springs the surprise. Nothing alters the fact that the surprise is paralysing, or at any rate engrossing--all, practically, hang it, that one sees, that one CAN see.'' (he)

Her (Gostrey) silences were never barren, nor even dull.

``Is that what you've written home?'' (He)

He (man) tossed it off.

``Oh dear, yes!'' (She)

She (Gostrey) had another pause while, across her (Gostrey) carpets, he (man) had another walk.

``If you don't look out you'll have them straight over.'' (unknown)

``Oh but I've said he (you)'ll go back.'' (unknown)

``And WILL he (you)?'' (Miss Gostrey)
Miss Gostrey asked.

The special tone of it made him (man), pulling up, look at her (Gostrey) long.

``What's that but just the question I've spent treasures of patience and ingenuity in giving you, by the sight of him (you)--after everything had led up--every facility to answer? What is it but just the thing I came here to-day to get out of you? Will he (you)?'' (unknown)

``No--he (you) won't,'' (she)
she (Gostrey) said at last.
``He (you)'s not free.'' (him)

The air of it held him (man).

``Then you've all the while known--?'' (unknown)

``I've known nothing but what I've seen; and I wonder,'' (she)
