she (Gostrey) declared with some impatience,
``that you didn't see as much. It was enough to be with him (you) there--'' (she)

``In the box? Yes,'' (he)
he (man) rather blankly urged.

``Well--to feel sure.'' (unknown)

``Sure of what?'' (She)

She (Gostrey) got up from her (Gostrey) chair, at this, with a nearer approach than she (Gostrey) had ever yet shown to dismay at his (man) dimness. She (Gostrey) even, fairly pausing for it, spoke with a shade of pity.

``Guess!'' (unknown)

It was a shade, fairly, that brought a flush into his (man) face; so that for a moment, as they waited together, their difference was between them.

``You mean that just your hour with him (you) told you so much of his (you) story? Very good; I'm not such a fool, on my side, as that I don't understand you, or as that I didn't in some degree understand HIM. That he (you) has done what he (you) liked most isn't, among any of us, a matter the least in dispute. There's equally little question at this time of day of what it is he (you) does like most. But I'm not talking,'' (he)
he (man) reasonably explained,
``of any mere wretch he (you) may still pick up. I'm talking of some person who in his (you) present situation may have held her (you) own, may really have counted.'' (he)

``That's exactly what I am!'' (unknown)
said Miss Gostrey. But she (Gostrey) as quickly made her (Gostrey) point.
``I thought you thought--or that they think at Woollett--that that's what mere wretches necessarily do. Mere wretches necessarily DON'T!'' (she)
she (Gostrey) declared with spirit.
``There must, behind every appearance to the contrary, still be somebody--somebody who's not a mere wretch, since we accept the miracle. What else but such a somebody can such a miracle be?'' (He)

He (man) took it in.

``Because the fact itself IS the woman?'' (unknown)

``A woman. Some woman or other. It's one of the things that HAVE to be.'' (unknown)

``But you mean then at least a good one.'' (unknown)

``A good woman?'' (She)
She (Gostrey) threw up her (Gostrey) arms with a laugh.
``I should call her (woman) excellent!'' (unknown)

``Then why does he (somebody) deny her (woman)?'' (Miss Gostrey)

Miss Gostrey thought a moment.

``Because she (woman)'s too good to admit! Don't you see,'' (she)
she (Gostrey) went on,
``how she (woman) accounts for him (somebody)?'' (she)

Strether clearly, more and more, did see; yet it made him (Strether) also see other things.

``But isn't what we want that he (somebody) shall account for HER?'' (unknown)

``Well, he (somebody) does. What you have before you is his (somebody) way. You must forgive him (somebody) if it isn't quite outspoken. In Paris such debts are tacit.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether could imagine; but still--!

``Even when the woman's good?'' (she)

Again she (Gostrey) laughed out.

``Yes, and even when the man is! There's always a caution in such cases,'' (she)
she (Gostrey) more seriously explained--
``for what it may seem to show. There's nothing that's taken as showing so much here as sudden unnatural goodness.'' (she)

``Ah then you're speaking now,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether said,
``of people who are NOT nice.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

``I delight,'' (she)
she (Gostrey) replied,
``in your classifications. But do you want me,'' (she)
she (Gostrey) asked,
``to give you in the matter, on this ground, the wisest advice I'm capable of? Don't consider her (I), don't judge her (I) at all in herself. Consider her (I) and judge her (I) only in Chad.'' (she)

He (Strether) had the courage at least of his (Strether) companion's logic.

``Because then I shall like her (I)?'' (He)
He (Strether) almost looked, with his (Strether) quick imagination as if he (Strether) already did, though seeing at once also the full extent of how little it would suit his (Strether) book.
``But is that what I came out for?'' (She)

She (Gostrey) had to confess indeed that it wasn't. But there was something else.

``Don't make up your mind. There are all sorts of things. You haven't seen him (Chad) all.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

This on his (Strether) side Strether recognised; but his (Strether) acuteness none the less showed him (Strether) the danger.

``Yes, but if the more I see the better he (Chad) seems?'' (she)

Well, she (Gostrey) found something.

``That may be--but his (Chad) disavowal of her (I) isn't, all the same, pure consideration. There's a hitch.'' (She)
She (Gostrey) made it out.
``It's the effort to sink her (I).'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether winced at the image.

``To `sink'--?'' (unknown)

``Well, I mean there's a struggle, and a part of it is just what he (Chad) hides. Take time--that's the only way not to make some mistake that you'll regret. Then you'll see. He (Chad) does really want to shake her (I) off.'' (friend)

Our friend had by this time so got into the vision that he (Strether) almost gasped.

``After all she (I) has done for him (Chad)?'' (Miss Gostrey)

Miss Gostrey gave him (Strether) a look which broke the next moment into a wonderful smile.

``He (Chad)'s not so good as you think!'' (him)

They remained with him (Strether), these words, promising him (Strether), in their character of warning, considerable help; but the support he (Strether) tried to draw from them found itself on each renewal of contact with Chad defeated by something else. What could it be, this disconcerting force, he (Chad) asked himself, but the sense, constantly renewed, that Chad WAS--quite in fact insisted on being--as good as he (Chad) thought? It seemed somehow as if he (Chad) couldn't BUT be as good from the moment he (Chad) wasn't as bad. There was a succession of days at all events when contact with him (Chad)--and in its immediate effect, as if it could produce no other--elbowed out of Strether's consciousness everything but itself. Little Bilham once more pervaded the scene, but little Bilham became even in a higher degree than he (Bilham) had originally been one of the numerous forms of the inclusive relation; a consequence promoted, to our friend's sense, by two or three incidents with which we have yet to make acquaintance. Waymarsh himself, for the occasion, was drawn into the eddy; it absolutely, though but temporarily, swallowed him (acquaintance) down, and there were days when Strether seemed to bump against him (Strether) as a sinking swimmer might brush a submarine object. The fathomless medium held them--Chad's manner was the fathomless medium; and our friend felt as if they passed each other, in their deep immersion, with the round impersonal eye of silent fish. It was practically produced between them that Waymarsh was giving him (friend) then his (friend) chance; and the shade of discomfort that Strether drew from the allowance resembled not a little the embarrassment he (Strether) had known at school, as a boy, when members of his (Strether) family had been present at exhibitions. He (Strether) could perform before strangers, but relatives were fatal, and it was now as if, comparatively, Waymarsh were a relative. He (Strether) seemed to hear him (Strether) say

``Strike up then!'' (him)
and to enjoy a foretaste of conscientious domestic criticism. He (Strether) HAD struck up, so far as he (Strether) actually could; Chad knew by this time in profusion what he (Chad) wanted; and what vulgar violence did his (Chad) fellow pilgrim expect of him (Chad) when he (Chad) had really emptied his (Chad) mind? It went somehow to and fro that what poor Waymarsh meant was
``I told you so--that you'd lose your immortal soul!'' (Waymarsh/Mrs. Waymarsh)
but it was also fairly explicit that Strether had his (Strether) own challenge and that, since they must go to the bottom of things, he (Strether) wasted no more virtue in watching Chad than Chad wasted in watching him (Chad). His (Chad) dip for duty's sake--where was it worse than Waymarsh's own? For HE (Chad) needn't have stopped resisting and refusing, needn't have parleyed, at that rate, with the foe.

The strolls over Paris to see something or call somewhere were accordingly inevitable and natural, and the late sessions in the wondrous troisieme, the lovely home, when men dropped in and the picture composed more suggestively through the haze of tobacco, of music more or less good and of talk more or less polyglot, were on a principle not to be distinguished from that of the mornings and the afternoons. Nothing, Strether had to recognise as he (Strether) leaned back and smoked, could well less resemble a scene of violence than even the liveliest of these occasions. They were occasions of discussion, none the less, and Strether had never in his (Strether) life heard so many opinions on so many subjects. There were opinions at Woollett, but only on three or four. The differences were there to match; if they were doubtless deep, though few, they were quiet--they were, as might be said, almost as shy as if people had been ashamed of them. People showed little diffidence about such things, on the other hand, in the Boulevard Malesherbes, and were so far from being ashamed of them--or indeed of anything else--that they often seemed to have invented them to avert those agreements that destroy the taste of talk. No one had ever done that at Woollett, though Strether could remember times when he (Strether) himself had been tempted to it without quite knowing why. He (Strether) saw why at present--he (Strether) had but wanted to promote intercourse.

These, however, were but parenthetic memories, and the turn taken by his (Strether) affair on the whole was positively that if his (Strether) nerves were on the stretch it was because he (Strether) missed violence. When he (Strether) asked himself if none would then, in connexion with it, ever come at all, he (Strether) might almost have passed as wondering how to provoke it. It would be too absurd if such a vision as THAT should have to be invoked for relief; it was already marked enough as absurd that he (Strether) should actually have begun with flutters and dignities on the score of a single accepted meal. What sort of a brute had he (Strether) expected Chad to be, anyway?--Strether had occasion to make the enquiry but was careful to make it in private. He (Strether) could himself, comparatively recent as it was--it was truly but the fact of a few days since--focus his (Strether) primal crudity; but he (Strether) would on the approach of an observer, as if handling an illicit possession, have slipped the reminiscence out of sight. There were echoes of it still in Mrs. Newsome's letters, and there were moments when these echoes made him (Strether) exclaim on her (Newsome) want of tact. He (Strether) blushed of course, at once, still more for the explanation than for the ground of it: it came to him (Strether) in time to save his (Strether) manners that she (Newsome) couldn't at the best become tactful as quickly as he (Strether). Her (Newsome) tact had to reckon with the Atlantic Ocean, the General Post-Office and the extravagant curve of the globe. Chad had one day offered tea at the Boulevard Malesherbes to a chosen few, a group again including the unobscured Miss Barrace; and Strether had on coming out walked away with the acquaintance whom in his (Strether) letters to Mrs. Newsome he (Strether) always spoke of as the little artist-man. He (Strether) had had full occasion to mention him (Strether) as the other party, so oddly, to the only close personal alliance observation had as yet detected in Chad's existence. Little Bilham's way this afternoon was not Strether's, but he (Strether) had none the less kindly come with him (Strether), and it was somehow a part of his (Strether) kindness that as it had sadly begun to rain they suddenly found themselves seated for conversation at a cafe in which they had taken refuge. He (Strether) had passed no more crowded hour in Chad's society than the one just ended; he (Chad) had talked with Miss Barrace, who had reproached him (Chad) with not having come to see her (Barrace), and he (Chad) had above all hit on a happy thought for causing Waymarsh's tension to relax. Something might possibly be extracted for the latter from the idea of his (Chad) success with that lady, whose quick apprehension of what might amuse her (lady) had given Strether a free hand. What had she (lady) meant if not to ask whether she (lady) couldn't help him (Strether) with his (Strether) splendid encumbrance, and mightn't the sacred rage at any rate be kept a little in abeyance by thus creating for his (Strether) comrade's mind even in a world of irrelevance the possibility of a relation? What was it but a relation to be regarded as so decorative and, in especial, on the strength of it, to be whirled away, amid flounces and feathers, in a coupe lined, by what Strether could make out, with dark blue brocade? He (Strether) himself had never been whirled away--never at least in a coupe and behind a footman; he (footman) had driven with Miss Gostrey in cabs, with Mrs. Pocock, a few times, in an open buggy, with Mrs. Newsome in a four-seated cart and, occasionally up at the mountains, on a buckboard; but his (footman) friend's actual adventure transcended his (footman) personal experience. He (footman) now showed his (footman) companion soon enough indeed how inadequate, as a general monitor, this last queer quantity could once more feel itself.

``What game under the sun is he (Chad) playing?'' (He)
He (footman) signified the next moment that his (footman) allusion was not to the fat gentleman immersed in dominoes on whom his (footman) eyes had begun by resting, but to their host of the previous hour, as to whom, there on the velvet bench, with a final collapse of all consistency, he (footman) treated himself to the comfort of indiscretion.
``Where do you see him (Chad) come out?'' (Little Bilham/Bilham)

Little Bilham, in meditation, looked at him (footman) with a kindness almost paternal.

``Don't you like it over here?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether laughed out--for the tone was indeed droll; he (Strether) let himself go.

``What has that to do with it? The only thing I've any business to like is to feel that I'm moving him (Chad). That's why I ask you whether you believe I AM? Is the creature'' (he)
--and he (Strether) did his (Strether) best to show that he (Strether) simply wished to ascertain--
``honest?'' (he)

His (Strether) companion looked responsible, but looked it through a small dim smile.

``What creature do you mean?'' (unknown)

It was on this that they did have for a little a mute interchange.

``Is it untrue that he (Chad)'s free? How then,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether asked wondering
``does he (Chad) arrange his (Chad) life?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

``Is the creature you mean Chad himself?'' (Bilham/Mr. Bilham)
little Bilham said.

Strether here, with a rising hope, just thought,

``We must take one of them at a time.'' (Strether)
But his (Bilham) coherence lapsed.
``IS there some woman? Of whom he (Chad)'s really afraid of course I mean--or who does with him (Chad) what she (woman) likes.'' (unknown)

``It's awfully charming of you,'' (Bilham/Mr. Bilham)
Bilham presently remarked,
``not to have asked me that before.'' (Bilham/Mr. Bilham)

``Oh I'm not fit for my job!'' (friend)

The exclamation had escaped our friend, but it made little Bilham more deliberate.

``Chad's a rare case!'' (he)
he (Bilham) luminously observed.
``He (Chad)'s awfully changed,'' (he)
he (Bilham) added.

``Then you see it too?'' (unknown)

``The way he (Chad) has improved? Oh yes--I think every one must see it. But I'm not sure,'' (Bilham/Mr. Bilham)
said little Bilham,
``that I didn't like him (Chad) about as well in his (Chad) other state.'' (Bilham/Mr. Bilham)

``Then this IS really a new state altogether?'' (unknown)

``Well,'' (the man)
the young man after a moment returned,
``I'm not sure he (Chad) was really meant by nature to be quite so good. It's like the new edition of an old book that one has been fond of--revised and amended, brought up to date, but not quite the thing one knew and loved. However that may be at all events,'' (the man)
he (Bilham) pursued,
``I don't think, you know, that he (Chad)'s really playing, as you call it, any game. I believe he (Chad) really wants to go back and take up a career. He (Chad)'s capable of one, you know, that will improve and enlarge him (Chad) still more. He (Chad) won't then,'' (he)
little Bilham continued to remark,
``be my pleasant well-rubbed old-fashioned volume at all. But of course I'm beastly immoral. I'm afraid it would be a funny world altogether--a world with things the way I like them. I ought, I dare say, to go home and go into business myself. Only I'd simply rather die--simply. And I've not the least difficulty in making up my mind not to, and in knowing exactly why, and in defending my ground against all comers. All the same,'' (Bilham/Mr. Bilham)
he (Bilham) wound up,
``I assure you I don't say a word against it--for himself, I mean--to Chad. I seem to see it as much the best thing for him (Chad). You see he (Chad)'s not happy.'' (he)

``DO I?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
--Strether stared.
``I've been supposing I see just the opposite--an extraordinary case of the equilibrium arrived at and assured.'' (unknown)

``Oh there's a lot behind it.'' (unknown)

``Ah there you are!'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether exclaimed.
``That's just what I want to get at. You speak of your familiar volume altered out of recognition. Well, who's the editor?'' (Bilham/Mr. Bilham)

Little Bilham looked before him (Bilham) a minute in silence.

``He (editor) ought to get married. THAT would do it. And he (editor) wants to.'' (unknown)

``Wants to marry her (your)?'' (Bilham/Mr. Bilham)

Again little Bilham waited, and, with a sense that he (Bilham) had information, Strether scarce knew what was coming.

``He (editor) wants to be free. He (editor) isn't used, you see,'' (the man)
the young man explained in his (man) lucid way,
``to being so good.'' (the man)

Strether hesitated.

``Then I may take it from you that he (editor) IS good?'' (companion)

His (Strether) companion matched his (Strether) pause, but making it up with a quiet fulness.

``DO take it from me.'' (unknown)

``Well then why isn't he (editor) free? He (editor) swears to me he (editor) is, but meanwhile does nothing--except of course that he (editor)'s so kind to me--to prove it; and couldn't really act much otherwise if he (editor) weren't. My question to you just now was exactly on this queer impression of his (editor) diplomacy: as if instead of really giving ground his (editor) line were to keep me on here and set me a bad example.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

As the half-hour meanwhile had ebbed Strether paid his (Strether) score, and the waiter was presently in the act of counting out change. Our friend pushed back to him (friend) a fraction of it, with which, after an emphatic recognition, the personage in question retreated.

``You give too much,'' (Bilham/Mr. Bilham)
little Bilham permitted himself benevolently to observe.

``Oh I always give too much!'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether helplessly sighed.
``But you don't,'' (he)
he (Strether) went on as if to get quickly away from the contemplation of that doom,
``answer my question. Why isn't he (editor) free?'' (he)

Little Bilham had got up as if the transaction with the waiter had been a signal, and had already edged out between the table and the divan. The effect of this was that a minute later they had quitted the place, the gratified waiter alert again at the open door. Strether had found himself deferring to his (Strether) companion's abruptness as to a hint that he (Strether) should be answered as soon as they were more isolated. This happened when after a few steps in the outer air they had turned the next comer. There our friend had kept it up.

``Why isn't he (editor) free if he (editor)'s good?'' (Bilham/Mr. Bilham)

Little Bilham looked him (Bilham) full in the face.

``Because it's a virtuous attachment.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

This had settled the question so effectually for the time--that is for the next few days--that it had given Strether almost a new lease of life. It must be added however that, thanks to his (Strether) constant habit of shaking the bottle in which life handed him (Strether) the wine of experience, he (Strether) presently found the taste of the lees rising as usual into his (Strether) draught. His (Strether) imagination had in other words already dealt with his (Strether) young friend's assertion; of which it had made something that sufficiently came out on the very next occasion of his (Strether) seeing Maria Gostrey. This occasion moreover had been determined promptly by a new circumstance--a circumstance he (Strether) was the last man to leave her (Gostrey) for a day in ignorance of.

``When I said to him (editor) last night,'' (he)
he (Strether) immediately began,
``that without some definite word from him (editor) now that will enable me to speak to them over there of our sailing--or at least of mine, giving them some sort of date--my responsibility becomes uncomfortable and my situation awkward; when I said that to him (editor) what do you think was his (editor) reply?'' (he)
And then as she (Gostrey) this time gave it up:
``Why that he (editor) has two particular friends, two ladies, mother and daughter, about to arrive in Paris--coming back from an absence; and that he (editor) wants me so furiously to meet them, know them and like them, that I shall oblige him (editor) by kindly not bringing our business to a crisis till he (editor) has had a chance to see them again himself. Is that,'' (she)
Strether enquired,
``the way he (editor)'s going to try to get off? These are the people,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
he (Strether) explained,
``that he (editor) must have gone down to see before I arrived. They're the best friends he (editor) has in the world, and they take more interest than any one else in what concerns him (editor). As I'm his (editor) next best he (editor) sees a thousand reasons why we should comfortably meet. He (editor) hasn't broached the question sooner because their return was uncertain--seemed in fact for the present impossible. But he (editor) more than intimates that--if you can believe it--their desire to make my acquaintance has had to do with their surmounting difficulties.'' (he)

``They're dying to see you?'' (Miss Gostrey)
Miss Gostrey asked.

``Dying. Of course,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
said Strether,
``they're the virtuous attachment.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
He (Strether) had already told her (Gostrey) about that--had seen her (Gostrey) the day after his (Strether) talk with little Bilham; and they had then threshed out together the bearing of the revelation. She (Gostrey) had helped him (Strether) to put into it the logic in which little Bilham had left it slightly deficient Strether hadn't pressed him (Strether) as to the object of the preference so unexpectedly described; feeling in the presence of it, with one of his (Strether) irrepressible scruples, a delicacy from which he (Strether) had in the quest of the quite other article worked himself sufficiently free. He (Strether) had held off, as on a small principle of pride, from permitting his (Strether) young friend to mention a name; wishing to make with this the great point that Chad's virtuous attachments were none of his (Chad) business. He (Chad) had wanted from the first not to think too much of his (Chad) dignity, but that was no reason for not allowing it any little benefit that might turn up. He (Chad) had often enough wondered to what degree his (Chad) interference might pass for interested; so that there was no want of luxury in letting it be seen whenever he (Chad) could that he (Chad) didn't interfere. That had of course at the same time not deprived him (Chad) of the further luxury of much private astonishment; which however he (Chad) had reduced to some order before communicating his (Chad) knowledge. When he (Chad) had done this at last it was with the remark that, surprised as Miss Gostrey might, like himself, at first be, she (Gostrey) would probably agree with him (Chad) on reflexion that such an account of the matter did after all fit the confirmed appearances. Nothing certainly, on all the indications, could have been a greater change for him (Chad) than a virtuous attachment, and since they had been in search of the
``word'' (him)
as the French called it, of that change, little Bilham's announcement--though so long and so oddly delayed--would serve as well as another. She (Gostrey) had assured Strether in fact after a pause that the more she (Gostrey) thought of it the more it did serve; and yet her (Gostrey) assurance hadn't so weighed with him (Strether) as that before they parted he (Strether) hadn't ventured to challenge her (Gostrey) sincerity. Didn't she (Gostrey) believe the attachment was virtuous?--he (Strether) had made sure of her (Gostrey) again with the aid of that question. The tidings he (Strether) brought her (Gostrey) on this second occasion were moreover such as would help him (Strether) to make surer still.

She (Gostrey) showed at first none the less as only amused.

``You say there are two? An attachment to them both then would, I suppose, almost necessarily be innocent.'' (friend)

Our friend took the point, but he (friend) had his (friend) clue.

``Mayn't he (acquaintance) be still in the stage of not quite knowing which of them, mother or daughter, he (acquaintance) likes best?'' (She)

She (Gostrey) gave it more thought.

``Oh it must be the daughter--at his (acquaintance) age.'' (unknown)

``Possibly. Yet what do we know,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether asked,
``about hers? She (daughter) may be old enough.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

``Old enough for what?'' (unknown)

``Why to marry Chad. That may be, you know, what they want. And if Chad wants it too, and little Bilham wants it, and even we, at a pinch, could do with it--that is if she (daughter) doesn't prevent repatriation--why it may be plain sailing yet.'' (him)

It was always the case for him (Strether) in these counsels that each of his (Strether) remarks, as it came, seemed to drop into a deeper well. He (Strether) had at all events to wait a moment to hear the slight splash of this one.

``I don't see why if Mr. Newsome wants to marry the young lady he (Newsome) hasn't already done it or hasn't been prepared with some statement to you about it. And if he (Newsome) both wants to marry her (lady) and is on good terms with them why isn't he (Newsome) `free'?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether, responsively, wondered indeed.

``Perhaps the girl herself doesn't like him (Newsome).'' (unknown)

``Then why does he (Newsome) speak of them to you as he (Newsome) does?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether's mind echoed the question, but also again met it.

``Perhaps it's with the mother he (Newsome)'s on good terms.'' (unknown)

``As against the daughter?'' (unknown)

``Well, if she (daughter)'s trying to persuade the daughter to consent to him (Newsome), what could make him (Newsome) like the mother more? Only,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether threw out,
``why shouldn't the daughter consent to him (Newsome)?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

``Oh,'' (Miss Gostrey)
said Miss Gostrey,
``mayn't it be that every one else isn't quite so struck with him (Newsome) as you?'' (Miss Gostrey)

``Doesn't regard him (Newsome) you mean as such an `eligible' young man? Is that what I've come to?'' (he)
he (Strether) audibly and rather gravely sought to know.
``However,'' (he)
he (Strether) went on,
``his (man) marriage is what his (man) mother most desires--that is if it will help. And oughtn't ANY marriage to help? They must want him (man)'' (he)
--he (Strether) had already worked it out--
``to be better off. Almost any girl he (man) may marry will have a direct interest in his (man) taking up his (man) chances. It won't suit HER at least that he (man) shall miss them.'' (he)

Miss Gostrey cast about.

``No--you reason well! But of course on the other hand there's always dear old Woollett itself.'' (unknown)

``Oh yes,'' (he)
he (Strether) mused--
``there's always dear old Woollett itself.'' (he)

She (Gostrey) waited a moment.

``The young lady mayn't find herself able to swallow THAT quantity. She (lady) may think it's paying too much; she (lady) may weigh one thing against another.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether, ever restless in such debates, took a vague turn

``It will all depend on who she (lady) is. That of course--the proved ability to deal with dear old Woollett, since I'm sure she (lady) does deal with it--is what makes so strongly for Mamie.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

``Mamie?'' (He)

He (Strether) stopped short, at her (Gostrey) tone, before her (Gostrey); then, though seeing that it represented not vagueness, but a momentary embarrassed fulness, let his (Strether) exclamation come.

``You surely haven't forgotten about Mamie!'' (unknown)

``No, I haven't forgotten about Mamie,'' (she)
she (Gostrey) smiled.
``There's no doubt whatever that there's ever so much to be said for her (Mamie). Mamie's MY girl!'' (she)
she (Gostrey) roundly declared.

Strether resumed for a minute his (Strether) walk.

``She (Mamie)'s really perfectly lovely, you know. Far prettier than any girl I've seen over here yet.'' (unknown)

``That's precisely on what I perhaps most build.'' (she)
And she (Gostrey) mused a moment in her (Gostrey) friend's way.
``I should positively like to take her (girl) in hand!'' (He)

He (Strether) humoured the fancy, though indeed finally to deprecate it.

``Oh but don't, in your zeal, go over to her (girl)! I need you most and can't, you know, be left.'' (she)

But she (Gostrey) kept it up.

``I wish they'd send her (girl) out to me!'' (unknown)

``If they knew you,'' (he)
he (Strether) returned,
``they would.'' (he)

``Ah but don't they?--after all that, as I've understood you you've told them about me?'' (He)

He (Strether) had paused before her (Gostrey) again, but he (Strether) continued his (Strether) course

``They WILL--before, as you say, I've done.'' (he)
Then he (Strether) came out with the point he (Strether) had wished after all most to make.
``It seems to give away now his (girl) game. This is what he (girl) has been doing--keeping me along for. He (girl) has been waiting for them.'' (Miss Gostrey)

Miss Gostrey drew in her (Gostrey) lips.

``You see a good deal in it!'' (unknown)

``I doubt if I see as much as you. Do you pretend,'' (he)
he (Strether) went on,
``that you don't see--?'' (he)

``Well, what?'' (she)
--she (Gostrey) pressed him (Strether) as he (Strether) paused.

``Why that there must be a lot between them--and that it has been going on from the first; even from before I came.'' (She)

She (Gostrey) took a minute to answer.

``Who are they then--if it's so grave?'' (unknown)

``It mayn't be grave--it may be gay. But at any rate it's marked. Only I don't know,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether had to confess,
``anything about them. Their name for instance was a thing that, after little Bilham's information, I found it a kind of refreshment not to feel obliged to follow up.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

``Oh,'' (she)
she (Gostrey) returned,
``if you think you've got off--!'' (she)

Her (Gostrey) laugh produced in him (Strether) a momentary gloom.

``I don't think I've got off. I only think I'm breathing for about five minutes. I dare say I SHALL have, at the best, still to get on.'' (he)
A look, over it all, passed between them, and the next minute he (Strether) had come back to good humour.
``I don't meanwhile take the smallest interest in their name.'' (unknown)

``Nor in their nationality?--American, French, English, Polish?'' (unknown)

``I don't care the least little `hang,''' (he)
he (Strether) smiled,
``for their nationality. It would be nice if they're Polish!'' (he)
he (Strether) almost immediately added.

``Very nice indeed.'' (spirits)
The transition kept up her (Gostrey) spirits.
``So you see you do care.'' (He)

He (Strether) did this contention a modified justice.

``I think I should if they WERE Polish. Yes,'' (he)
he (Strether) thought--
``there might be joy in THAT.'' (he)

``Let us then hope for it.'' (she)
But she (Gostrey) came after this nearer to the question. ``If the girl's of the right age of course the mother can't be. I mean for the virtuous attachment. If the girl's twenty--and she (girl) can't be less--the mother must be at least forty. So it puts the mother out. SHE
``S too old for him (mother).'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether, arrested again, considered and demurred. ``Do you think so? Do you think any one would be too old for him (mother)? I``M eighty, and I'm too young. But perhaps the girl,'' he (Strether) continued,

``ISn't twenty. Perhaps she (girl)'s only ten--but such a little dear that Chad finds himself counting her (girl) in as an attraction of the acquaintance. Perhaps she (girl)'s only five. Perhaps the mother's but five-and-twenty--a charming young widow.'' (the girl)

Miss Gostrey entertained the suggestion.

``She (widow) IS a widow then?'' (unknown)

``I haven't the least idea!'' (unknown)
They once more, in spite of this vagueness, exchanged a look--a look that was perhaps the longest yet. It seemed in fact, the next thing, to require to explain itself; which it did as it could.
``I only feel what I've told you--that he (Chad) has some reason.'' (unknown)

Miss Gostrey's imagination had taken its own flight.

``Perhaps she (widow)'s NOT a widow.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether seemed to accept the possibility with reserve. Still he (Strether) accepted it.

``Then that's why the attachment--if it's to her (widow)--is virtuous.'' (she)

But she (Gostrey) looked as if she (Gostrey) scarce followed.

``Why is it virtuous if--since she (widow)'s free--there's nothing to impose on it any condition?'' (He)

He (Strether) laughed at her (Gostrey) question.

``Oh I perhaps don't mean as virtuous as THAT! Your idea is that it can be virtuous--in any sense worthy of the name--only if she (widow)'s NOT free? But what does it become then,'' (he)
he (Strether) asked,
``for HER?'' (he)

``Ah that's another matter.'' (He)
He (Strether) said nothing for a moment, and she (Gostrey) soon went on.
``I dare say you're right, at any rate, about Mr. Newsome's little plan. He (Newsome) HAS been trying you--has been reporting on you to these friends.'' (Strether)

Strether meanwhile had had time to think more.

``Then where's his (Newsome) straightness?'' (unknown)

``Well, as we say, it's struggling up, breaking out, asserting itself as it can. We can be on the side, you see, of his (Newsome) straightness. We can help him (Newsome). But he (Newsome) has made out,'' (Miss Gostrey)
said Miss Gostrey,
``that you'll do.'' (Miss Gostrey)

``Do for what?'' (unknown)

``Why, for THEM--for ces dames. He (Newsome) has watched you, studied you, liked you--and recognised that THEY must. It's a great compliment to you, my dear man; for I'm sure they're particular. You came out for a success. Well,'' (she)
she (Gostrey) gaily declared,
``you're having it!'' (she)

He (Strether) took it from her (Gostrey) with momentary patience and then turned abruptly away. It was always convenient to him (Strether) that there were so many fine things in her (Gostrey) room to look at. But the examination of two or three of them appeared soon to have determined a speech that had little to do with them.

``You don't believe in it!'' (unknown)

``In what?'' (unknown)

``In the character of the attachment. In its innocence.'' (she)

But she (Gostrey) defended herself.

``I don't pretend to know anything about it. Everything's possible. We must see.'' (unknown)

``See?'' (he)
he (Strether) echoed with a groan.
``Haven't we seen enough?'' (unknown)

``I haven't,'' (she)
she (Gostrey) smiled.

``But do you suppose then little Bilham has lied?'' (unknown)

``You must find out.'' (him)

It made him (Strether) almost turn pale.

``Find out any MORE?'' (He)

He (Strether) had dropped on a sofa for dismay; but she (Gostrey) seemed, as she (Gostrey) stood over him (Strether), to have the last word.

``Wasn't what you came out for to find out ALL?'' (I)

Book Fifth

I

The Sunday of the next week was a wonderful day, and Chad Newsome had let his (Newsome) friend know in advance that he (Newsome) had provided for it. There had already been a question of his (Newsome) taking him (Newsome) to see the great Gloriani, who was at home on Sunday afternoons and at whose house, for the most part, fewer bores were to be met than elsewhere; but the project, through some accident, had not had instant effect, and now revived in happier conditions. Chad had made the point that the celebrated sculptor had a queer old garden, for which the weather--spring at last frank and fair--was propitious; and two or three of his (Chad) other allusions had confirmed for Strether the expectation of something special. He (Chad) had by this time, for all introductions and adventures, let himself recklessly go, cherishing the sense that whatever the young man showed him (man) he (man) was showing at least himself. He (man) could have wished indeed, so far as this went, that Chad were less of a mere cicerone; for he (Chad) was not without the impression--now that the vision of his (Chad) game, his (Chad) plan, his (Chad) deep diplomacy, did recurrently assert itself--of his (Chad) taking refuge from the realities of their intercourse in profusely dispensing, as our friend mentally phrased et panem et circenses. Our friend continued to feel rather smothered in flowers, though he (friend) made in his (friend) other moments the almost angry inference that this was only because of his (friend) odious ascetic suspicion of any form of beauty. He (friend) periodically assured himself--for his (friend) reactions were sharp--that he (friend) shouldn't reach the truth of anything till he (friend) had at least got rid of that.

He (friend) had known beforehand that Madame de Vionnet and her (friend) daughter would probably be on view, an intimation to that effect having constituted the only reference again made by Chad to his (Chad) good friends from the south. The effect of Strether's talk about them with Miss Gostrey had been quite to consecrate his (Strether) reluctance to pry; something in the very air of Chad's silence--judged in the light of that talk--offered it to him (Chad) as a reserve he (Chad) could markedly match. It shrouded them about with he (Chad) scarce knew what, a consideration, a distinction; he (Chad) was in presence at any rate--so far as it placed him (Chad) there--of ladies; and the one thing that was definite for him (Chad) was that they themselves should be, to the extent of his (Chad) responsibility, in presence of a gentleman. Was it because they were very beautiful, very clever, or even very good--was it for one of these reasons that Chad was, so to speak, nursing his (Chad) effect? Did he (Chad) wish to spring them, in the Woollett phrase, with a fuller force--to confound his (Chad) critic, slight though as yet the criticism, with some form of merit exquisitely incalculable? The most the critic had at all events asked was whether the persons in question were French; and that enquiry had been but a proper comment on the sound of their name.

``Yes. That is no!'' (Chad/Chad Newsome/Newsome)
had been Chad's reply; but he (Chad) had immediately added that their English was the most charming in the world, so that if Strether were wanting an excuse for not getting on with them he (Strether) wouldn't in the least find one. Never in fact had Strether--in the mood into which the place had quickly launched him (Strether)--felt, for himself, less the need of an excuse. Those he (Strether) might have found would have been, at the worst, all for the others, the people before him (Strether), in whose liberty to be as they were he (Strether) was aware that he (Strether) positively rejoiced. His (Strether) fellow guests were multiplying, and these things, their liberty, their intensity, their variety, their conditions at large, were in fusion in the admirable medium of the scene.

The place itself was a great impression--a small pavilion, clear-faced and sequestered, an effect of polished parquet, of fine white panel and spare sallow gilt, of decoration delicate and rare, in the heart of the Faubourg Saint-Germain and on the edge of a cluster of gardens attached to old noble houses. Far back from streets and unsuspected by crowds, reached by a long passage and a quiet court, it was as striking to the unprepared mind, he (itself) immediately saw, as a treasure dug up; giving him (itself) too, more than anything yet, the note of the range of the immeasurable town and sweeping away, as by a last brave brush, his (itself) usual landmarks and terms. It was in the garden, a spacious cherished remnant, out of which a dozen persons had already passed, that Chad's host presently met them while the tall bird-haunted trees, all of a twitter with the spring and the weather, and the high party-walls, on the other side of which grave hotels stood off for privacy, spoke of survival, transmission, association, a strong indifferent persistent order. The day was so soft that the little party had practically adjourned to the open air but the open air was in such conditions all a chamber of state. Strether had presently the sense of a great convent, a convent of missions, famous for he (Strether) scarce knew what, a nursery of young priests, of scattered shade, of straight alleys and chapel-bells, that spread its mass in one quarter; he (Strether) had the sense of names in the air, of ghosts at the windows, of signs and tokens, a whole range of expression, all about him (Strether), too thick for prompt discrimination.

This assault of images became for a moment, in the address of the distinguished sculptor, almost formidable: Gloriani showed him (sculptor), in such perfect confidence, on Chad's introduction of him (Chad), a fine worn handsome face, a face that was like an open letter in a foreign tongue. With his (Chad) genius in his (Chad) eyes, his (Chad) manners on his (Chad) lips, his (Chad) long career behind him (Chad) and his (Chad) honours and rewards all round, the great artist, in the course of a single sustained look and a few words of delight at receiving him (Chad), affected our friend as a dazzling prodigy of type. Strether had seen in museums--in the Luxembourg as well as, more reverently, later on, in the New York of the billionaires--the work of his (Strether) hand; knowing too that after an earlier time in his (Strether) native Rome he (Strether) had migrated, in mid-career, to Paris, where, with a personal lustre almost violent, he (Strether) shone in a constellation: all of which was more than enough to crown him (Strether), for his (Strether) guest, with the light, with the romance, of glory. Strether, in contact with that element as he (Strether) had never yet so intimately been, had the consciousness of opening to it, for the happy instant, all the windows of his (Strether) mind, of letting this rather grey interior drink in for once the sun of a clime not marked in his (Strether) old geography. He (Strether) was to remember again repeatedly the medal-like Italian face, in which every line was an artist's own, in which time told only as tone and consecration; and he (artist) was to recall in especial, as the penetrating radiance, as the communication of the illustrious spirit itself, the manner in which, while they stood briefly, in welcome and response, face to face, he (artist) was held by the sculptor's eyes. He (artist) wasn't soon to forget them, was to think of them, all unconscious, unintending, preoccupied though they were, as the source of the deepest intellectual sounding to which he (artist) had ever been exposed. He (artist) was in fact quite to cherish his (artist) vision of it, to play with it in idle hours; only speaking of it to no one and quite aware he (artist) couldn't have spoken without appearing to talk nonsense. Was what it had told him (artist) or what it had asked him (artist) the greater of the mysteries? Was it the most special flare, unequalled, supreme, of the aesthetic torch, lighting that wondrous world for ever, or was it above all the long straight shaft sunk by a personal acuteness that life had seasoned to steel? Nothing on earth could have been stranger and no one doubtless more surprised than the artist himself, but it was for all the world to Strether just then as if in the matter of his (Strether) accepted duty he (Strether) had positively been on trial. The deep human expertness in Gloriani's charming smile--oh the terrible life behind it!--was flashed upon him (Strether) as a test of his (Strether) stuff.

Chad meanwhile, after having easily named his (Strether) companion, had still more easily turned away and was already greeting other persons present. He (Strether) was as easy, clever Chad, with the great artist as with his (Chad) obscure compatriot, and as easy with every one else as with either: this fell into its place for Strether and made almost a new light, giving him (Strether), as a concatenation, something more he (Strether) could enjoy. He (Strether) liked Gloriani, but should never see him (Strether) again; of that he (Strether) was sufficiently sure. Chad accordingly, who was wonderful with both of them, was a kind of link for hopeless fancy, an implication of possibilities--oh if everything had been different! Strether noted at all events that he (Strether) was thus on terms with illustrious spirits, and also that--yes, distinctly--he (Strether) hadn't in the least swaggered about it. Our friend hadn't come there only for this figure of Abel Newsome's son, but that presence threatened to affect the observant mind as positively central. Gloriani indeed, remembering something and excusing himself, pursued Chad to speak to him (Chad), and Strether was left musing on many things. One of them was the question of whether, since he (Strether) had been tested, he (Strether) had passed. Did the artist drop him (Strether) from having made out that he (Strether) wouldn't do? He (Strether) really felt just to-day that he (Strether) might do better than usual. Hadn't he (Strether) done well enough, so far as that went, in being exactly so dazzled? and in not having too, as he (Strether) almost believed, wholly hidden from his (Strether) host that he (Strether) felt the latter's plummet? Suddenly, across the garden, he (Strether) saw little Bilham approach, and it was a part of the fit that was on him (Strether) that as their eyes met he (Strether) guessed also HIS (Strether) knowledge. If he (Strether) had said to him (Strether) on the instant what was uppermost he (Strether) would have said:

``HAVE I passed?--for of course I know one has to pass here.'' (he)
Little Bilham would have reassured him (Bilham), have told him (Bilham) that he (Bilham) exaggerated, and have adduced happily enough the argument of little Bilham's own very presence; which, in truth, he (Bilham) could see, was as easy a one as Gloriani's own or as Chad's. He (Chad) himself would perhaps then after a while cease to be frightened, would get the point of view for some of the faces--types tremendously alien, alien to Woollett--that he (Chad) had already begun to take in. Who were they all, the dispersed groups and couples, the ladies even more unlike those of Woollett than the gentlemen?--this was the enquiry that, when his (Chad) young friend had greeted him (Chad), he (Chad) did find himself making.

``Oh they're every one--all sorts and sizes; of course I mean within limits, though limits down perhaps rather more than limits up. There are always artists--he (Bilham)'s beautiful and inimitable to the cher confrere; and then gros bonnets of many kinds--ambassadors, cabinet ministers, bankers, generals, what do I know? even Jews. Above all always some awfully nice women--and not too many; sometimes an actress, an artist, a great performer--but only when they're not monsters; and in particular the right femmes du monde. You can fancy his (performer) history on that side--I believe it's fabulous: they NEVER give him (performer) up. Yet he (performer) keeps them down: no one knows how he (performer) manages; it's too beautiful and bland. Never too many--and a mighty good thing too; just a perfect choice. But there are not in any way many bores; it has always been so; he (performer) has some secret. It's extraordinary. And you don't find it out. He (performer)'s the same to every one. He (performer) doesn't ask questions.'' (unknown)

``Ah doesn't he (performer)?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether laughed.

Bilham met it with all his (Bilham) candour. ``How then should I be here?

``Oh for what you tell me. You're part of the perfect choice.'' (the man)

Well, the young man took in the scene.

``It seems rather good to-day.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether followed the direction of his (Strether) eyes.

``Are they all, this time, femmes du monde?'' (Bilham/Mr. Bilham)

Little Bilham showed his (Bilham) competence.

``Pretty well.'' (friend)

This was a category our friend had a feeling for; a light, romantic and mysterious, on the feminine element, in which he (friend) enjoyed for a little watching it.

``Are there any Poles?'' (companion)

His (friend) companion considered. ``I think I make out a ``Portuguee.

'' But I've seen Turks.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether wondered, desiring justice.

``They seem--all the women--very harmonious.'' (unknown)

``Oh in closer quarters they come out!'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
And then, while Strether was aware of fearing closer quarters, though giving himself again to the harmonies,
``Well,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
little Bilham went on,
``it IS at the worst rather good, you know. If you like it, you feel it, this way, that shows you're not in the least out But you always know things,'' (Bilham/Mr. Bilham)
he (Bilham) handsomely added,
``immediately.'' (he)

Strether liked it and felt it only too much; so

``I say, don't lay traps for me!'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
he (Strether) rather helplessly murmured.

``Well,'' (companion)
his (Strether) companion returned,
``he (I)'s wonderfully kind to us.'' (companion)

``To us Americans you mean?'' (unknown)

``Oh no--he (I) doesn't know anything about THAT. That's half the battle here--that you can never hear politics. We don't talk them. I mean to poor young wretches of all sorts. And yet it's always as charming as this; it's as if, by something in the air, our squalor didn't show. It puts us all back--into the last century.'' (unknown)

``I'm afraid,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether said, amused,
``that it puts me rather forward: oh ever so far!'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

``Into the next? But isn't that only,'' (Bilham/Mr. Bilham)
little Bilham asked,
``because you're really of the century before?'' (Bilham/Mr. Bilham)

``The century before the last? Thank you!'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether laughed.
``If I ask you about some of the ladies it can't be then that I may hope, as such a specimen of the rococo, to please them.'' (unknown)

``On the contrary they adore--we all adore here--the rococo, and where is there a better setting for it than the whole thing, the pavilion and the garden, together? There are lots of people with collections,'' (Bilham/Mr. Bilham)
little Bilham smiled as he (Bilham) glanced round.
``You'll be secured!'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

It made Strether for a moment give himself again to contemplation. There were faces he (Strether) scarce knew what to make of. Were they charming or were they only strange? He (Strether) mightn't talk politics, yet he (Strether) suspected a Pole or two. The upshot was the question at the back of his (Strether) head from the moment his (Strether) friend had joined him (Strether).

``Have Madame de Vionnet and her (Vionnet) daughter arrived?'' (unknown)

``I haven't seen them yet, but Miss Gostrey has come. She (Gostrey)'s in the pavilion looking at objects. One can see SHE

``S a collector,'' (unknown)
little Bilham added without offence.

``Oh yes, she (Gostrey)'s a collector, and I knew she (Gostrey) was to come. Is Madame de Vionnet a collector?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether went on.

``Rather, I believe; almost celebrated.'' (The man)
The young man met, on it, a little, his (Strether) friend's eyes.
``I happen to know--from Chad, whom I saw last night--that they've come back; but only yesterday. He (Chad) wasn't sure--up to the last. This, accordingly,'' (Bilham/Mr. Bilham)
little Bilham went on,
``will be--if they ARE here--their first appearance after their return.'' (Bilham/Mr. Bilham)

Strether, very quickly, turned these things over.

``Chad told you last night? To me, on our way here, he (Chad) said nothing about it.'' (unknown)

``But did you ask him (Chad)?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether did him (Strether) the justice.

``I dare say not.'' (unknown)

``Well,'' (Bilham/Mr. Bilham)
said little Bilham,
``you're not a person to whom it's easy to tell things you don't want to know. Though it is easy, I admit--it's quite beautiful,'' (Bilham/Mr. Bilham)
he (Bilham) benevolently added,
``when you do want to.'' (he)

Strether looked at him (Strether) with an indulgence that matched his (Strether) intelligence.

``Is that the deep reasoning on which--about these ladies--you've been yourself so silent?'' (Bilham/Mr. Bilham)

Little Bilham considered the depth of his (Bilham) reasoning.

``I haven't been silent. I spoke of them to you the other day, the day we sat together after Chad's tea-party.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether came round to it.

``They then are the virtuous attachment?'' (unknown)

``I can only tell you that it's what they pass for. But isn't that enough? What more than a vain appearance does the wisest of us know? I commend you,'' (the man)
the young man declared with a pleasant emphasis,
``the vain appearance.'' (the man)

Strether looked more widely round, and what he (Strether) saw, from face to face, deepened the effect of his (Strether) young friend's words.

``Is it so good?'' (unknown)

``Magnificent.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether had a pause.

``The husband's dead?'' (unknown)

``Dear no. Alive.'' (unknown)

``Oh!'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
said Strether. After which, as his (Strether) companion laughed:
``How then can it be so good?'' (companion)

``You'll see for yourself. One does see.'' (unknown)

``Chad's in love with the daughter?'' (unknown)

``That's what I mean.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether wondered.

``Then where's the difficulty?'' (unknown)

``Why, aren't you and I--with our grander bolder ideas?'' (unknown)

``Oh mine--!'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether said rather strangely. But then as if to attenuate:
``You mean they won't hear of Woollett?'' (Bilham/Mr. Bilham)

Little Bilham smiled.

``Isn't that just what you must see about?'' (she)

It had brought them, as she (Strether) caught the last words, into relation with Miss Barrace, whom Strether had already observed--as he (Strether) had never before seen a lady at a party--moving about alone. Coming within sound of them she (lady) had already spoken, and she (lady) took again, through her (lady) long-handled glass, all her (lady) amused and amusing possession.

``How much, poor Mr. Strether, you seem to have to see about! But you can't say,'' (she)
she (lady) gaily declared,
``that I don't do what I can to help you. Mr. Waymarsh is placed. I've left him (Waymarsh) in the house with Miss Gostrey.'' (she)

``The way,'' (Bilham/Mr. Bilham)
little Bilham exclaimed,
``Mr. Strether gets the ladies to work for him (Strether)! He (Strether)'s just preparing to draw in another; to pounce--don't you see him (Strether)?--on Madame de Vionnet.'' (Bilham/Mr. Bilham)

``Madame de Vionnet? Oh, oh, oh!'' (unknown)
Miss Barrace cried in a wonderful crescendo. There was more in it, our friend made out, than met the ear. Was it after all a joke that he (friend) should be serious about anything? He (friend) envied Miss Barrace at any rate her (lady) power of not being. She (lady) seemed, with little cries and protests and quick recognitions, movements like the darts of some fine high-feathered free-pecking bird, to stand before life as before some full shop-window. You could fairly hear, as she (lady) selected and pointed, the tap of her (lady) tortoise-shell against the glass.
``It's certain that we do need seeing about; only I'm glad it's not I who have to do it. One does, no doubt, begin that way; then suddenly one finds that one has given it up. It's too much, it's too difficult. You're wonderful, you people,'' (she)
she (lady) continued to Strether,
``for not feeling those things--by which I mean impossibilities. You never feel them. You face them with a fortitude that makes it a lesson to watch you.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

``Ah but'' (Bilham/Mr. Bilham)
--little Bilham put it with discouragement--
``what do we achieve after all? We see about you and report--when we even go so far as reporting. But nothing's done.'' (Bilham/Mr. Bilham)

``Oh you, Mr. Bilham,'' (she)
she (lady) replied as with an impatient rap on the glass,
``you're not worth sixpence! You come over to convert the savages--for I know you verily did, I remember you--and the savages simply convert YOU.'' (she)

``Not even!'' (the man)
the young man woefully confessed:
``they haven't gone through that form. They've simply--the cannibals!--eaten me; converted me if you like, but converted me into food. I'm but the bleached bones of a Christian.'' (the man)

``Well then there we are! Only'' (Miss Barrace)
--and Miss Barrace appealed again to Strether--
``don't let it discourage you. You'll break down soon enough, but you'll meanwhile have had your moments. Il faut en avoir. I always like to see you while you last. And I'll tell you who WILL last.'' (Strether)

``Waymarsh?'' (he)
--he (man) had already taken her (Barrace) up.

She (Barrace) laughed out as at the alarm of it.

``He (Christian)'ll resist even Miss Gostrey: so grand is it not to understand. He (Christian)'s wonderful.'' (unknown)

``He (Christian) is indeed,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether conceded.
``He (Christian) wouldn't tell me of this affair--only said he (Christian) had an engagement; but with such a gloom, you must let me insist, as if it had been an engagement to be hanged. Then silently and secretly he (Christian) turns up here with you. Do you call THAT `lasting'?'' (unknown)

``Oh I hope it's lasting!'' (Miss Barrace)
Miss Barrace said.
``But he (Christian) only, at the best, bears with me. He (Christian) doesn't understand--not one little scrap. He (Christian)'s delightful. He (Christian)'s wonderful,'' (she)
she (Barrace) repeated.

``Michelangelesque!'' (Bilham/Mr. Bilham)
--little Bilham completed her (Barrace) meaning.
``He (Christian) IS a success. Moses, on the ceiling, brought down to the floor; overwhelming, colossal, but somehow portable.'' (unknown)

``Certainly, if you mean by portable,'' (she)
she (Barrace) returned,
``looking so well in one's carriage. He (Christian)'s too funny beside me in his (Christian) comer; he (Christian) looks like somebody, somebody foreign and famous, en exil; so that people wonder--it's very amusing--whom I'm taking about. I show him (Christian) Paris, show him (Christian) everything, and he (Christian) never turns a hair. He (Christian)'s like the Indian chief one reads about, who, when he (Christian) comes up to Washington to see the Great Father, stands wrapt in his (Great) blanket and gives no sign. I might be the Great Father--from the way he (Father) takes everything.'' (she)
She (Barrace) was delighted at this hit of her (Barrace) identity with that personage--it fitted so her (Barrace) character; she (Barrace) declared it was the title she (Barrace) meant henceforth to adopt.
``And the way he (Father) sits, too, in the corner of my room, only looking at my visitors very hard and as if he (Father) wanted to start something! They wonder what he (Father) does want to start. But he (Father)'s wonderful,'' (unknown)
Miss Barrace once more insisted.
``He (Father) has never started anything yet.'' (him)

It presented him (character) none the less, in truth, to her (Barrace) actual friends, who looked at each other in intelligence, with frank amusement on Bilham's part and a shade of sadness on Strether's. Strether's sadness sprang--for the image had its grandeur--from his (Strether) thinking how little he (Strether) himself was wrapt in his (Strether) blanket, how little, in marble halls, all too oblivious of the Great Father, he (Father) resembled a really majestic aboriginal. But he (Father) had also another reflexion.

``You've all of you here so much visual sense that you've somehow all `run' to it. There are moments when it strikes one that you haven't any other.'' (unknown)

``Any moral,'' (Bilham/Mr. Bilham)
little Bilham explained, watching serenely, across the garden, the several femmes du monde.
``But Miss Barrace has a moral distinction,'' (he)
he (Bilham) kindly continued; speaking as if for Strether's benefit not less than for her (Bilham) own.

``HAVE you?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether, scarce knowing what he (Strether) was about, asked of her (Bilham) almost eagerly.

``Oh not a distinction'' (she)
--she (Bilham) was mightily amused at his (Strether) tone--
``Mr. Bilham's too good. But I think I may say a sufficiency. Yes, a sufficiency. Have you supposed strange things of me?'' (she)
--and she (Bilham) fixed him (Strether) again, through all her (Bilham) tortoise-shell, with the droll interest of it.
``You ARE all indeed wonderful. I should awfully disappoint you. I do take my stand on my sufficiency. But I know, I confess,'' (she)
she (Bilham) went on,
``strange people. I don't know how it happens; I don't do it on purpose; it seems to be my doom--as if I were always one of their habits: it's wonderful! I dare say moreover,'' (she)
she (Bilham) pursued with an interested gravity,
``that I do, that we all do here, run too much to mere eye. But how can it be helped? We're all looking at each other--and in the light of Paris one sees what things resemble. That's what the light of Paris seems always to show. It's the fault of the light of Paris--dear old light!'' (she)

``Dear old Paris!'' (Bilham/Mr. Bilham)
little Bilham echoed.

``Everything, every one shows,'' (unknown)
Miss Barrace went on.

``But for what they really are?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether asked.

``Oh I like your Boston `reallys'! But sometimes--yes.'' (unknown)

``Dear old Paris then!'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether resignedly sighed while for a moment they looked at each other. Then he (Strether) broke out:
``Does Madame de Vionnet do that? I mean really show for what she (I) is?'' (he)

Her (Bilham) answer was prompt.

``She (I)'s charming. She (I)'s perfect.'' (unknown)

``Then why did you a minute ago say ``Oh, oh, oh!

'' at her (Bilham) name?'' (She)

She (Bilham) easily remembered.

``Why just because--! She (I)'s wonderful.'' (unknown)

``Ah she (I) too?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
--Strether had almost a groan.

But Miss Barrace had meanwhile perceived relief.

``Why not put your question straight to the person who can answer it best?'' (unknown)

``No,'' (Bilham/Mr. Bilham)
said little Bilham;
``don't put any question; wait, rather--it will be much more fun--to judge for yourself. He (I) has come to take you to her (I).'' (Bilham/Mr. Bilham)

II

On which Strether saw that Chad was again at hand, and he (Strether) afterwards scarce knew, absurd as it may seem, what had then quickly occurred. The moment concerned him (Strether), he (Strether) felt, more deeply than he (Strether) could have explained, and he (Strether) had a subsequent passage of speculation as to whether, on walking off with Chad, he (Chad) hadn't looked either pale or red. The only thing he (Chad) was clear about was that, luckily, nothing indiscreet had in fact been said and that Chad himself was more than ever, in Miss Barrace's great sense, wonderful. It was one of the connexions--though really why it should be, after all, was none so apparent--in which the whole change in him (Chad) came out as most striking. Strether recalled as they approached the house that he (Strether) had impressed him (Strether) that first night as knowing how to enter a box. Well, he (Strether) impressed him (Strether) scarce less now as knowing how to make a presentation. It did something for Strether's own quality--marked it as estimated; so that our poor friend, conscious and passive, really seemed to feel himself quite handed over and delivered; absolutely, as he (friend) would have said, made a present of, given away. As they reached the house a young woman, about to come forth, appeared, unaccompanied, on the steps; at the exchange with whom of a word on Chad's part Strether immediately perceived that, obligingly, kindly, she (woman) was there to meet them. Chad had left her (woman) in the house, but she (woman) had afterwards come halfway and then the next moment had joined them in the garden. Her (woman) air of youth, for Strether, was at first almost disconcerting, while his (Strether) second impression was, not less sharply, a degree of relief at there not having just been, with the others, any freedom used about her (woman). It was upon him (Strether) at a touch that she (woman) was no subject for that, and meanwhile, on Chad's introducing him (Chad), she (woman) had spoken to him (Chad), very simply and gently, in an English clearly of the easiest to her (woman), yet unlike any other he (Chad) had ever heard. It wasn't as if she (woman) tried; nothing, he (Chad) could see after they had been a few minutes together, was as if she (woman) tried; but her (woman) speech, charming correct and odd, was like a precaution against her (woman) passing for a Pole. There were precautions, he (Chad) seemed indeed to see, only when there were really dangers.

Later on he (Chad) was to feel many more of them, but by that time he (Chad) was to feel other things besides. She (woman) was dressed in black, but in black that struck him (Chad) as light and transparent; she (woman) was exceedingly fair, and, though she (woman) was as markedly slim, her (woman) face had a roundness, with eyes far apart and a little strange. Her (woman) smile was natural and dim; her (woman) hat not extravagant; he (Chad) had only perhaps a sense of the clink, beneath her (woman) fine black sleeves, of more gold bracelets and bangles than he (Chad) had ever seen a lady wear. Chad was excellently free and light about their encounter; it was one of the occasions on which Strether most wished he (Strether) himself might have arrived at such ease and such humour:

``Here you are then, face to face at last; you're made for each other--vous allez voir; and I bless your union.'' (he)
It was indeed, after he (Strether) had gone off, as if he (Strether) had been partly serious too. This latter motion had been determined by an enquiry from him (Strether) about
``Jeanne'' (him)
; to which her (lady) mother had replied that she (lady) was probably still in the house with Miss Gostrey, to whom she (Gostrey) had lately committed her (Gostrey).
``Ah but you know,'' (the man)
the young man had rejoined,
``he (I) must see her (Jeanne)'' (the man)
; with which, while Strether pricked up his (Strether) ears, he (Strether) had started as if to bring her (Gostrey), leaving the other objects of his (Strether) interest together. Strether wondered to find Miss Gostrey already involved, feeling that he (Strether) missed a link; but feeling also, with small delay, how much he (Strether) should like to talk with her (Gostrey) of Madame de Vionnet on this basis of evidence.

The evidence as yet in truth was meagre; which, for that matter, was perhaps a little why his (Vionnet) expectation had had a drop. There was somehow not quite a wealth in her (Gostrey); and a wealth was all that, in his (Vionnet) simplicity, he (Vionnet) had definitely prefigured. Still, it was too much to be sure already that there was but a poverty. They moved away from the house, and, with eyes on a bench at some distance, he (Vionnet) proposed that they should sit down.

``I've heard a great deal about you,'' (she)
she (Gostrey) said as they went; but he (Vionnet) had an answer to it that made her (Gostrey) stop short.
``Well, about YOU, Madame de Vionnet, I've heard, I'm bound to say, almost nothing'' (him)
--those struck him (Vionnet) as the only words he (Vionnet) himself could utter with any lucidity; conscious as he (Vionnet) was, and as with more reason, of the determination to be in respect to the rest of his (Vionnet) business perfectly plain and go perfectly straight. It hadn't at any rate been in the least his (Vionnet) idea to spy on Chad's proper freedom. It was possibly, however, at this very instant and under the impression of Madame de Vionnet's pause, that going straight began to announce itself as a matter for care. She (It) had only after all to smile at him (Vionnet) ever so gently in order to make him (Vionnet) ask himself if he (Vionnet) weren't already going crooked. It might be going crooked to find it of a sudden just only clear that she (It) intended very definitely to be what he (Vionnet) would have called nice to him (Vionnet). This was what passed between them while, for another instant, they stood still; he (Vionnet) couldn't at least remember afterwards what else it might have been. The thing indeed really unmistakeable was its rolling over him (Vionnet) as a wave that he (Vionnet) had been, in conditions incalculable and unimaginable, a subject of discussion. He (Vionnet) had been, on some ground that concerned her (It), answered for; which gave her (It) an advantage he (Vionnet) should never be able to match.

``Hasn't Miss Gostrey,'' (she)
she (It) asked,
``said a good word for me?'' (she)

What had struck him (Vionnet) first was the way he (Vionnet) was bracketed with that lady; and he (Vionnet) wondered what account Chad would have given of their acquaintance. Something not as yet traceable, at all events, had obviously happened.

``I didn't even know of her (Jeanne) knowing you.'' (unknown)

``Well, now she (Jeanne)'ll tell you all. I'm so glad you're in relation with her (Jeanne).'' (unknown)

This was one of the things--the

``all'' (Miss Gostrey)
Miss Gostrey would now tell him (Chad)--that, with every deference to present preoccupation, was uppermost for Strether after they had taken their seat. One of the others was, at the end of five minutes, that she (Gostrey)--oh incontestably, yes--DIFFERED less; differed, that is, scarcely at all--well, superficially speaking, from Mrs. Newsome or even from Mrs. Pocock. She (Pocock) was ever so much younger than the one and not so young as the other; but what WAS there in her (Pocock), if anything, that would have made it impossible he (Strether) should meet her (Pocock) at Woollett? And wherein was her (Pocock) talk during their moments on the bench together not the same as would have been found adequate for a Woollett garden-party?--unless perhaps truly in not being quite so bright. She (Pocock) observed to him (Strether) that Mr. Newsome had, to her (Pocock) knowledge, taken extraordinary pleasure in his (Newsome) visit; but there was no good lady at Woollett who wouldn't have been at least up to that. Was there in Chad, by chance, after all, deep down, a principle of aboriginal loyalty that had made him (Chad), for sentimental ends, attach himself to elements, happily encountered, that would remind him (Chad) most of the old air and the old soil? Why accordingly be in a flutter--Strether could even put it that way--about this unfamiliar phenomenon of the femme du monde? On these terms Mrs. Newsome herself was as much of one. Little Bilham verily had testified that they came out, the ladies of the type, in close quarters; but it was just in these quarters--now comparatively close--that he (Bilham) felt Madame de Vionnet's common humanity. She (Newsome) did come out, and certainly to his (Bilham) relief, but she (Newsome) came out as the usual thing. There might be motives behind, but so could there often be even at Woollett. The only thing was that if she (Newsome) showed him (Bilham) she (Newsome) wished to like him (Bilham)--as the motives behind might conceivably prompt--it would possibly have been more thrilling for him (Bilham) that she (Newsome) should have shown as more vividly alien. Ah she (Newsome) was neither Turk nor Pole!--which would be indeed flat once more for Mrs. Newsome and Mrs. Pocock. A lady and two gentlemen had meanwhile, however, approached their bench, and this accident stayed for the time further developments.

They presently addressed his (Turk) companion, the brilliant strangers; she (Newsome) rose to speak to them, and Strether noted how the escorted lady, though mature and by no means beautiful, had more of the bold high look, the range of expensive reference, that he (Strether) had, as might have been said, made his (Strether) plans for. Madame de Vionnet greeted her (lady) as

``Duchesse'' (her)
and was greeted in turn, while talk started in French, as
``Ma toute-belle'' (French)
; little facts that had their due, their vivid interest for Strether. Madame de Vionnet didn't, none the less, introduce him (Vionnet)--a note he (Vionnet) was conscious of as false to the Woollett scale and the Woollett humanity; though it didn't prevent the Duchess, who struck him (Vionnet) as confident and free, very much what he (Vionnet) had obscurely supposed duchesses, from looking at him (Vionnet) as straight and as hard--for it WAS hard--as if she (Duchess) would have liked, all the same, to know him (Vionnet).
``Oh yes, my dear, it's all right, it's ME; and who are YOU, with your interesting wrinkles and your most effective -LRB-is it the handsomest, is it the ugliest?-RRB- of noses?'' (some handful)
--some such loose handful of bright flowers she (Duchess) seemed, fragrantly enough, to fling at him (Vionnet). Strether almost wondered--at such a pace was he (Strether) going--if some divination of the influence of either party were what determined Madame de Vionnet's abstention. One of the gentlemen, in any case, succeeded in placing himself in close relation with our friend's companion; a gentleman rather stout and importantly short, in a hat with a wonderful wide curl to its brim and a frock coat buttoned with an effect of superlative decision. His (gentleman) French had quickly turned to equal English, and it occurred to Strether that he (Strether) might well be one of the ambassadors. His (Strether) design was evidently to assert a claim to Madame de Vionnet's undivided countenance, and he (Vionnet) made it good in the course of a minute--led her (Strether) away with a trick of three words; a trick played with a social art of which Strether, looking after them as the four, whose backs were now all turned, moved off, felt himself no master.

He (master) sank again upon his (master) bench and, while his (master) eyes followed the party, reflected, as he (master) had done before, on Chad's strange communities. He (master) sat there alone for five minutes, with plenty to think of; above all with his (master) sense of having suddenly been dropped by a charming woman overlaid now by other impressions and in fact quite cleared and indifferent. He (master) hadn't yet had so quiet a surrender; he (master) didn't in the least care if nobody spoke to him (master) more. He (master) might have been, by his (master) attitude, in for something of a march so broad that the want of ceremony with which he (master) had just been used could fall into its place as but a minor incident of the procession. Besides, there would be incidents enough, as he (master) felt when this term of contemplation was closed by the reappearance of little Bilham, who stood before him (Bilham) a moment with a suggestive

``Well?'' (him)
in which he (Bilham) saw himself reflected as disorganised, as possibly floored. He (Bilham) replied with a
``Well!'' (He)
intended to show that he (Bilham) wasn't floored in the least. No indeed; he (Bilham) gave it out, as the young man sat down beside him (Bilham), that if, at the worst, he (Bilham) had been overturned at all, he (Bilham) had been overturned into the upper air, the sublimer element with which he (Bilham) had an affinity and in which he (Bilham) might be trusted a while to float. It wasn't a descent to earth to say after an instant and in sustained response to the reference:
``You're quite sure her (Jeanne) husband's living?'' (unknown)

``Oh dear, yes.'' (unknown)

``Ah then--!'' (unknown)

``Ah then what?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether had after all to think.

``Well, I'm sorry for them.'' (unknown)
But it didn't for the moment matter more than that. He (Strether) assured his (Strether) young friend he (Strether) was quite content. They wouldn't stir; were all right as they were. He (Strether) didn't want to be introduced; had been introduced already about as far as he (Strether) could go. He (Strether) had seen moreover an immensity; liked Gloriani, who, as Miss Barrace kept saying, was wonderful; had made out, he (Strether) was sure, the half-dozen other `men who were distinguished, the artists, the critics and oh the great dramatist--HIM it was easy to spot; but wanted--no, thanks, really--to talk with none of them; having nothing at all to say and finding it would do beautifully as it was; do beautifully because what it was--well, was just simply too late. And when after this little Bilham, submissive and responsive, but with an eye to the consolation nearest, easily threw off some
``Better late than never!'' (Bilham/Mr. Bilham)
all he (Bilham) got in return for it was a sharp
``Better early than late!'' (he)
This note indeed the next thing overflowed for Strether into a quiet stream of demonstration that as soon as he (Strether) had let himself go he (Strether) felt as the real relief. It had consciously gathered to a head, but the reservoir had filled sooner than he (Strether) knew, and his (Strether) companion's touch was to make the waters spread. There were some things that had to come in time if they were to come at all. If they didn't come in time they were lost for ever. It was the general sense of them that had overwhelmed him (Strether) with its long slow rush.

``It's not too late for YOU, on any side, and you don't strike me as in danger of missing the train; besides which people can be in general pretty well trusted, of course--with the clock of their freedom ticking as loud as it seems to do here--to keep an eye on the fleeting hour. All the same don't forget that you're young--blessedly young; be glad of it on the contrary and live up to it. Live all you can; it's a mistake not to. It doesn't so much matter what you do in particular, so long as you have your life. If you haven't had that what HAVE you had? This place and these impressions--mild as you may find them to wind a man up so; all my impressions of Chad and of people I've seen at HIS (Chad) place--well, have had their abundant message for me, have just dropped THAT into my mind.
