I see it now. I haven't done so enough before--and now I'm old; too old at any rate for what I see. Oh I DO see, at least; and more than you'd believe or I can express. It's too late. And it's as if the train had fairly waited at the station for me without my having had the gumption to know it was there. Now I hear its faint receding whistle miles and miles down the line. What one loses one loses; make no mistake about that. The affair--I mean the affair of life--couldn't, no doubt, have been different for me; for it's at the best a tin mould, either fluted and embossed, with ornamental excrescences, or else smooth and dreadfully plain, into which, a helpless jelly, one's consciousness is poured--so that one `takes' the form as the great cook says, and is more or less compactly held by it: one lives in fine as one can. Still, one has the illusion of freedom; therefore don't be, like me, without the memory of that illusion. I was either, at the right time, too stupid or too intelligent to have it; I don't quite know which. Of course at present I'm a case of reaction against the mistake; and the voice of reaction should, no doubt, always be taken with an allowance. But that doesn't affect the point that the right time is now yours. The right time is ANY time that one is still so lucky as to have. You've plenty; that's the great thing; you're, as I say, damn you, so happily and hatefully young. Don't at any rate miss things out of stupidity. Of course I don't take you for a fool, or I shouldn't be addressing you thus awfully. Do what you like so long as you don't make MY mistake. For it was a mistake. Live!'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
... Slowly and sociably, with full pauses and straight dashes, Strether had so delivered himself; holding little Bilham from step to step deeply and gravely attentive. The end of all was that the young man had turned quite solemn, and that this was a contradiction of the innocent gaiety the speaker had wished to promote. He (speaker) watched for a moment the consequence of his (speaker) words, and then, laying a hand on his (speaker) listener's knee and as if to end with the proper joke:
``And now for the eye I shall keep on you!'' (listener)

``Oh but I don't know that I want to be, at your age, too different from you!'' (unknown)

``Ah prepare while you're about it,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
said Strether,
``to be more amusing.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Little Bilham continued to think, but at last had a smile.

``Well, you ARE amusing--to ME.'' (unknown)

``Impayable, as you say, no doubt. But what am I to myself?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether had risen with this, giving his (Strether) attention now to an encounter that, in the middle of the garden, was in the act of taking place between their host and the lady at whose side Madame de Vionnet had quitted him (Vionnet). This lady, who appeared within a few minutes to have left her (lady) friends, awaited Gloriani's eager approach with words on her (lady) lips that Strether couldn't catch, but of which her (lady) interesting witty face seemed to give him (Strether) the echo. He (Strether) was sure she (lady) was prompt and fine, but also that she (lady) had met her (lady) match, and he (Strether) liked--in the light of what he (Strether) was quite sure was the Duchess's latent insolence--the good humour with which the great artist asserted equal resources. Were they, this pair, of the
``great world'' (unknown)
?--and was he (artist) himself, for the moment and thus related to them by his (artist) observation, IN it? Then there was something in the great world covertly tigerish, which came to him (artist) across the lawn and in the charming air as a waft from the jungle. Yet it made him (artist) admire most of the two, made him (artist) envy, the glossy male tiger, magnificently marked. These absurdities of the stirred sense, fruits of suggestion ripening on the instant, were all reflected in his (artist) next words to little Bilham.
``I know--if we talk of that--whom I should enjoy being like!'' (Little Bilham/Bilham)

Little Bilham followed his (Bilham) eyes; but then as with a shade of knowing surprise:

``Gloriani?'' (Little Bilham/Bilham)

Our friend had in fact already hesitated, though not on the hint of his (friend) companion's doubt, in which there were depths of critical reserve. He (friend) had just made out, in the now full picture, something and somebody else; another impression had been superimposed. A young girl in a white dress and a softly plumed white hat had suddenly come into view, and what was presently clear was that her (girl) course was toward them. What was clearer still was that the handsome young man at her (girl) side was Chad Newsome, and what was clearest of all was that she (girl) was therefore Mademoiselle de Vionnet, that she (girl) was unmistakeably pretty--bright gentle shy happy wonderful--and that Chad now, with a consummate calculation of effect, was about to present her (girl) to his (Chad) old friend's vision. What was clearest of all indeed was something much more than this, something at the single stroke of which--and wasn't it simply juxtaposition?--all vagueness vanished. It was the click of a spring--he (Chad) saw the truth. He (Chad) had by this time also met Chad's look; there was more of it in that; and the truth, accordingly, so far as Bilham's enquiry was concerned, had thrust in the answer.

``Oh Chad!'' (youth)
--it was that rare youth he (Bilham) should have enjoyed being
``like.'' (he)
The virtuous attachment would be all there before him (Bilham); the virtuous attachment would be in the very act of appeal for his (Bilham) blessing; Jeanne de Vionnet, this charming creature, would be exquisitely, intensely now--the object of it. Chad brought her (Vionnet) straight up to him (Chad), and Chad was, oh yes, at this moment--for the glory of Woollett or whatever--better still even than Gloriani. He (Chad) had plucked this blossom; he (Chad) had kept it over-night in water; and at last as he (Chad) held it up to wonder he (Chad) did enjoy his (Chad) effect. That was why Strether had felt at first the breath of calculation--and why moreover, as he (Strether) now knew, his (Strether) look at the girl would be, for the young man, a sign of the latter's success. What young man had ever paraded about that way, without a reason, a maiden in her (girl) flower? And there was nothing in his (man) reason at present obscure. Her (girl) type sufficiently told of it--they wouldn't, they couldn't, want her (girl) to go to Woollett. Poor Woollett, and what it might miss!--though brave Chad indeed too, and what it might gain! Brave Chad however had just excellently spoken.
``This is a good little friend of mine who knows all about you and has moreover a message for you. And this, my dear'' (he)
--he (Chad) had turned to the child herself--
``is the best man in the world, who has it in his (man) power to do a great deal for us and whom I want you to like and revere as nearly as possible as much as I do.'' (the child)

She (girl) stood there quite pink, a little frightened, prettier and prettier and not a bit like her (girl) mother. There was in this last particular no resemblance but that of youth to youth; and here was in fact suddenly Strether's sharpest impression. It went wondering, dazed, embarrassed, back to the woman he (Strether) had just been talking with; it was a revelation in the light of which he (Strether) already saw she (woman) would become more interesting. So slim and fresh and fair, she (woman) had yet put forth this perfection; so that for really believing it of her (woman), for seeing her (woman) to any such developed degree as a mother, comparison would be urgent. Well, what was it now but fairly thrust upon him (Strether)?

``Mamma wishes me to tell you before we go,'' (the girl)
the girl said,
``that she (you) hopes very much you'll come to see us very soon. She (you) has something important to say to you.'' (the girl)

``She (you) quite reproaches herself,'' (Chad/Chad Newsome/Newsome)
Chad helpfully explained:
``you were interesting her (you) so much when she (you) accidentally suffered you to be interrupted.'' (Chad/Chad Newsome/Newsome)

``Ah don't mention it!'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether murmured, looking kindly from one to the other and wondering at many things.

``And I'm to ask you for myself,'' (Jeanne/Jeanne de Vionnet)
Jeanne continued with her (Jeanne) hands clasped together as if in some small learnt prayer--
``I'm to ask you for myself if you won't positively come.'' (Jeanne/Jeanne de Vionnet)

``Leave it to me, dear--I'll take care of it!'' (Chad/Chad Newsome/Newsome)
Chad genially declared in answer to this, while Strether himself almost held his (Strether) breath. What was in the girl was indeed too soft, too unknown for direct dealing; so that one could only gaze at it as at a picture, quite staying one's own hand. But with Chad he (Chad) was now on ground--Chad he (Chad) could meet; so pleasant a confidence in that and in everything did the young man freely exhale. There was the whole of a story in his (man) tone to his (man) companion, and he (man) spoke indeed as if already of the family. It made Strether guess the more quickly what it might be about which Madame de Vionnet was so urgent. Having seen him (Vionnet) then she (man) had found him (Vionnet) easy; she (man) wished to have it out with him (Vionnet) that some way for the young people must be discovered, some way that would not impose as a condition the transplantation of her (man) daughter. He (Vionnet) already saw himself discussing with this lady the attractions of Woollett as a residence for Chad's companion. Was that youth going now to trust her (man) with the affair--so that it would be after all with one of his (Chad)
``lady-friends'' (youth)
that his (Chad) mother's missionary should be condemned to deal? It was quite as if for an instant the two men looked at each other on this question. But there was no mistaking at last Chad's pride in the display of such a connexion. This was what had made him (Chad) so carry himself while, three minutes before, he (Chad) was bringing it into view; what had caused his (Chad) friend, first catching sight of him (Chad), to be so struck with his (Chad) air. It was, in a word, just when he (Chad) thus finally felt Chad putting things straight off on him (Chad) that he (Chad) envied him (Chad), as he (Chad) had mentioned to little Bilham, most. The whole exhibition however was but a matter of three or four minutes, and the author of it had soon explained that, as Madame de Vionnet was immediately going
``on,'' (Madame de Vionnet/Vionnet/de Vionnet)
this could be for Jeanne but a snatch. They would all meet again soon, and Strether was meanwhile to stay and amuse himself--
``I'll pick you up again in plenty of time.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
He (Strether) took the girl off as he (Strether) had brought her (girl), and Strether, with the faint sweet foreignness of her (girl)
``Au revoir, monsieur!'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
in his (Strether) ears as a note almost unprecedented, watched them recede side by side and felt how, once more, her (girl) companion's relation to her (girl) got an accent from it. They disappeared among the others and apparently into the house; whereupon our friend turned round to give out to little Bilham the conviction of which he (Bilham) was full. But there was no little Bilham any more; little Bilham had within the few moments, for reasons of his (Bilham) own, proceeded further: a circumstance by which, in its order, Strether was also sensibly affected.

III

Chad was not in fact on this occasion to keep his (Chad) promise of coming back; but Miss Gostrey had soon presented herself with an explanation of his (Chad) failure. There had been reasons at the last for his (Chad) going off with ces dames; and he (Chad) had asked her (Gostrey) with much instance to come out and take charge of their friend. She (Gostrey) did so, Strether felt as she (Gostrey) took her (Gostrey) place beside him (Strether), in a manner that left nothing to desire. He (Strether) had dropped back on his (Strether) bench, alone again for a time, and the more conscious for little Bilham's defection of his (Bilham) unexpressed thought; in respect to which however this next converser was a still more capacious vessel.

``It's the child!'' (he)
he (Bilham) had exclaimed to her (Gostrey) almost as soon as she (Gostrey) appeared; and though her (Gostrey) direct response was for some time delayed he (Bilham) could feel in her (Gostrey) meanwhile the working of this truth. It might have been simply, as she (Gostrey) waited, that they were now in presence altogether of truth spreading like a flood and not for the moment to be offered her (Gostrey) in the mere cupful; inasmuch as who should ces dames prove to be but persons about whom--once thus face to face with them--she (Gostrey) found she (Gostrey) might from the first have told him (Bilham) almost everything? This would have freely come had he (Bilham) taken the simple precaution of giving her (Gostrey) their name. There could be no better example--and she (Gostrey) appeared to note it with high amusement--than the way, making things out already so much for himself, he (Bilham) was at last throwing precautions to the winds. They were neither more nor less, she (Gostrey) and the child's mother, than old school-friends--friends who had scarcely met for years but whom this unlooked-for chance had brought together with a rush. It was a relief, Miss Gostrey hinted, to feel herself no longer groping; she (Gostrey) was unaccustomed to grope and as a general thing, he (Bilham) might well have seen, made straight enough for her (Gostrey) clue. With the one she (Gostrey) had now picked up in her (Gostrey) hands there need be at least no waste of wonder.
``She (you)'s coming to see me--that's for YOU,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether's counsellor continued;
``but I don't require it to know where I am.'' (Strether counsellor)

The waste of wonder might be proscribed; but Strether, characteristically, was even by this time in the immensity of space.

``By which you mean that you know where SHE is?'' (She)

She (Gostrey) just hesitated.

``I mean that if she (you) comes to see me I shall--now that I've pulled myself round a bit after the shock--not be at home.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether hung poised.

``You call it--your recognition--a shock?'' (She)

She (Gostrey) gave one of her (Gostrey) rare flickers of impatience.

``It was a surprise, an emotion. Don't be so literal. I wash my hands of her (you).'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Poor Strether's face lengthened.

``She (you)'s impossible--?'' (unknown)

``She (you)'s even more charming than I remembered her (you).'' (unknown)

``Then what's the matter?'' (She)

She (Gostrey) had to think how to put it. ``Well, I

``M impossible. It's impossible. Everything's impossible.'' (He)

He (Strether) looked at her (Gostrey) an instant.

``I see where you're coming out. Everything's possible.'' (unknown)
Their eyes had on it in fact an exchange of some duration; after which he (Strether) pursued:
``Isn't it that beautiful child?'' (he)
Then as she (Gostrey) still said nothing:
``Why don't you mean to receive her (you)?'' (she)

Her (Gostrey) answer in an instant rang clear.

``Because I wish to keep out of the business.'' (him)

It provoked in him (Strether) a weak wail.

``You're going to abandon me NOW?'' (unknown)

``No, I'm only going to abandon HER. She (you)'ll want me to help her (you) with you. And I won't.'' (unknown)

``You'll only help me with her (you)? Well then--!'' (the persons)
Most of the persons previously gathered had, in the interest of tea, passed into the house, and they had the gardens mainly to themselves. The shadows were long, the last call of the birds, who had made a home of their own in the noble interspaced quarter, sounded from the high trees in the other gardens as well, those of the old convent and of the old hotels; it was as if our friends had waited for the full charm to come out. Strether's impressions were still present; it was as if something had happened that
``nailed'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
them, made them more intense; but he (Strether) was to ask himself soon afterwards, that evening, what really HAD happened--conscious as he (Strether) could after all remain that for a gentleman taken, and taken the first time, into the
``great world,'' (a gentleman)
the world of ambassadors and duchesses, the items made a meagre total. It was nothing new to him (Strether), however, as we know, that a man might have--at all events such a man as he (man)--an amount of experience out of any proportion to his (man) adventures; so that, though it was doubtless no great adventure to sit on there with Miss Gostrey and hear about Madame de Vionnet, the hour, the picture, the immediate, the recent, the possible--as well as the communication itself, not a note of which failed to reverberate--only gave the moments more of the taste of history.

It was history, to begin with, that Jeanne's mother had been three-and-twenty years before, at Geneva, schoolmate and good girlfriend to Maria Gostrey, who had moreover enjoyed since then, though interruptedly and above all with a long recent drop, other glimpses of her (Gostrey). Twenty-three years put them both on, no doubt; and Madame de Vionnet--though she (Gostrey) had married straight after school--couldn't be today an hour less than thirty-eight. This made her (Gostrey) ten years older than Chad--though ten years, also, if Strether liked, older than she (Gostrey) looked; the least, at any rate, that a prospective mother-in-law could be expected to do with. She (mother-in-law) would be of all mothers-in-law the most charming; unless indeed, through some perversity as yet insupposeable, she (mother-in-law) should utterly belie herself in that relation. There was none surely in which, as Maria remembered her (Maria), she (Maria) mustn't be charming; and this frankly in spite of the stigma of failure in the tie where failure always most showed. It was no test there--when indeed WAS it a test there?--for Monsieur de Vionnet had been a brute. She (Maria) had lived for years apart from him (Vionnet)--which was of course always a horrid position; but Miss Gostrey's impression of the matter had been that she (Gostrey) could scarce have made a better thing of it had she (Gostrey) done it on purpose to show she (Gostrey) was amiable. She (Gostrey) was so amiable that nobody had had a word to say; which was luckily not the case for her (Gostrey) husband. He (husband) was so impossible that she (Gostrey) had the advantage of all her (Gostrey) merits.

It was still history for Strether that the Comte de Vionnet--it being also history that the lady in question was a Countess--should now, under Miss Gostrey's sharp touch, rise before him (Strether) as a high distinguished polished impertinent reprobate, the product of a mysterious order; it was history, further, that the charming girl so freely sketched by his (Strether) companion should have been married out of hand by a mother, another figure of striking outline, full of dark personal motive; it was perhaps history most of all that this company was, as a matter of course, governed by such considerations as put divorce out of the question.

``Ces gens-la don't divorce, you know, any more than they emigrate or abjure--they think it impious and vulgar'' (unknown)
; a fact in the light of which they seemed but the more richly special. It was all special; it was all, for Strether's imagination, more or less rich. The girl at the Genevese school, an isolated interesting attaching creature, then both sensitive and violent, audacious but always forgiven, was the daughter of a French father and an English mother who, early left a widow, had married again--tried afresh with a foreigner; in her (widow) career with whom she (widow) had apparently given her (widow) child no example of comfort. All these people--the people of the English mother's side--had been of condition more or less eminent; yet with oddities and disparities that had often since made Maria, thinking them over, wonder what they really quite rhymed to. It was in any case her (Maria) belief that the mother, interested and prone to adventure, had been without conscience, had only thought of ridding herself most quickly of a possible, an actual encumbrance. The father, by her (Maria) impression, a Frenchman with a name one knew, had been a different matter, leaving his (Frenchman) child, she (Maria) clearly recalled, a memory all fondness, as well as an assured little fortune which was unluckily to make her (Maria) more or less of a prey later on. She (Maria) had been in particular, at school, dazzlingly, though quite booklessly, clever; as polyglot as a little Jewess -LRB-which she (Maria) wasn't, oh no!-RRB- and chattering French, English, German, Italian, anything one would, in a way that made a clean sweep, if not of prizes and parchments, at least of every
``part,'' (mates)
whether memorised or improvised, in the curtained costumed school repertory, and in especial of all mysteries of race and vagueness of reference, all swagger about
``home,'' (mates)
among their variegated mates.

It would doubtless be difficult to-day, as between French and English, to name her (Maria) and place her (Maria); she (Maria) would certainly show, on knowledge, Miss Gostrey felt, as one of those convenient types who don't keep you explaining--minds with doors as numerous as the many-tongued cluster of confessionals at Saint Peter's. You might confess to her (Gostrey) with confidence in Roumelian, and even Roumelian sins. Therefore--! But Strether's narrator covered her (Gostrey) implication with a laugh; a laugh by which his (narrator) betrayal of a sense of the lurid in the picture was also perhaps sufficiently protected. He (narrator) had a moment of wondering, while his (narrator) friend went on, what sins might be especially Roumelian. She (Gostrey) went on at all events to the mention of her (Gostrey) having met the young thing--again by some Swiss lake--in her (Gostrey) first married state, which had appeared for the few intermediate years not at least violently disturbed. She (Gostrey) had been lovely at that moment, delightful to HER, full of responsive emotion, of amused recognitions and amusing reminders, and then once more, much later, after a long interval, equally but differently charming--touching and rather mystifying for the five minutes of an encounter at a railway-station en province, during which it had come out that her (Gostrey) life was all changed. Miss Gostrey had understood enough to see, essentially, what had happened, and yet had beautifully dreamed that she (Gostrey) was herself faultless. There were doubtless depths in her (Gostrey), but she (Gostrey) was all right; Strether would see if she (Gostrey) wasn't. She (Gostrey) was another person however--that had been promptly marked--from the small child of nature at the Geneva school, a little person quite made over -LRB-as foreign women WERE, compared with American-RRB- by marriage. Her (Gostrey) situation too had evidently cleared itself up; there would have been--all that was possible--a judicial separation. She (Gostrey) had settled in Paris, brought up her (Gostrey) daughter, steered her (Gostrey) boat. It was no very pleasant boat--especially there--to be in; but Marie de Vionnet would have headed straight. She (Vionnet) would have friends, certainly--and very good ones. There she (Vionnet) was at all events--and it was very interesting. Her (Vionnet) knowing Mr. Chad didn't in the least prove she (Vionnet) hadn't friends; what it proved was what good ones HE (Chad) had.

``I saw that,'' (Miss Gostrey)
said Miss Gostrey,
``that night at the Francais; it came out for me in three minutes. I saw HER--or somebody like her (you). And so,'' (Miss Gostrey)
she (Gostrey) immediately added,
``did you.'' (she)

``Oh no--not anybody like her (you)!'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether laughed.
``But you mean,'' (he)
he (Strether) as promptly went on,
``that she (you) has had such an influence on him (they)?'' (he)

Miss Gostrey was on her (Gostrey) feet; it was time for them to go.

``She (you) has brought him (they) up for her (you) daughter.'' (unknown)

Their eyes, as so often, in candid conference, through their settled glasses, met over it long; after which Strether's again took in the whole place. They were quite alone there now.

``Mustn't she (you) rather--in the time then--have rushed it?'' (unknown)

``Ah she (you) won't of course have lost an hour. But that's just the good mother--the good French one. You must remember that of her (mother)--that as a mother she (mother)'s French, and that for them there's a special providence. It precisely however--that she (mother) mayn't have been able to begin as far back as she (mother)'d have liked--makes her (mother) grateful for aid.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether took this in as they slowly moved to the house on their way out.

``She (mother) counts on me then to put the thing through?'' (unknown)

``Yes--she (mother) counts on you. Oh and first of all of course,'' (Miss Gostrey)
Miss Gostrey added,
``on her (mother)--well, convincing you.'' (Miss Gostrey)

``Ah,'' (friend)
her (Gostrey) friend returned,
``she (mother) caught Chad young!'' (friend)

``Yes, but there are women who are for all your `times of life.'' (unknown)
They're the most wonderful sort.''

She (Gostrey) had laughed the words out, but they brought her (Gostrey) companion, the next thing, to a stand.

``Is what you mean that she (mother)'ll try to make a fool of me?'' (unknown)

``Well, I'm wondering what she (mother) WILL--with an opportunity--make.'' (unknown)

``What do you call,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether asked,
``an opportunity? My going to see her (mother)?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

``Ah you must go to see her (mother)'' (Miss Gostrey)
--Miss Gostrey was a trifle evasive.
``You can't not do that. You'd have gone to see the other woman. I mean if there had been one--a different sort. It's what you came out for.'' (unknown)

It might be; but Strether distinguished.

``I didn't come out to see THIS sort.'' (She)

She (Gostrey) had a wonderful look at him (Strether) now.

``Are you disappointed she (woman) isn't worse?'' (He)

He (Strether) for a moment entertained the question, then found for it the frankest of answers.

``Yes. If she (woman) were worse she (woman)'d be better for our purpose. It would be simpler.'' (unknown)

``Perhaps,'' (she)
she (Gostrey) admitted.
``But won't this be pleasanter?'' (unknown)

``Ah you know,'' (he)
he (Strether) promptly replied,
``I didn't come out--wasn't that just what you originally reproached me with?--for the pleasant.'' (he)

``Precisely. Therefore I say again what I said at first. You must take things as they come. Besides,'' (Miss Gostrey)
Miss Gostrey added,
``I'm not afraid for myself.'' (Miss Gostrey)

``For yourself--?'' (unknown)

``Of your seeing her (woman). I trust her (woman). There's nothing she (woman)'ll say about me. In fact there's nothing she (woman) CAN.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether wondered--little as he (Strether) had thought of this. Then he (Strether) broke out.

``Oh you women!'' (she)

There was something in it at which she (Gostrey) flushed.

``Yes--there we are. We're abysses.'' (she)
At last she (Gostrey) smiled.
``But I risk her (woman)!'' (He)

He (Strether) gave himself a shake.

``Well then so do I!'' (he)
But he (Strether) added as they passed into the house that he (Strether) would see Chad the first thing in the morning.

This was the next day the more easily effected that the young man, as it happened, even before he (man) was down, turned up at his (man) hotel. Strether took his (Strether) coffee, by habit, in the public room; but on his (Strether) descending for this purpose Chad instantly proposed an adjournment to what he (Chad) called greater privacy. He (Chad) had himself as yet had nothing--they would sit down somewhere together; and when after a few steps and a turn into the Boulevard they had, for their greater privacy, sat down among twenty others, our friend saw in his (friend) companion's move a fear of the advent of Waymarsh. It was the first time Chad had to that extent given this personage

``away'' (this personage)
; and Strether found himself wondering of what it was symptomatic. He (Strether) made out in a moment that the youth was in earnest as he (Strether) hadn't yet seen him (Strether); which in its turn threw a ray perhaps a trifle startling on what they had each up to that time been treating as earnestness. It was sufficiently flattering however that the real thing--if this WAS at last the real thing--should have been determined, as appeared, precisely by an accretion of Strether's importance. For this was what it quickly enough came to--that Chad, rising with the lark, had rushed down to let him (Chad) know while his (Chad) morning consciousness was yet young that he (Chad) had literally made the afternoon before a tremendous impression. Madame de Vionnet wouldn't, couldn't rest till she (Chad) should have some assurance from him (Chad) that he (Chad) WOULD consent again to see her (Chad). The announcement was made, across their marble-topped table, while the foam of the hot milk was in their cups and its plash still in the air, with the smile of Chad's easiest urbanity; and this expression of his (Chad) face caused our friend's doubts to gather on the spot into a challenge of the lips.
``See here'' (he)
--that was all; he (Chad) only for the moment said again
``See here.'' (he)
Chad met it with all his (Chad) air of straight intelligence, while Strether remembered again that fancy of the first impression of him (Strether), the happy young Pagan, handsome and hard but oddly indulgent, whose mysterious measure he (Strether) had under the street-lamp tried mentally to take. The young Pagan, while a long look passed between them, sufficiently understood. Strether scarce needed at last to say the rest--
``I want to know where I am.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
But he (Strether) said it, adding before any answer something more.
``Are you engaged to be married--is that your secret?--to the young lady?'' (Chad/Chad Newsome/Newsome)

Chad shook his (Chad) head with the slow amenity that was one of his (Chad) ways of conveying that there was time for everything.

``I have no secret--though I may have secrets! I haven't at any rate that one. We're not engaged. No.'' (unknown)

``Then where's the hitch?'' (unknown)

``Do you mean why I haven't already started with you?'' (Chad/Chad Newsome/Newsome)
Chad, beginning his (Chad) coffee and buttering his (Chad) roll, was quite ready to explain.
``Nothing would have induced me--nothing will still induce me--not to try to keep you here as long as you can be made to stay. It's too visibly good for you.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether had himself plenty to say about this, but it was amusing also to measure the march of Chad's tone. He (Chad) had never been more a man of the world, and it was always in his (Chad) company present to our friend that one was seeing how in successive connexions a man of the world acquitted himself. Chad kept it up beautifully.
``My idea--voyons!--is simply that you should let Madame de Vionnet know you, simply that you should consent to know HER. I don't in the least mind telling you that, clever and charming as she (you) is, she (you)'s ever so much in my confidence. All I ask of you is to let her (you) talk to you. You've asked me about what you call my hitch, and so far as it goes she (you)'ll explain it to you. She (you)'s herself my hitch, hang it--if you must really have it all out. But in a sense,'' (he)
he (Chad) hastened in the most wonderful manner to add,
``that you'll quite make out for yourself. She (you)'s too good a friend, confound her (you). Too good, I mean, for me to leave without--without--'' (he)
It was his (Chad) first hesitation.

``Without what?'' (unknown)

``Well, without my arranging somehow or other the damnable terms of my sacrifice.'' (unknown)

``It WILL be a sacrifice then?'' (unknown)

``It will be the greatest loss I ever suffered. I owe her (you) so much.'' (Chad)

It was beautiful, the way Chad said these things, and his (Chad) plea was now confessedly--oh quite flagrantly and publicly--interesting. The moment really took on for Strether an intensity. Chad owed Madame de Vionnet so much? What DID that do then but clear up the whole mystery? He (Chad) was indebted for alterations, and she (man) was thereby in a position to have sent in her (man) bill for expenses incurred in reconstruction. What was this at bottom but what had been to be arrived at? Strether sat there arriving at it while he (Strether) munched toast and stirred his (Strether) second cup. To do this with the aid of Chad's pleasant earnest face was also to do more besides. No, never before had he (Chad) been so ready to take him (Chad) as he (Chad) was. What was it that had suddenly so cleared up? It was just everybody's character; that is everybody's but--in a measure--his (character) own. Strether felt HIS (Strether) character receive for the instant a smutch from all the wrong things he (Strether) had suspected or believed. The person to whom Chad owed it that he (Chad) could positively turn out such a comfort to other persons--such a person was sufficiently raised above any

``breath'' (a person)
by the nature of her (everybody) work and the young man's steady light. All of which was vivid enough to come and go quickly; though indeed in the midst of it Strether could utter a question.
``Have I your word of honour that if I surrender myself to Madame de Vionnet you'll surrender yourself to me?'' (Chad/Chad Newsome/Newsome)

Chad laid his (Chad) hand firmly on his (Chad) friend's.

``My dear man, you have it.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

There was finally something in his (Chad) felicity almost embarrassing and oppressive--Strether had begun to fidget under it for the open air and the erect posture. He (Strether) had signed to the waiter that he (Strether) wished to pay, and this transaction took some moments, during which he (Strether) thoroughly felt, while he (Strether) put down money and pretended--it was quite hollow--to estimate change, that Chad's higher spirit, his (Chad) youth, his (Chad) practice, his (Chad) paganism, his (Chad) felicity, his (Chad) assurance, his (Chad) impudence, whatever it might be, had consciously scored a success. Well, that was all right so far as it went; his (Chad) sense of the thing in question covered our friend for a minute like a veil through which--as if he (Chad) had been muffled--he (Chad) heard his (Chad) interlocutor ask him (Chad) if he (Chad) mightn't take him (Chad) over about five.

``Over'' (Madame de Vionnet/Vionnet/de Vionnet)
was over the river, and over the river was where Madame de Vionnet lived, and five was that very afternoon. They got at last out of the place--got out before he (Vionnet) answered. He (Vionnet) lighted, in the street, a cigarette, which again gave him (Vionnet) more time. But it was already sharp for him (Vionnet) that there was no use in time.
``What does she (you) propose to do to me?'' (he)
he (Vionnet) had presently demanded.

Chad had no delays.

``Are you afraid of her (you)?'' (unknown)

``Oh immensely. Don't you see it?'' (unknown)

``Well,'' (Chad)
said Chad,
``she (you) won't do anything worse to you than make you like her (you).'' (Chad)

``It's just of that I'm afraid.'' (unknown)

``Then it's not fair to me.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether cast about.

``It's fair to your mother.'' (unknown)

``Oh,'' (Chad)
said Chad,
``are you afraid of HER?'' (Chad)

``Scarcely less. Or perhaps even more. But is this lady against your interests at home?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether went on.

``Not directly, no doubt; but she (lady)'s greatly in favour of them here.'' (unknown)

``And what--`here'--does she (lady) consider them to be?'' (unknown)

``Well, good relations!'' (unknown)

``With herself?'' (unknown)

``With herself.'' (unknown)

``And what is it that makes them so good?'' (unknown)

``What? Well, that's exactly what you'll make out if you'll only go, as I'm supplicating you, to see her (lady).'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether stared at him (Strether) with a little of the wanness, no doubt, that the vision of more to

``make out'' (him)
could scarce help producing.
``I mean HOW good are they?'' (unknown)

``Oh awfully good.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Again Strether had faltered, but it was brief. It was all very well, but there was nothing now he (Strether) wouldn't risk.

``Excuse me, but I must really--as I began by telling you--know where I am. Is she (lady) bad?'' (unknown)

''`Bad'?'' (Chad)
--Chad echoed it, but without a shock.
``Is that what's implied--?'' (unknown)

``When relations are good?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether felt a little silly, and was even conscious of a foolish laugh, at having it imposed on him (Strether) to have appeared to speak so. What indeed was he (Strether) talking about? His (Strether) stare had relaxed; he (Strether) looked now all round him (Strether). But something in him (Strether) brought him (Strether) back, though he (Strether) still didn't know quite how to turn it. The two or three ways he (Strether) thought of, and one of them in particular, were, even with scruples dismissed, too ugly. He (Strether) none the less at last found something.
``Is her (lady) life without reproach?'' (him)

It struck him (Strether), directly he (Strether) had found it, as pompous and priggish; so much so that he (Strether) was thankful to Chad for taking it only in the right spirit. The young man spoke so immensely to the point that the effect was practically of positive blandness.

``Absolutely without reproach. A beautiful life. Allez donc voir!'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

These last words were, in the liberality of their confidence, so imperative that Strether went through no form of assent; but before they separated it had been confirmed that he (Strether) should be picked up at a quarter to five.

Book Sixth

I

It was quite by half-past five--after the two men had been together in Madame de Vionnet's drawing-room not more than a dozen minutes--that Chad, with a look at his (Chad) watch and then another at their hostess, said genially, gaily:

``I've an engagement, and I know you won't complain if I leave him (I) with you. He (I)'ll interest you immensely; and as for her (lady),'' (hostess)
he (Chad) declared to Strether,
``I assure you, if you're at all nervous, she (lady)'s perfectly safe.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

He (Strether) had left them to be embarrassed or not by this guarantee, as they could best manage, and embarrassment was a thing that Strether wasn't at first sure Madame de Vionnet escaped. He (Strether) escaped it himself, to his (Strether) surprise; but he (Strether) had grown used by this time to thinking of himself as brazen. She (hostess) occupied, his (Strether) hostess, in the Rue de Bellechasse, the first floor of an old house to which our visitors had had access from an old clean court. The court was large and open, full of revelations, for our friend, of the habit of privacy, the peace of intervals, the dignity of distances and approaches; the house, to his (friend) restless sense, was in the high homely style of an elder day, and the ancient Paris that he (friend) was always looking for--sometimes intensely felt, sometimes more acutely missed--was in the immemorial polish of the wide waxed staircase and in the fine boiseries, the medallions, mouldings, mirrors, great clear spaces, of the greyish-white salon into which he (friend) had been shown. He (friend) seemed at the very outset to see her (friend) in the midst of possessions not vulgarly numerous, but hereditary cherished charming. While his (friend) eyes turned after a little from those of his (friend) hostess and Chad freely talked--not in the least about HIM, but about other people, people he (friend) didn't know, and quite as if he (friend) did know them--he (friend) found himself making out, as a background of the occupant, some glory, some prosperity of the First Empire, some Napoleonic glamour, some dim lustre of the great legend; elements clinging still to all the consular chairs and mythological brasses and sphinxes' heads and faded surfaces of satin striped with alternate silk.

The place itself went further back--that he (friend) guessed, and how old Paris continued in a manner to echo there; but the post-revolutionary period, the world he (friend) vaguely thought of as the world of Chateaubriand, of Madame de Stael, even of the young Lamartine, had left its stamp of harps and urns and torches, a stamp impressed on sundry small objects, ornaments and relics. He (friend) had never before, to his (friend) knowledge, had present to him (friend) relics, of any special dignity, of a private order--little old miniatures, medallions, pictures, books; books in leather bindings, pinkish and greenish, with gilt garlands on the back, ranged, together with other promiscuous properties, under the glass of brass-mounted cabinets. His (friend) attention took them all tenderly into account. They were among the matters that marked Madame de Vionnet's apartment as something quite different from Miss Gostrey's little museum of bargains and from Chad's lovely home; he (Chad) recognised it as founded much more on old accumulations that had possibly from time to time shrunken than on any contemporary method of acquisition or form of curiosity. Chad and Miss Gostrey had rummaged and purchased and picked up and exchanged, sifting, selecting, comparing; whereas the mistress of the scene before him (Chad), beautifully passive under the spell of transmission--transmission from her (mistress) father's line, he (father) quite made up his (father) mind--had only received, accepted and been quiet. When she (mistress) hadn't been quiet she (mistress) had been moved at the most to some occult charity for some fallen fortune. There had been objects she (mistress) or her (mistress) predecessors might even conceivably have parted with under need, but Strether couldn't suspect them of having sold old pieces to get

``better'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
ones. They would have felt no difference as to better or worse. He (Strether) could but imagine their having felt--perhaps in emigration, in proscription, for his (Strether) sketch was slight and confused--the pressure of want or the obligation of sacrifice.

The pressure of want--whatever might be the case with the other force--was, however, presumably not active now, for the tokens of a chastened ease still abounded after all, many marks of a taste whose discriminations might perhaps have been called eccentric. He (Strether) guessed at intense little preferences and sharp little exclusions, a deep suspicion of the vulgar and a personal view of the right. The general result of this was something for which he (Strether) had no name on the spot quite ready, but something he (Strether) would have come nearest to naming in speaking of it as the air of supreme respectability, the consciousness, small, still, reserved, but none the less distinct and diffused, of private honour. The air of supreme respectability--that was a strange blank wall for his (Strether) adventure to have brought him (Strether) to break his (Strether) nose against. It had in fact, as he (Strether) was now aware, filled all the approaches, hovered in the court as he (Strether) passed, hung on the staircase as he (Strether) mounted, sounded in the grave rumble of the old bell, as little electric as possible, of which Chad, at the door, had pulled the ancient but neatly-kept tassel; it formed in short the clearest medium of its particular kind that he (Chad) had ever breathed. He (Chad) would have answered for it at the end of a quarter of an hour that some of the glass cases contained swords and epaulettes of ancient colonels and generals; medals and orders once pinned over hearts that had long since ceased to beat; snuff-boxes bestowed on ministers and envoys; copies of works presented, with inscriptions, by authors now classic. At bottom of it all for him (Chad) was the sense of her (Chad) rare unlikeness to the women he (Chad) had known. This sense had grown, since the day before, the more he (Chad) recalled her (Chad), and had been above all singularly fed by his (Chad) talk with Chad in the morning. Everything in fine made her (Chad) immeasurably new, and nothing so new as the old house and the old objects. There were books, two or three, on a small table near his (Chad) chair, but they hadn't the lemon-coloured covers with which his (Chad) eye had begun to dally from the hour of his (Chad) arrival and to the opportunity of a further acquaintance with which he (Chad) had for a fortnight now altogether succumbed. On another table, across the room, he (Chad) made out the great _Revue_; but even that familiar face, conspicuous in Mrs. Newsome's parlours, scarce counted here as a modern note. He (Chad) was sure on the spot--and he (Chad) afterwards knew he (Chad) was right--that this was a touch of Chad's own hand. What would Mrs. Newsome say to the circumstance that Chad's interested

``influence'' (Chad)
kept her (Newsome) paper-knife in the _Revue_? The interested influence at any rate had, as we say, gone straight to the point--had in fact soon left it quite behind.

She (Newsome) was seated, near the fire, on a small stuffed and fringed chair one of the few modern articles in the room, and she (Newsome) leaned back in it with her (Newsome) hands clasped in her (Newsome) lap and no movement, in all her (Newsome) person, but the fine prompt play of her (Newsome) deep young face. The fire, under the low white marble, undraped and academic, had burnt down to the silver ashes of light wood, one of the windows, at a distance, stood open to the mildness and stillness, out of which, in the short pauses, came the faint sound, pleasant and homely, almost rustic, of a plash and a clatter of sabots from some coach-house on the other side of the court. Madame de Vionnet, while Strether sat there, wasn't to shift her (Newsome) posture by an inch.

``I don't think you seriously believe in what you're doing,'' (she)
she (Newsome) said;
``but all the same, you know, I'm going to treat you quite as if I did.'' (she)

``By which you mean,'' (Strether)
Strether directly replied,
``quite as if you didn't! I assure you it won't make the least difference with me how you treat me.'' (Strether)

``Well,'' (she)
she (Newsome) said, taking that menace bravely and philosophically enough,
``the only thing that really matters is that you shall get on with me.'' (she)

``Ah but I don't!'' (he)
he (Strether) immediately returned.

It gave her (Newsome) another pause; which, however, she (Newsome) happily enough shook off.

``Will you consent to go on with me a little--provisionally--as if you did?'' (he)

Then it was that he (Strether) saw how she (Newsome) had decidedly come all the way; and there accompanied it an extraordinary sense of her (Newsome) raising from somewhere below him (Strether) her (Newsome) beautiful suppliant eyes. He (Strether) might have been perched at his (Strether) door-step or at his (Strether) window and she (Newsome) standing in the road. For a moment he (Strether) let her (Newsome) stand and couldn't moreover have spoken. It had been sad, of a sudden, with a sadness that was like a cold breath in his (Strether) face.

``What can I do,'' (he)
he (Strether) finally asked,
``but listen to you as I promised Chadwick?'' (he)

``Ah but what I'm asking you,'' (she)
she (Newsome) quickly said,
``isn't what Mr. Newsome had in mind.'' (she)
She (Newsome) spoke at present, he (Strether) saw, as if to take courageously ALL her (Newsome) risk.
``This is my own idea and a different thing.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

It gave poor Strether in truth--uneasy as it made him (Strether) too--something of the thrill of a bold perception justified.

``Well,'' (he)
he (Strether) answered kindly enough,
``I was sure a moment since that some idea of your own had come to you.'' (he)

She (Newsome) seemed still to look up at him (Strether), but now more serenely.

``I made out you were sure--and that helped it to come. So you see,'' (she)
she (Newsome) continued,
``we do get on.'' (she)

``Oh but it appears to me I don't at all meet your request. How can I when I don't understand it?'' (unknown)

``It isn't at all necessary you should understand; it will do quite well enough if you simply remember it. Only feel I trust you--and for nothing so tremendous after all. Just,'' (she)
she (Newsome) said with a wonderful smile,
``for common civility.'' (she)

Strether had a long pause while they sat again face to face, as they had sat, scarce less conscious, before the poor lady had crossed the stream. She (lady) was the poor lady for Strether now because clearly she (lady) had some trouble, and her (lady) appeal to him (Strether) could only mean that her (lady) trouble was deep. He (Strether) couldn't help it; it wasn't his (Strether) fault; he (Strether) had done nothing; but by a turn of the hand she (lady) had somehow made their encounter a relation. And the relation profited by a mass of things that were not strictly in it or of it; by the very air in which they sat, by the high cold delicate room, by the world outside and the little plash in the court, by the First Empire and the relics in the stiff cabinets, by matters as far off as those and by others as near as the unbroken clasp of her (lady) hands in her (lady) lap and the look her (lady) expression had of being most natural when her (lady) eyes were most fixed.

``You count upon me of course for something really much greater than it sounds.'' (unknown)

``Oh it sounds great enough too!'' (she)
she (lady) laughed at this.

He (lady) found himself in time on the point of telling her (lady) that she (lady) was, as Miss Barrace called it, wonderful; but, catching himself up, he (lady) said something else instead.

``What was it Chad's idea then that you should say to me?'' (unknown)

``Ah his (Chad) idea was simply what a man's idea always is--to put every effort off on the woman.'' (unknown)

``The `woman'--?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether slowly echoed.

``The woman he (Chad) likes--and just in proportion as he (Chad) likes her (woman). In proportion too--for shifting the trouble--as she (woman) likes HIM.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether followed it; then with an abruptness of his (Strether) own:

``How much do you like Chad?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

``Just as much as THAT--to take all, with you, on myself.'' (she)
But she (Barrace) got at once again away from this.
``I've been trembling as if we were to stand or fall by what you may think of me; and I'm even now,'' (she)
she (Barrace) went on wonderfully,
``drawing a long breath--and, yes, truly taking a great courage--from the hope that I don't in fact strike you as impossible.'' (she)

``That's at all events, clearly,'' (he)
he (Strether) observed after an instant,
``the way I don't strike YOU.'' (he)

``Well,'' (she)
she (Barrace) so far assented, ``as you haven't yet said you WON
``T have the little patience with me I ask for--'' (she)

``You draw splendid conclusions? Perfectly. But I don't understand them,'' (I)
Strether pursued.
``You seem to me to ask for much more than you need. What, at the worst for you, what at the best for myself, can I after all do? I can use no pressure that I haven't used. You come really late with your request. I've already done all that for myself the case admits of. I've said my say, and here I am.'' (unknown)

``Yes, here you are, fortunately!'' (Madame)
Madame de Vionnet laughed.
``Mrs. Newsome,'' (she)
she (Barrace) added in another tone,
``didn't think you can do so little.'' (she)

He (Vionnet) had an hesitation, but he (Vionnet) brought the words out.

``Well, she (Newsome) thinks so now.'' (unknown)

``Do you mean by that--?'' (she)
But she (Barrace) also hung fire.

``Do I mean what?'' (She)

She (Barrace) still rather faltered.

``Pardon me if I touch on it, but if I'm saying extraordinary things, why, perhaps, mayn't I? Besides, doesn't it properly concern us to know?'' (unknown)

``To know what?'' (he)
he (Vionnet) insisted as after thus beating about the bush she (Barrace) had again dropped.

She (Barrace) made the effort.

``Has she (Newsome) given you up?'' (He)

He (Vionnet) was amazed afterwards to think how simply and quietly he (Vionnet) had met it.

``Not yet.'' (he)
It was almost as if he (Vionnet) were a trifle disappointed--had expected still more of her (Barrace) freedom. But he (Vionnet) went straight on.
``Is that what Chad has told you will happen to me?'' (She)

She (Barrace) was evidently charmed with the way he (Vionnet) took it.

``If you mean if we've talked of it--most certainly. And the question's not what has had least to do with my wishing to see you.'' (unknown)

``To judge if I'm the sort of man a woman CAN--?'' (unknown)

``Precisely,'' (she)
she (Barrace) exclaimed--
``you wonderful gentleman! I do judge--I HAVE judged. A woman can't. You're safe--with every right to be. You'd be much happier if you'd only believe it.'' (she)

Strether was silent a little; then he (Strether) found himself speaking with a cynicism of confidence of which even at the moment the sources were strange to him (Strether).

``I try to believe it. But it's a marvel,'' (he)
he (Strether) exclaimed,
``how YOU already get at it!'' (he)

Oh she (Barrace) was able to say.

``Remember how much I was on the way to it through Mr. Newsome--before I saw you. He (Newsome) thinks everything of your strength.'' (unknown)

``Well, I can bear almost anything!'' (friend)
our friend briskly interrupted. Deep and beautiful on this her (Barrace) smile came back, and with the effect of making him (friend) hear what he (friend) had said just as she (Barrace) had heard it. He (friend) easily enough felt that it gave him (friend) away, but what in truth had everything done but that? It had been all very well to think at moments that he (friend) was holding her (Barrace) nose down and that he (friend) had coerced her (Barrace): what had he (friend) by this time done but let her (Barrace) practically see that he (friend) accepted their relation? What was their relation moreover--though light and brief enough in form as yet--but whatever she (Barrace) might choose to make it? Nothing could prevent her (Barrace)--certainly he (friend) couldn't--from making it pleasant. At the back of his (friend) head, behind everything, was the sense that she (Barrace) was--there, before him (friend), close to him (friend), in vivid imperative form--one of the rare women he (friend) had so often heard of, read of, thought of, but never met, whose very presence, look, voice, the mere contemporaneous FACT of whom, from the moment it was at all presented, made a relation of mere recognition. That was not the kind of woman he (friend) had ever found Mrs. Newsome, a contemporaneous fact who had been distinctly slow to establish herself; and at present, confronted with Madame de Vionnet, he (Vionnet) felt the simplicity of his (Vionnet) original impression of Miss Gostrey. She (Newsome) certainly had been a fact of rapid growth; but the world was wide, each day was more and more a new lesson. There were at any rate even among the stranger ones relations and relations.
``Of course I suit Chad's grand way,'' (he)
he (stranger) quickly added.
``He (Chad) hasn't had much difficulty in working me in.'' (She)

She (Newsome) seemed to deny a little, on the young man's behalf, by the rise of her (Newsome) eyebrows, an intention of any process at all inconsiderate.

``You must know how grieved he (Chad)'d be if you were to lose anything. He (Chad) believes you can keep his (Chad) mother patient.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether wondered with his (Strether) eyes on her (Newsome). ``I see. THAT

``S then what you really want of me. And how am I to do it? Perhaps you'll tell me that.'' (unknown)

``Simply tell her (mother) the truth.'' (unknown)

``And what do you call the truth?'' (unknown)

``Well, any truth--about us all--that you see yourself. I leave it to you.'' (unknown)

``Thank you very much. I like,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether laughed with a slight harshness,
``the way you leave things!'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

But she (Newsome) insisted kindly, gently, as if it wasn't so bad.

``Be perfectly honest. Tell her (mother) all.'' (unknown)

``All?'' (he)
he (Strether) oddly echoed.

``Tell her (mother) the simple truth,'' (Madame de Vionnet/Vionnet/de Vionnet)
Madame de Vionnet again pleaded.

``But what is the simple truth? The simple truth is exactly what I'm trying to discover.'' (She)

She (Newsome) looked about a while, but presently she (Newsome) came back to him (Vionnet).

``Tell her (mother), fully and clearly, about US.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether meanwhile had been staring.

``You and your daughter?'' (unknown)

``Yes--little Jeanne and me. Tell her (Jeanne),'' (she)
she (Newsome) just slightly quavered,
``you like us.'' (she)

``And what good will that do me? Or rather'' (he)
--he (Strether) caught himself up--
``what good will it do YOU?'' (he)

She (Newsome) looked graver.

``None, you believe, really?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether debated.

``She (Jeanne) didn't send me out to `like' you.'' (unknown)

``Oh,'' (she)
she (Newsome) charmingly contended,
``she (Jeanne) sent you out to face the facts.'' (she)

He (Strether) admitted after an instant that there was something in that.

``But how can I face them till I know what they are? Do you want him (me),'' (he)
he (Strether) then braced himself to ask,
``to marry your daughter?'' (he)

She (Newsome) gave a headshake as noble as it was prompt.

``No--not that.'' (unknown)

``And he (me) really doesn't want to himself?'' (She)

She (Newsome) repeated the movement, but now with a strange light in her (Newsome) face.

``He (me) likes her (daughter) too much.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether wondered.

``To be willing to consider, you mean, the question of taking her (daughter) to America?'' (unknown)

``To be willing to do anything with her (daughter) but be immensely kind and nice--really tender of her (daughter). We watch over her (daughter), and you must help us. You must see her (daughter) again.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether felt awkward.

``Ah with pleasure--she (daughter)'s so remarkably attractive.'' (The mother)

The mother's eagerness with which Madame de Vionnet jumped at this was to come back to him (Strether) later as beautiful in its grace.

``The dear thing DID please you?'' (he)
Then as he (Strether) met it with the largest
``Oh!'' (he)
of enthusiasm:
``She (daughter)'s perfect. She (daughter)'s my joy.'' (unknown)

``Well, I'm sure that--if one were near her (daughter) and saw more of her (daughter)--she (daughter)'d be mine.'' (unknown)

``Then,'' (Madame de Vionnet/Vionnet/de Vionnet)
said Madame de Vionnet,
``tell Mrs. Newsome that!'' (Madame de Vionnet/Vionnet/de Vionnet)

He (Vionnet) wondered the more.

``What good will that do you?'' (she)
As she (Newsome) appeared unable at once to say, however, he (Vionnet) brought out something else.
``Is your daughter in love with our friend?'' (unknown)

``Ah,'' (she)
she (Newsome) rather startlingly answered,
``I wish you'd find out!'' (she)

He (Vionnet) showed his (Vionnet) surprise.

``I? A stranger?'' (unknown)

``Oh you won't be a stranger--presently. You shall see her (daughter) quite, I assure you, as if you weren't.'' (him)

It remained for him (Vionnet) none the less an extraordinary notion.

``It seems to me surely that if her (daughter) mother can't--'' (she)

``Ah little girls and their mothers to-day!'' (she)
she (Newsome) rather inconsequently broke in. But she (Newsome) checked herself with something she (Newsome) seemed to give out as after all more to the point.
``Tell her (daughter) I've been good for him (stranger). Don't you think I have?'' (him)

It had its effect on him (Vionnet)--more than at the moment he (Vionnet) quite measured. Yet he (Vionnet) was consciously enough touched.

``Oh if it's all you--!'' (unknown)

``Well, it may not be `all,''' (she)
she (Newsome) interrupted,
``but it's to a great extent. Really and truly,'' (she)
she (Newsome) added in a tone that was to take its place with him (Vionnet) among things remembered.

``Then it's very wonderful.'' (He)
He (Vionnet) smiled at her (Newsome) from a face that he (Vionnet) felt as strained, and her (Newsome) own face for a moment kept him (Vionnet) so. At last she (Newsome) also got up.
``Well, don't you think that for that--'' (unknown)

``I ought to save you?'' (him)
So it was that the way to meet her (Newsome)--and the way, as well, in a manner, to get off--came over him (Vionnet). He (Vionnet) heard himself use the exorbitant word, the very sound of which helped to determine his (Vionnet) flight.
``I'll save you if I can.'' (Chad)

II

In Chad's lovely home, however, one evening ten days later, he (Vionnet) felt himself present at the collapse of the question of Jeanne de Vionnet's shy secret. He (Vionnet) had been dining there in the company of that young lady and her (lady) mother, as well as of other persons, and he (Vionnet) had gone into the petit salon, at Chad's request, on purpose to talk with her (lady). The young man had put this to him (man) as a favour--

``I should like so awfully to know what you think of her (daughter). It will really be a chance for you,'' (him)
he (man) had said,
``to see the jeune fille--I mean the type--as she (daughter) actually is, and I don't think that, as an observer of manners, it's a thing you ought to miss. It will be an impression that--whatever else you take--you can carry home with you, where you'll find again so much to compare it with.'' (he)

Strether knew well enough with what Chad wished him (Chad) to compare it, and though he (Chad) entirely assented he (Chad) hadn't yet somehow been so deeply reminded that he (Chad) was being, as he (Chad) constantly though mutely expressed it, used. He (Chad) was as far as ever from making out exactly to what end; but he (Chad) was none the less constantly accompanied by a sense of the service he (Chad) rendered. He (Chad) conceived only that this service was highly agreeable to those who profited by it; and he (Chad) was indeed still waiting for the moment at which he (Chad) should catch it in the act of proving disagreeable, proving in some degree intolerable, to himself. He (Chad) failed quite to see how his (Chad) situation could clear up at all logically except by some turn of events that would give him (Chad) the pretext of disgust. He (Chad) was building from day to day on the possibility of disgust, but each day brought forth meanwhile a new and more engaging bend of the road. That possibility was now ever so much further from sight than on the eve of his (Chad) arrival, and he (Chad) perfectly felt that, should it come at all, it would have to be at best inconsequent and violent. He (Chad) struck himself as a little nearer to it only when he (Chad) asked himself what service, in such a life of utility, he (Chad) was after all rendering Mrs. Newsome. When he (Chad) wished to help himself to believe that he (Chad) was still all right he (Chad) reflected--and in fact with wonder--on the unimpaired frequency of their correspondence; in relation to which what was after all more natural than that it should become more frequent just in proportion as their problem became more complicated?

Certain it is at any rate that he (Chad) now often brought himself balm by the question, with the rich consciousness of yesterday's letter,

``Well, what can I do more than that--what can I do more than tell her (daughter) everything?'' (he)
To persuade himself that he (Chad) did tell her (Newsome), had told her (Newsome), everything, he (Chad) used to try to think of particular things he (Chad) hadn't told her (Newsome). When at rare moments and in the watches of the night he (Chad) pounced on one it generally showed itself to be--to a deeper scrutiny--not quite truly of the essence. When anything new struck him (Chad) as coming up, or anything already noted as reappearing, he (Chad) always immediately wrote, as if for fear that if he (Chad) didn't he (Chad) would miss something; and also that he (Chad) might be able to say to himself from time to time
``She (daughter) knows it NOW--even while I worry.'' (he)
It was a great comfort to him (Chad) in general not to have left past things to be dragged to light and explained; not to have to produce at so late a stage anything not produced, or anything even veiled and attenuated, at the moment. She (Chad) knew it now: that was what he (Chad) said to himself to-night in relation to the fresh fact of Chad's acquaintance with the two ladies--not to speak of the fresher one of his (Chad) own. Mrs. Newsome knew in other words that very night at Woollett that he (Chad) himself knew Madame de Vionnet and that he (Chad) had conscientiously been to see her (Newsome); also that he (Chad) had found her (Newsome) remarkably attractive and that there would probably be a good deal more to tell. But she (Newsome) further knew, or would know very soon, that, again conscientiously, he (Chad) hadn't repeated his (Chad) visit; and that when Chad had asked him (Chad) on the Countess's behalf--Strether made her (Countess) out vividly, with a thought at the back of his (Strether) head, a Countess--if he (Strether) wouldn't name a day for dining with her (Countess), he (Strether) had replied lucidly:
``Thank you very much--impossible.'' (he)
He (Strether) had begged the young man would present his (Strether) excuses and had trusted him (Strether) to understand that it couldn't really strike one as quite the straight thing. He (Strether) hadn't reported to Mrs. Newsome that he (Strether) had promised to
``save'' (he)
Madame de Vionnet; but, so far as he (Vionnet) was concerned with that reminiscence, he (Vionnet) hadn't at any rate promised to haunt her (Newsome) house. What Chad had understood could only, in truth, be inferred from Chad's behaviour, which had been in this connexion as easy as in every other. He (Chad) was easy, always, when he (Chad) understood; he (Chad) was easier still, if possible, when he (Chad) didn't; he (Chad) had replied that he (Chad) would make it all right; and he (Chad) had proceeded to do this by substituting the present occasion--as he (Chad) was ready to substitute others--for any, for every occasion as to which his (Chad) old friend should have a funny scruple.

``Oh but I'm not a little foreign girl; I'm just as English as I can be,'' (Jeanne/Jeanne de Vionnet)
Jeanne de Vionnet had said to him (Chad) as soon as, in the petit salon, he (Chad) sank, shyly enough on his (Chad) own side, into the place near her (Vionnet) vacated by Madame Gloriani at his (Chad) approach. Madame Gloriani, who was in black velvet, with white lace and powdered hair, and whose somewhat massive majesty melted, at any contact, into the graciousness of some incomprehensible tongue, moved away to make room for the vague gentleman, after benevolent greetings to him (gentleman) which embodied, as he (gentleman) believed, in baffling accents, some recognition of his (gentleman) face from a couple of Sundays before. Then he (gentleman) had remarked--making the most of the advantage of his (gentleman) years--that it frightened him (gentleman) quite enough to find himself dedicated to the entertainment of a little foreign girl. There were girls he (gentleman) wasn't afraid of--he (gentleman) was quite bold with little Americans. Thus it was that she (girl) had defended herself to the end--
``Oh but I'm almost American too. That's what mamma has wanted me to be--I mean LIKE that; for she (girl) has wanted me to have lots of freedom. She (girl) has known such good results from it.'' (she)

She (girl) was fairly beautiful to him (gentleman)--a faint pastel in an oval frame: he (gentleman) thought of her (girl) already as of some lurking image in a long gallery, the portrait of a small old-time princess of whom nothing was known but that she (princess) had died young. Little Jeanne wasn't, doubtless, to die young, but one couldn't, all the same, bear on her (Jeanne) lightly enough. It was bearing hard, it was bearing as HE (gentleman), in any case, wouldn't bear, to concern himself, in relation to her (Jeanne), with the question of a young man. Odious really the question of a young man; one didn't treat such a person as a maid-servant suspected of a

``follower.'' (a person)
And then young men, young men--well, the thing was their business simply, or was at all events hers. She (Jeanne) was fluttered, fairly fevered--to the point of a little glitter that came and went in her (Jeanne) eyes and a pair of pink spots that stayed in her (Jeanne) cheeks--with the great adventure of dining out and with the greater one still, possibly, of finding a gentleman whom she (Jeanne) must think of as very, very old, a gentleman with eye-glasses, wrinkles, a long grizzled moustache. She (Jeanne) spoke the prettiest English, our friend thought, that he (friend) had ever heard spoken, just as he (friend) had believed her (Jeanne) a few minutes before to be speaking the prettiest French. He (friend) wondered almost wistfully if such a sweep of the lyre didn't react on the spirit itself; and his (friend) fancy had in fact, before he (friend) knew it, begun so to stray and embroider that he (friend) finally found himself, absent and extravagant, sitting with the child in a friendly silence. Only by this time he (friend) felt her (Jeanne) flutter to have fortunately dropped and that she (Jeanne) was more at her (Jeanne) ease. She (Jeanne) trusted him (friend), liked him (friend), and it was to come back to him (friend) afterwards that she (Jeanne) had told him (friend) things. She (Jeanne) had dipped into the waiting medium at last and found neither surge nor chill--nothing but the small splash she (Jeanne) could herself make in the pleasant warmth, nothing but the safety of dipping and dipping again. At the end of the ten minutes he (friend) was to spend with her (Jeanne) his (friend) impression--with all it had thrown off and all it had taken in--was complete. She (Jeanne) had been free, as she (Jeanne) knew freedom, partly to show him (friend) that, unlike other little persons she (Jeanne) knew, she (Jeanne) had imbibed that ideal. She (Jeanne) was delightfully quaint about herself, but the vision of what she (Jeanne) had imbibed was what most held him (friend). It really consisted, he (friend) was soon enough to feel, in just one great little matter, the fact that, whatever her (Jeanne) nature, she (Jeanne) was thoroughly--he (friend) had to cast about for the word, but it came--bred. He (friend) couldn't of course on so short an acquaintance speak for her (Jeanne) nature, but the idea of breeding was what she (Jeanne) had meanwhile dropped into his (friend) mind. He (friend) had never yet known it so sharply presented. Her (Jeanne) mother gave it, no doubt; but her (Jeanne) mother, to make that less sensible, gave so much else besides, and on neither of the two previous occasions, extraordinary woman, Strether felt, anything like what she (woman) was giving tonight. Little Jeanne was a case, an exquisite case of education; whereas the Countess, whom it so amused him (Strether) to think of by that denomination, was a case, also exquisite, of--well, he (Strether) didn't know what.

``He (follower) has wonderful taste, notre jeune homme'' (Gloriani/Madame Gloriani)
: this was what Gloriani said to him (Strether) on turning away from the inspection of a small picture suspended near the door of the room. The high celebrity in question had just come in, apparently in search of Mademoiselle de Vionnet, but while Strether had got up from beside her (Countess) their fellow guest, with his (Strether) eye sharply caught, had paused for a long look. The thing was a landscape, of no size, but of the French school, as our friend was glad to feel he (friend) knew, and also of a quality--which he (friend) liked to think he (friend) should also have guessed; its frame was large out of proportion to the canvas, and he (friend) had never seen a person look at anything, he (friend) thought, just as Gloriani, with his (friend) nose very near and quick movements of the head from side to side and bottom to top, examined this feature of Chad's collection. The artist used that word the next moment smiling courteously, wiping his (artist) nippers and looking round him (artist) further--paying the place in short by the very manner of his (artist) presence and by something Strether fancied he (Strether) could make out in this particular glance, such a tribute as, to the latter's sense, settled many things once for all. Strether was conscious at this instant, for that matter, as he (Strether) hadn't yet been, of how, round about him (Strether), quite without him (Strether), they WERE consistently settled. Gloriani's smile, deeply Italian, he (Strether) considered, and finely inscrutable, had had for him (Strether), during dinner, at which they were not neighbours, an indefinite greeting; but the quality in it was gone that had appeared on the other occasion to turn him (Strether) inside out; it was as if even the momentary link supplied by the doubt between them had snapped. He (Strether) was conscious now of the final reality, which was that there wasn't so much a doubt as a difference altogether; all the more that over the difference the famous sculptor seemed to signal almost condolingly, yet oh how vacantly! as across some great flat sheet of water. He (sculptor) threw out the bridge of a charming hollow civility on which Strether wouldn't have trusted his (Strether) own full weight a moment. That idea, even though but transient and perhaps belated, had performed the office of putting Strether more at his (Strether) ease, and the blurred picture had already dropped--dropped with the sound of something else said and with his (Strether) becoming aware, by another quick turn, that Gloriani was now on the sofa talking with Jeanne, while he (Strether) himself had in his (Strether) ears again the familiar friendliness and the elusive meaning of the
``Oh, oh, oh!'' (he)
that had made him (Strether), a fortnight before, challenge Miss Barrace in vain. She (Jeanne) had always the air, this picturesque and original lady, who struck him (Strether), so oddly, as both antique and modern--she (Jeanne) had always the air of taking up some joke that one had already had out with her (Jeanne). The point itself, no doubt, was what was antique, and the use she (Jeanne) made of it what was modern. He (Strether) felt just now that her (Jeanne) good-natured irony did bear on something, and it troubled him (Strether) a little that she (Jeanne) wouldn't be more explicit only assuring him (Strether), with the pleasure of observation so visible in her (Jeanne), that she (Jeanne) wouldn't tell him (Strether) more for the world. He (Strether) could take refuge but in asking her (Jeanne) what she (Jeanne) had done with Waymarsh, though it must be added that he (Strether) felt himself a little on the way to a clue after she (Jeanne) had answered that this personage was, in the other room, engaged in conversation with Madame de Vionnet. He (Vionnet) stared a moment at the image of such a conjunction; then, for Miss Barrace's benefit, he (Vionnet) wondered.
``Is she (girl) too then under the charm--?'' (unknown)

``No, not a bit'' (unknown)
--Miss Barrace was prompt.
``She (girl) makes nothing of him (follower). She (girl)'s bored. She (girl) won't help you with him (follower).'' (unknown)

``Oh,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether laughed, ``she (girl) can't do everything.

``Of course not--wonderful as she (girl) is. Besides, he (follower) makes nothing of HER. She (girl) won't take him (follower) from me--though she (girl) wouldn't, no doubt, having other affairs in hand, even if she (girl) could. I've never,'' (Miss Barrace)
said Miss Barrace,
``seen her (girl) fail with any one before. And to-night, when she (girl)'s so magnificent, it would seem to her (girl) strange--if she (girl) minded. So at any rate I have him (follower) all. Je suis tranquille!'' (Miss Barrace)

Strether understood, so far as that went; but he (Strether) was feeling for his (Strether) clue.

``She (girl) strikes you to-night as particularly magnificent?'' (unknown)

``Surely. Almost as I've never seen her (girl). Doesn't she (girl) you? Why it's FOR you.'' (He)

He (Strether) persisted in his (Strether) candour.

''`For' me--?'' (He)

``Oh, oh, oh!'' (unknown)
cried Miss Barrace, who persisted in the opposite of that quality.

``Well,'' (he)
he (Strether) acutely admitted,
``she (girl) IS different. She (girl)'s gay.'' (he)

``She (girl)'s gay!'' (unknown)
Miss Barrace laughed.
``And she (girl) has beautiful shoulders--though there's nothing different in that.'' (unknown)

``No,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
said Strether,
``one was sure of her (girl) shoulders. It isn't her (girl) shoulders.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

His (Strether) companion, with renewed mirth and the finest sense, between the puffs of her (Barrace) cigarette, of the drollery of things, appeared to find their conversation highly delightful.

``Yes, it isn't her (girl) shoulders .'' (unknown)

``What then is it?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether earnestly enquired.

``Why, it's SHE--simply. It's her (girl) mood. It's her (girl) charm.'' (unknown)

``Of course it's her (girl) charm, but we're speaking of the difference.'' (unknown)
``Well,'' (Miss Barrace)
Miss Barrace explained,
``she (girl)'s just brilliant, as we used to say. That's all. She (girl)'s various. She (girl)'s fifty women.'' (Miss Barrace)

``Ah but only one'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
--Strether kept it clear--
``at a time.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

``Perhaps. But in fifty times--!'' (unknown)

``Oh we shan't come to that,'' (friend)
our friend declared; and the next moment he (Strether) had moved in another direction.
``Will you answer me a plain question? Will she (girl) ever divorce?'' (him)

Miss Barrace looked at him (Strether) through all her (Barrace) tortoise-shell.

``Why should she (girl)?'' (he)

It wasn't what he (Strether) had asked for, he (Strether) signified; but he (Strether) met it well enough.

``To marry Chad.'' (unknown)

``Why should she (girl) marry Chad?'' (unknown)

``Because I'm convinced she (girl)'s very fond of him (Chad). She (girl) has done wonders for him (Chad).'' (unknown)

``Well then, how could she (girl) do more? Marrying a man, or woman either,'' (unknown)
Miss Barrace sagely went on,
``is never the wonder for any Jack and Jill can bring THAT off. The wonder is their doing such things without marrying.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether considered a moment this proposition.

``You mean it's so beautiful for our friends simply to go on so?'' (he)

But whatever he (Strether) said made her (Barrace) laugh.

``Beautiful.'' (He)

He (Strether) nevertheless insisted.

``And THAT because it's disinterested?'' (She)
