She (Barrace) was now, however, suddenly tired of the question.

``Yes then--call it that. Besides, she (Jill)'ll never divorce. Don't, moreover,'' (she)
she (Barrace) added,
``believe everything you hear about her (Jill) husband.'' (she)

``He (husband)'s not then,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether asked,
``a wretch?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

``Oh yes. But charming.'' (unknown)

``Do you know him (husband)?'' (unknown)

``I've met him (husband). He (husband)'s bien aimable.'' (unknown)

``To every one but his (husband) wife?'' (unknown)

``Oh for all I know, to her (wife) too--to any, to every woman. I hope you at any rate,'' (she)
she (Barrace) pursued with a quick change,
``appreciate the care I take of Mr. Waymarsh.'' (she)

``Oh immensely.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
But Strether was not yet in line.
``At all events,'' (he)
he (Strether) roundly brought out,
``the attachment's an innocent one.'' (he)

``Mine and his (Waymarsh)? Ah,'' (she)
she (Barrace) laughed,
``don't rob it of ALL interest!'' (she)

``I mean our friend's here--to the lady we've been speaking of.'' (he)
That was what he (Strether) had settled to as an indirect but none the less closely involved consequence of his (Strether) impression of Jeanne. That was where he (Strether) meant to stay.
``It's innocent,'' (he)
he (Strether) repeated--
``I see the whole thing.'' (he)

Mystified by his (Strether) abrupt declaration, she (Jeanne) had glanced over at Gloriani as at the unnamed subject of his (Strether) allusion, but the next moment she (Jeanne) had understood; though indeed not before Strether had noticed her (Jeanne) momentary mistake and wondered what might possibly be behind that too. He (Strether) already knew that the sculptor admired Madame de Vionnet; but did this admiration also represent an attachment of which the innocence was discussable? He (Vionnet) was moving verily in a strange air and on ground not of the firmest. He (Vionnet) looked hard for an instant at Miss Barrace, but she (Jeanne) had already gone on.

``All right with Mr. Newsome? Why of course she (lady) is!'' (she)
--and she (Jeanne) got gaily back to the question of her (Jeanne) own good friend.
``I dare say you're surprised that I'm not worn out with all I see--it being so much!--of Sitting Bull. But I'm not, you know--I don't mind him (Newsome); I bear up, and we get on beautifully. I'm very strange; I'm like that; and often I can't explain. There are people who are supposed interesting or remarkable or whatever, and who bore me to death; and then there are others as to whom nobody can understand what anybody sees in them--in whom I see no end of things.'' (she)
Then after she (Jeanne) had smoked a moment,
``He (Newsome)'s touching, you know,'' (she)
she (Jeanne) said.

''`Know'?'' (she)
Strether echoed--
``don't I, indeed? We must move you almost to tears.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

``Oh but I don't mean YOU!'' (she)
she (Jeanne) laughed.

``You ought to then, for the worst sign of all--as I must have it for you--is that you can't help me. That's when a woman pities.'' (unknown)

``Ah but I do help you!'' (she)
she (Jeanne) cheerfully insisted.

Again he (Strether) looked at her (Jeanne) hard, and then after a pause:

``No you don't!'' (he)

Her (Jeanne) tortoise-shell, on its long chain, rattled down.

``I help you with Sitting Bull. That's a good deal.'' (unknown)

``Oh that, yes.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
But Strether hesitated.
``Do you mean he (you) talks of me?'' (unknown)

``So that I have to defend you? No, never.'' (unknown)

``I see,'' (Strether)
Strether mused.
``It's too deep.'' (unknown)

``That's his (you) only fault,'' (she)
she (Jeanne) returned--
``that everything, with him (you), is too deep. He (you) has depths of silence--which he (you) breaks only at the longest intervals by a remark. And when the remark comes it's always something he (you) has seen or felt for himself--never a bit banal THAT would be what one might have feared and what would kill me But never.'' (she)
She (Jeanne) smoked again as she (Jeanne) thus, with amused complacency, appreciated her (Jeanne) acquisition.
``And never about you. We keep clear of you. We're wonderful. But I'll tell you what he (you) does do,'' (she)
she (Jeanne) continued:
``he (you) tries to make me presents.'' (she)

``Presents?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
poor Strether echoed, conscious with a pang that HE (Strether) hadn't yet tried that in any quarter.

``Why you see,'' (she)
she (Jeanne) explained,
``he (you)'s as fine as ever in the victoria; so that when I leave him (you), as I often do almost for hours--he (you) likes it so--at the doors of shops, the sight of him (you) there helps me, when I come out, to know my carriage away off in the rank. But sometimes, for a change, he (you) goes with me into the shops, and then I've all I can do to prevent his (you) buying me things.'' (she)

``He (you) wants to `treat' you?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether almost gasped at all he (Strether) himself hadn't thought of. He (Strether) had a sense of admiration.
``Oh he (you)'s much more in the real tradition than I. Yes,'' (he)
he (Strether) mused,
``it's the sacred rage.'' (he)

``The sacred rage, exactly!'' (Miss Barrace)
--and Miss Barrace, who hadn't before heard this term applied, recognised its bearing with a clap of her (Barrace) gemmed hands.
``Now I do know why he (you)'s not banal. But I do prevent him (you) all the same--and if you saw what he (you) sometimes selects--from buying. I save him (you) hundreds and hundreds. I only take flowers.'' (unknown)

``Flowers?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether echoed again with a rueful reflexion. How many nosegays had her (Barrace) present converser sent?

``Innocent flowers,'' (she)
she (Barrace) pursued,
``as much as he (you) likes. And he (you) sends me splendours; he (you) knows all the best places--he (you) has found them for himself; he (you)'s wonderful.'' (she)

``He (you) hasn't told them to me,'' (friend)
her (Barrace) friend smiled,
``he (you) has a life of his (you) own.'' (friend)
But Strether had swung back to the consciousness that for himself after all it never would have done. Waymarsh hadn't Mrs. Waymarsh in the least to consider, whereas Lambert Strether had constantly, in the inmost honour of his (Strether) thoughts, to consider Mrs. Newsome. He (Strether) liked moreover to feel how much his (Strether) friend was in the real tradition. Yet he (Strether) had his (Strether) conclusion.
``WHAT a rage it is!'' (He)
He (Strether) had worked it out.
``It's an opposition.'' (She)

She (Newsome) followed, but at a distance.

``That's what I feel. Yet to what?'' (unknown)

``Well, he (you) thinks, you know, that I

``VE a life of my own. And I haven't!'' (unknown)

``You haven't?'' (She)
She (Newsome) showed doubt, and her (Newsome) laugh confirmed it.
``Oh, oh, oh!'' (unknown)

``No--not for myself. I seem to have a life only for other people.'' (unknown)

``Ah for them and WITH them! Just now for instance with--'' (he)

``Well, with whom?'' (he)
he (Strether) asked before she (Newsome) had had time to say.

His (Strether) tone had the effect of making her (Newsome) hesitate and even, as he (Strether) guessed, speak with a difference.

``Say with Miss Gostrey. What do you do for HER?'' (him)
It really made him (Strether) wonder.
``Nothing at all!'' (Madame de Vionnet/Vionnet/de Vionnet)

III

Madame de Vionnet, having meanwhile come in, was at present close to them, and Miss Barrace hereupon, instead of risking a rejoinder, became again with a look that measured her (Newsome) from top to toe all mere long-handled appreciative tortoise-shell. She (Newsome) had struck our friend, from the first of her (Newsome) appearing, as dressed for a great occasion, and she (Newsome) met still more than on either of the others the conception reawakened in him (friend) at their garden-party, the idea of the femme du monde in her (Newsome) habit as she (Newsome) lived. Her (Newsome) bare shoulders and arms were white and beautiful; the materials of her (Newsome) dress, a mixture, as he (friend) supposed, of silk and crape, were of a silvery grey so artfully composed as to give an impression of warm splendour; and round her (Newsome) neck she (Newsome) wore a collar of large old emeralds, the green note of which was more dimly repeated, at other points of her (Newsome) apparel, in embroidery, in enamel, in satin, in substances and textures vaguely rich. Her (Newsome) head, extremely fair and exquisitely festal, was like a happy fancy, a notion of the antique, on an old precious medal, some silver coin of the Renaissance; while her (Newsome) slim lightness and brightness, her (Newsome) gaiety, her (Newsome) expression, her (Newsome) decision, contributed to an effect that might have been felt by a poet as half mythological and half conventional. He (poet) could have compared her (Newsome) to a goddess still partly engaged in a morning cloud, or to a sea-nymph waist-high in the summer surge. Above all she (Newsome) suggested to him (poet) the reflexion that the femme du monde--in these finest developments of the type--was, like Cleopatra in the play, indeed various and multifold. She (Cleopatra) had aspects, characters, days, nights--or had them at least, showed them by a mysterious law of her (Cleopatra) own, when in addition to everything she (Cleopatra) happened also to be a woman of genius. She (Cleopatra) was an obscure person, a muffled person one day, and a showy person, an uncovered person the next. He (genius) thought of Madame de Vionnet to-night as showy and uncovered, though he (genius) felt the formula rough, because, thanks to one of the short-cuts of genius she (Cleopatra) had taken all his (genius) categories by surprise. Twice during dinner he (genius) had met Chad's eyes in a longish look; but these communications had in truth only stirred up again old ambiguities--so little was it clear from them whether they were an appeal or an admonition.

``You see how I'm fixed,'' (he)
was what they appeared to convey; yet how he (genius) was fixed was exactly what Strether didn't see. However, perhaps he (Strether) should see now.

``Are you capable of the very great kindness of going to relieve Newsome, for a few minutes, of the rather crushing responsibility of Madame Gloriani, while I say a word, if he (Newsome)'ll allow me, to Mr. Strether, of whom I've a question to ask? Our host ought to talk a bit to those other ladies, and I'll come back in a minute to your rescue.'' (She)
She (Cleopatra) made this proposal to Miss Barrace as if her (Cleopatra) consciousness of a special duty had just flickered-up, but that lady's recognition of Strether's little start at it--as at a betrayal on the speaker's part of a domesticated state--was as mute as his (speaker) own comment; and after an instant, when their fellow guest had good-naturedly left them, he (guest) had been given something else to think of.
``Why has Maria so suddenly gone? Do you know?'' (Madame de Vionnet/Vionnet/de Vionnet)
That was the question Madame de Vionnet had brought with her (Cleopatra).

``I'm afraid I've no reason to give you but the simple reason I've had from her (Maria) in a note--the sudden obligation to join in the south a sick friend who has got worse.'' (unknown)

``Ah then she (Maria) has been writing you?'' (unknown)

``Not since she (Maria) went--I had only a brief explanatory word before she (Maria) started. I went to see her (Maria),'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether explained--
``it was the day after I called on you--but she (Maria) was already on her (Maria) way, and her (Maria) concierge told me that in case of my coming I was to be informed she (Maria) had written to me. I found her (Maria) note when I got home.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Madame de Vionnet listened with interest and with her (Cleopatra) eyes on Strether's face; then her (Cleopatra) delicately decorated head had a small melancholy motion.

``She (Maria) didn't write to ME. I went to see her (Maria),'' (she)
she (Cleopatra) added,
``almost immediately after I had seen you, and as I assured her (Maria) I would do when I met her (Maria) at Gloriani's. She (Maria) hadn't then told me she (Maria) was to be absent, and I felt at her (Maria) door as if I understood. She (Maria)'s absent--with all respect to her (Maria) sick friend, though I know indeed she (Maria) has plenty--so that I may not see her (Maria). She (Maria) doesn't want to meet me again. Well,'' (she)
she (Cleopatra) continued with a beautiful conscious mildness,
``I liked and admired her (Maria) beyond every one in the old time, and she (Maria) knew it--perhaps that's precisely what has made her (Maria) go--and I dare say I haven't lost her (Maria) for ever.'' (she)
Strether still said nothing; he (Strether) had a horror, as he (Strether) now thought of himself, of being in question between women--was in fact already quite enough on his (Strether) way to that, and there was moreover, as it came to him (Strether), perceptibly, something behind these allusions and professions that, should he (Strether) take it in, would square but ill with his (Strether) present resolve to simplify. It was as if, for him (Strether), all the same, her (Cleopatra) softness and sadness were sincere. He (Strether) felt that not less when she (Cleopatra) soon went on:
``I'm extremely glad of her (Maria) happiness.'' (she)
But it also left him (Strether) mute--sharp and fine though the imputation it conveyed. What it conveyed was that HE (Strether) was Maria Gostrey's happiness, and for the least little instant he (Strether) had the impulse to challenge the thought. He (Strether) could have done so however only by saying
``What then do you suppose to be between us?'' (He)
and he (Strether) was wonderfully glad a moment later not to have spoken. He (Strether) would rather seem stupid any day than fatuous, and he (Strether) drew back as well, with a smothered inward shudder, from the consideration of what women--of highly-developed type in particular--might think of each other. Whatever he (Strether) had come out for he (Strether) hadn't come to go into that; so that he (Strether) absolutely took up nothing his (Strether) interlocutress had now let drop. Yet, though he (Strether) had kept away from her (Strether) for days, had laid wholly on herself the burden of their meeting again, she (Strether) hadn't a gleam of irritation to show him (Strether).
``Well, about Jeanne now?'' (she)
she (Strether) smiled--it had the gaiety with which she (Strether) had originally come in. He (Strether) felt it on the instant to represent her (Strether) motive and real errand. But he (Strether) had been schooling her (Strether) of a truth to say much in proportion to his (Strether) little.
``Do you make out that she (Jeanne) has a sentiment? I mean for Mr. Newsome.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Almost resentful, Strether could at last be prompt.

``How can I make out such things?'' (She)

She (Strether) remained perfectly good-natured.

``Ah but they're beautiful little things, and you make out--don't pretend--everything in the world. Haven't you,'' (she)
she (Strether) asked,
``been talking with her (Jeanne)?'' (she)

``Yes, but not about Chad. At least not much.'' (unknown)

``Oh you don't require `much'!'' (she)
she (Strether) reassuringly declared. But she (Strether) immediately changed her (Strether) ground.
``I hope you remember your promise of the other day.'' (unknown)

``To `save' you, as you called it?'' (unknown)

``I call it so still. You WILL?'' (she)
she (Strether) insisted.
``You haven't repented?'' (He)

He (Strether) wondered.

``No--but I've been thinking what I meant.'' (She)

She (Strether) kept it up.

``And not, a little, what I did?'' (unknown)

``No--that's not necessary. It will be enough if I know what I meant myself.'' (unknown)

``And don't you know,'' (she)
she (Strether) asked,
``by this time?'' (she)

Again he (Strether) had a pause.

``I think you ought to leave it to me. But how long,'' (he)
he (Strether) added,
``do you give me?'' (he)

``It seems to me much more a question of how long you give ME. Doesn't our friend here himself, at any rate,'' (she)
she (Strether) went on,
``perpetually make me present to you?'' (she)

``Not,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether replied,
``by ever speaking of you to me.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

``He (friend) never does that?'' (unknown)

``Never.'' (She)

She (Strether) considered, and, if the fact was disconcerting to her (Strether), effectually concealed it. The next minute indeed she (Strether) had recovered.

``No, he (friend) wouldn't. But do you NEED that?'' (he)

Her (Strether) emphasis was wonderful, and though his (Strether) eyes had been wandering he (Strether) looked at her (Strether) longer now.

``I see what you mean.'' (unknown)

``Of course you see what I mean.'' (she)

Her (Strether) triumph was gentle, and she (Strether) really had tones to make justice weep.

``I've before me what he (friend) owes you.'' (unknown)

``Admit then that that's something,'' (she)
she (Strether) said, yet still with the same discretion in her (Strether) pride.

He (Strether) took in this note but went straight on.

``You've made of him (friend) what I see, but what I don't see is how in the world you've done it.'' (unknown)

``Ah that's another question!'' (she)
she (Strether) smiled.
``The point is of what use is your declining to know me when to know Mr. Newsome--as you do me the honour to find him (Newsome)--IS just to know me.'' (unknown)

``I see,'' (he)
he (Strether) mused, still with his (Strether) eyes on her (Strether).
``I shouldn't have met you to-night.'' (She)

She (Strether) raised and dropped her (Strether) linked hands.

``It doesn't matter. If I trust you why can't you a little trust me too? And why can't you also,'' (she)
she (Strether) asked in another tone,
``trust yourself?'' (she)
But she (Strether) gave him (Strether) no time to reply.
``Oh I shall be so easy for you! And I'm glad at any rate you've seen my child.'' (unknown)

``I'm glad too,'' (he)
he (Strether) said;
``but she (me) does you no good.'' (he)

``No good?'' (Madame de Vionnet/Vionnet/de Vionnet)
--Madame de Vionnet had a clear stare.
``Why she (me)'s an angel of light.'' (unknown)

``That's precisely the reason. Leave her (me) alone. Don't try to find out. I mean,'' (he)
he (Vionnet) explained,
``about what you spoke to me of--the way she (me) feels.'' (he)

His (Vionnet) companion wondered.

``Because one really won't?'' (unknown)

``Well, because I ask you, as a favour to myself, not to. She (me)'s the most charming creature I've ever seen. Therefore don't touch her (me). Don't know--don't want to know. And moreover--yes--you won't.'' (she)

It was an appeal, of a sudden, and she (Strether) took it in.

``As a favour to you?'' (unknown)

``Well--since you ask me.'' (unknown)

``Anything, everything you ask,'' (she)
she (Strether) smiled.
``I shan't know then--never. Thank you,'' (she)
she (Strether) added with peculiar gentleness as she (Strether) turned away.

The sound of it lingered with him (Vionnet), making him (Vionnet) fairly feel as if he (Vionnet) had been tripped up and had a fall. In the very act of arranging with her (Strether) for his (Vionnet) independence he (Vionnet) had, under pressure from a particular perception, inconsistently, quite stupidly, committed himself, and, with her (Strether) subtlety sensitive on the spot to an advantage, she (Strether) had driven in by a single word a little golden nail, the sharp intention of which he (nail) signally felt. He (nail) hadn't detached, he (nail) had more closely connected himself, and his (nail) eyes, as he (nail) considered with some intensity this circumstance, met another pair which had just come within their range and which struck him (nail) as reflecting his (nail) sense of what he (nail) had done. He (nail) recognised them at the same moment as those of little Bilham, who had apparently drawn near on purpose to speak to him (Bilham), and little Bilham wasn't, in the conditions, the person to whom his (Bilham) heart would be most closed. They were seated together a minute later at the angle of the room obliquely opposite the corner in which Gloriani was still engaged with Jeanne de Vionnet, to whom at first and in silence their attention had been benevolently given.

``I can't see for my life,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether had then observed,
``how a young fellow of any spirit--such a one as you for instance--can be admitted to the sight of that young lady without being hard hit. Why don't you go in, little Bilham?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
He (Strether) remembered the tone into which he (Strether) had been betrayed on the garden-bench at the sculptor's reception, and this might make up for that by being much more the right sort of thing to say to a young man worthy of any advice at all.
``There WOULD be some reason.'' (unknown)

``Some reason for what?'' (unknown)

``Why for hanging on here.'' (unknown)

``To offer my hand and fortune to Mademoiselle de Vionnet?'' (unknown)

``Well,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether asked,
``to what lovelier apparition COULD you offer them? She (lady)'s the sweetest little thing I've ever seen.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

``She (lady)'s certainly immense. I mean she (lady)'s the real thing. I believe the pale pink petals are folded up there for some wondrous efflorescence in time; to open, that is, to some great golden sun. I

``M unfortunately but a small farthing candle. What chance in such a field for a poor little painter-man?'' (unknown)

``Oh you're good enough,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether threw out.

``Certainly I'm good enough. We're good enough, I consider, nous autres, for anything. But she (lady)'s TOO good. There's the difference. They wouldn't look at me.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether, lounging on his (Strether) divan and still charmed by the young girl, whose eyes had consciously strayed to him (Strether), he (Strether) fancied, with a vague smile--Strether, enjoying the whole occasion as with dormant pulses at last awake and in spite of new material thrust upon him (Strether), thought over his (Strether) companion's words.

``Whom do you mean by `they'? She (lady) and her (lady) mother?'' (unknown)

``She (lady) and her (lady) mother. And she (lady) has a father too, who, whatever else he (father) may be, certainly can't be indifferent to the possibilities she (lady) represents. Besides, there's Chad.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether was silent a little.

``Ah but he (Chad) doesn't care for her (lady)--not, I mean, it appears, after all, in the sense I'm speaking of. He (Chad)'s NOT in love with her (lady).'' (unknown)

``No--but he (Chad)'s her (lady) best friend; after her (lady) mother. He (Chad)'s very fond of her (lady). He (Chad) has his (Chad) ideas about what can be done for her (lady).'' (unknown)

``Well, it's very strange!'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether presently remarked with a sighing sense of fulness.

``Very strange indeed. That's just the beauty of it. Isn't it very much the kind of beauty you had in mind,'' (Bilham/Mr. Bilham)
little Bilham went on,
``when you were so wonderful and so inspiring to me the other day? Didn't you adjure me, in accents I shall never forget, to see, while I've a chance, everything I can?--and REALLY to see, for it must have been that only you meant. Well, you did me no end of good, and I'm doing my best. I DO make it out a situation.'' (Bilham/Mr. Bilham)

``So do I!'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether went on after a moment. But he (Strether) had the next minute an inconsequent question.
``How comes Chad so mixed up, anyway?'' (unknown)

``Ah, ah, ah!'' (Bilham/Mr. Bilham)
--and little Bilham fell back on his (Bilham) cushions.

It reminded our friend of Miss Barrace, and he (Bilham) felt again the brush of his (Bilham) sense of moving in a maze of mystic closed allusions. Yet he (Bilham) kept hold of his (Bilham) thread.

``Of course I understand really; only the general transformation makes me occasionally gasp. Chad with such a voice in the settlement of the future of a little countess--no,'' (he)
he (Bilham) declared,
``it takes more time! You say moreover,'' (he)
he (Bilham) resumed,
``that we're inevitably, people like you and me, out of the running. The curious fact remains that Chad himself isn't. The situation doesn't make for it, but in a different one he (Chad) could have her (countess) if he (Chad) would.'' (he)

``Yes, but that's only because he (Chad)'s rich and because there's a possibility of his (Chad) being richer. They won't think of anything but a great name or a great fortune.'' (unknown)

``Well,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
said Strether,
``he (Chad)'ll have no great fortune on THESE lines. He (Chad) must stir his (Chad) stumps.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

``Is that,'' (Bilham/Mr. Bilham)
little Bilham enquired,
``what you were saying to Madame de Vionnet?'' (Bilham/Mr. Bilham)

``No--I don't say much to her (countess). Of course, however,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether continued,
``he (Vionnet) can make sacrifices if he (Vionnet) likes.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Little Bilham had a pause.

``Oh he (Vionnet)'s not keen for sacrifices; or thinks, that is, possibly, that he (Vionnet) has made enough.'' (unknown)

``Well, it IS virtuous,'' (companion)
his (Bilham) companion observed with some decision.

``That's exactly,'' (the man)
the young man dropped after a moment,
``what I mean.'' (the man)

It kept Strether himself silent a little.

``I've made it out for myself,'' (he)
he (Strether) then went on;
``I've really, within the last half-hour, got hold of it. I understand it in short at last; which at first--when you originally spoke to me--I didn't. Nor when Chad originally spoke to me either.'' (he)

``Oh,'' (Bilham/Mr. Bilham)
said little Bilham,
``I don't think that at that time you believed me.'' (Bilham/Mr. Bilham)

``Yes--I did; and I believed Chad too. It would have been odious and unmannerly--as well as quite perverse--if I hadn't. What interest have you in deceiving me?'' (The man)

The young man cast about.

``What interest have I?'' (unknown)

``Yes. Chad MIGHT have. But you?'' (unknown)

``Ah, ah, ah!'' (Bilham/Mr. Bilham)
little Bilham exclaimed.

It might, on repetition, as a mystification, have irritated our friend a little, but he (friend) knew, once more, as we have seen, where he (friend) was, and his (friend) being proof against everything was only another attestation that he (friend) meant to stay there.

``I couldn't, without my own impression, realise. She (I)'s a tremendously clever brilliant capable woman, and with an extraordinary charm on top of it all--the charm we surely all of us this evening know what to think of. It isn't every clever brilliant capable woman that has it. In fact it's rare with any woman. So there you are,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether proceeded as if not for little Bilham's benefit alone.
``I understand what a relation with such a woman--what such a high fine friendship--may be. It can't be vulgar or coarse, anyway--and that's the point.'' (unknown)

``Yes, that's the point,'' (Bilham/Mr. Bilham)
said little Bilham.
``It can't be vulgar or coarse. And, bless us and save us, it ISn't! It's, upon my word, the very finest thing I ever saw in my life, and the most distinguished.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether, from beside him (Bilham) and leaning back with him (Bilham) as he (Bilham) leaned, dropped on him (Bilham) a momentary look which filled a short interval and of which he (Bilham) took no notice. He (Bilham) only gazed before him (Bilham) with intent participation.

``Of course what it has done for him (woman),'' (Strether)
Strether at all events presently pursued,
``of course what it has done for him (woman)--that is as to HOW it has so wonderfully worked--isn't a thing I pretend to understand. I've to take it as I find it. There he (woman) is.'' (Strether)

``There he (woman) is!'' (Bilham/Mr. Bilham)
little Bilham echoed.
``And it's really and truly she (it). I don't understand either, even with my longer and closer opportunity. But I'm like you,'' (he)
he (Bilham) added;
``I can admire and rejoice even when I'm a little in the dark. You see I've watched it for some three years, and especially for this last. He (woman) wasn't so bad before it as I seem to have made out that you think--'' (he)

``Oh I don't think anything now!'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether impatiently broke in:
``that is but what I DO think! I mean that originally, for her (it) to have cared for him (woman)--'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

``There must have been stuff in him (woman)? Oh yes, there was stuff indeed, and much more of it than ever showed, I dare say, at home. Still, you know,'' (the man)
the young man in all fairness developed,
``there was room for her (it), and that's where she (it) came in. She (it) saw her (it) chance and took it. That's what strikes me as having been so fine. But of course,'' (the man)
he (Strether) wound up,
``he (woman) liked her (it) first.'' (he)

``Naturally,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
said Strether.

``I mean that they first met somehow and somewhere--I believe in some American house--and she (it), without in the least then intending it, made her (it) impression. Then with time and opportunity he (woman) made his (woman); and after THAT she (it) was as bad as he (woman).'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether vaguely took it up.

``As `bad'?'' (unknown)

``She (it) began, that is, to care--to care very much. Alone, and in her (it) horrid position, she (it) found it, when once she (it) had started, an interest. It was, it is, an interest, and it did--it continues to do--a lot for herself as well. So she (it) still cares. She (it) cares in fact,'' (Bilham/Mr. Bilham)
said little Bilham thoughtfully
``more.'' (Bilham/Mr. Bilham)

Strether's theory that it was none of his (Strether) business was somehow not damaged by the way he (Strether) took this.

``More, you mean, than he (woman)?'' (companion)
On which his (Strether) companion looked round at him (Strether), and now for an instant their eyes met.
``More than he (woman)?'' (he)
he (Strether) repeated.

Little Bilham, for as long, hung fire.

``Will you never tell any one?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether thought.

``Whom should I tell?'' (unknown)

``Why I supposed you reported regularly--'' (unknown)

``To people at home?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
--Strether took him (Strether) up.
``Well, I won't tell them this.'' (The man)

The young man at last looked away.

``Then she (it) does now care more than he (woman).'' (unknown)

``Oh!'' (Strether)
Strether oddly exclaimed.

But his (Strether) companion immediately met it.

``Haven't you after all had your impression of it? That's how you've got hold of him (woman).'' (unknown)

``Ah but I haven't got hold of him (woman)!'' (unknown)

``Oh I say!'' (Bilham/Mr. Bilham)
But it was all little Bilham said.

``It's at any rate none of my business. I mean,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether explained,
``nothing else than getting hold of him (woman) is.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
It appeared, however, to strike him (Strether) as his (Strether) business to add:
``The fact remains nevertheless that she (it) has saved him (woman).'' (him)

Little Bilham just waited.

``I thought that was what you were to do.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

But Strether had his (Strether) answer ready.

``I'm speaking--in connexion with her (it)--of his (woman) manners and morals, his (woman) character and life. I'm speaking of him (woman) as a person to deal with and talk with and live with--speaking of him (woman) as a social animal.'' (unknown)

``And isn't it as a social animal that you also want him (woman)?'' (unknown)

``Certainly; so that it's as if she (it) had saved him (woman) FOR us.'' (unknown)

``It strikes you accordingly then,'' (the man)
the young man threw out,
``as for you all to save HER?'' (the man)

``Oh for us `all'--!'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether could but laugh at that. It brought him (Strether) back, however, to the point he (Strether) had really wished to make.
``They've accepted their situation--hard as it is. They're not free--at least she (it)'s not; but they take what's left to them. It's a friendship, of a beautiful sort; and that's what makes them so strong. They're straight, they feel; and they keep each other up. It's doubtless she (it), however, who, as you yourself have hinted, feels it most.'' (Bilham/Mr. Bilham)

Little Bilham appeared to wonder what he (Bilham) had hinted.

``Feels most that they're straight?'' (unknown)

``Well, feels that SHE is, and the strength that comes from it. She (it) keeps HIM up--she (it) keeps the whole thing up. When people are able to it's fine. She (it)'s wonderful, wonderful, as Miss Barrace says; and he (Barrace) is, in his (Barrace) way, too; however, as a mere man, he (Barrace) may sometimes rebel and not feel that he (Barrace) finds his (Barrace) account in it. She (Barrace) has simply given him (Barrace) an immense moral lift, and what that can explain is prodigious. That's why I speak of it as a situation. It IS one, if there ever was.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
And Strether, with his (Strether) head back and his (Strether) eyes on the ceiling, seemed to lose himself in the vision of it.

His (Strether) companion attended deeply.

``You state it much better than I could.'' (unknown)
``Oh you see it doesn't concern you.'' (Bilham/Mr. Bilham)

Little Bilham considered.

``I thought you said just now that it doesn't concern you either.'' (unknown)

``Well, it doesn't a bit as Madame de Vionnet's affair. But as we were again saying just now, what did I come out for but to save him (Vionnet)?'' (unknown)

``Yes--to remove him (Vionnet).'' (unknown)

``To save him (Vionnet) by removal; to win him (Vionnet) over to HIMSELF thinking it best he (Vionnet) shall take up business--thinking he (Vionnet) must immediately do therefore what's necessary to that end.'' (unknown)

``Well,'' (Bilham/Mr. Bilham)
said little Bilham after a moment,
``you HAVE won him (Vionnet) over. He (Vionnet) does think it best. He (Vionnet) has within a day or two again said to me as much.'' (Bilham/Mr. Bilham)

``And that,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether asked,
``is why you consider that he (Vionnet) cares less than she (me)?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

``Cares less for her (me) than she (me) for him (Vionnet)? Yes, that's one of the reasons. But other things too have given me the impression. A man, don't you think?'' (Bilham/Mr. Bilham)
little Bilham presently pursued,
``CAN'T, in such conditions, care so much as a woman. It takes different conditions to make him (man), and then perhaps he (man) cares more. Chad,'' (Bilham/Mr. Bilham)
he (Bilham) wound up,
``has his (Chad) possible future before him (Chad).'' (he)

``Are you speaking of his (Chad) business future?'' (unknown)

``No--on the contrary; of the other, the future of what you so justly call their situation. M. de Vionnet may live for ever.'' (unknown)

``So that they can't marry?'' (The man)

The young man waited a moment.

``Not being able to marry is all they've with any confidence to look forward to. A woman--a particular woman--may stand that strain. But can a man?'' (he)
he (man) propounded.

Strether's answer was as prompt as if he (man) had already, for himself, worked it out.

``Not without a very high ideal of conduct. But that's just what we're attributing to Chad. And how, for that matter,'' (he)
he (man) mused,
``does his (Chad) going to America diminish the particular strain? Wouldn't it seem rather to add to it?'' (he)

``Out of sight out of mind!'' (companion)
his (man) companion laughed. Then more bravely:
``Wouldn't distance lessen the torment?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
But before Strether could reply,
``The thing is, you see, Chad ought to marry!'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
he (Strether) wound up.

Strether, for a little, appeared to think of it.

``If you talk of torments you don't diminish mine!'' (he)
he (Strether) then broke out. The next moment he (Strether) was on his (Strether) feet with a question.
``He (Chad) ought to marry whom?'' (Bilham/Mr. Bilham)

Little Bilham rose more slowly.

``Well, some one he (Chad) CAN--some thoroughly nice girl.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether's eyes, as they stood together, turned again to Jeanne.

``Do you mean HER?'' (friend)

His (Strether) friend made a sudden strange face.

``After being in love with her (girl) mother? No.'' (unknown)

``But isn't it exactly your idea that he (Chad) ISn't in love with her (girl) mother?'' (friend)

His (Strether) friend once more had a pause.

``Well, he (Chad) isn't at any rate in love with Jeanne.'' (unknown)

``I dare say not.'' (unknown)

``How CAN he (Chad) be with any other woman?'' (unknown)

``Oh that I admit. But being in love isn't, you know, here'' (Bilham/Mr. Bilham)
--little Bilham spoke in friendly reminder--
``thought necessary, in strictness, for marriage.'' (Bilham/Mr. Bilham)

``And what torment--to call a torment--can there ever possibly be with a woman like that?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
As if from the interest of his (Bilham) own question Strether had gone on without hearing.
``Is it for her (woman) to have turned a man out so wonderfully, too, only for somebody else?'' (He)
He (Strether) appeared to make a point of this, and little Bilham looked at him (Bilham) now.
``When it's for each other that people give things up they don't miss them.'' (he)
Then he (Bilham) threw off as with an extravagance of which he (Bilham) was conscious:
``Let them face the future together!'' (he)

Little Bilham looked at him (Bilham) indeed.

``You mean that after all he (man) shouldn't go back?'' (unknown)

``I mean that if he (man) gives her (woman) up--!'' (unknown)

``Yes?'' (unknown)

``Well, he (man) ought to be ashamed of himself.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
But Strether spoke with a sound that might have passed for a laugh.

Volume II

Book Seventh

I

It wasn't the first time Strether had sat alone in the great dim church--still less was it the first of his (Strether) giving himself up, so far as conditions permitted, to its beneficent action on his (Strether) nerves. He (Strether) had been to Notre Dame with Waymarsh, he (Strether) had been there with Miss Gostrey, he (Strether) had been there with Chad Newsome, and had found the place, even in company, such a refuge from the obsession of his (Newsome) problem that, with renewed pressure from that source, he (Newsome) had not unnaturally recurred to a remedy meeting the case, for the moment, so indirectly, no doubt, but so relievingly. He (Newsome) was conscious enough that it was only for the moment, but good moments--if he (Newsome) could call them good--still had their value for a man who by this time struck himself as living almost disgracefully from hand to mouth. Having so well learnt the way, he (man) had lately made the pilgrimage more than once by himself--had quite stolen off, taking an unnoticed chance and making no point of speaking of the adventure when restored to his (man) friends.

His (man) great friend, for that matter, was still absent, as well as remarkably silent; even at the end of three weeks Miss Gostrey hadn't come back. She (Gostrey) wrote to him (man) from Mentone, admitting that he (man) must judge her (Gostrey) grossly inconsequent--perhaps in fact for the time odiously faithless; but asking for patience, for a deferred sentence, throwing herself in short on his (man) generosity. For her (Gostrey) too, she (Gostrey) could assure him (man), life was complicated--more complicated than he (man) could have guessed; she (Gostrey) had moreover made certain of him (man)--certain of not wholly missing him (man) on her (Gostrey) return--before her (Gostrey) disappearance. If furthermore she (Gostrey) didn't burden him (man) with letters it was frankly because of her (Gostrey) sense of the other great commerce he (man) had to carry on. He (man) himself, at the end of a fortnight, had written twice, to show how his (man) generosity could be trusted; but he (man) reminded himself in each case of Mrs. Newsome's epistolary manner at the times when Mrs. Newsome kept off delicate ground. He (man) sank his (man) problem, he (man) talked of Waymarsh and Miss Barrace, of little Bilham and the set over the river, with whom he (Bilham) had again had tea, and he (Bilham) was easy, for convenience, about Chad and Madame de Vionnet and Jeanne. He (Vionnet) admitted that he (Vionnet) continued to see them, he (Vionnet) was decidedly so confirmed a haunter of Chad's premises and that young man's practical intimacy with them was so undeniably great; but he (Chad) had his (Chad) reason for not attempting to render for Miss Gostrey's benefit the impression of these last days. That would be to tell her (Gostrey) too much about himself--it being at present just from himself he (Chad) was trying to escape.

This small struggle sprang not a little, in its way, from the same impulse that had now carried him (Chad) across to Notre Dame; the impulse to let things be, to give them time to justify themselves or at least to pass. He (Chad) was aware of having no errand in such a place but the desire not to be, for the hour, in certain other places; a sense of safety, of simplification, which each time he (Chad) yielded to it he (Chad) amused himself by thinking of as a private concession to cowardice. The great church had no altar for his (Chad) worship, no direct voice for his (Chad) soul; but it was none the less soothing even to sanctity; for he (Chad) could feel while there what he (Chad) couldn't elsewhere, that he (Chad) was a plain tired man taking the holiday he (Chad) had earned. He (Chad) was tired, but he (Chad) wasn't plain--that was the pity and the trouble of it; he (Chad) was able, however, to drop his (Chad) problem at the door very much as if it had been the copper piece that he (Chad) deposited, on the threshold, in the receptacle of the inveterate blind beggar. He (beggar) trod the long dim nave, sat in the splendid choir, paused before the cluttered chapels of the east end, and the mighty monument laid upon him (beggar) its spell. He (beggar) might have been a student under the charm of a museum--which was exactly what, in a foreign town, in the afternoon of life, he (beggar) would have liked to be free to be. This form of sacrifice did at any rate for the occasion as well as another; it made him (beggar) quite sufficiently understand how, within the precinct, for the real refugee, the things of the world could fall into abeyance. That was the cowardice, probably--to dodge them, to beg the question, not to deal with it in the hard outer light; but his (refugee) own oblivions were too brief, too vain, to hurt any one but himself, and he (refugee) had a vague and fanciful kindness for certain persons whom he (refugee) met, figures of mystery and anxiety, and whom, with observation for his (refugee) pastime, he (refugee) ranked as those who were fleeing from justice. Justice was outside, in the hard light, and injustice too; but one was as absent as the other from the air of the long aisles and the brightness of the many altars.

Thus it was at all events that, one morning some dozen days after the dinner in the Boulevard Malesherbes at which Madame de Vionnet had been present with her (refugee) daughter, he (refugee) was called upon to play his (refugee) part in an encounter that deeply stirred his (refugee) imagination. He (refugee) had the habit, in these contemplations, of watching a fellow visitant, here and there, from a respectable distance, remarking some note of behaviour, of penitence, of prostration, of the absolved, relieved state; this was the manner in which his (refugee) vague tenderness took its course, the degree of demonstration to which it naturally had to confine itself. It hadn't indeed so felt its responsibility as when on this occasion he (refugee) suddenly measured the suggestive effect of a lady whose supreme stillness, in the shade of one of the chapels, he (refugee) had two or three times noticed as he (refugee) made, and made once more, his (refugee) slow circuit. She (lady) wasn't prostrate--not in any degree bowed, but she (lady) was strangely fixed, and her (lady) prolonged immobility showed her (lady), while he (refugee) passed and paused, as wholly given up to the need, whatever it was, that had brought her (lady) there. She (lady) only sat and gazed before her (lady), as he (refugee) himself often sat; but she (lady) had placed herself, as he (refugee) never did, within the focus of the shrine, and she (lady) had lost herself, he (refugee) could easily see, as he (refugee) would only have liked to do. She (lady) was not a wandering alien, keeping back more than she (lady) gave, but one of the familiar, the intimate, the fortunate, for whom these dealings had a method and a meaning. She (lady) reminded our friend--since it was the way of nine tenths of his (friend) current impressions to act as recalls of things imagined--of some fine firm concentrated heroine of an old story, something he (friend) had heard, read, something that, had he (friend) had a hand for drama, he (friend) might himself have written, renewing her (heroine) courage, renewing her (heroine) clearness, in splendidly-protected meditation. Her (heroine) back, as she (heroine) sat, was turned to him (friend), but his (friend) impression absolutely required that she (heroine) should be young and interesting, and she (heroine) carried her (heroine) head moreover, even in the sacred shade, with a discernible faith in herself, a kind of implied conviction of consistency, security, impunity. But what had such a woman come for if she (woman) hadn't come to pray? Strether's reading of such matters was, it must be owned, confused; but he (Strether) wondered if her (woman) attitude were some congruous fruit of absolution, of

``indulgence.'' (he)
He (Strether) knew but dimly what indulgence, in such a place, might mean; yet he (Strether) had, as with a soft sweep, a vision of how it might indeed add to the zest of active rites. All this was a good deal to have been denoted by a mere lurking figure who was nothing to him (Strether); but, the last thing before leaving the church, he (Strether) had the surprise of a still deeper quickening.

He (Strether) had dropped upon a seat halfway down the nave and, again in the museum mood, was trying with head thrown back and eyes aloft, to reconstitute a past, to reduce it in fact to the convenient terms of Victor Hugo, whom, a few days before, giving the rein for once in a way to the joy of life, he (Hugo) had purchased in seventy bound volumes, a miracle of cheapness, parted with, he (Hugo) was assured by the shopman, at the price of the red-and-gold alone. He (Hugo) looked, doubtless, while he (Hugo) played his (Hugo) eternal nippers over Gothic glooms, sufficiently rapt in reverence; but what his (Hugo) thought had finally bumped against was the question of where, among packed accumulations, so multiform a wedge would be able to enter. Were seventy volumes in red-and-gold to be perhaps what he (Hugo) should most substantially have to show at Woollett as the fruit of his (Hugo) mission? It was a possibility that held him (Hugo) a minute--held him (Hugo) till he (Hugo) happened to feel that some one, unnoticed, had approached him (Hugo) and paused. Turning, he (Hugo) saw that a lady stood there as for a greeting, and he (Hugo) sprang up as he (Hugo) next took her (lady), securely, for Madame de Vionnet, who appeared to have recognised him (Vionnet) as she (lady) passed near him (Vionnet) on her (lady) way to the door. She (lady) checked, quickly and gaily, a certain confusion in him (Vionnet), came to meet it, turned it back, by an art of her (lady) own; the confusion having threatened him (Vionnet) as he (Vionnet) knew her (lady) for the person he (Vionnet) had lately been observing. She (lady) was the lurking figure of the dim chapel; she (lady) had occupied him (Vionnet) more than she (lady) guessed; but it came to him (Vionnet) in time, luckily, that he (Vionnet) needn't tell her (lady) and that no harm, after all, had been done. She (lady) herself, for that matter, straightway showing she (lady) felt their encounter as the happiest of accidents, had for him (Vionnet) a

``You come here too?'' (him)
that despoiled surprise of every awkwardness.

``I come often,'' (she)
she (lady) said.
``I love this place, but I'm terrible, in general, for churches. The old women who live in them all know me; in fact I'm already myself one of the old women. It's like that, at all events, that I foresee I shall end.'' (he)
Looking about for a chair, so that he (Vionnet) instantly pulled one nearer, she (lady) sat down with him (Vionnet) again to the sound of an
``Oh, I like so much your also being fond--!'' (him)

He (Vionnet) confessed the extent of his (Vionnet) feeling, though she (lady) left the object vague; and he (Vionnet) was struck with the tact, the taste of her (lady) vagueness, which simply took for granted in him (Vionnet) a sense of beautiful things. He (Vionnet) was conscious of how much it was affected, this sense, by something subdued and discreet in the way she (lady) had arranged herself for her (lady) special object and her (lady) morning walk--he (Vionnet) believed her (lady) to have come on foot; the way her (lady) slightly thicker veil was drawn--a mere touch, but everything; the composed gravity of her (lady) dress, in which, here and there, a dull wine-colour seemed to gleam faintly through black; the charming discretion of her (lady) small compact head; the quiet note, as she (lady) sat, of her (lady) folded, grey-gloved hands. It was, to Strether's mind, as if she (lady) sat on her (lady) own ground, the light honours of which, at an open gate, she (lady) thus easily did him (Strether), while all the vastness and mystery of the domain stretched off behind. When people were so completely in possession they could be extraordinarily civil; and our friend had indeed at this hour a kind of revelation of her (lady) heritage. She (lady) was romantic for him (friend) far beyond what she (lady) could have guessed, and again he (friend) found his (friend) small comfort in the conviction that, subtle though she (lady) was, his (friend) impression must remain a secret from her (lady). The thing that, once more, made him (friend) uneasy for secrets in general was this particular patience she (lady) could have with his (friend) own want of colour; albeit that on the other hand his (friend) uneasiness pretty well dropped after he (friend) had been for ten minutes as colourless as possible and at the same time as responsive.

The moments had already, for that matter, drawn their deepest tinge from the special interest excited in him (friend) by his (friend) vision of his (friend) companion's identity with the person whose attitude before the glimmering altar had so impressed him (friend). This attitude fitted admirably into the stand he (friend) had privately taken about her (lady) connexion with Chad on the last occasion of his (Chad) seeing them together. It helped him (Chad) to stick fast at the point he (Chad) had then reached; it was there he (Chad) had resolved that he (Chad) WOULD stick, and at no moment since had it seemed as easy to do so. Unassailably innocent was a relation that could make one of the parties to it so carry herself. If it wasn't innocent why did she (lady) haunt the churches?--into which, given the woman he (Chad) could believe he (Chad) made out, she (lady) would never have come to flaunt an insolence of guilt. She (lady) haunted them for continued help, for strength, for peace--sublime support which, if one were able to look at it so, she (lady) found from day to day. They talked, in low easy tones and with lifted lingering looks, about the great monument and its history and its beauty--all of which, Madame de Vionnet professed, came to her (lady) most in the other, the outer view.

``We'll presently, after we go,'' (she)
she (lady) said,
``walk round it again if you like. I'm not in a particular hurry, and it will be pleasant to look at it well with you.'' (she)
He (Vionnet) had spoken of the great romancer and the great romance, and of what, to his (Vionnet) imagination, they had done for the whole, mentioning to her (lady) moreover the exorbitance of his (Vionnet) purchase, the seventy blazing volumes that were so out of proportion.

``Out of proportion to what?'' (unknown)

``Well, to any other plunge.'' (he)
Yet he (Vionnet) felt even as he (Vionnet) spoke how at that instant he (Vionnet) was plunging. He (Vionnet) had made up his (Vionnet) mind and was impatient to get into the air; for his (Vionnet) purpose was a purpose to be uttered outside, and he (Vionnet) had a fear that it might with delay still slip away from him (Vionnet). She (lady) however took her (lady) time; she (lady) drew out their quiet gossip as if she (lady) had wished to profit by their meeting, and this confirmed precisely an interpretation of her (lady) manner, of her (lady) mystery. While she (lady) rose, as he (Vionnet) would have called it, to the question of Victor Hugo, her (lady) voice itself, the light low quaver of her (lady) deference to the solemnity about them, seemed to make her (lady) words mean something that they didn't mean openly. Help, strength, peace, a sublime support--she (lady) hadn't found so much of these things as that the amount wouldn't be sensibly greater for any scrap his (Hugo) appearance of faith in her (lady) might enable her (lady) to feel in her (lady) hand. Every little, in a long strain, helped, and if he (Hugo) happened to affect her (lady) as a firm object she (lady) could hold on by, he (Hugo) wouldn't jerk himself out of her (lady) reach. People in difficulties held on by what was nearest, and he (Hugo) was perhaps after all not further off than sources of comfort more abstract. It was as to this he (Hugo) had made up his (Hugo) mind; he (Hugo) had made it up, that is, to give her (lady) a sign. The sign would be that--though it was her (lady) own affair--he (Hugo) understood; the sign would be that--though it was her (lady) own affair--she (lady) was free to clutch. Since she (lady) took him (Hugo) for a firm object--much as he (Hugo) might to his (Hugo) own sense appear at times to rock--he (Hugo) would do his (Hugo) best to BE one.

The end of it was that half an hour later they were seated together for an early luncheon at a wonderful, a delightful house of entertainment on the left bank--a place of pilgrimage for the knowing, they were both aware, the knowing who came, for its great renown, the homage of restless days, from the other end of the town. Strether had already been there three times--first with Miss Gostrey, then with Chad, then with Chad again and with Waymarsh and little Bilham, all of whom he (Bilham) had himself sagaciously entertained; and his (Bilham) pleasure was deep now on learning that Madame de Vionnet hadn't yet been initiated. When he (Vionnet) had said as they strolled round the church, by the river, acting at last on what, within, he (Vionnet) had made up his (Vionnet) mind to,

``Will you, if you have time, come to dejeuner with me somewhere? For instance, if you know it, over there on the other side, which is so easy a walk'' (he)
--and then had named the place; when he (Vionnet) had done this she (Waymarsh) stopped short as for quick intensity, and yet deep difficulty, of response. She (Waymarsh) took in the proposal as if it were almost too charming to be true; and there had perhaps never yet been for her (Waymarsh) companion so unexpected a moment of pride--so fine, so odd a case, at any rate, as his (companion) finding himself thus able to offer to a person in such universal possession a new, a rare amusement. She (Waymarsh) had heard of the happy spot, but she (Waymarsh) asked him (companion) in reply to a further question how in the world he (companion) could suppose her (Waymarsh) to have been there. He (companion) supposed himself to have supposed that Chad might have taken her (Waymarsh), and she (Waymarsh) guessed this the next moment to his (Chad) no small discomfort.

``Ah, let me explain,'' (she)
she (Waymarsh) smiled,
``that I don't go about with him (you) in public; I never have such chances--not having them otherwise--and it's just the sort of thing that, as a quiet creature living in my hole, I adore.'' (she)
It was more than kind of him (Chad) to have thought of it--though, frankly, if he (Chad) asked whether she (Waymarsh) had time she (Waymarsh) hadn't a single minute. That however made no difference--she (Waymarsh)'d throw everything over. Every duty at home, domestic, maternal, social, awaited her (Waymarsh); but it was a case for a high line. Her (Waymarsh) affairs would go to smash, but hadn't one a right to one's snatch of scandal when one was prepared to pay? It was on this pleasant basis of costly disorder, consequently, that they eventually seated themselves, on either side of a small table, at a window adjusted to the busy quay and the shining barge-burdened Seine; where, for an hour, in the matter of letting himself go, of diving deep, Strether was to feel he (Strether) had touched bottom. He (Strether) was to feel many things on this occasion, and one of the first of them was that he (Strether) had travelled far since that evening in London, before the theatre, when his (Strether) dinner with Maria Gostrey, between the pink-shaded candles, had struck him (Strether) as requiring so many explanations. He (Strether) had at that time gathered them in, the explanations--he (Strether) had stored them up; but it was at present as if he (Strether) had either soared above or sunk below them--he (Strether) couldn't tell which; he (Strether) could somehow think of none that didn't seem to leave the appearance of collapse and cynicism easier for him (Strether) than lucidity. How could he (Strether) wish it to be lucid for others, for any one, that he (Strether), for the hour, saw reasons enough in the mere way the bright clean ordered water-side life came in at the open window?--the mere way Madame de Vionnet, opposite him (Vionnet) over their intensely white table-linen, their omelette aux tomates, their bottle of straw-coloured Chablis, thanked him (Vionnet) for everything almost with the smile of a child, while her (Strether) grey eyes moved in and out of their talk, back to the quarter of the warm spring air, in which early summer had already begun to throb, and then back again to his (Vionnet) face and their human questions.

Their human questions became many before they had done--many more, as one after the other came up, than our friend's free fancy had at all foreseen. The sense he (friend) had had before, the sense he (friend) had had repeatedly, the sense that the situation was running away with him (friend), had never been so sharp as now; and all the more that he (friend) could perfectly put his (friend) finger on the moment it had taken the bit in its teeth. That accident had definitely occurred, the other evening, after Chad's dinner; it had occurred, as he (Chad) fully knew, at the moment when he (Chad) interposed between this lady and her (lady) child, when he (Chad) suffered himself so to discuss with her (lady) a matter closely concerning them that her (lady) own subtlety, marked by its significant

``Thank you!'' (her)
instantly sealed the occasion in her (lady) favour. Again he (Chad) had held off for ten days, but the situation had continued out of hand in spite of that; the fact that it was running so fast being indeed just WHY he (Chad) had held off. What had come over him (Chad) as he (Chad) recognised her (lady) in the nave of the church was that holding off could be but a losing game from the instant she (lady) was worked for not only by her (lady) subtlety, but by the hand of fate itself. If all the accidents were to fight on her (lady) side--and by the actual showing they loomed large--he (Chad) could only give himself up. This was what he (Chad) had done in privately deciding then and there to propose she (lady) should breakfast with him (Chad). What did the success of his (Chad) proposal in fact resemble but the smash in which a regular runaway properly ends? The smash was their walk, their dejeuner, their omelette, the Chablis, the place, the view, their present talk and his (Chad) present pleasure in it--to say nothing, wonder of wonders, of her (lady) own. To this tune and nothing less, accordingly, was his (Chad) surrender made good. It sufficiently lighted up at least the folly of holding off. Ancient proverbs sounded, for his (Chad) memory, in the tone of their words and the clink of their glasses, in the hum of the town and the plash of the river. It WAS clearly better to suffer as a sheep than as a lamb. One might as well perish by the sword as by famine.

``Maria's still away?'' (she)
--that was the first thing she (lady) had asked him (Chad); and when he (Chad) had found the frankness to be cheerful about it in spite of the meaning he (Chad) knew her (lady) to attach to Miss Gostrey's absence, she (lady) had gone on to enquire if he (Chad) didn't tremendously miss her (lady). There were reasons that made him (Chad) by no means sure, yet he (Chad) nevertheless answered
``Tremendously'' (he)
; which she (lady) took in as if it were all she (lady) had wished to prove. Then,
``A man in trouble MUST be possessed somehow of a woman,'' (she)
she (lady) said;
``if she (woman) doesn't come in one way she (woman) comes in another.'' (she)

``Why do you call me a man in trouble?'' (unknown)

``Ah because that's the way you strike me.'' (She)
She (lady) spoke ever so gently and as if with all fear of wounding him (Chad) while she (lady) sat partaking of his (Chad) bounty.
``AREn't you in trouble?'' (He)

He (Chad) felt himself colour at the question, and then hated that--hated to pass for anything so idiotic as woundable. Woundable by Chad's lady, in respect to whom he (Chad) had come out with such a fund of indifference--was he (Chad) already at that point? Perversely, none the less, his (Chad) pause gave a strange air of truth to her (lady) supposition; and what was he (Chad) in fact but disconcerted at having struck her (lady) just in the way he (Chad) had most dreamed of not doing?

``I'm not in trouble yet,'' (he)
he (Chad) at last smiled.
``I'm not in trouble now.'' (unknown)

``Well, I'm always so. But that you sufficiently know.'' (She)
She (lady) was a woman who, between courses, could be graceful with her (lady) elbows on the table. It was a posture unknown to Mrs. Newsome, but it was easy for a femme du monde.
``Yes--I am `now'!'' (unknown)

``There was a question you put to me,'' (he)
he (Chad) presently returned,
``the night of Chad's dinner. I didn't answer it then, and it has been very handsome of you not to have sought an occasion for pressing me about it since.'' (he)

She (Newsome) was instantly all there.

``Of course I know what you allude to. I asked you what you had meant by saying, the day you came to see me, just before you left me, that you'd save me. And you then said--at our friend's--that you'd have really to wait to see, for yourself, what you did mean.'' (unknown)

``Yes, I asked for time,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
said Strether.
``And it sounds now, as you put it, like a very ridiculous speech.'' (unknown)

``Oh!'' (she)
she (Newsome) murmured--she (Newsome) was full of attenuation. But she (Newsome) had another thought.
``If it does sound ridiculous why do you deny that you're in trouble?'' (unknown)

``Ah if I were,'' (he)
he (Strether) replied,
``it wouldn't be the trouble of fearing ridicule. I don't fear it.'' (he)

``What then do you?'' (unknown)

``Nothing--now.'' (he)
And he (Strether) leaned back in his (Strether) chair.

``I like your `now'!'' (she)
she (Newsome) laughed across at him (Strether).

``Well, it's precisely that it fully comes to me at present that I've kept you long enough. I know by this time, at any rate, what I meant by my speech; and I really knew it the night of Chad's dinner.'' (unknown)

``Then why didn't you tell me?'' (unknown)

``Because it was difficult at the moment. I had already at that moment done something for you, in the sense of what I had said the day I went to see you; but I wasn't then sure of the importance I might represent this as having.'' (She)

She (Newsome) was all eagerness.

``And you're sure now?'' (unknown)

``Yes; I see that, practically, I've done for you--had done for you when you put me your question--all that it's as yet possible to me to do. I feel now,'' (he)
he (Strether) went on,
``that it may go further than I thought. What I did after my visit to you,'' (he)
he (Strether) explained,
``was to write straight off to Mrs. Newsome about you, and I'm at last, from one day to the other, expecting her (Newsome) answer. It's this answer that will represent, as I believe, the consequences.'' (he)

Patient and beautiful was her (Newsome) interest.

``I see--the consequences of your speaking for me.'' (she)
And she (Newsome) waited as if not to hustle him (Strether).

He (Strether) acknowledged it by immediately going on.

``The question, you understand, was HOW I should save you. Well, I'm trying it by thus letting her (Newsome) know that I consider you worth saving.'' (unknown)

``I see--I see.'' (unknown)
Her (Newsome) eagerness broke through.

``How can I thank you enough?'' (He)
He (Strether) couldn't tell her (Newsome) that, however, and she (Newsome) quickly pursued.
``You do really, for yourself, consider it?'' (her)

His (Strether) only answer at first was to help her (Newsome) to the dish that had been freshly put before them.

``I've written to her (Newsome) again since then--I've left her (Newsome) in no doubt of what I think. I've told her (Newsome) all about you.'' (unknown)

``Thanks--not so much. ``All about' me,'' she (Newsome) went on--

``yes.'' (me)

``All it seems to me you've done for him (it).'' (unknown)

``Ah and you might have added all it seems to ME!'' (She)
She (Newsome) laughed again, while she (Newsome) took up her (Newsome) knife and fork, as in the cheer of these assurances.
``But you're not sure how she (Newsome)'ll take it.'' (unknown)

``No, I'll not pretend I'm sure.'' (unknown)

``Voila.'' (she)
And she (Newsome) waited a moment.
``I wish you'd tell me about her (Newsome).'' (unknown)

``Oh,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
said Strether with a slightly strained smile,
``all that need concern you about her (Newsome) is that she (Newsome)'s really a grand person.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Madame de Vionnet seemed to demur.

``Is that all that need concern me about her (Newsome)?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

But Strether neglected the question.

``Hasn't Chad talked to you?'' (unknown)

``Of his (Chad) mother? Yes, a great deal--immensely. But not from your point of view.'' (unknown)

``He (Chad) can't,'' (friend)
our friend returned,
``have said any ill of her (mother).'' (friend)

``Not the least bit. He (Chad) has given me, like you, the assurance that she (mother)'s really grand. But her (mother) being really grand is somehow just what hasn't seemed to simplify our case. Nothing,'' (she)
she (Newsome) continued,
``is further from me than to wish to say a word against her (mother); but of course I feel how little she (mother) can like being told of her (mother) owing me anything. No woman ever enjoys such an obligation to another woman.'' (she)

This was a proposition Strether couldn't contradict.

``And yet what other way could I have expressed to her (woman) what I felt? It's what there was most to say about you.'' (unknown)

``Do you mean then that she (woman) WILL be good to me?'' (unknown)

``It's what I'm waiting to see. But I've little doubt she (woman) would,'' (he)
he (Strether) added,
``if she (woman) could comfortably see you.'' (he)

It seemed to strike her (Newsome) as a happy, a beneficent thought.

``Oh then couldn't that be managed? Wouldn't she (woman) come out? Wouldn't she (woman) if you so put it to her (woman)? DID you by any possibility?'' (she)
she (Newsome) faintly quavered.

``Oh no'' (he)
--he (Strether) was prompt.
``Not that. It would be, much more, to give an account of you that--since there's no question of YOUR paying the visit--I should go home first.'' (unknown)

It instantly made her (Newsome) graver.

``And are you thinking of that?'' (unknown)

``Oh all the while, naturally.'' (unknown)

``Stay with us--stay with us!'' (she)
she (Newsome) exclaimed on this.
``That's your only way to make sure.'' (unknown)

``To make sure of what?'' (unknown)

``Why that he (It) doesn't break up. You didn't come out to do that to him (It).'' (unknown)

``Doesn't it depend,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether returned after a moment,
``on what you mean by breaking up?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

``Oh you know well enough what I mean!'' (unknown)

His (Strether) silence seemed again for a little to denote an understanding.

``You take for granted remarkable things.'' (unknown)

``Yes, I do--to the extent that I don't take for granted vulgar ones. You're perfectly capable of seeing that what you came out for wasn't really at all to do what you'd now have to do.'' (unknown)

``Ah it's perfectly simple,'' (Strether)
Strether good-humouredly pleaded.
``I've had but one thing to do--to put our case before him (you). To put it as it could only be put here on the spot--by personal pressure. My dear lady,'' (he)
he (Strether) lucidly pursued,
``my work, you see, is really done, and my reasons for staying on even another day are none of the best. Chad's in possession of our case and professes to do it full justice. What remains is with himself. I've had my rest, my amusement and refreshment; I've had, as we say at Woollett, a lovely time. Nothing in it has been more lovely than this happy meeting with you--in these fantastic conditions to which you've so delightfully consented. I've a sense of success. It's what I wanted. My getting all this good is what Chad has waited for, and I gather that if I'm ready to go he (Chad)'s the same.'' (he)

She (Newsome) shook her (Newsome) head with a finer deeper wisdom.

``You're not ready. If you're ready why did you write to Mrs. Newsome in the sense you've mentioned to me?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether considered.

``I shan't go before I hear from her (Newsome). You're too much afraid of her (Newsome),'' (he)
he (Strether) added.

It produced between them a long look from which neither shrank.

``I don't think you believe that--believe I've not really reason to fear her (Newsome).'' (unknown)

``She (Newsome)'s capable of great generosity,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether presently stated.

``Well then let her (Newsome) trust me a little. That's all I ask. Let her (Newsome) recognise in spite of everything what I've done.'' (unknown)

``Ah remember,'' (friend)
our friend replied,
``that she (Newsome) can't effectually recognise it without seeing it for herself. Let Chad go over and show her (Newsome) what you've done, and let him (Chad) plead with her (Newsome) there for it and, as it were, for YOU.'' (friend)

She (Newsome) measured the depth of this suggestion.

``Do you give me your word of honour that if she (Newsome) once has him (Chad) there she (Newsome) won't do her (Newsome) best to marry him (Chad)?'' (companion)

It made her (Newsome) companion, this enquiry, look again a while out at the view; after which he (companion) spoke without sharpness.

``When she (Newsome) sees for herself what he (Chad) is--'' (she)

But she (Newsome) had already broken in.

``It's when she (Newsome) sees for herself what he (Chad) is that she (Newsome)'ll want to marry him (Chad) most.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether's attitude, that of due deference to what she (Newsome) said, permitted him (Strether) to attend for a minute to his (Strether) luncheon.

``I doubt if that will come off. It won't be easy to make it.'' (unknown)

``It will be easy if he (Chad) remains there--and he (Chad)'ll remain for the money. The money appears to be, as a probability, so hideously much.'' (unknown)

``Well,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether presently concluded,
``nothing COULD really hurt you but his (Chad) marrying.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

She (Newsome) gave a strange light laugh.

``Putting aside what may really hurt HIM.'' (friend)

But her (Newsome) friend looked at her (Newsome) as if he (friend) had thought of that too.

``The question will come up, of course, of the future that you yourself offer him (Chad).'' (She)

She (Newsome) was leaning back now, but she (Newsome) fully faced him (friend).

``Well, let it come up!'' (unknown)

``The point is that it's for Chad to make of it what he (Chad) can. His (Chad) being proof against marriage will show what he (Chad) does make.'' (unknown)

``If he (Chad) IS proof, yes'' (she)
--she (Newsome) accepted the proposition.
``But for myself,'' (she)
she (Newsome) added,
``the question is what YOU make.'' (she)

``Ah I make nothing. It's not my affair.'' (unknown)

``I beg your pardon. It's just there that, since you've taken it up and are committed to it, it most intensely becomes yours. You're not saving me, I take it, for your interest in myself, but for your interest in our friend. The one's at any rate wholly dependent on the other. You can't in honour not see me through,'' (she)
she (Newsome) wound up,
``because you can't in honour not see HIM.'' (she)

Strange and beautiful to him (friend) was her (Newsome) quiet soft acuteness. The thing that most moved him (friend) was really that she (Newsome) was so deeply serious. She (Newsome) had none of the portentous forms of it, but he (friend) had never come in contact, it struck him (friend), with a force brought to so fine a head. Mrs. Newsome, goodness knew, was serious; but it was nothing to this. He (friend) took it all in, he (friend) saw it all together.

``No,'' (he)
he (friend) mused,
``I can't in honour not see him (friend).'' (he)

Her (Newsome) face affected him (friend) as with an exquisite light.

``You WILL then?'' (unknown)

``I will.'' (she)

At this she (Newsome) pushed back her (Newsome) chair and was the next moment on her (Newsome) feet.

``Thank you!'' (she)
she (Newsome) said with her (Newsome) hand held out to him (friend) across the table and with no less a meaning in the words than her (Newsome) lips had so particularly given them after Chad's dinner. The golden nail she (Newsome) had then driven in pierced a good inch deeper. Yet he (nail) reflected that he (nail) himself had only meanwhile done what he (nail) had made up his (nail) mind to on the same occasion. So far as the essence of the matter went he (nail) had simply stood fast on the spot on which he (nail) had then planted his (nail) feet.

II

He (nail) received three days after this a communication from America, in the form of a scrap of blue paper folded and gummed, not reaching him (nail) through his (nail) bankers, but delivered at his (nail) hotel by a small boy in uniform, who, under instructions from the concierge, approached him (nail) as he (nail) slowly paced the little court. It was the evening hour, but daylight was long now and Paris more than ever penetrating. The scent of flowers was in the streets, he (nail) had the whiff of violets perpetually in his (nail) nose; and he (nail) had attached himself to sounds and suggestions, vibrations of the air, human and dramatic, he (nail) imagined, as they were not in other places, that came out for him (nail) more and more as the mild afternoons deepened--a far-off hum, a sharp near click on the asphalt, a voice calling, replying, somewhere and as full of tone as an actor's in a play. He (actor) was to dine at home, as usual, with Waymarsh--they had settled to that for thrift and simplicity; and he (actor) now hung about before his (actor) friend came down.

He (actor) read his (actor) telegram in the court, standing still a long time where he (actor) had opened it and giving five minutes afterwards to the renewed study of it. At last, quickly, he (actor) crumpled it up as if to get it out of the way; in spite of which, however, he (actor) kept it there--still kept it when, at the end of another turn, he (actor) had dropped into a chair placed near a small table. Here, with his (actor) scrap of paper compressed in his (actor) fist and further concealed by his (actor) folding his (actor) arms tight, he (actor) sat for some time in thought, gazed before him (actor) so straight that Waymarsh appeared and approached him (actor) without catching his (actor) eye. The latter in fact, struck with his (actor) appearance, looked at him (actor) hard for a single instant and then, as if determined to that course by some special vividness in it, dropped back into the salon de lecture without addressing him (actor). But the pilgrim from Milrose permitted himself still to observe the scene from behind the clear glass plate of that retreat. Strether ended, as he (Strether) sat, by a fresh scrutiny of his (Strether) compressed missive, which he (Strether) smoothed out carefully again as he (Strether) placed it on his (Strether) table. There it remained for some minutes, until, at last looking up, he (Strether) saw Waymarsh watching him (Strether) from within. It was on this that their eyes met--met for a moment during which neither moved. But Strether then got up, folding his (Strether) telegram more carefully and putting it into his (Strether) waistcoat pocket.

A few minutes later the friends were seated together at dinner; but Strether had meanwhile said nothing about it, and they eventually parted, after coffee in the court, with nothing said on either side. Our friend had moreover the consciousness that even less than usual was on this occasion said between them, so that it was almost as if each had been waiting for something from the other. Waymarsh had always more or less the air of sitting at the door of his (friend) tent, and silence, after so many weeks, had come to play its part in their concert. This note indeed, to Strether's sense, had lately taken a fuller tone, and it was his (Strether) fancy to-night that they had never quite so drawn it out. Yet it befell, none the less that he (Strether) closed the door to confidence when his (Strether) companion finally asked him (Strether) if there were anything particular the matter with him (Strether).

``Nothing,'' (he)
he (Strether) replied,
``more than usual.'' (he)

On the morrow, however, at an early hour, he (Strether) found occasion to give an answer more in consonance with the facts. What was the matter had continued to be so all the previous evening, the first hours of which, after dinner, in his (Strether) room, he (Strether) had devoted to the copious composition of a letter. He (Strether) had quitted Waymarsh for this purpose, leaving him (Strether) to his (Strether) own resources with less ceremony than their wont, but finally coming down again with his (Strether) letter unconcluded and going forth into the streets without enquiry for his (Strether) comrade. He (Strether) had taken a long vague walk, and one o'clock had struck before his (Strether) return and his (Strether) re-ascent to his (Strether) room by the aid of the glimmering candle-end left for him (Strether) on the shelf outside the porter's lodge.
