He (Strether) had possessed himself, on closing his (Strether) door, of the numerous loose sheets of his (Strether) unfinished composition, and then, without reading them over, had torn them into small pieces. He (Strether) had thereupon slept--as if it had been in some measure thanks to that sacrifice--the sleep of the just, and had prolonged his (Strether) rest considerably beyond his (Strether) custom. Thus it was that when, between nine and ten, the tap of the knob of a walking-stick sounded on his (Strether) door, he (Strether) had not yet made himself altogether presentable. Chad Newsome's bright deep voice determined quickly enough none the less the admission of the visitor. The little blue paper of the evening before, plainly an object the more precious for its escape from premature destruction, now lay on the sill of the open window, smoothed out afresh and kept from blowing away by the superincumbent weight of his (visitor) watch. Chad, looking about with careless and competent criticism, as he (Chad) looked wherever he (Chad) went immediately espied it and permitted himself to fix it for a moment rather hard. After which he (Chad) turned his (Chad) eyes to his (Chad) host.

``It has come then at last?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether paused in the act of pinning his (Strether) necktie.

``Then you know--? You've had one too?'' (unknown)

``No, I've had nothing, and I only know what I see. I see that thing and I guess. Well,'' (he)
he (Strether) added,
``it comes as pat as in a play, for I've precisely turned up this morning--as I would have done yesterday, but it was impossible--to take you.'' (he)

``To take me?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether had turned again to his (Strether) glass.

``Back, at last, as I promised. I'm ready--I've really been ready this month. I've only been waiting for you--as was perfectly right. But you're better now; you're safe--I see that for myself; you've got all your good. You're looking, this morning, as fit as a flea.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether, at his (Strether) glass, finished dressing; consulting that witness moreover on this last opinion. WAS he (Strether) looking preternaturally fit? There was something in it perhaps for Chad's wonderful eye, but he (Chad) had felt himself for hours rather in pieces. Such a judgement, however, was after all but a contribution to his (Chad) resolve; it testified unwittingly to his (Chad) wisdom. He (Chad) was still firmer, apparently--since it shone in him (Chad) as a light--than he (Chad) had flattered himself. His (Chad) firmness indeed was slightly compromised, as he (Chad) faced about to his (Chad) friend, by the way this very personage looked--though the case would of course have been worse hadn't the secret of personal magnificence been at every hour Chad's unfailing possession. There he (Chad) was in all the pleasant morning freshness of it--strong and sleek and gay, easy and fragrant and fathomless, with happy health in his (Chad) colour, and pleasant silver in his (Chad) thick young hair, and the right word for everything on the lips that his (Chad) clear brownness caused to show as red. He (Chad) had never struck Strether as personally such a success; it was as if now, for his (Strether) definite surrender, he (Strether) had gathered himself vividly together. This, sharply and rather strangely, was the form in which he (Strether) was to be presented to Woollett. Our friend took him (friend) in again--he (friend) was always taking him (friend) in and yet finding that parts of him (friend) still remained out; though even thus his (friend) image showed through a mist of other things.

``I've had a cable,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether said,
``from your mother.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

``I dare say, my dear man. I hope she (mother)'s well.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether hesitated.

``No--she (mother)'s not well, I'm sorry to have to tell you.'' (unknown)

``Ah,'' (Chad)
said Chad,
``I must have had the instinct of it. All the more reason then that we should start straight off.'' (Chad)

Strether had now got together hat, gloves and stick, but Chad had dropped on the sofa as if to show where he (Chad) wished to make his (Chad) point. He (Chad) kept observing his (Chad) companion's things; he (Chad) might have been judging how quickly they could be packed. He (Chad) might even have wished to hint that he (Chad)'d send his (Chad) own servant to assist.

``What do you mean,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether enquired,
``by `straight off'?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

``Oh by one of next week's boats. Everything at this season goes out so light that berths will be easy anywhere.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether had in his (Strether) hand his (Strether) telegram, which he (Strether) had kept there after attaching his (Strether) watch, and he (Strether) now offered it to Chad, who, however, with an odd movement, declined to take it.

``Thanks, I'd rather not. Your correspondence with Mother's your own affair. I'm only WITH you both on it, whatever it is.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether, at this, while their eyes met, slowly folded the missive and put it in his (Strether) pocket; after which, before he (Strether) had spoken again, Chad broke fresh ground.
``Has Miss Gostrey come back?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

But when Strether presently spoke it wasn't in answer.

``It's not, I gather, that your mother's physically ill; her (mother) health, on the whole, this spring, seems to have been better than usual. But she (mother)'s worried, she (mother)'s anxious, and it appears to have risen within the last few days to a climax. We've tired out, between us, her (mother) patience.'' (unknown)

``Oh it isn't YOU!'' (Chad/Chad Newsome/Newsome)
Chad generously protested.

``I beg your pardon--it IS me.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether was mild and melancholy, but firm. He (Strether) saw it far away and over his (Strether) companion's head.
``It's very particularly me.'' (unknown)

``Well then all the more reason. Marchons, marchons!'' (the man)
said the young man gaily. His (man) host, however, at this, but continued to stand agaze; and he (man) had the next thing repeated his (man) question of a moment before.
``Has Miss Gostrey come back?'' (unknown)

``Yes, two days ago.'' (unknown)

``Then you've seen her (mother)?'' (unknown)

``No--I'm to see her (mother) to-day.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
But Strether wouldn't linger now on Miss Gostrey.
``Your mother sends me an ultimatum. If I can't bring you I'm to leave you; I'm to come at any rate myself.'' (unknown)

``Ah but you CAN bring me now,'' (Chad)
Chad, from his (Chad) sofa, reassuringly replied.

Strether had a pause.

``I don't think I understand you. Why was it that, more than a month ago, you put it to me so urgently to let Madame de Vionnet speak for you?'' (unknown)

''`Why'?'' (Chad/Chad Newsome/Newsome)
Chad considered, but he (Chad) had it at his (Chad) fingers' ends.
``Why but because I knew how well she (mother)'d do it? It was the way to keep you quiet and, to that extent, do you good. Besides,'' (he)
he (Chad) happily and comfortably explained,
``I wanted you really to know her (mother) and to get the impression of her (mother)--and you see the good that HAS done you.'' (he)

``Well,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
said Strether,
``the way she (mother) has spoken for you, all the same--so far as I've given her (mother) a chance--has only made me feel how much she (mother) wishes to keep you. If you make nothing of that I don't see why you wanted me to listen to her (mother).'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

``Why my dear man,'' (Chad/Chad Newsome/Newsome)
Chad exclaimed,
``I make everything of it! How can you doubt--?'' (Chad/Chad Newsome/Newsome)

``I doubt only because you come to me this morning with your signal to start.'' (Chad/Chad Newsome/Newsome)

Chad stared, then gave a laugh.

``And isn't my signal to start just what you've been waiting for?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether debated; he (Chad) took another turn.

``This last month I've been awaiting, I think, more than anything else, the message I have here.'' (unknown)

``You mean you've been afraid of it?'' (unknown)

``Well, I was doing my business in my own way. And I suppose your present announcement,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether went on,
``isn't merely the result of your sense of what I've expected. Otherwise you wouldn't have put me in relation--'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
But he (Strether) paused, pulling up.

At this Chad rose.

``Ah HER wanting me not to go has nothing to do with it! It's only because she (you)'s afraid--afraid of the way that, over there, I may get caught. But her (you) fear's groundless.'' (He)

He (Chad) had met again his (Chad) companion's sufficiently searching look.

``Are you tired of her (you)?'' (Chad/Chad Newsome/Newsome)

Chad gave him (Chad) in reply to this, with a movement of the head, the strangest slow smile he (Chad) had ever had from him (Chad).

``Never.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

It had immediately, on Strether's imagination, so deep and soft an effect that our friend could only for the moment keep it before him (friend).

``Never?'' (unknown)

``Never,'' (Chad/Chad Newsome/Newsome)
Chad obligingly and serenely repeated.

It made his (Chad) companion take several more steps. ``Then YOU

``RE not afraid.'' (unknown)

``Afraid to go?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether pulled up again.

``Afraid to stay.'' (The man)

The young man looked brightly amazed.

``You want me now to `stay'?'' (unknown)

``If I don't immediately sail the Pococks will immediately come out. That's what I mean,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
said Strether,
``by your mother's ultimatum .'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Chad showed a still livelier, but not an alarmed interest.

``She (mother) has turned on Sarah and Jim?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether joined him (Strether) for an instant in the vision. ``Oh and you may be sure Mamie. THAT

``S whom she (Mamie)'s turning on.'' (Chad/Chad Newsome/Newsome)

This also Chad saw--he (Chad) laughed out.

``Mamie--to corrupt me?'' (unknown)

``Ah,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
said Strether,
``she (Mamie)'s very charming.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

``So you've already more than once told me. I should like to see her (Mamie).'' (he)

Something happy and easy, something above all unconscious, in the way he (Strether) said this, brought home again to his (Strether) companion the facility of his (Strether) attitude and the enviability of his (Strether) state.

``See her (Mamie) then by all means. And consider too,'' (Strether)
Strether went on,
``that you really give your sister a lift in letting her (sister) come to you. You give her (sister) a couple of months of Paris, which she (sister) hasn't seen, if I'm not mistaken, since just after she (sister) was married, and which I'm sure she (sister) wants but the pretext to visit.'' (Strether)

Chad listened, but with all his (Chad) own knowledge of the world.

``She (sister) has had it, the pretext, these several years, yet she (sister) has never taken it.'' (unknown)

``Do you mean YOU?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether after an instant enquired.

``Certainly--the lone exile. And whom do you mean?'' (Chad)
said Chad.

``Oh I mean ME. I'm her (sister) pretext. That is--for it comes to the same thing--I'm your mother's.'' (unknown)

``Then why,'' (Chad)
Chad asked,
``doesn't Mother come herself?'' (Chad)

His (Chad) friend gave him (Chad) a long look.

``Should you like her (Mother) to?'' (he)
And as he (Chad) for the moment said nothing:
``It's perfectly open to you to cable for her (Mother).'' (he)

Chad continued to think.

``Will she (Mother) come if I do?'' (unknown)

``Quite possibly. But try, and you'll see.'' (unknown)

``Why don't YOU try?'' (Chad)
Chad after a moment asked.

``Because I don't want to.'' (Chad/Chad Newsome/Newsome)

Chad thought.

``Don't desire her (Mother) presence here?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether faced the question, and his (Strether) answer was the more emphatic.

``Don't put it off, my dear boy, on ME!'' (unknown)

``Well--I see what you mean. I'm sure you'd behave beautifully but you DON

``T want to see her (Mother). So I won't play you that trick.'' (unknown)

``Ah,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether declared,
``I shouldn't call it a trick. You've a perfect right, and it would be perfectly straight of you.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Then he (Strether) added in a different tone:
``You'd have moreover, in the person of Madame de Vionnet, a very interesting relation prepared for her (Mother).'' (he)

Their eyes, on this proposition, continued to meet, but Chad's pleasant and bold, never flinched for a moment. He (Chad) got up at last and he (Chad) said something with which Strether was struck.

``She (Mother) wouldn't understand her (Mother), but that makes no difference. Madame de Vionnet would like to see her (Mother). She (Mother)'d like to be charming to her (Mother). She (Mother) believes she (Mother) could work it.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether thought a moment, affected by this, but finally turning away.

``She (Mother) couldn't!'' (unknown)

``You're quite sure?'' (Chad/Chad Newsome/Newsome)
Chad asked.

``Well, risk it if you like!'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether, who uttered this with serenity, had urged a plea for their now getting into the air; but the young man still waited.

``Have you sent your answer?'' (unknown)

``No, I've done nothing yet.'' (unknown)

``Were you waiting to see me?'' (unknown)

``No, not that.'' (unknown)

``Only waiting'' (Chad)
--and Chad, with this, had a smile for him (Chad)--
``to see Miss Gostrey?'' (him)

``No--not even Miss Gostrey. I wasn't waiting to see any one. I had only waited, till now, to make up my mind--in complete solitude; and, since I of course absolutely owe you the information, was on the point of going out with it quite made up. Have therefore a little more patience with me. Remember,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether went on,
``that that's what you originally asked ME to have. I've had it, you see, and you see what has come of it. Stay on with me.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Chad looked grave.

``How much longer?'' (unknown)

``Well, till I make you a sign. I can't myself, you know, at the best, or at the worst, stay for ever. Let the Pococks come,'' (Strether)
Strether repeated.

``Because it gains you time?'' (unknown)

``Yes--it gains me time.'' (Chad)

Chad, as if it still puzzled him (Chad), waited a minute.

``You don't want to get back to Mother?'' (unknown)

``Not just yet. I'm not ready.'' (unknown)

``You feel,'' (Chad)
Chad asked in a tone of his (Chad) own,
``the charm of life over here?'' (Chad)

``Immensely.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether faced it.
``You've helped me so to feel it that that surely needn't surprise you.'' (unknown)

``No, it doesn't surprise me, and I'm delighted. But what, my dear man,'' (Chad)
Chad went on with conscious queerness,
``does it all lead to for you?'' (Chad)

The change of position and of relation, for each, was so oddly betrayed in the question that Chad laughed out as soon as he (Chad) had uttered it--which made Strether also laugh.

``Well, to my having a certitude that has been tested--that has passed through the fire. But oh,'' (he)
he (Strether) couldn't help breaking out,
``if within my first month here you had been willing to move with me--!'' (he)

``Well?'' (Chad/Chad Newsome/Newsome)
said Chad, while he (Chad) broke down as for weight of thought.

``Well, we should have been over there by now.'' (unknown)

``Ah but you wouldn't have had your fun!'' (unknown)

``I should have had a month of it; and I'm having now, if you want to know,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether continued,
``enough to last me for the rest of my days.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Chad looked amused and interested, yet still somewhat in the dark; partly perhaps because Strether's estimate of fun had required of him (Strether) from the first a good deal of elucidation.

``It wouldn't do if I left you--?'' (unknown)

``Left me?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
--Strether remained blank.

``Only for a month or two--time to go and come. Madame de Vionnet,'' (Chad)
Chad smiled,
``would look after you in the interval.'' (Chad)

``To go back by yourself, I remaining here?'' (unknown)
Again for an instant their eyes had the question out; after which Strether said:
``Grotesque!'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

``But I want to see Mother,'' (Chad)
Chad presently returned.
``Remember how long it is since I've seen Mother.'' (unknown)

``Long indeed; and that's exactly why I was originally so keen for moving you. Hadn't you shown us enough how beautifully you could do without it?'' (unknown)

``Oh but,'' (Chad)
said Chad wonderfully,
``I'm better now.'' (Chad)

There was an easy triumph in it that made his (Chad) friend laugh out again.

``Oh if you were worse I SHOULD know what to do with you. In that case I believe I'd have you gagged and strapped down, carried on board resisting, kicking. How MUCH,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether asked,
``do you want to see Mother?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

``How much?'' (Chad)
--Chad seemed to find it in fact difficult to say.

``How much.'' (unknown)

``Why as much as you've made me. I'd give anything to see her (Mother). And you've left me,'' (Chad)
Chad went on,
``in little enough doubt as to how much SHE wants it.'' (Chad)

Strether thought a minute.

``Well then if those things are really your motive catch the French steamer and sail to-morrow. Of course, when it comes to that, you're absolutely free to do as you choose. From the moment you can't hold yourself I can only accept your flight.'' (unknown)

``I'll fly in a minute then,'' (Chad)
said Chad,
``if you'll stay here.'' (Chad)

``I'll stay here till the next steamer--then I'll follow you.'' (unknown)

``And do you call that,'' (Chad/Chad Newsome/Newsome)
Chad asked,
``accepting my flight?'' (Chad/Chad Newsome/Newsome)

``Certainly--it's the only thing to call it. The only way to keep me here, accordingly,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether explained,
``is by staying yourself.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Chad took it in.

``All the more that I've really dished you, eh?'' (unknown)

``Dished me?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether echoed as inexpressively as possible.

``Why if she (you) sends out the Pococks it will be that she (you) doesn't trust you, and if she (you) doesn't trust you, that bears upon--well, you know what.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether decided after a moment that he (Strether) did know what, and in consonance with this he (Strether) spoke.

``You see then all the more what you owe me.'' (unknown)

``Well, if I do see, how can I pay?'' (unknown)

``By not deserting me. By standing by me.'' (unknown)

``Oh I say--!'' (Chad)
But Chad, as they went downstairs, clapped a firm hand, in the manner of a pledge, upon his (Chad) shoulder. They descended slowly together and had, in the court of the hotel, some further talk, of which the upshot was that they presently separated. Chad Newsome departed, and Strether, left alone, looked about, superficially, for Waymarsh. But Waymarsh hadn't yet, it appeared, come down, and our friend finally went forth without sight of him (friend).

III

At four o'clock that afternoon he (friend) had still not seen him (friend), but he (friend) was then, as to make up for this, engaged in talk about him (friend) with Miss Gostrey. Strether had kept away from home all day, given himself up to the town and to his (Strether) thoughts, wandered and mused, been at once restless and absorbed--and all with the present climax of a rich little welcome in the Quartier Marboeuf.

``Waymarsh has been, `unbeknown' to me, I'm convinced'' (Miss Gostrey)
--for Miss Gostrey had enquired--
``in communication with Woollett: the consequence of which was, last night, the loudest possible call for me.'' (Miss Gostrey)

``Do you mean a letter to bring you home?'' (unknown)

``No--a cable, which I have at this moment in my pocket: a

``Come back by the first ship.''' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether's hostess, it might have been made out, just escaped changing colour. Reflexion arrived but in time and established a provisional serenity. It was perhaps exactly this that enabled her (hostess) to say with duplicity:

``And you're going--?'' (her)

``You almost deserve it when you abandon me so.'' (She)

She (hostess) shook her (hostess) head as if this were not worth taking up.

``My absence has helped you--as I've only to look at you to see. It was my calculation, and I'm justified. You're not where you were. And the thing,'' (she)
she (hostess) smiled,
``was for me not to be there either. You can go of yourself.'' (she)

``Oh but I feel to-day,'' (he)
he (Strether) comfortably declared,
``that I shall want you yet.'' (he)

She (hostess) took him (Strether) all in again.

``Well, I promise you not again to leave you, but it will only be to follow you. You've got your momentum and can toddle alone.'' (He)

He (Strether) intelligently accepted it.

``Yes--I suppose I can toddle. It's the sight of that in fact that has upset Waymarsh. He (You) can bear it--the way I strike him (You) as going--no longer. That's only the climax of his (You) original feeling. He (You) wants me to quit; and he (You) must have written to Woollett that I'm in peril of perdition.'' (unknown)

``Ah good!'' (she)
she (hostess) murmured.
``But is it only your supposition?'' (unknown)

``I make it out--it explains.'' (unknown)

``Then he (You) denies?--or you haven't asked him (You)?'' (unknown)

``I've not had time,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether said;
``I made it out but last night, putting various things together, and I've not been since then face to face with him (You).'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

She (hostess) wondered.

``Because you're too disgusted? You can't trust yourself?'' (He)

He (Strether) settled his (Strether) glasses on his (Strether) nose.

``Do I look in a great rage?'' (unknown)

``You look divine!'' (unknown)

``There's nothing,'' (he)
he (Strether) went on,
``to be angry about. He (You) has done me on the contrary a service.'' (he)

She (hostess) made it out.

``By bringing things to a head?'' (unknown)

``How well you understand!'' (he)
he (Strether) almost groaned.
``Waymarsh won't in the least, at any rate, when I have it out with him (You), deny or extenuate. He (You) has acted from the deepest conviction, with the best conscience and after wakeful nights. He (You)'ll recognise that he (You)'s fully responsible, and will consider that he (You) has been highly successful; so that any discussion we may have will bring us quite together again--bridge the dark stream that has kept us so thoroughly apart. We shall have at last, in the consequences of his (You) act, something we can definitely talk about.'' (She)

She (hostess) was silent a little.

``How wonderfully you take it! But you're always wonderful.'' (He)

He (Strether) had a pause that matched her (hostess) own; then he (Strether) had, with an adequate spirit, a complete admission.

``It's quite true. I'm extremely wonderful just now. I dare say in fact I'm quite fantastic, and I shouldn't be at all surprised if I were mad.'' (unknown)

``Then tell me!'' (she)
she (hostess) earnestly pressed. As he (Strether), however, for the time answered nothing, only returning the look with which she (hostess) watched him (Strether), she (hostess) presented herself where it was easier to meet her (hostess).
``What will Mr. Waymarsh exactly have done?'' (unknown)

``Simply have written a letter. One will have been quite enough. He (Waymarsh) has told them I want looking after.'' (unknown)

``And DO you?'' (she)
--she (hostess) was all interest.

``Immensely. And I shall get it.'' (unknown)

``By which you mean you don't budge?'' (unknown)

``I don't budge.'' (unknown)

``You've cabled?'' (unknown)

``No--I've made Chad do it.'' (unknown)

``That you decline to come?'' (unknown)

``That HE (Chad) declines. We had it out this morning and I brought him (Chad) round. He (Chad) had come in, before I was down, to tell me he (Chad) was ready--ready, I mean, to return. And he (Chad) went off, after ten minutes with me, to say he (Chad) wouldn't.'' (Miss Gostrey)

Miss Gostrey followed with intensity.

``Then you've STOPPED him (Chad)?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether settled himself afresh in his (Strether) chair.

``I've stopped him (Chad). That is for the time. That'' (he)
--he (Strether) gave it to her (Gostrey) more vividly--
``is where I am.'' (he)

``I see, I see. But where's Mr. Newsome? He (Newsome) was ready,'' (she)
she (Gostrey) asked,
``to go?'' (she)

``All ready.'' (unknown)

``And sincerely--believing YOU

``D be?'' (unknown)

``Perfectly, I think; so that he (Newsome) was amazed to find the hand I had laid on him (Newsome) to pull him (Newsome) over suddenly converted into an engine for keeping him (Newsome) still.'' (unknown)

It was an account of the matter Miss Gostrey could weigh.

``Does he (Newsome) think the conversion sudden?'' (unknown)

``Well,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
said Strether,
``I'm not altogether sure what he (Newsome) thinks. I'm not sure of anything that concerns him (Newsome), except that the more I've seen of him (Newsome) the less I've found him (Newsome) what I originally expected. He (Newsome)'s obscure, and that's why I'm waiting.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

She (Gostrey) wondered.

``But for what in particular?'' (unknown)

``For the answer to his (Newsome) cable.'' (unknown)

``And what was his (Newsome) cable?'' (unknown)

``I don't know,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether replied; ``it was to be, when he (Newsome) left me, according to his (Newsome) own taste. I simply said to him (Newsome): ``I want to stay, and the only way for me to do so is for you to.
'' That I wanted to stay seemed to interest him (Strether), and he (Strether) acted on that.'' (me)

Miss Gostrey turned it over.

``He (Newsome) wants then himself to stay.'' (unknown)

``He (Newsome) half wants it. That is he (Newsome) half wants to go. My original appeal has to that extent worked in him (Newsome). Nevertheless,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether pursued,
``he (Newsome) won't go. Not, at least, so long as I'm here.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

``But you can't,'' (companion)
his (Strether) companion suggested,
``stay here always. I wish you could.'' (companion)

``By no means. Still, I want to see him (Newsome) a little further. He (Newsome)'s not in the least the case I supposed, he (Newsome)'s quite another case. And it's as such that he (Newsome) interests me.'' (friend)
It was almost as if for his (Strether) own intelligence that, deliberate and lucid, our friend thus expressed the matter.
``I don't want to give him (Newsome) up.'' (Miss Gostrey)

Miss Gostrey but desired to help his (friend) lucidity. She (Gostrey) had however to be light and tactful.

``Up, you mean--a--to his (Newsome) mother?'' (unknown)

``Well, I'm not thinking of his (Newsome) mother now. I'm thinking of the plan of which I was the mouthpiece, which, as soon as we met, I put before him (Newsome) as persuasively as I knew how, and which was drawn up, as it were, in complete ignorance of all that, in this last long period, has been happening to him (Newsome). It took no account whatever of the impression I was here on the spot immediately to begin to receive from him (Newsome)--impressions of which I feel sure I'm far from having had the last.'' (Miss Gostrey)

Miss Gostrey had a smile of the most genial criticism.

``So your idea is--more or less--to stay out of curiosity?'' (unknown)

``Call it what you like! I don't care what it's called--'' (unknown)

``So long as you do stay? Certainly not then. I call it, all the same, immense fun,'' (Maria/Maria Gostrey)
Maria Gostrey declared;
``and to see you work it out will be one of the sensations of my life. It IS clear you can toddle alone!'' (Maria/Maria Gostrey)

He (friend) received this tribute without elation.

``I shan't be alone when the Pococks have come.'' (unknown)

Her (Gostrey) eyebrows went up.

``The Pococks are coming?'' (unknown)

``That, I mean, is what will happen--and happen as quickly as possible--in consequence of Chad's cable. They'll simply embark. Sarah will come to speak for her (Sarah) mother--with an effect different from MY muddle.'' (unknown)

Miss Gostrey more gravely wondered.

``SHE then will take him (Chad) back?'' (unknown)

``Very possibly--and we shall see. She (Sarah) must at any rate have the chance, and she (Sarah) may be trusted to do all she (Sarah) can.'' (unknown)

``And do you WANT that?'' (unknown)

``Of course,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
said Strether,
``I want it. I want to play fair.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

But she (Gostrey) had lost for a moment the thread.

``If it devolves on the Pococks why do you stay?'' (unknown)

``Just to see that I DO play fair--and a little also, no doubt, that they do.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether was luminous as he (Strether) had never been.
``I came out to find myself in presence of new facts--facts that have kept striking me as less and less met by our old reasons. The matter's perfectly simple. New reasons--reasons as new as the facts themselves--are wanted; and of this our friends at Woollett--Chad's and mine--were at the earliest moment definitely notified. If any are producible Mrs. Pocock will produce them; she (Pocock)'ll bring over the whole collection. They'll be,'' (he)
he (Strether) added with a pensive smile
``a part of the `fun' you speak of.'' (he)

She (Gostrey) was quite in the current now and floating by his (Strether) side.

``It's Mamie--so far as I've had it from you--who'll be their great card.'' (she)
And then as his (Strether) contemplative silence wasn't a denial she (Gostrey) significantly added:
``I think I'm sorry for her (Mamie).'' (she)

``I think I am!'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
--and Strether sprang up, moving about a little as her (Gostrey) eyes followed him (Strether).
``But it can't be helped.'' (unknown)

``You mean her (Mamie) coming out can't be?'' (He)

He (Strether) explained after another turn what he (Strether) meant.

``The only way for her (Mamie) not to come is for me to go home--as I believe that on the spot I could prevent it. But the difficulty as to that is that if I do go home--'' (she)

``I see, I see'' (she)
--she (Gostrey) had easily understood.
``Mr. Newsome will do the same, and that's not'' (she)
--she (Gostrey) laughed out now--
``to be thought of.'' (she)

Strether had no laugh; he (Strether) had only a quiet comparatively placid look that might have shown him (Strether) as proof against ridicule.

``Strange, isn't it?'' (unknown)

They had, in the matter that so much interested them, come so far as this without sounding another name--to which however their present momentary silence was full of a conscious reference. Strether's question was a sufficient implication of the weight it had gained with him (Strether) during the absence of his (Strether) hostess; and just for that reason a single gesture from her (hostess) could pass for him (Strether) as a vivid answer. Yet he (Strether) was answered still better when she (hostess) said in a moment:

``Will Mr. Newsome introduce his (Newsome) sister--?'' (she)

``To Madame de Vionnet?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether spoke the name at last.
``I shall be greatly surprised if he (Newsome) doesn't.'' (She)

She (hostess) seemed to gaze at the possibility.

``You mean you've thought of it and you're prepared.'' (unknown)

``I've thought of it and I'm prepared.'' (visitor)

It was to her (hostess) visitor now that she (hostess) applied her (hostess) consideration.

``Bon! You ARE magnificent!'' (unknown)

``Well,'' (he)
he (visitor) answered after a pause and a little wearily, but still standing there before her (hostess)--
``well, that's what, just once in all my dull days, I think I shall like to have been!'' (he)

Two days later he (visitor) had news from Chad of a communication from Woollett in response to their determinant telegram, this missive being addressed to Chad himself and announcing the immediate departure for France of Sarah and Jim and Mamie. Strether had meanwhile on his (Strether) own side cabled; he (Strether) had but delayed that act till after his (Strether) visit to Miss Gostrey, an interview by which, as so often before, he (Strether) felt his (Strether) sense of things cleared up and settled. His (Strether) message to Mrs. Newsome, in answer to her (Newsome) own, had consisted of the words:

``Judge best to take another month, but with full appreciation of all re-enforcements.'' (Mrs. Newsome)
He (Strether) had added that he (Strether) was writing, but he (Strether) was of course always writing; it was a practice that continued, oddly enough, to relieve him (Strether), to make him (Strether) come nearer than anything else to the consciousness of doing something: so that he (Strether) often wondered if he (Strether) hadn't really, under his (Strether) recent stress, acquired some hollow trick, one of the specious arts of make-believe. Wouldn't the pages he (Strether) still so freely dispatched by the American post have been worthy of a showy journalist, some master of the great new science of beating the sense out of words? Wasn't he (master) writing against time, and mainly to show he (master) was kind?--since it had become quite his (master) habit not to like to read himself over. On those lines he (master) could still be liberal, yet it was at best a sort of whistling in the dark. It was unmistakeable moreover that the sense of being in the dark now pressed on him (master) more sharply--creating thereby the need for a louder and livelier whistle. He (master) whistled long and hard after sending his (master) message; he (master) whistled again and again in celebration of Chad's news; there was an interval of a fortnight in which this exercise helped him (Chad). He (Chad) had no great notion of what, on the spot, Sarah Pocock would have to say, though he (Chad) had indeed confused premonitions; but it shouldn't be in her (Pocock) power to say--it shouldn't be in any one's anywhere to say--that he (Chad) was neglecting her (Pocock) mother. He (Chad) might have written before more freely, but he (Chad) had never written more copiously; and he (Chad) frankly gave for a reason at Woollett that he (Chad) wished to fill the void created there by Sarah's departure.

The increase of his (Chad) darkness, however, and the quickening, as I have called it, of his (Chad) tune, resided in the fact that he (Chad) was hearing almost nothing. He (Chad) had for some time been aware that he (Chad) was hearing less than before, and he (Chad) was now clearly following a process by which Mrs. Newsome's letters could but logically stop. He (Chad) hadn't had a line for many days, and he (Chad) needed no proof--though he (Chad) was, in time, to have plenty--that she (Newsome) wouldn't have put pen to paper after receiving the hint that had determined her (Newsome) telegram. She (Newsome) wouldn't write till Sarah should have seen him (Chad) and reported on him (Chad). It was strange, though it might well be less so than his (Chad) own behaviour appeared at Woollett. It was at any rate significant, and what WAS remarkable was the way his (Chad) friend's nature and manner put on for him (Chad), through this very drop of demonstration, a greater intensity. It struck him (Chad) really that he (Chad) had never so lived with her (Sarah) as during this period of her (Sarah) silence; the silence was a sacred hush, a finer clearer medium, in which her (Sarah) idiosyncrasies showed. He (Chad) walked about with her (Sarah), sat with her (Sarah), drove with her (Sarah) and dined face-to-face with her (Sarah)--a rare treat

``in his (Judge) life,'' (her)
as he (Chad) could perhaps have scarce escaped phrasing it; and if he (Chad) had never seen her (Sarah) so soundless he (Chad) had never, on the other hand, felt her (Sarah) so highly, so almost austerely, herself: pure and by the vulgar estimate
``cold,'' (he)
but deep devoted delicate sensitive noble. Her (Sarah) vividness in these respects became for him (Chad), in the special conditions, almost an obsession; and though the obsession sharpened his (Chad) pulses, adding really to the excitement of life, there were hours at which, to be less on the stretch, he (Chad) directly sought forgetfulness. He (Chad) knew it for the queerest of adventures--a circumstance capable of playing such a part only for Lambert Strether--that in Paris itself, of all places, he (Strether) should find this ghost of the lady of Woollett more importunate than any other presence.

When he (Strether) went back to Maria Gostrey it was for the change to something else. And yet after all the change scarcely operated for he (Strether) talked to her (Gostrey) of Mrs. Newsome in these days as he (Strether) had never talked before. He (Strether) had hitherto observed in that particular a discretion and a law; considerations that at present broke down quite as if relations had altered. They hadn't REALLY altered, he (Strether) said to himself, so much as that came to; for if what had occurred was of course that Mrs. Newsome had ceased to trust him (Strether), there was nothing on the other hand to prove that he (Strether) shouldn't win back her (Newsome) confidence. It was quite his (Strether) present theory that he (Strether) would leave no stone unturned to do so; and in fact if he (Strether) now told Maria things about her (Maria) that he (Strether) had never told before this was largely because it kept before him (Strether) the idea of the honour of such a woman's esteem. His (Strether) relation with Maria as well was, strangely enough, no longer quite the same; this truth--though not too disconcertingly--had come up between them on the renewal of their meetings. It was all contained in what she (Maria) had then almost immediately said to him (Strether); it was represented by the remark she (Maria) had needed but ten minutes to make and that he (Strether) hadn't been disposed to gainsay. He (Strether) could toddle alone, and the difference that showed was extraordinary. The turn taken by their talk had promptly confirmed this difference; his (Strether) larger confidence on the score of Mrs. Newsome did the rest; and the time seemed already far off when he (Strether) had held out his (Strether) small thirsty cup to the spout of her (Newsome) pail. Her (Newsome) pail was scarce touched now, and other fountains had flowed for him (Strether); she (Newsome) fell into her (Newsome) place as but one of his (Strether) tributaries; and there was a strange sweetness--a melancholy mildness that touched him (Strether)--in her (Newsome) acceptance of the altered order.

It marked for himself the flight of time, or at any rate what he (Strether) was pleased to think of with irony and pity as the rush of experience; it having been but the day before yesterday that he (Strether) sat at her (Newsome) feet and held on by her (Newsome) garment and was fed by her (Newsome) hand. It was the proportions that were changed, and the proportions were at all times, he (Strether) philosophised, the very conditions of perception, the terms of thought. It was as if, with her (Newsome) effective little entresol and and her (Newsome) wide acquaintance, her (Newsome) activities, varieties, promiscuities, the duties and devotions that took up nine tenths of her (Newsome) time and of which he (acquaintance) got, guardedly, but the side-wind--it was as if she (Newsome) had shrunk to a secondary element and had consented to the shrinkage with the perfection of tact. This perfection had never failed her (Newsome); it had originally been greater than his (acquaintance) prime measure for it; it had kept him (acquaintance) quite apart, kept him (acquaintance) out of the shop, as she (Newsome) called her (Newsome) huge general acquaintance, made their commerce as quiet, as much a thing of the home alone--the opposite of the shop--as if she (Newsome) had never another customer. She (Newsome) had been wonderful to him (acquaintance) at first, with the memory of her (Newsome) little entresol, the image to which, on most mornings at that time, his (acquaintance) eyes directly opened; but now she (Newsome) mainly figured for him (acquaintance) as but part of the bristling total--though of course always as a person to whom he (acquaintance) should never cease to be indebted. It would never be given to him (acquaintance) certainly to inspire a greater kindness. She (Newsome) had decked him (acquaintance) out for others, and he (acquaintance) saw at this point at least nothing she (Newsome) would ever ask for. She (Newsome) only wondered and questioned and listened, rendering him (acquaintance) the homage of a wistful speculation. She (Newsome) expressed it repeatedly; he (acquaintance) was already far beyond her (Newsome), and she (Newsome) must prepare herself to lose him (acquaintance). There was but one little chance for her (Newsome).

Often as she (Newsome) had said it he (acquaintance) met it--for it was a touch he (acquaintance) liked--each time the same way.

``My coming to grief?'' (unknown)

``Yes--then I might patch you up.'' (unknown)

``Oh for my real smash, if it takes place, there will be no patching.'' (unknown)

``But you surely don't mean it will kill you.'' (unknown)

``No--worse. It will make me old.'' (unknown)

``Ah nothing can do that! The wonderful and special thing about you is that you ARE, at this time of day, youth.'' (she)
Then she (Newsome) always made, further, one of those remarks that she (Newsome) had completely ceased to adorn with hesitations or apologies, and that had, by the same token, in spite of their extreme straightness, ceased to produce in Strether the least embarrassment. She (Newsome) made him (acquaintance) believe them, and they became thereby as impersonal as truth itself.
``It's just your particular charm.'' (unknown)

His (acquaintance) answer too was always the same. ``Of course I'm youth--youth for the trip to Europe. I began to be young, or at least to get the benefit of it, the moment I met you at Chester, and that's what has been taking place ever since. I never had the benefit at the proper time--which comes to saying that I never had the thing itself. I'm having the benefit at this moment; I had it the other day when I said to Chad

``Wait'; I shall have it still again when Sarah Pocock arrives. It's a benefit that would make a poor show for many people; and I don't know who else but you and I, frankly, could begin to see in it what I feel. I don't get drunk; I don't pursue the ladies; I don't spend money; I don't even write sonnets. But nevertheless I'm making up late for what I didn't have early. I cultivate my little benefit in my own little way. It amuses me more than anything that has happened to me in all my life. They may say what they like--it's my surrender, it's my tribute, to youth. One puts that in where one can--it has to come in somewhere, if only out of the lives, the conditions, the feelings of other persons. Chad gives me the sense of it, for all his (Chad) grey hairs, which merely make it solid in him (Chad) and safe and serene; and SHE does the same, for all her (it) being older than he (Chad), for all her (it) marriageable daughter, her (it) separated husband, her (it) agitated history. Though they're young enough, my pair, I don't say they're, in the freshest way, their own absolutely prime adolescence; for that has nothing to do with it. The point is that they're mine. Yes, they're my youth; since somehow at the right time nothing else ever was. What I meant just now therefore is that it would all go--go before doing its work--if they were to fail me.'' (Miss Gostrey)

On which, just here, Miss Gostrey inveterately questioned.

``What do you, in particular, call its work?'' (unknown)

``Well, to see me through.'' (unknown)

``But through what?'' (she)
--she (Gostrey) liked to get it all out of him (acquaintance).

``Why through this experience.'' (unknown)
That was all that would come.

It regularly gave her (Gostrey) none the less the last word.

``Don't you remember how in those first days of our meeting it was I who was to see you through?'' (unknown)

``Remember? Tenderly, deeply'' (he)
--he (acquaintance) always rose to it.
``You're just doing your part in letting me maunder to you thus.'' (unknown)

``Ah don't speak as if my part were small; since whatever else fails you--'' (unknown)

``YOU won't, ever, ever, ever?'' (he)
--he (acquaintance) thus took her (Gostrey) up.
``Oh I beg your pardon; you necessarily, you inevitably WILL. Your conditions--that's what I mean--won't allow me anything to do for you.'' (unknown)

``Let alone--I see what you mean--that I'm drearily dreadfully old. I AM, but there's a service--possible for you to render--that I know, all the same, I shall think of.'' (unknown)

``And what will it be?'' (she)

This, in fine, however, she (Gostrey) would never tell him (acquaintance).

``You shall hear only if your smash takes place. As that's really out of the question, I won't expose myself'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
--a point at which, for reasons of his (acquaintance) own, Strether ceased to press.

He (acquaintance) came round, for publicity--it was the easiest thing--to the idea that his (acquaintance) smash WAS out of the question, and this rendered idle the discussion of what might follow it. He (acquaintance) attached an added importance, as the days elapsed, to the arrival of the Pococks; he (acquaintance) had even a shameful sense of waiting for it insincerely and incorrectly. He (acquaintance) accused himself of making believe to his (acquaintance) own mind that Sarah's presence, her (Sarah) impression, her (Sarah) judgement would simplify and harmonise, he (acquaintance) accused himself of being so afraid of what they MIGHT do that he (acquaintance) sought refuge, to beg the whole question, in a vain fury. He (acquaintance) had abundantly seen at home what they were in the habit of doing, and he (acquaintance) had not at present the smallest ground. His (acquaintance) clearest vision was when he (acquaintance) made out that what he (acquaintance) most desired was an account more full and free of Mrs. Newsome's state of mind than any he (acquaintance) felt he (acquaintance) could now expect from herself; that calculation at least went hand in hand with the sharp consciousness of wishing to prove to himself that he (acquaintance) was not afraid to look his (acquaintance) behaviour in the face. If he (acquaintance) was by an inexorable logic to pay for it he (acquaintance) was literally impatient to know the cost, and he (acquaintance) held himself ready to pay in instalments. The first instalment would be precisely this entertainment of Sarah; as a consequence of which moreover, he (acquaintance) should know vastly better how he (acquaintance) stood.

Book Eighth

I

Strether rambled alone during these few days, the effect of the incident of the previous week having been to simplify in a marked fashion his (acquaintance) mixed relations with Waymarsh. Nothing had passed between them in reference to Mrs. Newsome's summons but that our friend had mentioned to his (friend) own the departure of the deputation actually at sea--giving him (friend) thus an opportunity to confess to the occult intervention he (friend) imputed to him (friend). Waymarsh however in the event confessed to nothing; and though this falsified in some degree Strether's forecast the latter amusedly saw in it the same depth of good conscience out of which the dear man's impertinence had originally sprung. He (man) was patient with the dear man now and delighted to observe how unmistakeably he (man) had put on flesh; he (man) felt his (man) own holiday so successfully large and free that he (man) was full of allowances and charities in respect to those cabined and confined' his (man) instinct toward a spirit so strapped down as Waymarsh's was to walk round it on tiptoe for fear of waking it up to a sense of losses by this time irretrievable. It was all very funny he (man) knew, and but the difference, as he (man) often said to himself, of tweedledum and tweedledee--an emancipation so purely comparative that it was like the advance of the door-mat on the scraper; yet the present crisis was happily to profit by it and the pilgrim from Milrose to know himself more than ever in the right.

Strether felt that when he (Strether) heard of the approach of the Pococks the impulse of pity quite sprang up in him (Strether) beside the impulse of triumph. That was exactly why Waymarsh had looked at him (Strether) with eyes in which the heat of justice was measured and shaded. He (Strether) had looked very hard, as if affectionately sorry for the friend--the friend of fifty-five--whose frivolity had had thus to be recorded; becoming, however, but obscurely sententious and leaving his (friend) companion to formulate a charge. It was in this general attitude that he (friend) had of late altogether taken refuge; with the drop of discussion they were solemnly sadly superficial; Strether recognised in him (Strether) the mere portentous rumination to which Miss Barrace had so good-humouredly described herself as assigning a corner of her (Strether) salon. It was quite as if he (Strether) knew his (Strether) surreptitious step had been divined, and it was also as if he (Strether) missed the chance to explain the purity of his (Strether) motive; but this privation of relief should be precisely his (Strether) small penance: it was not amiss for Strether that he (Strether) should find himself to that degree uneasy. If he (Strether) had been challenged or accused, rebuked for meddling or otherwise pulled up, he (Strether) would probably have shown, on his (Strether) own system, all the height of his (Strether) consistency, all the depth of his (Strether) good faith. Explicit resentment of his (Strether) course would have made him (Strether) take the floor, and the thump of his (Strether) fist on the table would have affirmed him (Strether) as consciously incorruptible. Had what now really prevailed with Strether been but a dread of that thump--a dread of wincing a little painfully at what it might invidiously demonstrate? However this might be, at any rate, one of the marks of the crisis was a visible, a studied lapse, in Waymarsh, of betrayed concern. As if to make up to his (Strether) comrade for the stroke by which he (Strether) had played providence he (Strether) now conspicuously ignored his (Strether) movements, withdrew himself from the pretension to share them, stiffened up his (Strether) sensibility to neglect, and, clasping his (Strether) large empty hands and swinging his (Strether) large restless foot, clearly looked to another quarter for justice.

This made for independence on Strether's part, and he (Strether) had in truth at no moment of his (Strether) stay been so free to go and come. The early summer brushed the picture over and blurred everything but the near; it made a vast warm fragrant medium in which the elements floated together on the best of terms, in which rewards were immediate and reckonings postponed. Chad was out of town again, for the first time since his (Chad) visitor's first view of him (Chad); he (Chad) had explained this necessity--without detail, yet also without embarrassment, the circumstance was one of those which, in the young man's life, testified to the variety of his (man) ties. Strether wasn't otherwise concerned with it than for its so testifying--a pleasant multitudinous image in which he (Strether) took comfort. He (Strether) took comfort, by the same stroke, in the swing of Chad's pendulum back from that other swing, the sharp jerk towards Woollett, so stayed by his (jerk) own hand. He (jerk) had the entertainment of thinking that if he (jerk) had for that moment stopped the clock it was to promote the next minute this still livelier motion. He (jerk) himself did what he (jerk) hadn't done before; he (jerk) took two or three times whole days off--irrespective of others, of two or three taken with Miss Gostrey, two or three taken with little Bilham: he (Bilham) went to Chartres and cultivated, before the front of the cathedral, a general easy beatitude; he (Bilham) went to Fontainebleau and imagined himself on the way to Italy; he (Bilham) went to Rouen with a little handbag and inordinately spent the night.

One afternoon he (Bilham) did something quite different; finding himself in the neighbourhood of a fine old house across the river, he (Bilham) passed under the great arch of its doorway and asked at the porter's lodge for Madame de Vionnet. He (Vionnet) had already hovered more than once about that possibility, been aware of it, in the course of ostensible strolls, as lurking but round the corner. Only it had perversely happened, after his (Vionnet) morning at Notre Dame, that his (Vionnet) consistency, as he (Vionnet) considered and intended it, had come back to him (Vionnet); whereby he (Vionnet) had reflected that the encounter in question had been none of his (Vionnet) making; clinging again intensely to the strength of his (Vionnet) position, which was precisely that there was nothing in it for himself. From the moment he (Vionnet) actively pursued the charming associate of his (Vionnet) adventure, from that moment his (Vionnet) position weakened, for he (Vionnet) was then acting in an interested way. It was only within a few days that he (Vionnet) had fixed himself a limit: he (Vionnet) promised himself his (Vionnet) consistency should end with Sarah's arrival. It was arguing correctly to feel the title to a free hand conferred on him (Vionnet) by this event. If he (Vionnet) wasn't to be let alone he (Vionnet) should be merely a dupe to act with delicacy. If he (Vionnet) wasn't to be trusted he (Vionnet) could at least take his (Vionnet) ease. If he (Vionnet) was to be placed under control he (Vionnet) gained leave to try what his (Vionnet) position MIGHT agreeably give him (Vionnet). An ideal rigour would perhaps postpone the trial till after the Pococks had shown their spirit; and it was to an ideal rigour that he (Vionnet) had quite promised himself to conform.

Suddenly, however, on this particular day, he (Vionnet) felt a particular fear under which everything collapsed. He (Vionnet) knew abruptly that he (Vionnet) was afraid of himself--and yet not in relation to the effect on his (Vionnet) sensibilities of another hour of Madame de Vionnet. What he (Vionnet) dreaded was the effect of a single hour of Sarah Pocock, as to whom he (Vionnet) was visited, in troubled nights, with fantastic waking dreams. She (Pocock) loomed at him (Vionnet) larger than life; she (Pocock) increased in volume as she (Pocock) drew nearer; she (Pocock) so met his (Vionnet) eyes that, his (Vionnet) imagination taking, after the first step, all, and more than all, the strides, he (Vionnet) already felt her (Pocock) come down on him (Vionnet), already burned, under her (Pocock) reprobation, with the blush of guilt, already consented, by way of penance, to the instant forfeiture of everything. He (Vionnet) saw himself, under her (Pocock) direction, recommitted to Woollett as juvenile offenders are committed to reformatories. It wasn't of course that Woollett was really a place of discipline; but he (Vionnet) knew in advance that Sarah's salon at the hotel would be. His (Vionnet) danger, at any rate, in such moods of alarm, was some concession, on this ground, that would involve a sharp rupture with the actual; therefore if he (Vionnet) waited to take leave of that actual he (Vionnet) might wholly miss his (Vionnet) chance. It was represented with supreme vividness by Madame de Vionnet, and that is why, in a word, he (Vionnet) waited no longer. He (Vionnet) had seen in a flash that he (Vionnet) must anticipate Mrs. Pocock. He (Vionnet) was accordingly much disappointed on now learning from the portress that the lady of his (Vionnet) quest was not in Paris. She (lady) had gone for some days to the country. There was nothing in this accident but what was natural; yet it produced for poor Strether a drop of all confidence. It was suddenly as if he (Strether) should never see her (lady) again, and as if moreover he (Strether) had brought it on himself by not having been quite kind to her (lady).

It was the advantage of his (Strether) having let his (Strether) fancy lose itself for a little in the gloom that, as by reaction, the prospect began really to brighten from the moment the deputation from Woollett alighted on the platform of the station. They had come straight from Havre, having sailed from New York to that port, and having also, thanks to a happy voyage, made land with a promptitude that left Chad Newsome, who had meant to meet them at the dock, belated. He (Newsome) had received their telegram, with the announcement of their immediate further advance, just as he (Newsome) was taking the train for Havre, so that nothing had remained for him (Newsome) but to await them in Paris. He (Newsome) hastily picked up Strether, at the hotel, for this purpose, and he (Strether) even, with easy pleasantry, suggested the attendance of Waymarsh as well--Waymarsh, at the moment his (Strether) cab rattled up, being engaged, under Strether's contemplative range, in a grave perambulation of the familiar court. Waymarsh had learned from his (Strether) companion, who had already had a note, delivered by hand, from Chad, that the Pococks were due, and had ambiguously, though, as always, impressively, glowered at him (Chad) over the circumstance; carrying himself in a manner in which Strether was now expert enough to recognise his (Strether) uncertainty, in the premises, as to the best tone. The only tone he (Strether) aimed at with confidence was a full tone--which was necessarily difficult in the absence of a full knowledge. The Pococks were a quantity as yet unmeasured, and, as he (Strether) had practically brought them over, so this witness had to that extent exposed himself. He (witness) wanted to feel right about it, but could only, at the best, for the time, feel vague.

``I shall look to you, you know, immensely,'' (friend)
our friend had said,
``to help me with them,'' (friend)
and he (friend) had been quite conscious of the effect of the remark, and of others of the same sort, on his (friend) comrade's sombre sensibility. He (friend) had insisted on the fact that Waymarsh would quite like Mrs. Pocock--one could be certain he (friend) would: he (friend) would be with her (Waymarsh) about everything, and she (Waymarsh) would also be with HIM, and Miss Barrace's nose, in short, would find itself out of joint.

Strether had woven this web of cheerfulness while they waited in the court for Chad; he (Chad) had sat smoking cigarettes to keep himself quiet while, caged and leonine, his (Chad) fellow traveller paced and turned before him (Chad). Chad Newsome was doubtless to be struck, when he (Newsome) arrived, with the sharpness of their opposition at this particular hour; he (Newsome) was to remember, as a part of it, how Waymarsh came with him (Newsome) and with Strether to the street and stood there with a face half-wistful and half-rueful. They talked of him (Strether), the two others, as they drove, and Strether put Chad in possession of much of his (Strether) own strained sense of things. He (Strether) had already, a few days before, named to him (Strether) the wire he (Strether) was convinced their friend had pulled--a confidence that had made on the young man's part quite hugely for curiosity and diversion. The action of the matter, moreover, Strether could see, was to penetrate; he (Strether) saw that is, how Chad judged a system of influence in which Waymarsh had served as a determinant--an impression just now quickened again; with the whole bearing of such a fact on the youth's view of his (Chad) relatives. As it came up between them that they might now take their friend for a feature of the control of these latter now sought to be exerted from Woollett, Strether felt indeed how it would be stamped all over him (Strether), half an hour later for Sarah Pocock's eyes, that he (Strether) was as much on Chad's

``side'' (Chad/Chad Newsome/Newsome)
as Waymarsh had probably described him (Chad). He (Chad) was letting himself at present, go; there was no denying it; it might be desperation, it might be confidence; he (Chad) should offer himself to the arriving travellers bristling with all the lucidity he (Chad) had cultivated.

He (Chad) repeated to Chad what he (Chad) had been saying in the court to Waymarsh; how there was no doubt whatever that his (Chad) sister would find the latter a kindred spirit, no doubt of the alliance, based on an exchange of views, that the pair would successfully strike up. They would become as thick as thieves--which moreover was but a development of what Strether remembered to have said in one of his (Strether) first discussions with his (Strether) mate, struck as he (Strether) had then already been with the elements of affinity between that personage and Mrs. Newsome herself.

``I told him (I), one day, when he (I) had questioned me on your mother, that she (mother) was a person who, when he (I) should know her (mother), would rouse in him (I), I was sure, a special enthusiasm; and that hangs together with the conviction we now feel--this certitude that Mrs. Pocock will take him (I) into her (Pocock) boat. For it's your mother's own boat that she (Pocock)'s pulling.'' (unknown)

``Ah,'' (Chad)
said Chad,
``Mother's worth fifty of Sally!'' (Chad)

``A thousand; but when you presently meet her (Sally), all the same you'll be meeting your mother's representative--just as I shall. I feel like the outgoing ambassador,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
said Strether,
``doing honour to his (ambassador) appointed successor.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
A moment after speaking as he (Strether) had just done he (Strether) felt he (Strether) had inadvertently rather cheapened Mrs. Newsome to her (Newsome) son; an impression audibly reflected, as at first seen, in Chad's prompt protest. He (Chad) had recently rather failed of apprehension of the young man's attitude and temper--remaining principally conscious of how little worry, at the worst, he (Chad) wasted, and he (Chad) studied him (Chad) at this critical hour with renewed interest. Chad had done exactly what he (Chad) had promised him (Chad) a fortnight previous--had accepted without another question his (Chad) plea for delay. He (Chad) was waiting cheerfully and handsomely, but also inscrutably and with a slight increase perhaps of the hardness originally involved in his (Chad) acquired high polish. He (Chad) was neither excited nor depressed; was easy and acute and deliberate--unhurried unflurried unworried, only at most a little less amused than usual. Strether felt him (Strether) more than ever a justification of the extraordinary process of which his (Strether) own absurd spirit had been the arena; he (Strether) knew as their cab rolled along, knew as he (Strether) hadn't even yet known, that nothing else than what Chad had done and had been would have led to his (Chad) present showing. They had made him (Chad), these things, what he (Chad) was, and the business hadn't been easy; it had taken time and trouble, it had cost, above all, a price. The result at any rate was now to be offered to Sally; which Strether, so far as that was concerned, was glad to be there to witness. Would she (Sally) in the least make it out or take it in, the result, or would she (Sally) in the least care for it if she (Sally) did? He (Strether) scratched his (Strether) chin as he (Strether) asked himself by what name, when challenged--as he (Strether) was sure he (Strether) should be--he (Strether) could call it for her (Sally). Oh those were determinations she (Sally) must herself arrive at; since she (Sally) wanted so much to see, let her (Sally) see then and welcome. She (Sally) had come out in the pride of her (Sally) competence, yet it hummed in Strether's inner sense that she (Sally) practically wouldn't see.

That this was moreover what Chad shrewdly suspected was clear from a word that next dropped from him (Chad).

``They're children; they play at life!'' (unknown)
--and the exclamation was significant and reassuring. It implied that he (Chad) hadn't then, for his (Chad) companion's sensibility, appeared to give Mrs. Newsome away; and it facilitated our friend's presently asking him (friend) if it were his (friend) idea that Mrs. Pocock and Madame de Vionnet should become acquainted. Strether was still more sharply struck, hereupon, with Chad's lucidity.
``Why, isn't that exactly--to get a sight of the company I keep--what she (mother) has come out for?'' (unknown)

``Yes--I'm afraid it is,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether unguardedly replied.

Chad's quick rejoinder lighted his (Strether) precipitation.

``Why do you say you're afraid?'' (unknown)

``Well, because I feel a certain responsibility. It's my testimony, I imagine, that will have been at the bottom of Mrs. Pocock's curiosity. My letters, as I've supposed you to understand from the beginning, have spoken freely. I've certainly said my little say about Madame de Vionnet.'' (Chad)

All that, for Chad, was beautifully obvious.

``Yes, but you've only spoken handsomely.'' (unknown)

``Never more handsomely of any woman. But it's just that tone--!'' (unknown)

``That tone,'' (Chad)
said Chad,
``that has fetched her (woman)? I dare say; but I've no quarrel with you about it. And no more has Madame de Vionnet. Don't you know by this time how she (woman) likes you?'' (Chad)

``Oh!'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
--and Strether had, with his (Strether) groan, a real pang of melancholy.
``For all I've done for her (woman)!'' (unknown)

``Ah you've done a great deal.'' (Chad/Chad Newsome/Newsome)

Chad's urbanity fairly shamed him (Chad), and he (Chad) was at this moment absolutely impatient to see the face Sarah Pocock would present to a sort of thing, as he (Chad) synthetically phrased it to himself, with no adequate forecast of which, despite his (Chad) admonitions, she (Pocock) would certainly arrive.

``I've done THIS!'' (unknown)

``Well, this is all right. She (woman) likes,'' (Chad/Chad Newsome/Newsome)
Chad comfortably remarked,
``to be liked.'' (Chad/Chad Newsome/Newsome)

It gave his (Chad) companion a moment's thought.

``And she (woman)'s sure Mrs. Pocock WILL--?'' (unknown)

``No, I say that for you. She (Pocock) likes your liking her (Pocock); it's so much, as it were,'' (Chad/Chad Newsome/Newsome)
Chad laughed,
``to the good. However, she (Pocock) doesn't despair of Sarah either, and is prepared, on her (Sarah) own side, to go all lengths.'' (Chad/Chad Newsome/Newsome)

``In the way of appreciation?'' (unknown)

``Yes, and of everything else. In the way of general amiability, hospitality and welcome. She (Sarah)'s under arms,'' (Chad/Chad Newsome/Newsome)
Chad laughed again;
``she (Sarah)'s prepared.'' (Chad/Chad Newsome/Newsome)

Strether took it in; then as if an echo of Miss Barrace were in the air:

``She (Sarah)'s wonderful.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

``You don't begin to know HOW wonderful!'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

There was a depth in it, to Strether's ear, of confirmed luxury--almost a kind of unconscious insolence of proprietorship; but the effect of the glimpse was not at this moment to foster speculation: there was something so conclusive in so much graceful and generous assurance. It was in fact a fresh evocation; and the evocation had before many minutes another consequence.

``Well, I shall see her (Sarah) oftener now. I shall see her (Sarah) as much as I like--by your leave; which is what I hitherto haven't done.'' (unknown)

``It has been,'' (Chad)
said Chad, but without reproach,
``only your own fault. I tried to bring you together, and SHE, my dear fellow--I never saw her (Sarah) more charming to any man. But you've got your extraordinary ideas.'' (Chad)

``Well, I DID have,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether murmured, while he (Strether) felt both how they had possessed him (Strether) and how they had now lost their authority. He (Strether) couldn't have traced the sequence to the end, but it was all because of Mrs. Pocock. Mrs. Pocock might be because of Mrs. Newsome, but that was still to be proved. What came over him (Strether) was the sense of having stupidly failed to profit where profit would have been precious. It had been open to him (Strether) to see so much more of her (Pocock), and he (Strether) had but let the good days pass. Fierce in him (Strether) almost was the resolve to lose no more of them, and he (Strether) whimsically reflected, while at Chad's side he (Chad) drew nearer to his (Chad) destination, that it was after all Sarah who would have quickened his (Chad) chance. What her (Sarah) visit of inquisition might achieve in other directions was as yet all obscure--only not obscure that it would do supremely much to bring two earnest persons together. He (Chad) had but to listen to Chad at this moment to feel it; for Chad was in the act of remarking to him (Chad) that they of course both counted on him (Chad)--he (Chad) himself and the other earnest person--for cheer and support. It was brave to Strether to hear him (Strether) talk as if the line of wisdom they had struck out was to make things ravishing to the Pococks. No, if Madame de Vionnet compassed THAT, compassed the ravishment of the Pococks, Madame de Vionnet would be prodigious. It would be a beautiful plan if it succeeded, and it all came to the question of Sarah's being really bribeable. The precedent of his (Vionnet) own case helped Strether perhaps but little to consider she (Sarah) might prove so; it being distinct that her (Sarah) character would rather make for every possible difference. This idea of his (character) own bribeability set him (character) apart for himself; with the further mark in fact that his (character) case was absolutely proved. He (character) liked always, where Lambert Strether was concerned, to know the worst, and what he (Strether) now seemed to know was not only that he (Strether) was bribeable, but that he (Strether) had been effectually bribed. The only difficulty was that he (Strether) couldn't quite have said with what. It was as if he (Strether) had sold himself, but hadn't somehow got the cash. That, however, was what, characteristically, WOULD happen to him (Strether). It would naturally be his (Strether) kind of traffic. While he (Strether) thought of these things he (Strether) reminded Chad of the truth they mustn't lose sight of--the truth that, with all deference to her (Strether) susceptibility to new interests, Sarah would have come out with a high firm definite purpose.
``She (Sarah) hasn't come out, you know, to be bamboozled. We may all be ravishing--nothing perhaps can be more easy for us; but she (Sarah) hasn't come out to be ravished. She (Sarah) has come out just simply to take you home.'' (unknown)

``Oh well, with HER I'll go,'' (Chad)
said Chad good-humouredly.
``I suppose you'll allow THAT.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
And then as for a minute Strether said nothing:
``Or is your idea that when I've seen her (Sarah) I shan't want to go?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
As this question, however, again left his (Strether) friend silent he (Strether) presently went on:
``My own idea at any rate is that they shall have while they're here the best sort of time.'' (he)

It was at this that Strether spoke.

``Ah there you are! I think if you really wanted to go--!'' (unknown)

``Well?'' (Chad)
said Chad to bring it out.

``Well, you wouldn't trouble about our good time. You wouldn't care what sort of a time we have.'' (Chad/Chad Newsome/Newsome)

Chad could always take in the easiest way in the world any ingenious suggestion.

``I see. But can I help it? I'm too decent.'' (unknown)

``Yes, you're too decent!'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether heavily sighed. And he (Strether) felt for the moment as if it were the preposterous end of his (Strether) mission.

It ministered for the time to this temporary effect that Chad made no rejoinder. But he (Chad) spoke again as they came in sight of the station.

``Do you mean to introduce her (I) to Miss Gostrey?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

As to this Strether was ready.

``No.'' (unknown)

``But haven't you told me they know about her (I)?'' (unknown)

``I think I've told you your mother knows.'' (unknown)

``And won't she (mother) have told Sally?'' (unknown)

``That's one of the things I want to see.'' (unknown)

``And if you find she (mother) HAS--?'' (unknown)

``Will I then, you mean, bring them together?'' (unknown)

``Yes,'' (Chad)
said Chad with his (Chad) pleasant promptness:
``to show her (mother) there's nothing in it.'' (Chad)

Strether hesitated.

``I don't know that I care very much what she (mother) may think there's in it.'' (unknown)

``Not if it represents what Mother thinks?'' (unknown)

``Ah what DOES your mother think?'' (unknown)
There was in this some sound of bewilderment.

But they were just driving up, and help, of a sort, might after all be quite at hand.

``Isn't that, my dear man, what we're both just going to make out?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

II

Strether quitted the station half an hour later in different company. Chad had taken charge, for the journey to the hotel, of Sarah, Mamie, the maid and the luggage, all spaciously installed and conveyed; and it was only after the four had rolled away that his (Chad) companion got into a cab with Jim. A strange new feeling had come over Strether, in consequence of which his (Chad) spirits had risen; it was as if what had occurred on the alighting of his (Chad) critics had been something other than his (Chad) fear, though his (Chad) fear had vet not been of an instant scene of violence. His (Chad) impression had been nothing but what was inevitable--he (Chad) said that to himself; yet relief and reassurance had softly dropped upon him (Chad). Nothing could be so odd as to be indebted for these things to the look of faces and the sound of voices that had been with him (Chad) to satiety, as he (Chad) might have said, for years; but he (Chad) now knew, all the same, how uneasy he (Chad) had felt; that was brought home to him (Chad) by his (Chad) present sense of a respite. It had come moreover in the flash of an eye, it had come in the smile with which Sarah, whom, at the window of her (Sarah) compartment, they had effusively greeted from the platform, rustled down to them a moment later, fresh and handsome from her (Sarah) cool June progress through the charming land. It was only a sign, but enough: she (Sarah) was going to be gracious and unallusive, she (Sarah) was going to play the larger game--which was still more apparent, after she (Sarah) had emerged from Chad's arms, in her (Sarah) direct greeting to the valued friend of her (Sarah) family.

Strether WAS then as much as ever the valued friend of her (Sarah) family, it was something he (friend) could at all events go on with; and the manner of his (friend) response to it expressed even for himself how little he (friend) had enjoyed the prospect of ceasing to figure in that likeness. He (friend) had always seen Sarah gracious--had in fact rarely seen her (Sarah) shy or dry, her (Sarah) marked thin-lipped smile, intense without brightness and as prompt to act as the scrape of a safety-match; the protrusion of her (Sarah) rather remarkably long chin, which in her (Sarah) case represented invitation and urbanity, and not, as in most others, pugnacity and defiance; the penetration of her (Sarah) voice to a distance, the general encouragement and approval of her (Sarah) manner, were all elements with which intercourse had made him (friend) familiar, but which he (friend) noted today almost as if she (Sarah) had been a new acquaintance. This first glimpse of her (Sarah) had given a brief but vivid accent to her (Sarah) resemblance to her (Sarah) mother; he (friend) could have taken her (Sarah) for Mrs. Newsome while she (Sarah) met his (friend) eyes as the train rolled into the station. It was an impression that quickly dropped; Mrs. Newsome was much handsomer, and while Sarah inclined to the massive her (Sarah) mother had, at an age, still the girdle of a maid; also the latter's chin was rather short, than long, and her (Sarah) smile, by good fortune, much more, oh ever so much more, mercifully vague. Strether had seen Mrs. Newsome reserved; he (Strether) had literally heard her (Newsome) silent, though he (Strether) had never known her (Newsome) unpleasant. It was the case with Mrs. Pocock that he (Strether) had known HER unpleasant, even though he (Strether) had never known her (Pocock) not affable. She (Pocock) had forms of affability that were in a high degree assertive; nothing for instance had ever been more striking than that she (Pocock) was affable to Jim.

What had told in any case at the window of the train was her (Pocock) high clear forehead, that forehead which her (Pocock) friends, for some reason, always thought of as a

``brow'' (friends)
; the long reach of her (Pocock) eyes--it came out at this juncture in such a manner as to remind him (Jim), oddly enough, also of that of Waymarsh's; and the unusual gloss of her (Waymarsh) dark hair, dressed and hatted, after her (Waymarsh) mother's refined example, with such an avoidance of extremes that it was always spoken of at Woollett as
``their own.'' (Woollett)
Though this analogy dropped as soon as she (Waymarsh) was on the platform it had lasted long enough to make him (Jim) feel all the advantage, as it were, of his (Jim) relief. The woman at home, the woman to whom he (Jim) was attached, was before him (Jim) just long enough to give him (Jim) again the measure of the wretchedness, in fact really of the shame, of their having to recognise the formation, between them, of a
``split.'' (him)
He (Jim) had taken this measure in solitude and meditation: but the catastrophe, as Sarah steamed up, looked for its seconds unprecedentedly dreadful--or proved, more exactly, altogether unthinkable; so that his (Jim) finding something free and familiar to respond to brought with it an instant renewal of his (Jim) loyalty. He (Jim) had suddenly sounded the whole depth, had gasped at what he (Jim) might have lost.

Well, he (Jim) could now, for the quarter of an hour of their detention hover about the travellers as soothingly as if their direct message to him (Jim) was that he (Jim) had lost nothing. He (Jim) wasn't going to have Sarah write to her (Sarah) mother that night that he (Jim) was in any way altered or strange. There had been times enough for a month when it had seemed to him (Jim) that he (Jim) was strange, that he (Jim) was altered, in every way; but that was a matter for himself; he (Jim) knew at least whose business it was not; it was not at all events such a circumstance as Sarah's own unaided lights would help her (Sarah) to. Even if she (Sarah) had come out to flash those lights more than yet appeared she (Sarah) wouldn't make much headway against mere pleasantness. He (Jim) counted on being able to be merely pleasant to the end, and if only from incapacity moreover to formulate anything different.
