He (Jim) couldn't even formulate to himself his (Jim) being changed and queer; it had taken place, the process, somewhere deep down; Maria Gostrey had caught glimpses of it; but how was he (Jim) to fish it up, even if he (Jim) desired, for Mrs. Pocock? This was then the spirit in which he (Jim) hovered, and with the easier throb in it much indebted furthermore to the impression of high and established adequacy as a pretty girl promptly produced in him (Jim) by Mamie. He (Jim) had wondered vaguely--turning over many things in the fidget of his (Jim) thoughts--if Mamie WERE as pretty as Woollett published her (Mamie); as to which issue seeing her (Mamie) now again was to be so swept away by Woollett's opinion that this consequence really let loose for the imagination an avalanche of others. There were positively five minutes in which the last word seemed of necessity to abide with a Woollett represented by a Mamie. This was the sort of truth the place itself would feel; it would send her (Mamie) forth in confidence; it would point to her (Mamie) with triumph; it would take its stand on her (Mamie) with assurance; it would be conscious of no requirements she (Mamie) didn't meet, of no question she (Mamie) couldn't answer.

Well, it was right, Strether slipped smoothly enough into the cheerfulness of saying: granted that a community MIGHT be best represented by a young lady of twenty-two, Mamie perfectly played the part, played it as if she (Mamie) were used to it, and looked and spoke and dressed the character. He (character) wondered if she (Mamie) mightn't, in the high light of Paris, a cool full studio-light, becoming yet treacherous, show as too conscious of these matters; but the next moment he (character) felt satisfied that her (Mamie) consciousness was after all empty for its size, rather too simple than too mixed, and that the kind way with her (Mamie) would be not to take many things out of it, but to put as many as possible in. She (Mamie) was robust and conveniently tall; just a trifle too bloodlessly fair perhaps, but with a pleasant public familiar radiance that affirmed her (Mamie) vitality. She (Mamie) might have been

``receiving'' (She)
for Woollett, wherever she (Mamie) found herself, and there was something in her (Mamie) manner, her (Mamie) tone, her (Mamie) motion, her (Mamie) pretty blue eyes, her (Mamie) pretty perfect teeth and her (Mamie) very small, too small, nose, that immediately placed her (Mamie), to the fancy, between the windows of a hot bright room in which voices were high--up at that end to which people were brought to be
``presented.'' (people)
They were there to congratulate, these images, and Strether's renewed vision, on this hint, completed the idea. What Mamie was like was the happy bride, the bride after the church and just before going away. She (bride) wasn't the mere maiden, and yet was only as much married as that quantity came to. She (bride) was in the brilliant acclaimed festal stage. Well, might it last her (bride) long!

Strether rejoiced in these things for Chad, who was all genial attention to the needs of his (Strether) friends, besides having arranged that his (Strether) servant should reinforce him (Strether); the ladies were certainly pleasant to see, and Mamie would be at any time and anywhere pleasant to exhibit. She (Mamie) would look extraordinarily like his (Strether) young wife--the wife of a honeymoon, should he (Strether) go about with her (Mamie); but that was his (Strether) own affair--or perhaps it was hers; it was at any rate something she (Mamie) couldn't help. Strether remembered how he (Strether) had seen him (Strether) come up with Jeanne de Vionnet in Gloriani's garden, and the fancy he (Strether) had had about that--the fancy obscured now, thickly overlaid with others; the recollection was during these minutes his (Strether) only note of trouble. He (Strether) had often, in spite of himself, wondered if Chad but too probably were not with Jeanne the object of a still and shaded flame. It was on the cards that the child MIGHT be tremulously in love, and this conviction now flickered up not a bit the less for his (Chad) disliking to think of it, for its being, in a complicated situation, a complication the more, and for something indescribable in Mamie, something at all events straightway lent her (Mamie) by his (Chad) own mind, something that gave her (Mamie) value, gave her (Mamie) intensity and purpose, as the symbol of an opposition. Little Jeanne wasn't really at all in question--how COULD she (Jeanne) be?--yet from the moment Miss Pocock had shaken her (Pocock) skirts on the platform, touched up the immense bows of her (Pocock) hat and settled properly over her (Pocock) shoulder the strap of her (Pocock) morocco-and-gilt travelling-satchel, from that moment little Jeanne was opposed.

It was in the cab with Jim that impressions really crowded on Strether, giving him (Strether) the strangest sense of length of absence from people among whom he (Strether) had lived for years. Having them thus come out to him (Strether) was as if he (Strether) had returned to find them: and the droll promptitude of Jim's mental reaction threw his (Jim) own initiation far back into the past. Whoever might or mightn't be suited by what was going on among them, Jim, for one, would certainly be: his (Jim) instant recognition--frank and whimsical--of what the affair was for HIM gave Strether a glow of pleasure.

``I say, you know, this IS about my shape, and if it hadn't been for YOU--!'' (he)
so he (Strether) broke out as the charming streets met his (Strether) healthy appetite; and he (Strether) wound up, after an expressive nudge, with a clap of his (Strether) companion's knee and an
``Oh you, you--you ARE doing it!'' (companion)
that was charged with rich meaning. Strether felt in it the intention of homage, but, with a curiosity otherwise occupied, postponed taking it up. What he (Strether) was asking himself for the time was how Sarah Pocock, in the opportunity already given her (Pocock), had judged her (Pocock) brother--from whom he (brother) himself, as they finally, at the station, separated for their different conveyances, had had a look into which he (brother) could read more than one message. However Sarah was judging her (Sarah) brother, Chad's conclusion about his (Chad) sister, and about her (Sarah) husband and her (Sarah) husband's sister, was at the least on the way not to fail of confidence. Strether felt the confidence, and that, as the look between them was an exchange, what he (Strether) himself gave back was relatively vague. This comparison of notes however could wait; everything struck him (Strether) as depending on the effect produced by Chad. Neither Sarah nor Mamie had in any way, at the station--where they had had after all ample time--broken out about it; which, to make up for this, was what our friend had expected of Jim as soon as they should find themselves together.

It was queer to him (Jim) that he (Jim) had that noiseless brush with Chad; an ironic intelligence with this youth on the subject of his (Chad) relatives, an intelligence carried on under their nose and, as might be said, at their expense--such a matter marked again for him (Chad) strongly the number of stages he (Chad) had come; albeit that if the number seemed great the time taken for the final one was but the turn of a hand. He (Chad) had before this had many moments of wondering if he (Chad) himself weren't perhaps changed even as Chad was changed. Only what in Chad was conspicuous improvement--well, he (Chad) had no name ready for the working, in his (Chad) own organism, of his (Chad) own more timid dose. He (Chad) should have to see first what this action would amount to. And for his (Chad) occult passage with the young man, after all, the directness of it had no greater oddity than the fact that the young man's way with the three travellers should have been so happy a manifestation. Strether liked him (Strether) for it, on the spot, as he (Strether) hadn't yet liked him (Strether); it affected him (Strether) while it lasted as he (Strether) might have been affected by some light pleasant perfect work of art: to that degree that he (Strether) wondered if they were really worthy of it, took it in and did it justice; to that degree that it would have been scarce a miracle if, there in the luggage-room, while they waited for their things, Sarah had pulled his (Strether) sleeve and drawn him (Strether) aside.

``You're right; we haven't quite known what you mean, Mother and I, but now we see. Chad's magnificent; what can one want more? If THIS is the kind of thing--!'' (unknown)
On which they might, as it were, have embraced and begun to work together.

Ah how much, as it was, for all her (Sarah) bridling brightness--which was merely general and noticed nothing--WOULD they work together? Strether knew he (Strether) was unreasonable; he (Strether) set it down to his (Strether) being nervous: people couldn't notice everything and speak of everything in a quarter of an hour. Possibly, no doubt, also, he (Strether) made too much of Chad's display. Yet, none the less, when, at the end of five minutes, in the cab, Jim Pocock had said nothing either--hadn't said, that is, what Strether wanted, though he (Strether) had said much else--it all suddenly bounced back to their being either stupid or wilful. It was more probably on the whole the former; so that that would be the drawback of the bridling brightness. Yes, they would bridle and be bright; they would make the best of what was before them, but their observation would fail; it would be beyond them; they simply wouldn't understand. Of what use would it be then that they had come?--if they weren't to be intelligent up to THAT point: unless indeed he (it) himself were utterly deluded and extravagant? Was he (it), on this question of Chad's improvement, fantastic and away from the truth? Did he (Chad) live in a false world, a world that had grown simply to suit him (Chad), and was his (Chad) present slight irritation--in the face now of Jim's silence in particular--but the alarm of the vain thing menaced by the touch of the real? Was this contribution of the real possibly the mission of the Pococks?--had they come to make the work of observation, as HE (Jim) had practised observation, crack and crumble, and to reduce Chad to the plain terms in which honest minds could deal with him (Chad)? Had they come in short to be sane where Strether was destined to feel that he (Strether) himself had only been silly?

He (Strether) glanced at such a contingency, but it failed to hold him (Strether) long when once he (Strether) had reflected that he (Strether) would have been silly, in this case, with Maria Gostrey and little Bilham, with Madame de Vionnet and little Jeanne, with Lambert Strether, in fine, and above all with Chad Newsome himself. Wouldn't it be found to have made more for reality to be silly with these persons than sane with Sarah and Jim? Jim in fact, he (Jim) presently made up his (Jim) mind, was individually out of it; Jim didn't care; Jim hadn't come out either for Chad or for him (Jim); Jim in short left the moral side to Sally and indeed simply availed himself now, for the sense of recreation, of the fact that he (Jim) left almost everything to Sally. He (Jim) was nothing compared to Sally, and not so much by reason of Sally's temper and will as by that of her (Sally) more developed type and greater acquaintance with the world. He (acquaintance) quite frankly and serenely confessed, as he (acquaintance) sat there with Strether, that he (Strether) felt his (Strether) type hang far in the rear of his (Strether) wife's and still further, if possible, in the rear of his (Strether) sister's. Their types, he (Strether) well knew, were recognised and acclaimed; whereas the most a leading Woollett business-man could hope to achieve socially, and for that matter industrially, was a certain freedom to play into this general glamour.

The impression he (Strether) made on our friend was another of the things that marked our friend's road. It was a strange impression, especially as so soon produced; Strether had received it, he (Strether) judged, all in the twenty minutes; it struck him (Strether) at least as but in a minor degree the work of the long Woollett years. Pocock was normally and consentingly though not quite wittingly out of the question. It was despite his (Strether) being normal; it was despite his (Strether) being cheerful; it was despite his (Strether) being a leading Woollett business-man; and the determination of his (Strether) fate left him (Strether) thus perfectly usual--as everything else about it was clearly, to his (Strether) sense, not less so. He (Strether) seemed to say that there was a whole side of life on which the perfectly usual WAS for leading Woollett business-men to be out of the question. He (Strether) made no more of it than that, and Strether, so far as Jim was concerned, desired to make no more. Only Strether's imagination, as always, worked, and he (Strether) asked himself if this side of life were not somehow connected, for those who figured on it with the fact of marriage. Would HIS (Strether) relation to it, had he (Strether) married ten years before, have become now the same as Pocock's? Might it even become the same should he (Strether) marry in a few months? Should he (Strether) ever know himself as much out of the question for Mrs. Newsome as Jim knew himself--in a dim way--for Mrs. Jim?

To turn his (Jim) eyes in that direction was to be personally reassured; he (Jim) was different from Pocock; he (Jim) had affirmed himself differently and was held after all in higher esteem. What none the less came home to him (Jim), however, at this hour, was that the society over there, that of which Sarah and Mamie--and, in a more eminent way, Mrs. Newsome herself--were specimens, was essentially a society of women, and that poor Jim wasn't in it. He (Jim) himself Lambert Strether, WAS as yet in some degree--which was an odd situation for a man; but it kept coming back to him (man) in a whimsical way that he (man) should perhaps find his (man) marriage had cost him (man) his (man) place. This occasion indeed, whatever that fancy represented, was not a time of sensible exclusion for Jim, who was in a state of manifest response to the charm of his (Jim) adventure. Small and fat and constantly facetious, straw-coloured and destitute of marks, he (Jim) would have been practically indistinguishable hadn't his (Jim) constant preference for light-grey clothes, for white hats, for very big cigars and very little stories, done what it could for his (Jim) identity. There were signs in him (Jim), though none of them plaintive, of always paying for others; and the principal one perhaps was just this failure of type. It was with this that he (Jim) paid, rather than with fatigue or waste; and also doubtless a little with the effort of humour--never irrelevant to the conditions, to the relations, with which he (Jim) was acquainted.

He (Jim) gurgled his (Jim) joy as they rolled through the happy streets; he (Jim) declared that his (Jim) trip was a regular windfall, and that he (Jim) wasn't there, he (Jim) was eager to remark, to hang back from anything: he (Jim) didn't know quite what Sally had come for, but HE (Jim) had come for a good time. Strether indulged him (Strether) even while wondering if what Sally wanted her (Sally) brother to go back for was to become like her (Sally) husband. He (husband) trusted that a good time was to be, out and out, the programme for all of them; and he (husband) assented liberally to Jim's proposal that, disencumbered and irresponsible--his (Jim) things were in the omnibus with those of the others--they should take a further turn round before going to the hotel. It wasn't for HIM to tackle Chad--it was Sally's job; and as it would be like her (Sally), he (Chad) felt, to open fire on the spot, it wouldn't be amiss of them to hold off and give her (Sally) time. Strether, on his (Strether) side, only asked to give her (Sally) time; so he (Strether) jogged with his (Strether) companion along boulevards and avenues, trying to extract from meagre material some forecast of his (Strether) catastrophe. He (Strether) was quick enough to see that Jim Pocock declined judgement, had hovered quite round the outer edge of discussion and anxiety, leaving all analysis of their question to the ladies alone and now only feeling his (Pocock) way toward some small droll cynicism. It broke out afresh, the cynicism--it had already shown a flicker--in a but slightly deferred:

``Well, hanged if I would if I were he (Chad)!'' (unknown)

``You mean you wouldn't in Chad's place--?'' (unknown)

``Give up this to go back and boss the advertising!'' (Poor Jim)
Poor Jim, with his (Jim) arms folded and his (Jim) little legs out in the open fiacre, drank in the sparkling Paris noon and carried his (Jim) eyes from one side of their vista to the other.
``Why I want to come right out and live here myself. And I want to live while I AM here too. I feel with YOU--oh you've been grand, old man, and I've twigged--that it ain't right to worry Chad. I don't mean to persecute him (Chad); I couldn't in conscience. It's thanks to you at any rate that I'm here, and I'm sure I'm much obliged. You're a lovely pair.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

There were things in this speech that Strether let pass for the time.

``Don't you then think it important the advertising should be thoroughly taken in hand? Chad WILL be, so far as capacity is concerned,'' (he)
he (Strether) went on,
``the man to do it.'' (he)

``Where did he (Chad) get his (Chad) capacity,'' (Jim/Jim Pocock)
Jim asked,
``over here?'' (Jim/Jim Pocock)

``He (Chad) didn't get it over here, and the wonderful thing is that over here he (Chad) hasn't inevitably lost it. He (Chad) has a natural turn for business, an extraordinary head. He (Chad) comes by that,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether explained,
``honestly enough. He (Chad)'s in that respect his (Chad) father's son, and also--for she (man)'s wonderful in her (man) way too--his (Chad) mother's. He (Chad) has other tastes and other tendencies; but Mrs. Newsome and your wife are quite right about his (Chad) having that. He (Chad)'s very remarkable.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

``Well, I guess he (Chad) is!'' (Jim/Jim Pocock)
Jim Pocock comfortably sighed.
``But if you've believed so in his (Chad) making us hum, why have you so prolonged the discussion? Don't you know we've been quite anxious about you?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

These questions were not informed with earnestness, but Strether saw he (Strether) must none the less make a choice and take a line.

``Because, you see, I've greatly liked it. I've liked my Paris, I dare say I've liked it too much.'' (unknown)

``Oh you old wretch!'' (Jim/Jim Pocock)
Jim gaily exclaimed.

``But nothing's concluded,'' (Strether)
Strether went on.
``The case is more complex than it looks from Woollett.'' (unknown)

``Oh well, it looks bad enough from Woollett!'' (Jim/Jim Pocock)
Jim declared.

``Even after all I've written?'' (Jim/Jim Pocock)

Jim bethought himself.

``Isn't it what you've written that has made Mrs. Newsome pack us off? That at least and Chad's not turning up?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether made a reflexion of his (Strether) own.

``I see. That she (Newsome) should do something was, no doubt, inevitable, and your wife has therefore of course come out to act.'' (unknown)

``Oh yes,'' (Jim/Jim Pocock)
Jim concurred--
``to act. But Sally comes out to act, you know,'' (Jim/Jim Pocock)
he (Jim) lucidly added,
``every time she (Sally) leaves the house. She (Sally) never comes out but she (Sally) DOES act. She (Sally)'s acting moreover now for her (Sally) mother, and that fixes the scale.'' (he)
Then he (Jim) wound up, opening all his (Jim) senses to it, with a renewed embrace of pleasant Paris.
``We haven't all the same at Woollett got anything like this.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether continued to consider.

``I'm bound to say for you all that you strike me as having arrived in a very mild and reasonable frame of mind. You don't show your claws. I felt just now in Mrs. Pocock no symptom of that. She (Pocock) isn't fierce,'' (he)
he (Strether) went on.
``I'm such a nervous idiot that I thought she (Pocock) might be.'' (unknown)

``Oh don't you know her (Pocock) well enough,'' (Sarah/Sarah Pocock/Pocock)
Pocock asked,
``to have noticed that she (Pocock) never gives herself away, any more than her (Pocock) mother ever does? They ain't fierce, either of 'em; they let you come quite close. They wear their fur the smooth side out--the warm side in. Do you know what they are?'' (Sarah/Sarah Pocock/Pocock)
Jim pursued as he (Jim) looked about him (Jim), giving the question, as Strether felt, but half his (Strether) care--
``do you know what they are? They're about as intense as they can live.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

``Yes'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
--and Strether's concurrence had a positive precipitation;
``they're about as intense as they can live.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

``They don't lash about and shake the cage,'' (Jim/Jim Pocock)
said Jim, who seemed pleased with his (Jim) analogy;
``and it's at feeding-time that they're quietest. But they always get there.'' (Jim/Jim Pocock)

``They do indeed--they always get there!'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether replied with a laugh that justified his (Strether) confession of nervousness. He (Strether) disliked to be talking sincerely of Mrs. Newsome with Pocock; he (Strether) could have talked insincerely. But there was something he (Strether) wanted to know, a need created in him (Strether) by her (Pocock) recent intermission, by his (Strether) having given from the first so much, as now more than ever appeared to him (Strether), and got so little. It was as if a queer truth in his (Strether) companion's metaphor had rolled over him (Strether) with a rush. She (Pocock) HAD been quiet at feeding-time; she (Pocock) had fed, and Sarah had fed with her (Sarah), out of the big bowl of all his (Strether) recent free communication, his (Strether) vividness and pleasantness, his (Strether) ingenuity and even his (Strether) eloquence, while the current of her (Sarah) response had steadily run thin. Jim meanwhile however, it was true, slipped characteristically into shallowness from the moment he (Jim) ceased to speak out of the experience of a husband.

``But of course Chad has now the advantage of being there before her (Chad). If he (Chad) doesn't work that for all it's worth--!'' (He)
He (Jim) sighed with contingent pity at his (Jim) brother-in-law's possible want of resource.
``He (Chad) has worked it on YOU, pretty well, eh?'' (he)
and he (Jim) asked the next moment if there were anything new at the Varieties, which he (Jim) pronounced in the American manner. They talked about the Varieties--Strether confessing to a knowledge which produced again on Pocock's part a play of innuendo as vague as a nursery-rhyme, yet as aggressive as an elbow in his (Jim) side; and they finished their drive under the protection of easy themes. Strether waited to the end, but still in vain, for any show that Jim had seen Chad as different; and he (Jim) could scarce have explained the discouragement he (Jim) drew from the absence of this testimony. It was what he (Jim) had taken his (Jim) own stand on, so far as he (Jim) had taken a stand; and if they were all only going to see nothing he (Jim) had only wasted his (Jim) time. He (Jim) gave his (Jim) friend till the very last moment, till they had come into sight of the hotel; and when poor Pocock only continued cheerful and envious and funny he (Jim) fairly grew to dislike him (Jim), to feel him (Jim) extravagantly common. If they were ALL going to see nothing!--Strether knew, as this came back to him (Strether), that he (Strether) was also letting Pocock represent for him (Strether) what Mrs. Newsome wouldn't see. He (Strether) went on disliking, in the light of Jim's commonness, to talk to him (Jim) about that lady; yet just before the cab pulled up he (Jim) knew the extent of his (Jim) desire for the real word from Woollett.

``Has Mrs. Newsome at all given way--?'' (unknown)

''`Given way'?'' (Jim/Jim Pocock)
--Jim echoed it with the practical derision of his (Jim) sense of a long past.

``Under the strain, I mean, of hope deferred, of disappointment repeated and thereby intensified.'' (unknown)

``Oh is she (Newsome) prostrate, you mean?'' (he)
--he (Jim) had his (Jim) categories in hand.
``Why yes, she (Newsome)'s prostrate--just as Sally is. But they're never so lively, you know, as when they're prostrate.'' (unknown)

``Ah Sarah's prostrate?'' (Strether)
Strether vaguely murmured.

``It's when they're prostrate that they most sit up.'' (unknown)

``And Mrs. Newsome's sitting up?'' (unknown)

``All night, my boy--for YOU!'' (Jim/Jim Pocock)
And Jim fetched him (Jim), with a vulgar little guffaw, a thrust that gave relief to the picture. But he (Jim) had got what he (Jim) wanted. He (Jim) felt on the spot that this WAS the real word from Woollett.
``So don't you go home!'' (Jim/Jim Pocock)
Jim added while he (Jim) alighted and while his (Jim) friend, letting him (Jim) profusely pay the cabman, sat on in a momentary muse. Strether wondered if that were the real word too.

III

As the door of Mrs. Pocock's salon was pushed open for him (Strether), the next day, well before noon, he (Strether) was reached by a voice with a charming sound that made him (Strether) just falter before crossing the threshold. Madame de Vionnet was already on the field, and this gave the drama a quicker pace than he (Vionnet) felt it as yet--though his (Vionnet) suspense had increased--in the power of any act of his (Vionnet) own to do. He (Vionnet) had spent the previous evening with all his (Vionnet) old friends together yet he (Vionnet) would still have described himself as quite in the dark in respect to a forecast of their influence on his (Vionnet) situation. It was strange now, none the less, that in the light of this unexpected note of her (Vionnet) presence he (Vionnet) felt Madame de Vionnet a part of that situation as she (Vionnet) hadn't even yet been. She (Vionnet) was alone, he (Vionnet) found himself assuming, with Sarah, and there was a bearing in that--somehow beyond his (Vionnet) control--on his (Vionnet) personal fate. Yet she (Sarah) was only saying something quite easy and independent--the thing she (Sarah) had come, as a good friend of Chad's, on purpose to say.

``There isn't anything at all--? I should be so delighted.'' (him)

It was clear enough, when they were there before him (Chad), how she (Sarah) had been received. He (Chad) saw this, as Sarah got up to greet him (Chad), from something fairly hectic in Sarah's face. He (Chad) saw furthermore that they weren't, as had first come to him (Chad), alone together; he (Chad) was at no loss as to the identity of the broad high back presented to him (Chad) in the embrasure of the window furthest from the door. Waymarsh, whom he (Chad) had to-day not yet seen, whom he (Chad) only knew to have left the hotel before him (Chad), and who had taken part, the night previous, on Mrs. Pocock's kind invitation, conveyed by Chad, in the entertainment, informal but cordial, promptly offered by that lady--Waymarsh had anticipated him (Chad) even as Madame de Vionnet had done, and, with his (Vionnet) hands in his (Vionnet) pockets and his (Vionnet) attitude unaffected by Strether's entrance, was looking out, in marked detachment, at the Rue de Rivoli. The latter felt it in the air--it was immense how Waymarsh could mark things--that he (Vionnet) had remained deeply dissociated from the overture to their hostess that we have recorded on Madame de Vionnet's side. He (Vionnet) had, conspicuously, tact, besides a stiff general view; and this was why he (Vionnet) had left Mrs. Pocock to struggle alone. He (Vionnet) would outstay the visitor; he (Vionnet) would unmistakeably wait; to what had he (Vionnet) been doomed for months past but waiting? Therefore she (Pocock) was to feel that she (Pocock) had him (Vionnet) in reserve. What support she (Pocock) drew from this was still to be seen, for, although Sarah was vividly bright, she (Sarah) had given herself up for the moment to an ambiguous flushed formalism. She (Sarah) had had to reckon more quickly than she (Sarah) expected; but it concerned her (Sarah) first of all to signify that she (Sarah) was not to be taken unawares. Strether arrived precisely in time for her (Sarah) showing it.

``Oh you're too good; but I don't think I feel quite helpless. I have my brother--and these American friends. And then you know I've been to Paris. I KNOW Paris,'' (Sally)
said Sally Pocock in a tone that breathed a certain chill on Strether's heart.

``Ah but a woman, in this tiresome place where everything's always changing, a woman of good will,'' (Madame)
Madame de Vionnet threw off,
``can always help a woman. I'm sure you `know'--but we know perhaps different things.'' (Madame de Vionnet/Vionnet/de Vionnet)
She (Sarah) too, visibly, wished to make no mistake; but it was a fear of a different order and more kept out of sight. She (Sarah) smiled in welcome at Strether; she (Sarah) greeted him (Vionnet) more familiarly than Mrs. Pocock; she (Pocock) put out her (Pocock) hand to him (Vionnet) without moving from her (Pocock) place; and it came to him (Vionnet) in the course of a minute and in the oddest way that--yes, positively--she (Pocock) was giving him (Vionnet) over to ruin. She (Pocock) was all kindness and ease, but she (Pocock) couldn't help so giving him (Vionnet); she (Pocock) was exquisite, and her (Pocock) being just as she (Pocock) was poured for Sarah a sudden rush of meaning into his (Vionnet) own equivocations. How could she (Pocock) know how she (Pocock) was hurting him (Vionnet)? She (Pocock) wanted to show as simple and humble--in the degree compatible with operative charm; but it was just this that seemed to put him (Vionnet) on her (Pocock) side. She (Pocock) struck him (Vionnet) as dressed, as arranged, as prepared infinitely to conciliate--with the very poetry of good taste in her (Pocock) view of the conditions of her (Pocock) early call. She (Pocock) was ready to advise about dressmakers and shops; she (Pocock) held herself wholly at the disposition of Chad's family. Strether noticed her (Pocock) card on the table--her (Pocock) coronet and her (Pocock)
``Comtesse'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
--and the imagination was sharp in him (Strether) of certain private adjustments in Sarah's mind. She (Sarah) had never, he (Strether) was sure, sat with a
``Comtesse'' (he)
before, and such was the specimen of that class he (Strether) had been keeping to play on her (Sarah). She (Sarah) had crossed the sea very particularly for a look at her (Sarah); but he (Strether) read in Madame de Vionnet's own eyes that this curiosity hadn't been so successfully met as that she (Sarah) herself wouldn't now have more than ever need of him (Strether). She (Sarah) looked much as she (Sarah) had looked to him (Strether) that morning at Notre Dame; he (Strether) noted in fact the suggestive sameness of her (Sarah) discreet and delicate dress. It seemed to speak--perhaps a little prematurely or too finely--of the sense in which she (Sarah) would help Mrs. Pocock with the shops. The way that lady took her (lady) in, moreover, added depth to his (Strether) impression of what Miss Gostrey, by their common wisdom, had escaped. He (Strether) winced as he (Strether) saw himself but for that timely prudence ushering in Maria as a guide and an example. There was however a touch of relief for him (Strether) in his (Strether) glimpse, so far as he (Strether) had got it, of Sarah's line. She (Sarah)
``knew Paris.'' (She)
Madame de Vionnet had, for that matter, lightly taken this up.
``Ah then you've a turn for that, an affinity that belongs to your family. Your brother, though his (brother) long experience makes a difference, I admit, has become one of us in a marvellous way.'' (she)
And she (Sarah) appealed to Strether in the manner of a woman who could always glide off with smoothness into another subject. Wasn't HE (Strether) struck with the way Mr. Newsome had made the place his (Newsome) own, and hadn't he (Newsome) been in a position to profit by his (Newsome) friend's wondrous expertness?

Strether felt the bravery, at the least, of her (Sarah) presenting herself so promptly to sound that note, and yet asked himself what other note, after all, she (Sarah) COULD strike from the moment she (Sarah) presented herself at all. She (Sarah) could meet Mrs. Pocock only on the ground of the obvious, and what feature of Chad's situation was more eminent than the fact that he (Chad) had created for himself a new set of circumstances? Unless she (Sarah) hid herself altogether she (Sarah) could show but as one of these, an illustration of his (Chad) domiciled and indeed of his (Chad) confirmed condition. And the consciousness of all this in her (Sarah) charming eyes was so clear and fine that as she (Sarah) thus publicly drew him (Chad) into her (Sarah) boat she (Sarah) produced in him (Chad) such a silent agitation as he (Chad) was not to fail afterwards to denounce as pusillanimous.

``Ah don't be so charming to me!--for it makes us intimate, and after all what IS between us when I've been so tremendously on my guard and have seen you but half a dozen times?'' (He)
He (Chad) recognised once more the perverse law that so inveterately governed his (Chad) poor personal aspects: it would be exactly LIKE the way things always turned out for him (Chad) that he (Chad) should affect Mrs. Pocock and Waymarsh as launched in a relation in which he (Chad) had really never been launched at all. They were at this very moment--they could only be--attributing to him (Chad) the full licence of it, and all by the operation of her (Waymarsh) own tone with him (Chad); whereas his (Chad) sole licence had been to cling with intensity to the brink, not to dip so much as a toe into the flood. But the flicker of his (Chad) fear on this occasion was not, as may be added, to repeat itself; it sprang up, for its moment, only to die down and then go out for ever. To meet his (Chad) fellow visitor's invocation and, with Sarah's brilliant eyes on him (Chad), answer, WAS quite sufficiently to step into her (Sarah) boat. During the rest of the time her (Sarah) visit lasted he (Chad) felt himself proceed to each of the proper offices, successively, for helping to keep the adventurous skiff afloat. It rocked beneath him (Chad), but he (Chad) settled himself in his (Chad) place. He (Chad) took up an oar and, since he (Chad) was to have the credit of pulling, pulled.

``That will make it all the pleasanter if it so happens that we DO meet,'' (Madame de Vionnet/Vionnet/de Vionnet)
Madame de Vionnet had further observed in reference to Mrs. Pocock's mention of her (Pocock) initiated state; and she (Pocock) had immediately added that, after all, her (Pocock) hostess couldn't be in need with the good offices of Mr. Strether so close at hand.
``It's he (guard), I gather, who has learnt to know his (guard) Paris, and to love it, better than any one ever before in so short a time; so that between him (guard) and your brother, when it comes to the point, how can you possibly want for good guidance? The great thing, Mr. Strether will show you,'' (she)
she (Pocock) smiled,
``is just to let one's self go.'' (she)

``Oh I've not let myself go very far,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether answered, feeling quite as if he (Strether) had been called upon to hint to Mrs. Pocock how Parisians could talk.
``I'm only afraid of showing I haven't let myself go far enough. I've taken a good deal of time, but I must quite have had the air of not budging from one spot.'' (He)
He (Strether) looked at Sarah in a manner that he (Strether) thought she (Sarah) might take as engaging, and he (Strether) made, under Madame de Vionnet's protection, as it were, his (Strether) first personal point.
``What has really happened has been that, all the while, I've done what I came out for.'' (Madame de Vionnet/Vionnet/de Vionnet)

Yet it only at first gave Madame de Vionnet a chance immediately to take him (Vionnet) up.

``You've renewed acquaintance with your friend--you've learnt to know him (friend) again.'' (She)
She (Sarah) spoke with such cheerful helpfulness that they might, in a common cause, have been calling together and pledged to mutual aid.

Waymarsh, at this, as if he (Vionnet) had been in question, straightway turned from the window.

``Oh yes, Countess--he (friend) has renewed acquaintance with ME, and he (friend) HAS, I guess, learnt something about me, though I don't know how much he (friend) has liked it. It's for Strether himself to say whether he (Strether) has felt it justifies his (Strether) course.'' (unknown)

``Oh but YOU,'' (the Countess)
said the Countess gaily,
``are not in the least what he (Strether) came out for--is he (Strether) really, Strether? and I hadn't you at all in my mind. I was thinking of Mr. Newsome, of whom we think so much and with whom, precisely, Mrs. Pocock has given herself the opportunity to take up threads. What a pleasure for you both!'' (the Countess)
Madame de Vionnet, with her (Countess) eyes on Sarah, bravely continued.

Mrs. Pocock met her (Pocock) handsomely, but Strether quickly saw she (Pocock) meant to accept no version of her (Pocock) movements or plans from any other lips. She (Pocock) required no patronage and no support, which were but other names for a false position; she (Pocock) would show in her (Pocock) own way what she (Pocock) chose to show, and this she (Pocock) expressed with a dry glitter that recalled to him (Strether) a fine Woollett winter morning.

``I've never wanted for opportunities to see my brother. We've many things to think of at home, and great responsibilities and occupations, and our home's not an impossible place. We've plenty of reasons,'' (Sarah/Sarah Pocock/Pocock)
Sarah continued a little piercingly,
``for everything we do'' (Sarah/Sarah Pocock/Pocock)
--and in short she (Sarah) wouldn't give herself the least little scrap away. But she (Sarah) added as one who was always bland and who could afford a concession:
``I've come because--well, because we do come.'' (she)

``Ah then fortunately!'' (Madame de Vionnet/Vionnet/de Vionnet)
--Madame de Vionnet breathed it to the air. Five minutes later they were on their feet for her (Sarah) to take leave, standing together in an affability that had succeeded in surviving a further exchange of remarks; only with the emphasised appearance on Waymarsh's part of a tendency to revert, in a ruminating manner and as with an instinctive or a precautionary lightening of his (Vionnet) tread, to an open window and his (Vionnet) point of vantage. The glazed and gilded room, all red damask, ormolu, mirrors, clocks, looked south, and the shutters were bowed upon the summer morning; but the Tuileries garden and what was beyond it, over which the whole place hung, were things visible through gaps; so that the far-spreading presence of Paris came up in coolness, dimness and invitation, in the twinkle of gilt-tipped palings, the crunch of gravel, the click of hoofs, the crack of whips, things that suggested some parade of the circus.
``I think it probable,'' (Mrs. Pocock/Pocock)
said Mrs. Pocock,
``that I shall have the opportunity of going to my brother's I've no doubt it's very pleasant indeed.'' (Mrs. Pocock/Pocock)
She (Pocock) spoke as to Strether, but her (Pocock) face was turned with an intensity of brightness to Madame de Vionnet, and there was a moment during which, while she (Pocock) thus fronted her (Pocock), our friend expected to hear her (Pocock) add:
``I'm much obliged to you, I'm sure, for inviting me there.'' (friend)
He (friend) guessed that for five seconds these words were on the point of coming; he (friend) heard them as clearly as if they had been spoken; but he (friend) presently knew they had just failed--knew it by a glance, quick and fine, from Madame de Vionnet, which told him (Vionnet) that she (Pocock) too had felt them in the air, but that the point had luckily not been made in any manner requiring notice. This left her (Pocock) free to reply only to what had been said.

``That the Boulevard Malesherbes may be common ground for us offers me the best prospect I see for the pleasure of meeting you again.'' (unknown)

``Oh I shall come to see you, since you've been so good'' (Mrs. Pocock/Pocock)
: and Mrs. Pocock looked her (Pocock) invader well in the eyes. The flush in Sarah's cheeks had by this time settled to a small definite crimson spot that was not without its own bravery; she (Sarah) held her (Sarah) head a good deal up, and it came to Strether that of the two, at this moment, she (Sarah) was the one who most carried out the idea of a Countess. He (Strether) quite took in, however, that she (Sarah) would really return her (Sarah) visitor's civility: she (Sarah) wouldn't report again at Woollett without at least so much producible history as that in her (Sarah) pocket.

``I want extremely to be able to show you my little daughter.'' (Madame de Vionnet/Vionnet/de Vionnet)
Madame de Vionnet went on;
``and I should have brought her (daughter) with me if I hadn't wished first to ask your leave. I was in hopes I should perhaps find Miss Pocock, of whose being with you I've heard from Mr. Newsome and whose acquaintance I should so much like my child to make. If I have the pleasure of seeing her (Pocock) and you do permit it I shall venture to ask her (Pocock) to be kind to Jeanne. Mr. Strether will tell you'' (Madame de Vionnet/Vionnet/de Vionnet)
--she (Sarah) beautifully kept it up--
``that my poor girl is gentle and good and rather lonely. They've made friends, he (Strether) and she (girl), ever so happily, and he (Strether) doesn't, I believe, think ill of her (girl). As for Jeanne herself he (Strether) has had the same success with her (Jeanne) that I know he (Strether) has had here wherever he (Strether) has turned.'' (she)
She (Sarah) seemed to ask him (Vionnet) for permission to say these things, or seemed rather to take it, softly and happily, with the ease of intimacy, for granted, and he (Vionnet) had quite the consciousness now that not to meet her (Sarah) at any point more than halfway would be odiously, basely to abandon her (Sarah). Yes, he (Vionnet) was WITH her (Sarah), and, opposed even in this covert, this semi-safe fashion to those who were not, he (Vionnet) felt, strangely and confusedly, but excitedly, inspiringly, how much and how far. It was as if he (Vionnet) had positively waited in suspense for something from her (Sarah) that would let him (Vionnet) in deeper, so that he (Vionnet) might show her (Sarah) how he (Vionnet) could take it. And what did in fact come as she (Sarah) drew out a little her (Sarah) farewell served sufficiently the purpose.
``As his (Strether) success is a matter that I'm sure he (Strether)'ll never mention for himself, I feel, you see, the less scruple; which it's very good of me to say, you know, by the way,'' (she)
she (Sarah) added as she (Sarah) addressed herself to him (Vionnet);
``considering how little direct advantage I've gained from your triumphs with ME. When does one ever see you? I wait at home and I languish. You'll have rendered me the service, Mrs. Pocock, at least,'' (him)
she (Sarah) wound up,
``of giving me one of my much-too-rare glimpses of this gentleman.'' (she)

``I certainly should be sorry to deprive you of anything that seems so much, as you describe it, your natural due. Mr. Strether and I are very old friends,'' (Sarah/Sarah Pocock/Pocock)
Sarah allowed,
``but the privilege of his (Strether) society isn't a thing I shall quarrel about with any one.'' (Sarah/Sarah Pocock/Pocock)

``And yet, dear Sarah,'' (he)
he (Vionnet) freely broke in,
``I feel, when I hear you say that, that you don't quite do justice to the important truth of the extent to which--as you're also mine--I'm your natural due. I should like much better,'' (he)
he (Vionnet) laughed,
``to see you fight for me.'' (he)

She (Sarah) met him (Vionnet), Mrs. Pocock, on this, with an arrest of speech--with a certain breathlessness, as he (Vionnet) immediately fancied, on the score of a freedom for which she (Pocock) wasn't quite prepared. It had flared up--for all the harm he (Vionnet) had intended by it--because, confoundedly, he (Vionnet) didn't want any more to be afraid about her (Pocock) than he (Vionnet) wanted to be afraid about Madame de Vionnet. He (Vionnet) had never, naturally, called her (Pocock) anything but Sarah at home, and though he (Vionnet) had perhaps never quite so markedly invoked her (Pocock) as his (Vionnet)

``dear,'' (her)
that was somehow partly because no occasion had hitherto laid so effective a trap for it. But something admonished him (Vionnet) now that it was too late--unless indeed it were possibly too early; and that he (Vionnet) at any rate shouldn't have pleased Mrs. Pocock the more by it.
``Well, Mr. Strether--!'' (she)
she (Pocock) murmured with vagueness, yet with sharpness, while her (Pocock) crimson spot burned a trifle brighter and he (Vionnet) was aware that this must be for the present the limit of her (Pocock) response. Madame de Vionnet had already, however, come to his (Vionnet) aid, and Waymarsh, as if for further participation, moved again back to them. It was true that the aid rendered by Madame de Vionnet was questionable; it was a sign that, for all one might confess to with her (Waymarsh), and for all she (Waymarsh) might complain of not enjoying, she (Waymarsh) could still insidiously show how much of the material of conversation had accumulated between them.

``The real truth is, you know, that you sacrifice one without mercy to dear old Maria. She (Maria) leaves no room in your life for anybody else. Do you know,'' (she)
she (Waymarsh) enquired of Mrs. Pocock,
``about dear old Maria? The worst is that Miss Gostrey is really a wonderful woman.'' (Mrs. Pocock/Pocock)

``Oh yes indeed,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether answered for her (Pocock),
``Mrs. Pocock knows about Miss Gostrey. Your mother, Sarah, must have told you about her (Sarah); your mother knows everything,'' (her)
he (Strether) sturdily pursued.
``And I cordially admit,'' (he)
he (Strether) added with his (Strether) conscious gaiety of courage,
``that she (Sarah)'s as wonderful a woman as you like.'' (he)

``Ah it isn't I who ``like,

'' dear Mr. Strether, anything to do with the matter!'' (Sarah/Sarah Pocock/Pocock)
Sarah Pocock promptly protested;
``and I'm by no means sure I have--from my mother or from any one else--a notion of whom you're talking about.'' (Sarah/Sarah Pocock/Pocock)

``Well, he (mother) won't let you see her (mother), you know,'' (Madame de Vionnet/Vionnet/de Vionnet)
Madame de Vionnet sympathetically threw in.
``He (mother) never lets me--old friends as we are: I mean as I am with Maria. He (mother) reserves her (Maria) for his (mother) best hours; keeps her (Maria) consummately to himself; only gives us others the crumbs of the feast.'' (unknown)

``Well, Countess, I

``VE had some of the crumbs,'' (unknown)
Waymarsh observed with weight and covering her (Pocock) with his (Vionnet) large look; which led her (Pocock) to break in before he (Vionnet) could go on.

``Comment donc, he (mother) shares her (Countess) with YOU?'' (she)
she (Pocock) exclaimed in droll stupefaction.
``Take care you don't have, before you go much further, rather more of all ces dames than you may know what to do with!'' (he)

But he (Vionnet) only continued in his (Vionnet) massive way.

``I can post you about the lady, Mrs. Pocock, so far as you may care to hear. I've seen her (Pocock) quite a number of times, and I was practically present when they made acquaintance. I've kept my eye on her (Pocock) right along, but I don't know as there's any real harm in her (Pocock).'' (unknown)

''`Harm'?'' (Madame)
Madame de Vionnet quickly echoed.
``Why she (Pocock)'s the dearest and cleverest of all the clever and dear.'' (unknown)

``Well, you run her (Pocock) pretty close, Countess,'' (Waymarsh/Mrs. Waymarsh)
Waymarsh returned with spirit;
``though there's no doubt she (Pocock)'s pretty well up in things. She (Pocock) knows her (Pocock) way round Europe. Above all there's no doubt she (Pocock) does love Strether.'' (Waymarsh/Mrs. Waymarsh)

``Ah but we all do that--we all love Strether: it isn't a merit!'' (visitor)
their fellow visitor laughed, keeping to her (Waymarsh) idea with a good conscience at which our friend was aware that he (friend) marvelled, though he (friend) trusted also for it, as he (friend) met her (Waymarsh) exquisitely expressive eyes, to some later light.

The prime effect of her (Waymarsh) tone, however--and it was a truth which his (friend) own eyes gave back to her (Waymarsh) in sad ironic play--could only be to make him (friend) feel that, to say such things to a man in public, a woman must practically think of him (friend) as ninety years old. He (friend) had turned awkwardly, responsively red, he (friend) knew, at her (woman) mention of Maria Gostrey; Sarah Pocock's presence--the particular quality of it--had made this inevitable; and then he (friend) had grown still redder in proportion as he (friend) hated to have shown anything at all. He (friend) felt indeed that he (friend) was showing much, as, uncomfortably and almost in pain, he (friend) offered up his (friend) redness to Waymarsh, who, strangely enough, seemed now to be looking at him (friend) with a certain explanatory yearning. Something deep--something built on their old old relation--passed, in this complexity, between them; he (friend) got the side-wind of a loyalty that stood behind all actual queer questions. Waymarsh's dry bare humour--as it gave itself to be taken--gloomed out to demand justice.

``Well, if you talk of Miss Barrace I've MY chance too,'' (him)
it appeared stiffly to nod, and it granted that it was giving him (friend) away, but struggled to add that it did so only to save him (friend). The sombre glow stared it at him (friend) till it fairly sounded out--
``to save you, poor old man, to save you; to save you in spite of yourself.'' (him)
Yet it was somehow just this communication that showed him (friend) to himself as more than ever lost. Still another result of it was to put before him (friend) as never yet that between his (friend) comrade and the interest represented by Sarah there was already a basis. Beyond all question now, yes: Waymarsh had been in occult relation with Mrs. Newsome--out, out it all came in the very effort of his (friend) face.
``Yes, you're feeling my hand'' (he)
--he (friend) as good as proclaimed it;
``but only because this at least I SHALL have got out of the damned Old World: that I shall have picked up the pieces into which it has caused you to crumble.'' (he)
It was as if in short, after an instant, Strether had not only had it from him (Strether), but had recognised that so far as this went the instant had cleared the air. Our friend understood and approved; he (friend) had the sense that they wouldn't otherwise speak of it. This would be all, and it would mark in himself a kind of intelligent generosity. It was with grim Sarah then--Sarah grim for all her (Sarah) grace--that Waymarsh had begun at ten o'clock in the morning to save him (friend). Well--if he (friend) COULD, poor dear man, with his (friend) big bleak kindness! The upshot of which crowded perception was that Strether, on his (Strether) own side, still showed no more than he (Strether) absolutely had to. He (Strether) showed the least possible by saying to Mrs. Pocock after an interval much briefer than our glance at the picture reflected in him (Strether):
``Oh it's as true as they please!--There's no Miss Gostrey for any one but me--not the least little peep. I keep her (MY) to myself.'' (him)

``Well, it's very good of you to notify me,'' (Sarah/Sarah Pocock/Pocock)
Sarah replied without looking at him (Strether) and thrown for a moment by this discrimination, as the direction of her (Sarah) eyes showed, upon a dimly desperate little community with Madame de Vionnet.
``But I hope I shan't miss her (MY) too much.'' (Madame)

Madame de Vionnet instantly rallied.

``And you know--though it might occur to one--it isn't in the least that he (it)'s ashamed of her (MY). She (MY)'s really--in a way--extremely good-looking.'' (unknown)

``Ah but extremely!'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether laughed while he (Strether) wondered at the odd part he (Strether) found thus imposed on him (Strether).

It continued to be so by every touch from Madame de Vionnet.

``Well, as I say, you know, I wish you would keep ME a little more to yourself. Couldn't you name some day for me, some hour--and better soon than late? I'll be at home whenever it best suits you. There--I can't say fairer.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether thought a moment while Waymarsh and Mrs. Pocock affected him (Strether) as standing attentive.

``I did lately call on you. Last week--while Chad was out of town.'' (unknown)

``Yes--and I was away, as it happened, too. You choose your moments well. But don't wait for my next absence, for I shan't make another,'' (Madame)
Madame de Vionnet declared,
``while Mrs. Pocock's here.'' (Madame de Vionnet/Vionnet/de Vionnet)

``That vow needn't keep you long, fortunately,'' (Sarah/Sarah Pocock/Pocock)
Sarah observed with reasserted suavity.
``I shall be at present but a short time in Paris. I have my plans for other countries. I meet a number of charming friends'' (these persons)
--and her (Sarah) voice seemed to caress that description of these persons.

``Ah then,'' (visitor)
her (Sarah) visitor cheerfully replied,
``all the more reason! To-morrow, for instance, or next day?'' (visitor)
she (Sarah) continued to Strether.
``Tuesday would do for me beautifully.'' (unknown)

``Tuesday then with pleasure.'' (unknown)

``And at half-past five?--or at six?'' (Mrs. Pocock/Pocock)

It was ridiculous, but Mrs. Pocock and Waymarsh struck him (Strether) as fairly waiting for his (Strether) answer. It was indeed as if they were arranged, gathered for a performance, the performance of

``Europe'' (confederate)
by his (Strether) confederate and himself. Well, the performance could only go on.
``Say five forty-five.'' (unknown)

``Five forty-five--good.'' (Madame)
And now at last Madame de Vionnet must leave them, though it carried, for herself, the performance a little further.
``I DID hope so much also to see Miss Pocock. Mayn't I still?'' (Sarah/Sarah Pocock/Pocock)

Sarah hesitated, but she (Sarah) rose equal.

``She (Pocock)'ll return your visit with me. She (Pocock)'s at present out with Mr. Pocock and my brother.'' (unknown)

``I see--of course Mr. Newsome has everything to show them. He (Newsome) has told me so much about her (Pocock). My great desire's to give my daughter the opportunity of making her (daughter) acquaintance. I'm always on the lookout for such chances for her (daughter). If I didn't bring her (daughter) to-day it was only to make sure first that you'd let me.'' (the woman)
After which the charming woman risked a more intense appeal.
``It wouldn't suit you also to mention some near time, so that we shall be sure not to lose you?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether on his (Strether) side waited, for Sarah likewise had, after all, to perform; and it occupied him (Strether) to have been thus reminded that she (Sarah) had stayed at home--and on her (Sarah) first morning of Paris--while Chad led the others forth. Oh she (Sarah) was up to her (Sarah) eyes; if she (Sarah) had stayed at home she (Sarah) had stayed by an understanding, arrived at the evening before, that Waymarsh would come and find her (Waymarsh) alone. This was beginning well--for a first day in Paris; and the thing might be amusing yet. But Madame de Vionnet's earnestness was meanwhile beautiful.
``You may think me indiscreet, but I've SUCH a desire my Jeanne shall know an American girl of the really delightful kind. You see I throw myself for it on your charity.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

The manner of this speech gave Strether such a sense of depths below it and behind it as he (Strether) hadn't yet had--ministered in a way that almost frightened him (Strether) to his (Strether) dim divinations of reasons; but if Sarah still, in spite of it, faltered, this was why he (Strether) had time for a sign of sympathy with her (Sarah) petitioner.

``Let me say then, dear lady, to back your plea, that Miss Mamie is of the most delightful kind of all--is charming among the charming.'' (Waymarsh/Mrs. Waymarsh)

Even Waymarsh, though with more to produce on the subject, could get into motion in time.

``Yes, Countess, the American girl's a thing that your country must at least allow ours the privilege to say we CAN show you. But her (girl) full beauty is only for those who know how to make use of her (girl).'' (unknown)

``Ah then,'' (Madame de Vionnet/Vionnet/de Vionnet)
smiled Madame de Vionnet,
``that's exactly what I want to do. I'm sure she (girl) has much to teach us.'' (Madame de Vionnet/Vionnet/de Vionnet)

It was wonderful, but what was scarce less so was that Strether found himself, by the quick effect of it, moved another way.

``Oh that may be! But don't speak of your own exquisite daughter, you know, as if she (daughter) weren't pure perfection. I at least won't take that from you. Mademoiselle de Vionnet,'' (he)
he (Strether) explained, in considerable form, to Mrs. Pocock,
``IS pure perfection. Mademoiselle de Vionnet IS exquisite.'' (Mrs. Pocock/Pocock)

It had been perhaps a little portentous, but

``Ah?'' (Sarah/Sarah Pocock/Pocock)
Sarah simply glittered.

Waymarsh himself, for that matter, apparently recognised, in respect to the facts, the need of a larger justice, and he (Strether) had with it an inclination to Sarah.

``Miss Jane's strikingly handsome--in the regular French style.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

It somehow made both Strether and Madame de Vionnet laugh out, though at the very moment he (Vionnet) caught in Sarah's eyes, as glancing at the speaker, a vague but unmistakeable

``You too?'' (the speaker)
It made Waymarsh in fact look consciously over her (Waymarsh) head. Madame de Vionnet meanwhile, however, made her (Waymarsh) point in her (Waymarsh) own way.
``I wish indeed I could offer you my poor child as a dazzling attraction: it would make one's position simple enough! She (Jane)'s as good as she (Jane) can be, but of course she (Jane)'s different, and the question is now--in the light of the way things seem to go--if she (Jane) isn't after all TOO different: too different I mean from the splendid type every one is so agreed that your wonderful country produces. On the other hand of course Mr. Newsome, who knows it so well, has, as a good friend, dear kind man that he (man) is, done everything he (man) can--to keep us from fatal benightedness--for my small shy creature. Well,'' (she)
she (Waymarsh) wound up after Mrs. Pocock had signified, in a murmur still a little stiff, that she (Pocock) would speak to her (Pocock) own young charge on the question--
``well, we shall sit, my child and I, and wait and wait and wait for you.'' (she)
But her (Pocock) last fine turn was for Strether.
``Do speak of us in such a way--!'' (unknown)

``As that something can't but come of it? Oh something SHALL come of it! I take a great interest!'' (he)
he (Vionnet) further declared; and in proof of it, the next moment, he (Vionnet) had gone with her (Pocock) down to her (Pocock) carriage.

Book Ninth

I

``The difficulty is,'' (I)
Strether said to Madame de Vionnet a couple of days later,
``that I can't surprise them into the smallest sign of his (man) not being the same old Chad they've been for the last three years glowering at across the sea. They simply won't give any, and as a policy, you know--what you call a parti pris, a deep game--that's positively remarkable.'' (a couple)

It was so remarkable that our friend had pulled up before his (friend) hostess with the vision of it; he (friend) had risen from his (friend) chair at the end of ten minutes and begun, as a help not to worry, to move about before her (hostess) quite as he (friend) moved before Maria. He (friend) had kept his (friend) appointment with her (hostess) to the minute and had been intensely impatient, though divided in truth between the sense of having everything to tell her (hostess) and the sense of having nothing at all. The short interval had, in the face of their complication, multiplied his (friend) impressions--it being meanwhile to be noted, moreover, that he (friend) already frankly, already almost publicly, viewed the complication as common to them. If Madame de Vionnet, under Sarah's eyes, had pulled him (Vionnet) into her (Sarah) boat, there was by this time no doubt whatever that he (Vionnet) had remained in it and that what he (Vionnet) had really most been conscious of for many hours together was the movement of the vessel itself. They were in it together this moment as they hadn't yet been, and he (Vionnet) hadn't at present uttered the least of the words of alarm or remonstrance that had died on his (Vionnet) lips at the hotel. He (Vionnet) had other things to say to her (Sarah) than that she (Sarah) had put him (Vionnet) in a position; so quickly had his (Vionnet) position grown to affect him (Vionnet) as quite excitingly, altogether richly, inevitable. That the outlook, however--given the point of exposure--hadn't cleared up half so much as he (Vionnet) had reckoned was the first warning she (Sarah) received from him (Vionnet) on his (Vionnet) arrival. She (Sarah) had replied with indulgence that he (Vionnet) was in too great a hurry, and had remarked soothingly that if she (Sarah) knew how to be patient surely HE (Vionnet) might be. He (Vionnet) felt her (Sarah) presence, on the spot, he (Vionnet) felt her (Sarah) tone and everything about her (Sarah), as an aid to that effort; and it was perhaps one of the proofs of her (Sarah) success with him (Vionnet) that he (Vionnet) seemed so much to take his (Vionnet) ease while they talked. By the time he (Vionnet) had explained to her (Sarah) why his (Vionnet) impressions, though multiplied, still baffled him (Vionnet), it was as if he (Vionnet) had been familiarly talking for hours. They baffled him (Vionnet) because Sarah--well, Sarah was deep, deeper than she (Sarah) had ever yet had a chance to show herself. He (Vionnet) didn't say that this was partly the effect of her (Sarah) opening so straight down, as it were, into her (Sarah) mother, and that, given Mrs. Newsome's profundity, the shaft thus sunk might well have a reach; but he (Vionnet) wasn't without a resigned apprehension that, at such a rate of confidence between the two women, he (Vionnet) was likely soon to be moved to show how already, at moments, it had been for him (Vionnet) as if he (Vionnet) were dealing directly with Mrs. Newsome. Sarah, to a certainty, would have begun herself to feel it in him (Vionnet)--and this naturally put it in her (Sarah) power to torment him (Vionnet) the more. From the moment she (Sarah) knew he (Vionnet) COULD be tormented--!

``But WHY can you be?'' (companion)
--his (Vionnet) companion was surprised at his (Vionnet) use of the word.

``Because I'm made so--I think of everything.'' (unknown)

``Ah one must never do that,'' (she)
she (Sarah) smiled.
``One must think of as few things as possible.'' (unknown)

``Then,'' (he)
he (Vionnet) answered,
``one must pick them out right. But all I mean is--for I express myself with violence--that she (them)'s in a position to watch me. There's an element of suspense for me, and she (them) can see me wriggle. But my wriggling doesn't matter,'' (he)
he (Vionnet) pursued.
``I can bear it. Besides, I shall wriggle out.'' (he)

The picture at any rate stirred in her (Sarah) an appreciation that he (Vionnet) felt to be sincere.

``I don't see how a man can be kinder to a woman than you are to me.'' (he)

Well, kind was what he (Vionnet) wanted to be; yet even while her (Sarah) charming eyes rested on him (Vionnet) with the truth of this he (Vionnet) none the less had his (Vionnet) humour of honesty.

``When I say suspense I mean, you know,'' (he)
he (Vionnet) laughed,
``suspense about my own case too!'' (he)

``Oh yes--about your own case too!'' (she)
It diminished his (Vionnet) magnanimity, but she (Sarah) only looked at him (Vionnet) the more tenderly.

``Not, however,'' (he)
he (Vionnet) went on,
``that I want to talk to you about that. It's my own little affair, and I mentioned it simply as part of Mrs. Pocock's advantage.'' (he)
No, no; though there was a queer present temptation in it, and his (Vionnet) suspense was so real that to fidget was a relief, he (Vionnet) wouldn't talk to her (Sarah) about Mrs. Newsome, wouldn't work off on her (Sarah) the anxiety produced in him (Vionnet) by Sarah's calculated omissions of reference. The effect she (Sarah) produced of representing her (Sarah) mother had been produced--and that was just the immense, the uncanny part of it--without her (Sarah) having so much as mentioned that lady. She (Sarah) had brought no message, had alluded to no question, had only answered his (Vionnet) enquiries with hopeless limited propriety. She (Sarah) had invented a way of meeting them--as if he (Vionnet) had been a polite perfunctory poor relation, of distant degree--that made them almost ridiculous in him (Vionnet). He (Vionnet) couldn't moreover on his (Vionnet) own side ask much without appearing to publish how he (Vionnet) had lately lacked news; a circumstance of which it was Sarah's profound policy not to betray a suspicion. These things, all the same, he (Vionnet) wouldn't breathe to Madame de Vionnet--much as they might make him (Vionnet) walk up and down. And what he (Vionnet) didn't say--as well as what SHE didn't, for she (Sarah) had also her (Sarah) high decencies--enhanced the effect of his (Vionnet) being there with her (Sarah) at the end of ten minutes more intimately on the basis of saving her (Sarah) than he (Vionnet) had yet had occasion to be. It ended in fact by being quite beautiful between them, the number of things they had a manifest consciousness of not saying. He (Vionnet) would have liked to turn her (Sarah), critically, to the subject of Mrs. Pocock, but he (Vionnet) so stuck to the line he (Vionnet) felt to be the point of honour and of delicacy that he (Vionnet) scarce even asked her (Pocock) what her (Pocock) personal impression had been. He (Vionnet) knew it, for that matter, without putting her (Pocock) to trouble: that she (Pocock) wondered how, with such elements, Sarah could still have no charm, was one of the principal things she (Sarah) held her (Sarah) tongue about. Strether would have been interested in her (Sarah) estimate of the elements--indubitably there, some of them, and to be appraised according to taste--but he (Strether) denied himself even the luxury of this diversion. The way Madame de Vionnet affected him (Vionnet) to-day was in itself a kind of demonstration of the happy employment of gifts. How could a woman think Sarah had charm who struck one as having arrived at it herself by such different roads? On the other hand of course Sarah wasn't obliged to have it. He (Vionnet) felt as if somehow Madame de Vionnet WAS. The great question meanwhile was what Chad thought of his (Chad) sister; which was naturally ushered in by that of Sarah's apprehension of Chad. THAT they could talk of, and with a freedom purchased by their discretion in other senses. The difficulty however was that they were reduced as yet to conjecture. He (Chad) had given them in the day or two as little of a lead as Sarah, and Madame de Vionnet mentioned that she (Sarah) hadn't seen him (Vionnet) since his (Vionnet) sister's arrival.

``And does that strike you as such an age?'' (She)

She (Sarah) met it in all honesty.

``Oh I won't pretend I don't miss him (my). Sometimes I see him (my) every day. Our friendship's like that. Make what you will of it!'' (she)
she (Sarah) whimsically smiled; a little flicker of the kind, occasional in her (Sarah), that had more than once moved him (Vionnet) to wonder what he (Vionnet) might best make of HER.
``But he (my)'s perfectly right,'' (she)
she (Sarah) hastened to add,
``and I wouldn't have him (my) fail in any way at present for the world. I'd sooner not see him (my) for three months. I begged him (my) to be beautiful to them, and he (my) fully feels it for himself.'' (she)

Strether turned away under his (Strether) quick perception; she (Sarah) was so odd a mixture of lucidity and mystery. She (Sarah) fell in at moments with the theory about her (Sarah) he (Strether) most cherished, and she (Sarah) seemed at others to blow it into air. She (Sarah) spoke now as if her (Sarah) art were all an innocence, and then again as if her (Sarah) innocence were all an art.

``Oh he (my)'s giving himself up, and he (my)'ll do so to the end. How can he (my) but want, now that it's within reach, his (my) full impression?--which is much more important, you know, than either yours or mine. But he (my)'s just soaking,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether said as he (Strether) came back;
``he (my)'s going in conscientiously for a saturation. I'm bound to say he (my) IS very good.'' (he)

``Ah,'' (she)
she (Sarah) quietly replied,
``to whom do you say it?'' (she)
And then more quietly still:
``He (my)'s capable of anything.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether more than reaffirmed--

``Oh he (my)'s excellent. I more and more like,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
he (Strether) insisted,
``to see him (my) with them;'' (he)
though the oddity of this tone between them grew sharper for him (Strether) even while they spoke. It placed the young man so before them as the result of her (Sarah) interest and the product of her (Sarah) genius, acknowledged so her (Sarah) part in the phenomenon and made the phenomenon so rare, that more than ever yet he (genius) might have been on the very point of asking her (Sarah) for some more detailed account of the whole business than he (genius) had yet received from her (Sarah). The occasion almost forced upon him (genius) some question as to how she (Sarah) had managed and as to the appearance such miracles presented from her (Sarah) own singularly close place of survey. The moment in fact however passed, giving way to more present history, and he (genius) continued simply to mark his (genius) appreciation of the happy truth.
``It's a tremendous comfort to feel how one can trust him (my).'' (she)
And then again while for a little she (Sarah) said nothing--as if after all to HER trust there might be a special limit:
``I mean for making a good show to them.'' (she)

``Yes,'' (she)
she (Sarah) thoughtfully returned--
``but if they shut their eyes to it!'' (she)

Strether for an instant had his (Strether) own thought.

``Well perhaps that won't matter!'' (unknown)

``You mean because he (my) probably--do what they will--won't like them?'' (unknown)

``Oh `do what they will'--! They won't do much; especially if Sarah hasn't more--well, more than one has yet made out--to give.'' (Madame)

Madame de Vionnet weighed it.

``Ah she (Sarah) has all her (Sarah) grace!'' (Strether)
It was a statement over which, for a little, they could look at each other sufficiently straight, and though it produced no protest from Strether the effect was somehow as if he (Vionnet) had treated it as a joke.
``She (Sarah) may be persuasive and caressing with him (my); she (Sarah) may be eloquent beyond words. She (Sarah) may get hold of him (my),'' (she)
she (Sarah) wound up--
``well, as neither you nor I have.'' (she)

``Yes, she (Sarah) MAY'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
--and now Strether smiled.
``But he (my) has spent all his (my) time each day with Jim. He (my)'s still showing Jim round.'' (She)

She (Sarah) visibly wondered.

``Then how about Jim?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether took a turn before he (Strether) answered.

``Hasn't he (Jim) given you Jim? Hasn't he (Jim) before this `done' him (Jim) for you?'' (He)
He (Strether) was a little at a loss.
``Doesn't he (Jim) tell you things?'' (She)

She (Sarah) hesitated.

``No'' (unknown)
--and their eyes once more gave and took.
``Not as you do. You somehow make me see them--or at least feel them. And I haven't asked too much,'' (she)
she (Sarah) added;
``I've of late wanted so not to worry him (Jim).'' (she)

``Ah for that, so have I,'' (he)
he (Strether) said with encouraging assent; so that--as if she (Sarah) had answered everything--they were briefly sociable on it. It threw him (Strether) back on his (Strether) other thought, with which he (Strether) took another turn; stopping again, however, presently with something of a glow.
``You see Jim's really immense. I think it will be Jim who'll do it.'' (She)

She (Sarah) wondered.

``Get hold of him (Jim)?'' (unknown)

``No--just the other thing. Counteract Sarah's spell.'' (he)
And he (Strether) showed now, our friend, how far he (Strether) had worked it out.
``Jim's intensely cynical.'' (unknown)

``Oh dear Jim!'' (Madame)
Madame de Vionnet vaguely smiled.

``Yes, literally--dear Jim! He (Jim)'s awful. What HE (Jim) wants, heaven forgive him (Jim), is to help us.'' (unknown)

``You mean'' (she)
--she (Sarah) was eager--
``help ME?'' (she)

``Well, Chad and me in the first place. But he (Chad) throws you in too, though without as yet seeing you much. Only, so far as he (Chad) does see you--if you don't mind--he (Chad) sees you as awful.'' (unknown)

''`Awful'?'' (she)
--she (Sarah) wanted it all.

``A regular bad one--though of course of a tremendously superior kind. Dreadful, delightful, irresistible.'' (unknown)

``Ah dear Jim! I should like to know him (Jim). I MUST.'' (unknown)

``Yes, naturally. But will it do? You may, you know,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether suggested,
``disappoint him (Jim).'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

She (Sarah) was droll and humble about it.

``I can but try. But my wickedness then,'' (she)
she (Sarah) went on,
``is my recommendation for him (Jim)?'' (she)

``Your wickedness and the charms with which, in such a degree as yours, he (Jim) associates it. He (Jim) understands, you see, that Chad and I have above all wanted to have a good time, and his (Chad) view is simple and sharp. Nothing will persuade him (Chad)--in the light, that is, of my behaviour--that I really didn't, quite as much as Chad, come over to have one before it was too late. He (Chad) wouldn't have expected it of me; but men of my age, at Woollett--and especially the least likely ones--have been noted as liable to strange outbreaks, belated uncanny clutches at the unusual, the ideal. It's an effect that a lifetime of Woollett has quite been observed as having; and I thus give it to you, in Jim's view, for what it's worth. Now his (Jim) wife and his (Jim) mother-in-law,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether continued to explain,
``have, as in honour bound, no patience with such phenomena, late or early--which puts Jim, as against his (Jim) relatives, on the other side. Besides,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
he (Strether) added,
``I don't think he (Jim) really wants Chad back. If Chad doesn't come--'' (he)

``He (Chad)'ll have'' (Madame de Vionnet/Vionnet/de Vionnet)
--Madame de Vionnet quite apprehended--
``more of the free hand?'' (Madame de Vionnet/Vionnet/de Vionnet)

``Well, Chad's the bigger man.'' (unknown)

``So he (Chad)'ll work now, en dessous, to keep him (Chad) quiet?'' (unknown)

``No--he (Chad) won't `work' at all, and he (Chad) won't do anything en dessous. He (Chad)'s very decent and won't be a traitor in the camp. But he (Chad)'ll be amused with his (Chad) own little view of our duplicity, he (Chad)'ll sniff up what he (Chad) supposes to be Paris from morning till night, and he (Chad)'ll be, as to the rest, for Chad--well, just what he (Chad) is.'' (She)

She (Sarah) thought it over.

``A warning?'' (He)

He (Vionnet) met it almost with glee.

``You ARE as wonderful as everybody says!'' (he)
And then to explain all he (Vionnet) meant:
``I drove him (Chad) about for his (Chad) first hour, and do you know what--all beautifully unconscious--he (Chad) most put before me? Why that something like THAT is at bottom, as an improvement to his (Chad) present state, as in fact the real redemption of it, what they think it may not be too late to make of our friend.'' (he)
With which, as, taking it in, she (Sarah) seemed, in her (Sarah) recurrent alarm, bravely to gaze at the possibility, he (Vionnet) completed his (Vionnet) statement.
``But it IS too late. Thanks to you!'' (unknown)

It drew from her (Sarah) again one of her (Sarah) indefinite reflexions.

``Oh `me'--after all!'' (He)

He (Vionnet) stood before her (Sarah) so exhilarated by his (Vionnet) demonstration that he (Vionnet) could fairly be jocular.

``Everything's comparative. You're better than THAT.'' (unknown)

``You'' (she)
--she (Sarah) could but answer him (Vionnet)--
``are better than anything.'' (him)
But she (Sarah) had another thought.
``WILL Mrs. Pocock come to me?'' (unknown)

``Oh yes--she (Pocock)'ll do that. As soon, that is, as my friend Waymarsh--HER friend now--leaves her (Waymarsh) leisure.'' (She)

She (Sarah) showed an interest.

``Is he (friend) so much her (Waymarsh) friend as that?'' (unknown)

``Why, didn't you see it all at the hotel?'' (unknown)

``Oh'' (she)
--she (Sarah) was amused--
''`all' is a good deal to say. I don't know--I forget. I lost myself in HER.'' (she)

``You were splendid,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether returned--
``but `all' isn't a good deal to say: it's only a little. Yet it's charming so far as it goes. She (Waymarsh) wants a man to herself.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

``And hasn't she (Waymarsh) got you?'' (unknown)

``Do you think she (Waymarsh) looked at me--or even at you--as if she (Waymarsh) had?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether easily dismissed that irony.
``Every one, you see, must strike her (Waymarsh) as having somebody. You've got Chad--and Chad has got you.'' (unknown)

``I see'' (she)
--she (Sarah) made of it what she (Sarah) could.
``And you've got Maria.'' (he)

Well, he (Strether) on his (Strether) side accepted that.

``I've got Maria. And Maria has got me. So it goes.'' (unknown)

``But Mr. Jim--whom has he (Jim) got?'' (unknown)

``Oh he (Jim) has got--or it's as IF he (Jim) had--the whole place.'' (unknown)

``But for Mr. Waymarsh'' (she)
--she (Sarah) recalled--
``isn't Miss Barrace before any one else?'' (she)

He (Strether) shook his (Strether) head.

``Miss Barrace is a raffinee, and her (Maria) amusement won't lose by Mrs. Pocock. It will gain rather--especially if Sarah triumphs and she (Sarah) comes in for a view of it.'' (unknown)

``How well you know us!'' (Madame de Vionnet/Vionnet/de Vionnet)
Madame de Vionnet, at this, frankly sighed.

``No--it seems to me it's we that I know. I know Sarah--it's perhaps on that ground only that my feet are firm. Waymarsh will take her (Waymarsh) round while Chad takes Jim--and I shall be, I assure you delighted for both of them. Sarah will have had what she (Sarah) requires--she (Sarah) will have paid her (Sarah) tribute to the ideal; and he (Chad) will have done about the same.
