In Paris it's in the air--so what can one do less? If there's a point that, beyond any other, Sarah wants to make, it's that she (Sarah) didn't come out to be narrow. We shall feel at least that.'' (unknown)

``Oh,'' (she)
she (Sarah) sighed,
``the quantity we seem likely to `feel'! But what becomes, in these conditions, of the girl?'' (she)

``Of Mamie--if we're all provided? Ah for that,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
said Strether,
``you can trust Chad.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

``To be, you mean, all right to her (Mamie)?'' (unknown)

``To pay her (Mamie) every attention as soon as he (Chad) has polished off Jim. He (Chad) wants what Jim can give him (Jim)--and what Jim really won't--though he (Jim) has had it all, and more than all, from me. He (Jim) wants in short his (Jim) own personal impression, and he (Jim)'ll get it--strong. But as soon as he (Jim) has got it Mamie won't suffer.'' (unknown)

``Oh Mamie mustn't SUFFER!'' (unknown)
Madame de Vionnet soothingly emphasised.

But Strether could reassure her (Sarah).

``Don't fear. As soon as he (Jim) has done with Jim, Jim will fall to me. And then you'll see.'' (she)

It was as if in a moment she (Sarah) saw already; yet she (Sarah) still waited. Then

``Is she (Mamie) really quite charming?'' (she)
she (Sarah) asked.

He (Strether) had got up with his (Strether) last words and gathered in his (Strether) hat and gloves.

``I don't know; I'm watching. I'm studying the case, as it were--and I dare say I shall be able to tell you.'' (She)

She (Sarah) wondered.

``Is it a case?'' (unknown)

``Yes--I think so. At any rate I shall see.'' (unknown)

``But haven't you known her (Mamie) before?'' (unknown)

``Yes,'' (he)
he (Strether) smiled--
``but somehow at home she (Mamie) wasn't a case. She (Mamie) has become one since.'' (he)
It was as if he (Strether) made it out for himself.
``She (Mamie) has become one here.'' (unknown)

``So very very soon?'' (He)

He (Strether) measured it, laughing.

``Not sooner than I did.'' (unknown)

``And you became one--?'' (unknown)

``Very very soon. The day I arrived.'' (unknown)

Her (Sarah) intelligent eyes showed her (Sarah) thought of it.

``Ah but the day you arrived you met Maria. Whom has Miss Pocock met?'' (He)

He (Strether) paused again, but he (Strether) brought it out.

``Hasn't she (Pocock) met Chad?'' (unknown)

``Certainly--but not for the first time. He (Chad)'s an old friend.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
At which Strether had a slow amused significant headshake that made her (Sarah) go on:
``You mean that for HER at least he (Chad)'s a new person--that she (Pocock) sees him (Chad) as different?'' (her)

``She (Pocock) sees him (Chad) as different.'' (unknown)

``And how does she (Pocock) see him (Chad)?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether gave it up.

``How can one tell how a deep little girl sees a deep young man?'' (unknown)

``Is every one so deep? Is she (girl) too?'' (unknown)

``So it strikes me deeper than I thought. But wait a little--between us we'll make it out. You'll judge for that matter yourself.'' (Madame)

Madame de Vionnet looked for the moment fairly bent on the chance.

``Then she (girl) WILL come with her (girl)?--I mean Mamie with Mrs. Pocock?'' (unknown)

``Certainly. Her (Pocock) curiosity, if nothing else, will in any case work that. But leave it all to Chad.'' (unknown)

``Ah,'' (Madame de Vionnet/Vionnet/de Vionnet)
wailed Madame de Vionnet, turning away a little wearily,
``the things I leave to Chad!'' (Madame de Vionnet/Vionnet/de Vionnet)

The tone of it made him (Vionnet) look at her (Sarah) with a kindness that showed his (Vionnet) vision of her (Sarah) suspense. But he (Vionnet) fell back on his (Vionnet) confidence.

``Oh well--trust him (Chad). Trust him (Chad) all the way.'' (He)
He (Vionnet) had indeed no sooner so spoken than the queer displacement of his (Vionnet) point of view appeared again to come up for him (Vionnet) in the very sound, which drew from him (Vionnet) a short laugh, immediately checked. He (Vionnet) became still more advisory.
``When they do come give them plenty of Miss Jeanne. Let Mamie see her (Mamie) well.'' (She)

She (Sarah) looked for a moment as if she (Sarah) placed them face to face.

``For Mamie to hate her (Mamie)?'' (He)

He (Vionnet) had another of his (Vionnet) corrective headshakes.

``Mamie won't. Trust THEM.'' (She)

She (Sarah) looked at him (Vionnet) hard, and then as if it were what she (Sarah) must always come back to:

``It's you I trust. But I was sincere,'' (she)
she (Sarah) said,
``at the hotel. I did, I do, want my child--'' (she)

``Well?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
--Strether waited with deference while she (Sarah) appeared to hesitate as to how to put it.

``Well, to do what she (Mamie) can for me.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether for a little met her (Sarah) eyes on it; after which something that might have been unexpected to her (Sarah) came from him (Strether).

``Poor little duck!'' (unknown)

Not more expected for himself indeed might well have been her (Sarah) echo of it.

``Poor little duck! But she (Mamie) immensely wants herself,'' (she)
she (Sarah) said,
``to see our friend's cousin.'' (she)

``Is that what she (Mamie) thinks her (Mamie)?'' (unknown)

``It's what we call the young lady.'' (He)

He (Strether) thought again; then with a laugh:

``Well, your daughter will help you.'' (He)

And now at last he (Strether) took leave of her (Sarah), as he (Strether) had been intending for five minutes. But she (Sarah) went part of the way with him (Strether), accompanying him (Strether) out of the room and into the next and the next. Her (Sarah) noble old apartment offered a succession of three, the first two of which indeed, on entering, smaller than the last, but each with its faded and formal air, enlarged the office of the antechamber and enriched the sense of approach. Strether fancied them, liked them, and, passing through them with her (Sarah) more slowly now, met a sharp renewal of his (Strether) original impression. He (Strether) stopped, he (Strether) looked back; the whole thing made a vista, which he (Strether) found high melancholy and sweet--full, once more, of dim historic shades, of the faint faraway cannon-roar of the great Empire. It was doubtless half the projection of his (Strether) mind, but his (Strether) mind was a thing that, among old waxed parquets, pale shades of pink and green, pseudo-classic candelabra, he (Strether) had always needfully to reckon with. They could easily make him (Strether) irrelevant. The oddity, the originality, the poetry--he (Strether) didn't know what to call it--of Chad's connexion reaffirmed for him (Chad) its romantic side.

``They ought to see this, you know. They MUST.'' (unknown)

``The Pococks?'' (she)
--she (Strether) looked about in deprecation; she (Strether) seemed to see gaps he (Chad) didn't.

``Mamie and Sarah--Mamie in particular.'' (unknown)

``My shabby old place? But THEIR things--!'' (unknown)

``Oh their things! You were talking of what will do something for you--'' (she)

``So that it strikes you,'' (she)
she (Strether) broke in,
``that my poor place may? Oh,'' (she)
she (Strether) ruefully mused,
``that WOULD be desperate!'' (she)

``Do you know what I wish?'' (he)
he (Chad) went on.
``I wish Mrs. Newsome herself could have a look.'' (She)

She (Strether) stared, missing a little his (Chad) logic.

``It would make a difference?'' (he)

Her (Strether) tone was so earnest that as he (Chad) continued to look about he (Chad) laughed.

``It might!'' (unknown)

``But you've told her (Newsome), you tell me--'' (unknown)

``All about you? Yes, a wonderful story. But there's all the indescribable--what one gets only on the spot.'' (unknown)

``Thank you!'' (she)
she (Strether) charmingly and sadly smiled.

``It's all about me here,'' (he)
he (Chad) freely continued.
``Mrs. Newsome feels things.'' (she)

But she (Strether) seemed doomed always to come back to doubt.

``No one feels so much as YOU. No--not any one.'' (unknown)

``So much the worse then for every one. It's very easy.'' (she)

They were by this time in the antechamber, still alone together, as she (Strether) hadn't rung for a servant. The antechamber was high and square, grave and suggestive too, a little cold and slippery even in summer, and with a few old prints that were precious, Strether divined, on the walls. He (Strether) stood in the middle, slightly lingering, vaguely directing his (Strether) glasses, while, leaning against the door-post of the room, she (Strether) gently pressed her (Strether) cheek to the side of the recess.

``YOU would have been a friend.'' (unknown)

``I?'' (him)
--it startled him (Strether) a little.

``For the reason you say. You're not stupid.'' (unknown)
And then abruptly, as if bringing it out were somehow founded on that fact:
``We're marrying Jeanne.'' (him)

It affected him (Strether) on the spot as a move in a game, and he (Strether) was even then not without the sense that that wasn't the way Jeanne should be married. But he (Strether) quickly showed his (Strether) interest, though--as quickly afterwards struck him (Strether)--with an absurd confusion of mind.

''`You'? You and--a--not Chad?'' (him)
Of course it was the child's father who made the
``we,'' (child father)
but to the child's father it would have cost him (father) an effort to allude. Yet didn't it seem the next minute that Monsieur de Vionnet was after all not in question?--since she (Jeanne) had gone on to say that it was indeed to Chad she (Jeanne) referred and that he (Chad) had been in the whole matter kindness itself.

``If I must tell you all, it is he (friend) himself who has put us in the way. I mean in the way of an opportunity that, so far as I can yet see, is all I could possibly have dreamed of. For all the trouble Monsieur de Vionnet will ever take!'' (she)
It was the first time she (Jeanne) had spoken to him (Chad) of her (Jeanne) husband, and he (Chad) couldn't have expressed how much more intimate with her (Jeanne) it suddenly made him (Chad) feel. It wasn't much, in truth--there were other things in what she (Jeanne) was saying that were far more; but it was as if, while they stood there together so easily in these cold chambers of the past, the single touch had shown the reach of her (Jeanne) confidence.
``But our friend,'' (she)
she (Jeanne) asked,
``hasn't then told you?'' (she)

``He (friend) has told me nothing.'' (unknown)

``Well, it has come with rather a rush--all in a very few days; and hasn't moreover yet taken a form that permits an announcement. It's only for you--absolutely you alone--that I speak; I so want you to know.'' (he)
The sense he (Chad) had so often had, since the first hour of his (Chad) disembarkment, of being further and further
``in,'' (he)
treated him (Chad) again at this moment to another twinge; but in this wonderful way of her (Jeanne) putting him (Chad) in there continued to be something exquisitely remorseless.
``Monsieur de Vionnet will accept what he (Vionnet) MUST accept. He (Vionnet) has proposed half a dozen things--each one more impossible than the other; and he (Vionnet) wouldn't have found this if he (Vionnet) lives to a hundred. Chad found it,'' (she)
she (Jeanne) continued with her (Jeanne) lighted, faintly flushed, her (Jeanne) conscious confidential face,
``in the quietest way in the world. Or rather it found HIM--for everything finds him (Chad); I mean finds him (Chad) right. You'll think we do such things strangely--but at my age,'' (she)
she (Jeanne) smiled,
``one has to accept one's conditions. Our young man's people had seen her (Chad); one of his (man) sisters, a charming woman--we know all about them--had observed her (Chad) somewhere with me. She (Chad) had spoken to her (Chad) brother--turned him (brother) on; and we were again observed, poor Jeanne and I, without our in the least knowing it. It was at the beginning of the winter; it went on for some time; it outlasted our absence; it began again on our return; and it luckily seems all right. The young man had met Chad, and he (Chad) got a friend to approach him (Chad)--as having a decent interest in us. Mr. Newsome looked well before he (Newsome) leaped; he (Newsome) kept beautifully quiet and satisfied himself fully; then only he (Newsome) spoke. It's what has for some time past occupied us. It seems as if it were what would do; really, really all one could wish. There are only two or three points to be settled--they depend on her (Newsome) father. But this time I think we're safe.'' (she)

Strether, consciously gaping a little, had fairly hung upon her (Jeanne) lips.

``I hope so with all my heart.'' (he)
And then he (Strether) permitted himself:
``Does nothing depend on HER?'' (he)

``Ah naturally; everything did. But she (Newsome)'s pleased comme tout. She (Newsome) has been perfectly free; and he (father)--our young friend--is really a combination. I quite adore him (father).'' (Strether)

Strether just made sure.

``You mean your future son-in-law?'' (unknown)

``Future if we all bring it off.'' (unknown)

``Ah well,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
said Strether decorously,
``I heartily hope you may.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
There seemed little else for him (Strether) to say, though her (Jeanne) communication had the oddest effect on him (Strether). Vaguely and confusedly he (Strether) was troubled by it; feeling as if he (Strether) had even himself been concerned in something deep and dim. He (Strether) had allowed for depths, but these were greater: and it was as if, oppressively--indeed absurdly--he (Strether) was responsible for what they had now thrown up to the surface. It was--through something ancient and cold in it--what he (Strether) would have called the real thing. In short his (Strether) hostess's news, though he (Strether) couldn't have explained why, was a sensible shock, and his (Strether) oppression a weight he (Strether) felt he (Strether) must somehow or other immediately get rid of. There were too many connexions missing to make it tolerable he (Strether) should do anything else. He (Strether) was prepared to suffer--before his (Strether) own inner tribunal--for Chad; he (Strether) was prepared to suffer even for Madame de Vionnet. But he (Vionnet) wasn't prepared to suffer for the little girl So now having said the proper thing, he (Vionnet) wanted to get away. She (girl) held him (Vionnet) an instant, however, with another appeal.

``Do I seem to you very awful?'' (unknown)

``Awful? Why so?'' (he)
But he (Vionnet) called it to himself, even as he (Vionnet) spoke, his (Vionnet) biggest insincerity yet.

``Our arrangements are so different from yours.'' (unknown)

``Mine?'' (he)
Oh he (Vionnet) could dismiss that too!
``I haven't any arrangements.'' (unknown)

``Then you must accept mine; all the more that they're excellent. They're founded on a vieille sagesse. There will be much more, if all goes well, for you to hear and to know, and everything, believe me, for you to like. Don't be afraid; you'll be satisfied.'' (she)
Thus she (girl) could talk to him (Vionnet) of what, of her (girl) innermost life--for that was what it came to--he (Vionnet) must
``accept'' (he)
; thus she (girl) could extraordinarily speak as if in such an affair his (Vionnet) being satisfied had an importance. It was all a wonder and made the whole case larger. He (Vionnet) had struck himself at the hotel, before Sarah and Waymarsh, as being in her (Waymarsh) boat; but where on earth was he (Vionnet) now? This question was in the air till her (Waymarsh) own lips quenched it with another.
``And do you suppose HE (I)--who loves her (me) so--would do anything reckless or cruel?'' (He)

He (Vionnet) wondered what he (Vionnet) supposed.

``Do you mean your young man--?'' (unknown)

``I mean yours. I mean Mr. Newsome.'' (Strether)
It flashed for Strether the next moment a finer light, and the light deepened as she (Waymarsh) went on.
``He (Newsome) takes, thank God, the truest tenderest interest in her (me).'' (unknown)

It deepened indeed.

``Oh I'm sure of that!'' (unknown)

``You were talking,'' (she)
she (Waymarsh) said,
``about one's trusting him (Newsome). You see then how I do.'' (she)

He (Vionnet) waited a moment--it all came.

``I see--I see.'' (He)
He (Vionnet) felt he (Vionnet) really did see.

``He (Newsome) wouldn't hurt her (me) for the world, nor--assuming she (me) marries at all--risk anything that might make against her (me) happiness. And--willingly, at least--he (Newsome) would never hurt ME.'' (he)

Her (Waymarsh) face, with what he (Vionnet) had by this time grasped, told him (Vionnet) more than her (Waymarsh) words; whether something had come into it, or whether he (Vionnet) only read clearer, her (Waymarsh) whole story--what at least he (Vionnet) then took for such--reached out to him (Vionnet) from it. With the initiative she (Waymarsh) now attributed to Chad it all made a sense, and this sense--a light, a lead, was what had abruptly risen before him (Chad). He (Chad) wanted, once more, to get off with these things; which was at last made easy, a servant having, for his (Chad) assistance, on hearing voices in the hall, just come forward. All that Strether had made out was, while the man opened the door and impersonally waited, summed up in his (man) last word.

``I don't think, you know, Chad will tell me anything.'' (unknown)

``No--perhaps not yet.'' (unknown)

``And I won't as yet speak to him (Chad).'' (unknown)

``Ah that's as you'll think best. You must judge.'' (She)

She (Waymarsh) had finally given him (man) her (Waymarsh) hand, which he (man) held a moment.

``How MUCH I have to judge!'' (unknown)

``Everything,'' (Madame de Vionnet/Vionnet/de Vionnet)
said Madame de Vionnet: a remark that was indeed--with the refined disguised suppressed passion of her (Waymarsh) face--what he (Vionnet) most carried away.

II

So far as a direct approach was concerned Sarah had neglected him (Vionnet), for the week now about to end, with a civil consistency of chill that, giving him (Vionnet) a higher idea of her (Sarah) social resource, threw him (Vionnet) back on the general reflexion that a woman could always be amazing. It indeed helped a little to console him (Vionnet) that he (Vionnet) felt sure she (woman) had for the same period also left Chad's curiosity hanging; though on the other hand, for his (Chad) personal relief, Chad could at least go through the various motions--and he (Chad) made them extraordinarily numerous--of seeing she (woman) had a good time. There wasn't a motion on which, in her (woman) presence, poor Strether could so much as venture, and all he (Strether) could do when he (Strether) was out of it was to walk over for a talk with Maria. He (Strether) walked over of course much less than usual, but he (Strether) found a special compensation in a certain half-hour during which, toward the close of a crowded empty expensive day, his (Strether) several companions seemed to him (Strether) so disposed of as to give his (Strether) forms and usages a rest. He (Strether) had been with them in the morning and had nevertheless called on the Pococks in the afternoon; but their whole group, he (Strether) then found, had dispersed after a fashion of which it would amuse Miss Gostrey to hear. He (Strether) was sorry again, gratefully sorry she (Strether) was so out of it--she (Strether) who had really put him (Strether) in; but she (Strether) had fortunately always her (Strether) appetite for news. The pure flame of the disinterested burned in her (Strether) cave of treasures as a lamp in a Byzantine vault. It was just now, as happened, that for so fine a sense as hers a near view would have begun to pay. Within three days, precisely, the situation on which he (Strether) was to report had shown signs of an equilibrium; the effect of his (Strether) look in at the hotel was to confirm this appearance. If the equilibrium might only prevail! Sarah was out with Waymarsh, Mamie was out with Chad, and Jim was out alone. Later on indeed he (Jim) himself was booked to Jim, was to take him (Jim) that evening to the Varieties--which Strether was careful to pronounce as Jim pronounced them.

Miss Gostrey drank it in.

``What then to-night do the others do?'' (unknown)

``Well, it has been arranged. Waymarsh takes Sarah to dine at Bignons.'' (She)

She (Gostrey) wondered.

``And what do they do after? They can't come straight home.'' (unknown)

``No, they can't come straight home--at least Sarah can't. It's their secret, but I think I've guessed it.'' (she)
Then as she (Gostrey) waited:
``The circus.'' (she)

It made her (Gostrey) stare a moment longer, then laugh almost to extravagance.

``There's no one like you!'' (unknown)

``Like ME?'' (he)
--he (Jim) only wanted to understand.

``Like all of you together--like all of us: Woollett, Milrose and their products. We're abysmal--but may we never be less so! Mr. Newsome,'' (she)
she (Gostrey) continued,
``meanwhile takes Miss Pocock--?'' (she)

``Precisely--to the Francais: to see what you took Waymarsh and me to, a family-bill.'' (unknown)

``Ah then may Mr. Chad enjoy it as I did!'' (she)
But she (Gostrey) saw so much in things.
``Do they spend their evenings, your young people, like that, alone together?'' (unknown)

``Well, they're young people--but they're old friends.'' (unknown)

``I see, I see. And do THEY dine--for a difference--at Brebant's?'' (unknown)

``Oh where they dine is their secret too. But I've my idea that it will be, very quietly, at Chad's own place.'' (unknown)

``She (I)'ll come to him (Chad) there alone?'' (unknown)

They looked at each other a moment.

``He (Chad) has known her (I) from a child. Besides,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
said Strether with emphasis,
``Mamie's remarkable. She (Mamie)'s splendid.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

She (Gostrey) wondered.

``Do you mean she (Mamie) expects to bring it off?'' (unknown)

``Getting hold of him (Chad)? No--I think not.'' (unknown)

``She (Mamie) doesn't want him (Chad) enough?--or doesn't believe in her (Mamie) power?'' (he)
On which as he (Strether) said nothing she (Gostrey) continued:
``She (Mamie) finds she (Mamie) doesn't care for him (Chad)?'' (she)

``No--I think she (Mamie) finds she (Mamie) does. But that's what I mean by so describing her (Mamie). It's IF she (Mamie) does that she (Mamie)'s splendid. But we'll see,'' (he)
he (Strether) wound up,
``where she (Mamie) comes out.'' (he)

``You seem to show me sufficiently,'' (Miss Gostrey)
Miss Gostrey laughed,
``where she (Mamie) goes in! But is her (Mamie) childhood's friend,'' (Miss Gostrey)
she (Gostrey) asked,
``permitting himself recklessly to flirt with her (Mamie)?'' (she)

``No--not that. Chad's also splendid. They're ALL splendid!'' (he)
he (Strether) declared with a sudden strange sound of wistfulness and envy.
``They're at least HAPPY.'' (unknown)

``Happy?'' (her)
--it appeared, with their various difficulties, to surprise her (Gostrey).

``Well--I seem to myself among them the only one who isn't.'' (She)

She (Gostrey) demurred.

``With your constant tribute to the ideal?'' (He)

He (Strether) had a laugh at his (Strether) tribute to the ideal, but he (Strether) explained after a moment his (Strether) impression.

``I mean they're living. They're rushing about. I've already had my rushing. I'm waiting.'' (unknown)

``But aren't you,'' (she)
she (Gostrey) asked by way of cheer,
``waiting with ME?'' (she)

He (Strether) looked at her (Gostrey) in all kindness.

``Yes--if it weren't for that!'' (unknown)

``And you help me to wait,'' (she)
she (Gostrey) said.
``However,'' (she)
she (Gostrey) went on,
``I've really something for you that will help you to wait and which you shall have in a minute. Only there's something more I want from you first. I revel in Sarah.'' (she)

``So do I. If it weren't,'' (he)
he (Strether) again amusedly sighed,
``for THAT--!'' (he)

``Well, you owe more to women than any man I ever saw. We do seem to keep you going. Yet Sarah, as I see her (Sarah), must be great.'' (unknown)

``She (Sarah) IS'' (Strether)
Strether fully assented:
``great! Whatever happens, she (Sarah) won't, with these unforgettable days, have lived in vain.'' (Strether)

Miss Gostrey had a pause.

``You mean she (Sarah) has fallen in love?'' (unknown)

``I mean she (Sarah) wonders if she (Sarah) hasn't--and it serves all her (Sarah) purpose.'' (unknown)

``It has indeed,'' (Maria/Maria Gostrey)
Maria laughed,
``served women's purposes before!'' (Maria/Maria Gostrey)

``Yes--for giving in. But I doubt if the idea--as an idea--has ever up to now answered so well for holding out. That's HER tribute to the ideal--we each have our own. It's her (Sarah) romance--and it seems to me better on the whole than mine. To have it in Paris too,'' (he)
he (Strether) explained--
``on this classic ground, in this charged infectious air, with so sudden an intensity: well, it's more than she (Sarah) expected. She (Sarah) has had in short to recognise the breaking out for her (Sarah) of a real affinity--and with everything to enhance the drama.'' (he)

Miss Gostrey followed.

``Jim for instance?'' (unknown)

``Jim. Jim hugely enhances. Jim was made to enhance. And then Mr. Waymarsh. It's the crowning touch--it supplies the colour. He (Jim)'s positively separated.'' (unknown)

``And she (Sarah) herself unfortunately isn't--that supplies the colour too.'' (Miss Gostrey)
Miss Gostrey was all there. But somehow--!
``Is HE (Jim) in love?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether looked at her (Gostrey) a long time; then looked all about the room; then came a little nearer.

``Will you never tell any one in the world as long as ever you live?'' (unknown)

``Never.'' (unknown)
It was charming.

``He (Jim) thinks Sarah really is. But he (Jim) has no fear,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether hastened to add.

``Of her (Sarah) being affected by it?'' (unknown)

``Of HIS (Jim) being. He (Jim) likes it, but he (Jim) knows she (Sarah) can hold out. He (Jim)'s helping her (Sarah), he (Jim)'s floating her (Sarah) over, by kindness.'' (Maria/Maria Gostrey)

Maria rather funnily considered it.

``Floating her (Sarah) over in champagne? The kindness of dining her (Sarah), nose to nose, at the hour when all Paris is crowding to profane delights, and in the--well, in the great temple, as one hears of it, of pleasure?'' (unknown)

``That's just IT, for both of them,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether insisted--
``and all of a supreme innocence. The Parisian place, the feverish hour, the putting before her (Sarah) of a hundred francs' worth of food and drink, which they'll scarcely touch--all that's the dear man's own romance; the expensive kind, expensive in francs and centimes, in which he (man) abounds. And the circus afterwards--which is cheaper, but which he (man)'ll find some means of making as dear as possible--that's also HIS (man) tribute to the ideal. It does for him (man). He (man)'ll see her (Sarah) through. They won't talk of anything worse than you and me.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

``Well, we're bad enough perhaps, thank heaven,'' (she)
she (Maria) laughed,
``to upset them! Mr. Waymarsh at any rate is a hideous old coquette.'' (she)
And the next moment she (Maria) had dropped everything for a different pursuit.
``What you don't appear to know is that Jeanne de Vionnet has become engaged. She (Vionnet)'s to marry--it has been definitely arranged--young Monsieur de Montbron.'' (He)

He (Strether) fairly blushed.

``Then--if you know it--it's `out'?'' (unknown)

``Don't I often know things that are NOT out? However,'' (she)
she (Maria) said,
``this will be out to-morrow. But I see I've counted too much on your possible ignorance. You've been before me, and I don't make you jump as I hoped.'' (she)

He (Strether) gave a gasp at her (Maria) insight.

``You never fail! I've HAD my jump. I had it when I first heard.'' (unknown)

``Then if you knew why didn't you tell me as soon as you came in?'' (unknown)

``Because I had it from her (I) as a thing not yet to be spoken of.'' (Miss Gostrey)

Miss Gostrey wondered.

``From Madame de Vionnet herself?'' (unknown)

``As a probability--not quite a certainty: a good cause in which Chad has been working. So I've waited.'' (unknown)

``You need wait no longer,'' (she)
she (Gostrey) returned.
``It reached me yesterday--roundabout and accidental, but by a person who had had it from one of the young man's own people--as a thing quite settled. I was only keeping it for you.'' (unknown)

``You thought Chad wouldn't have told me?'' (She)

She (Gostrey) hesitated.

``Well, if he (Chad) hasn't--'' (unknown)

``He (Chad) hasn't. And yet the thing appears to have been practically his (Chad) doing. So there we are.'' (unknown)

``There we are!'' (Maria/Maria Gostrey)
Maria candidly echoed.

``That's why I jumped. I jumped,'' (he)
he (Strether) continued to explain,
``because it means, this disposition of the daughter, that there's now nothing else: nothing else but him (Chad) and the mother.'' (he)

``Still--it simplifies.'' (unknown)

``It simplifies'' (he)
--he (Strether) fully concurred.
``But that's precisely where we are. It marks a stage in his (Chad) relation. The act is his (Chad) answer to Mrs. Newsome's demonstration.'' (unknown)

``It tells,'' (Maria/Maria Gostrey)
Maria asked,
``the worst?'' (Maria/Maria Gostrey)

``The worst.'' (unknown)

``But is the worst what he (Chad) wants Sarah to know?'' (unknown)

``He (Chad) doesn't care for Sarah.'' (unknown)

At which Miss Gostrey's eyebrows went up.

``You mean she (Sarah) has already dished herself?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether took a turn about; he (Strether) had thought it out again and again before this, to the end; but the vista seemed each time longer.

``He (Chad) wants his (Chad) good friend to know the best. I mean the measure of his (Chad) attachment. She (Sarah) asked for a sign, and he (Chad) thought of that one. There it is.'' (unknown)

``A concession to her (Sarah) jealousy?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether pulled up.

``Yes--call it that. Make it lurid--for that makes my problem richer.'' (unknown)

``Certainly, let us have it lurid--for I quite agree with you that we want none of our problems poor. But let us also have it clear. Can he (Chad), in the midst of such a preoccupation, or on the heels of it, have seriously cared for Jeanne?--cared, I mean, as a young man at liberty would have cared?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Well, Strether had mastered it.

``I think he (man) can have thought it would be charming if he (man) COULD care. It would be nicer.'' (unknown)

``Nicer than being tied up to Marie?'' (unknown)

``Yes--than the discomfort of an attachment to a person he (man) can never hope, short of a catastrophe, to marry. And he (man) was quite right,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
said Strether.
``It would certainly have been nicer. Even when a thing's already nice there mostly is some other thing that would have been nicer--or as to which we wonder if it wouldn't. But his (man) question was all the same a dream. He (man) COULDn't care in that way. He (man) IS tied up to Marie. The relation is too special and has gone too far. It's the very basis, and his (man) recent lively contribution toward establishing Jeanne in life has been his (man) definite and final acknowledgement to Madame de Vionnet that he (Vionnet) has ceased squirming. I doubt meanwhile,'' (he)
he (Strether) went on,
``if Sarah has at all directly attacked him (Vionnet).'' (he)

His (Strether) companion brooded.

``But won't he (Vionnet) wish for his (Vionnet) own satisfaction to make his (Vionnet) ground good to her (Sarah)?'' (unknown)

``No--he (Vionnet)'ll leave it to me, he (Vionnet)'ll leave everything to me. I `sort of' feel'' (he)
--he (Strether) worked it out--
``that the whole thing will come upon me. Yes, I shall have every inch and every ounce of it. I shall be USED for it--!'' (he)
And Strether lost himself in the prospect. Then he (Strether) fancifully expressed the issue.
``To the last drop of my blood.'' (Maria/Maria Gostrey)

Maria, however, roundly protested.

``Ah you'll please keep a drop for ME. I shall have a use for it!'' (she)
--which she (Maria) didn't however follow up. She (Maria) had come back the next moment to another matter.
``Mrs. Pocock, with her (Pocock) brother, is trusting only to her (Pocock) general charm?'' (unknown)

``So it would seem.'' (unknown)

``And the charm's not working?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Well, Strether put it otherwise,

``She (Pocock)'s sounding the note of home--which is the very best thing she (Pocock) can do.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

``The best for Madame de Vionnet?'' (unknown)

``The best for home itself. The natural one; the right one.'' (unknown)

``Right,'' (Maria/Maria Gostrey)
Maria asked,
``when it fails?'' (Maria/Maria Gostrey)

Strether had a pause.

``The difficulty's Jim. Jim's the note of home.'' (She)

She (Maria) debated.

``Ah surely not the note of Mrs. Newsome.'' (he)

But he (Strether) had it all.

``The note of the home for which Mrs. Newsome wants him (Jim)--the home of the business. Jim stands, with his (Jim) little legs apart, at the door of THAT tent; and Jim is, frankly speaking, extremely awful.'' (Maria/Maria Gostrey)

Maria stared.

``And you in, you poor thing, for your evening with him (Jim)?'' (unknown)

``Oh he (Jim)'s all right for ME!'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether laughed.
``Any one's good enough for ME. But Sarah shouldn't, all the same, have brought him (Jim). She (Sarah) doesn't appreciate him (Jim).'' (friend)

His (Strether) friend was amused with this statement of it.

``Doesn't know, you mean, how bad he (Jim) is?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether shook his (Strether) head with decision.

``Not really.'' (She)

She (Maria) wondered.

``Then doesn't Mrs. Newsome?'' (him)

It made him (Strether) frankly do the same.

``Well, no--since you ask me.'' (Maria/Maria Gostrey)

Maria rubbed it in.

``Not really either?'' (unknown)

``Not at all. She (Newsome) rates him (Jim) rather high.'' (he)
With which indeed, immediately, he (Strether) took himself up.
``Well, he (Jim) IS good too, in his (Jim) way. It depends on what you want him (Jim) for.'' (him)

Miss Gostrey, however, wouldn't let it depend on anything--wouldn't have it, and wouldn't want him (Strether), at any price.

``It suits my book,'' (she)
she (Maria) said,
``that he (Jim) should be impossible; and it suits it still better,'' (she)
she (Maria) more imaginatively added,
``that Mrs. Newsome doesn't know he (Jim) is.'' (she)

Strether, in consequence, had to take it from her (Maria), but he (Strether) fell back on something else.

``I'll tell you who does really know.'' (unknown)

``Mr. Waymarsh? Never!'' (unknown)

``Never indeed. I'm not ALWAYS thinking of Mr. Waymarsh; in fact I find now I never am.'' (he)
Then he (Strether) mentioned the person as if there were a good deal in it.
``Mamie.'' (unknown)

``His (Waymarsh) own sister?'' (her)
Oddly enough it but let her (Maria) down.
``What good will that do?'' (unknown)

``None perhaps. But there--as usual--we are!'' (unknown)

III

There they were yet again, accordingly, for two days more; when Strether, on being, at Mrs. Pocock's hotel, ushered into that lady's salon, found himself at first assuming a mistake on the part of the servant who had introduced him (servant) and retired. The occupants hadn't come in, for the room looked empty as only a room can look in Paris, of a fine afternoon when the faint murmur of the huge collective life, carried on out of doors, strays among scattered objects even as a summer air idles in a lonely garden. Our friend looked about and hesitated; observed, on the evidence of a table charged with purchases and other matters, that Sarah had become possessed--by no aid from HIM--of the last number of the salmon-coloured Revue; noted further that Mamie appeared to have received a present of Fromentin's

``Maitres d'Autrefois'' (Mamie/Mamie Pocock)
from Chad, who had written her (Mamie) name on the cover; and pulled up at the sight of a heavy letter addressed in a hand he (Chad) knew. This letter, forwarded by a banker and arriving in Mrs. Pocock's absence, had been placed in evidence, and it drew from the fact of its being unopened a sudden queer power to intensify the reach of its author. It brought home to him (author) the scale on which Mrs. Newsome--for she (Newsome) had been copious indeed this time--was writing to her (Newsome) daughter while she (Newsome) kept HIM in durance; and it had altogether such an effect upon him (author) as made him (author) for a few minutes stand still and breathe low. In his (author) own room, at his (author) own hotel, he (author) had dozens of well-filled envelopes superscribed in that character; and there was actually something in the renewal of his (author) interrupted vision of the character that played straight into the so frequent question of whether he (author) weren't already disinherited beyond appeal. It was such an assurance as the sharp downstrokes of her (Newsome) pen hadn't yet had occasion to give him (author); but they somehow at the present crisis stood for a probable absoluteness in any decree of the writer. He (writer) looked at Sarah's name and address, in short, as if he (writer) had been looking hard into her (Sarah) mother's face, and then turned from it as if the face had declined to relax. But since it was in a manner as if Mrs. Newsome were thereby all the more, instead of the less, in the room, and were conscious, sharply and sorely conscious, of himself, so he (writer) felt both held and hushed, summoned to stay at least and take his (writer) punishment. By staying, accordingly, he (writer) took it--creeping softly and vaguely about and waiting for Sarah to come in. She (Sarah) WOULD come in if he (writer) stayed long enough, and he (writer) had now more than ever the sense of her (Sarah) success in leaving him (writer) a prey to anxiety. It wasn't to be denied that she (Sarah) had had a happy instinct, from the point of view of Woollett, in placing him (writer) thus at the mercy of her (Sarah) own initiative. It was very well to try to say he (writer) didn't care--that she (Sarah) might break ground when she (Sarah) would, might never break it at all if she (Sarah) wouldn't, and that he (writer) had no confession whatever to wait upon her (Sarah) with: he (writer) breathed from day to day an air that damnably required clearing, and there were moments when he (writer) quite ached to precipitate that process. He (writer) couldn't doubt that, should she (Sarah) only oblige him (writer) by surprising him (writer) just as he (writer) then was, a clarifying scene of some sort would result from the concussion.

He (writer) humbly circulated in this spirit till he (writer) suddenly had a fresh arrest. Both the windows of the room stood open to the balcony, but it was only now that, in the glass of the leaf of one of them, folded back, he (writer) caught a reflexion quickly recognised as the colour of a lady's dress. Somebody had been then all the while on the balcony, and the person, whoever it might be, was so placed between the windows as to be hidden from him (writer); while on the other hand the many sounds of the street had covered his (writer) own entrance and movements. If the person were Sarah he (writer) might on the spot therefore be served to his (writer) taste. He (writer) might lead her (Sarah) by a move or two up to the remedy for his (writer) vain tension; as to which, should he (writer) get nothing else from it, he (writer) would at least have the relief of pulling down the roof on their heads. There was fortunately no one at hand to observe--in respect to his (writer) valour--that even on this completed reasoning he (writer) still hung fire. He (writer) had been waiting for Mrs. Pocock and the sound of the oracle; but he (writer) had to gird himself afresh--which he (writer) did in the embrasure of the window, neither advancing nor retreating--before provoking the revelation. It was apparently for Sarah to come more into view; he (writer) was in that case there at her (Sarah) service. She (Sarah) did however, as meanwhile happened, come more into view; only she (Sarah) luckily came at the last minute as a contradiction of Sarah. The occupant of the balcony was after all quite another person, a person presented, on a second look, by a charming back and a slight shift of her (Sarah) position, as beautiful brilliant unconscious Mamie--Mamie alone at home, Mamie passing her (Mamie) time in her (Mamie) own innocent way, Mamie in short rather shabbily used, but Mamie absorbed interested and interesting. With her (Mamie) arms on the balustrade and her (Mamie) attention dropped to the street she (Mamie) allowed Strether to watch her (Mamie), to consider several things, without her (Mamie) turning round.

But the oddity was that when he (Strether) HAD so watched and considered he (Strether) simply stepped back into the room without following up his (Strether) advantage. He (Strether) revolved there again for several minutes, quite as with something new to think of and as if the bearings of the possibility of Sarah had been superseded. For frankly, yes, it HAD bearings thus to find the girl in solitary possession. There was something in it that touched him (Strether) to a point not to have been reckoned beforehand, something that softly but quite pressingly spoke to him (Strether), and that spoke the more each time he (Strether) paused again at the edge of the balcony and saw her (girl) still unaware. Her (girl) companions were plainly scattered; Sarah would be off somewhere with Waymarsh and Chad off somewhere with Jim. Strether didn't at all mentally impute to Chad that he (Chad) was with his (Chad)

``good friend'' (he)
; he (Chad) gave him (Chad) the benefit of supposing him (Chad) involved in appearances that, had he (Chad) had to describe them--for instance to Maria--he (Chad) would have conveniently qualified as more subtle. It came to him (Chad) indeed the next thing that there was perhaps almost an excess of refinement in having left Mamie in such weather up there alone; however she (Mamie) might in fact have extemporised, under the charm of the Rue de Rivoli, a little makeshift Paris of wonder arid fancy. Our friend in any case now recognised--and it was as if at the recognition Mrs. Newsome's fixed intensity had suddenly, with a deep audible gasp, grown thin and vague--that day after day he (friend) had been conscious in respect to his (friend) young lady of something odd and ambiguous, yet something into which he (friend) could at last read a meaning. It had been at the most, this mystery, an obsession--oh an obsession agreeable; and it had just now fallen into its place as at the touch of a spring. It had represented the possibility between them of some communication baffled by accident and delay--the possibility even of some relation as yet unacknowledged.

There was always their old relation, the fruit of the Woollett years; but that--and it was what was strangest--had nothing whatever in common with what was now in the air. As a child, as a

``bud,'' (a child)
and then again as a flower of expansion, Mamie had bloomed for him (Mamie), freely, in the almost incessantly open doorways of home; where he (Mamie) remembered her (Mamie) as first very forward, as then very backward--for he (Mamie) had carried on at one period, in Mrs. Newsome's parlours -LRB-oh Mrs. Newsome's phases and his (Mamie) own!-RRB- a course of English Literature re-enforced by exams and teas--and once more, finally, as very much in advance. But he (Mamie) had kept no great sense of points of contact; it not being in the nature of things at Woollett that the freshest of the buds should find herself in the same basket with the most withered of the winter apples. The child had given sharpness, above all, to his (Mamie) sense of the flight of time; it was but the day before yesterday that he (Mamie) had tripped up on her (Mamie) hoop, yet his (Mamie) experience of remarkable women--destined, it would seem, remarkably to grow--felt itself ready this afternoon, quite braced itself, to include her (Mamie). She (Mamie) had in fine more to say to him (Mamie) than he (Mamie) had ever dreamed the pretty girl of the moment COULD have; and the proof of the circumstance was that, visibly, unmistakeably, she (girl) had been able to say it to no one else. It was something she (girl) could mention neither to her (girl) brother, to her (girl) sister-in-law nor to Chad; though he (Chad) could just imagine that had she (girl) still been at home she (girl) might have brought it out, as a supreme tribute to age, authority and attitude, for Mrs. Newsome. It was moreover something in which they all took an interest; the strength of their interest was in truth just the reason of her (Newsome) prudence. All this then, for five minutes, was vivid to Strether, and it put before him (Strether) that, poor child, she (Newsome) had now but her (Newsome) prudence to amuse her (Newsome). That, for a pretty girl in Paris, struck him (Strether), with a rush, as a sorry state; so that under the impression he (Strether) went out to her (Newsome) with a step as hypocritically alert, he (Strether) was well aware, as if he (Strether) had just come into the room. She (Newsome) turned with a start at his (Strether) voice; preoccupied with him (Strether) though she (Newsome) might be, she (Newsome) was just a scrap disappointed.
``Oh I thought you were Mr. Bilham!'' (friend)

The remark had been at first surprising and our friend's private thought, under the influence of it, temporarily blighted; yet we are able to add that he (friend) presently recovered his (friend) inward tone and that many a fresh flower of fancy was to bloom in the same air. Little Bilham--since little Bilham was, somewhat incongruously, expected--appeared behindhand; a circumstance by which Strether was to profit. They came back into the room together after a little, the couple on the balcony, and amid its crimson-and-gold elegance, with the others still absent, Strether passed forty minutes that he (Strether) appraised even at the time as far, in the whole queer connexion, from his (Strether) idlest. Yes indeed, since he (Strether) had the other day so agreed with Maria about the inspiration of the lurid, here was something for his (Strether) problem that surely didn't make it shrink and that was floated in upon him (Strether) as part of a sudden flood. He (Strether) was doubtless not to know till afterwards, on turning them over in thought, of how many elements his (Strether) impression was composed; but he (Strether) none the less felt, as he (Strether) sat with the charming girl, the signal growth of a confidence. For she (girl) WAS charming, when all was said--and none the less so for the visible habit and practice of freedom and fluency. She (girl) was charming, he (Strether) was aware, in spite of the fact that if he (Strether) hadn't found her (girl) so he (Strether) would have found her (girl) something he (Strether) should have been in peril of expressing as

``funny.'' (he)
Yes, she (girl) was funny, wonderful Mamie, and without dreaming it; she (girl) was bland, she (girl) was bridal--with never, that he (Strether) could make out as yet, a bridegroom to support it; she (girl) was handsome and portly and easy and chatty, soft and sweet and almost disconcertingly reassuring. She (girl) was dressed, if we might so far discriminate, less as a young lady than as an old one--had an old one been supposable to Strether as so committed to vanity; the complexities of her (lady) hair missed moreover also the looseness of youth; and she (lady) had a mature manner of bending a little, as to encourage and reward, while she (lady) held neatly together in front of her (lady) a pair of strikingly polished hands: the combination of all of which kept up about her (lady) the glamour of her (lady)
``receiving,'' (she)
placed her (lady) again perpetually between the windows and within sound of the ice-cream plates, suggested the enumeration of all the names, all the Mr. Brookses and Mr. Snookses, gregarious specimens of a single type, she (lady) was happy to
``meet.'' (she)
But if all this was where she (lady) was funny, and if what was funnier than the rest was the contrast between her (lady) beautiful benevolent patronage--such a hint of the polysyllabic as might make her (lady) something of a bore toward middle age--and her (lady) rather flat little voice, the voice, naturally, unaffectedly yet, of a girl of fifteen; so Strether, none the less, at the end of ten minutes, felt in her (girl) a quiet dignity that pulled things bravely together. If quiet dignity, almost more than matronly, with voluminous, too voluminous clothes, was the effect she (girl) proposed to produce, that was an ideal one could like in her (girl) when once one had got into relation. The great thing now for her (girl) visitor was that this was exactly what he (visitor) had done; it made so extraordinary a mixture of the brief and crowded hour. It was the mark of a relation that he (visitor) had begun so quickly to find himself sure she (girl) was, of all people, as might have been said, on the side and of the party of Mrs. Newsome's original ambassador. She (Newsome) was in HIS (ambassador) interest and not in Sarah's, and some sign of that was precisely what he (ambassador) had been feeling in her (Sarah), these last days, as imminent. Finally placed, in Paris, in immediate presence of the situation and of the hero of it--by whom Strether was incapable of meaning any one but Chad--she (Sarah) had accomplished, and really in a manner all unexpected to herself, a change of base; deep still things had come to pass within her (Sarah), and by the time she (Sarah) had grown sure of them Strether had become aware of the little drama. When she (Sarah) knew where she (Sarah) was, in short, he (Strether) had made it out; and he (Strether) made it out at present still better; though with never a direct word passing between them all the while on the subject of his (Strether) own predicament. There had been at first, as he (Strether) sat there with her (Sarah), a moment during which he (Strether) wondered if she (Sarah) meant to break ground in respect to his (Strether) prime undertaking. That door stood so strangely ajar that he (Strether) was half-prepared to be conscious, at any juncture, of her (Sarah) having, of any one's having, quite bounced in. But, friendly, familiar, light of touch and happy of tact, she (Sarah) exquisitely stayed out; so that it was for all the world as if to show she (Sarah) could deal with him (Strether) without being reduced to--well, scarcely anything.

It fully came up for them then, by means of their talking of everything BUT Chad, that Mamie, unlike Sarah, unlike Jim, knew perfectly what had become of him (Jim). It fully came up that she (Sarah) had taken to the last fraction of an inch the measure of the change in him (Jim), and that she (Sarah) wanted Strether to know what a secret she (Sarah) proposed to make of it. They talked most conveniently--as if they had had no chance yet--about Woollett; and that had virtually the effect of their keeping the secret more close. The hour took on for Strether, little by little, a queer sad sweetness of quality, he (Strether) had such a revulsion in Mamie's favour and on behalf of her (Mamie) social value as might have come from remorse at some early injustice. She (Mamie) made him (Strether), as under the breath of some vague western whiff, homesick and freshly restless; he (Strether) could really for the time have fancied himself stranded with her (Mamie) on a far shore, during an ominous calm, in a quaint community of shipwreck. Their little interview was like a picnic on a coral strand; they passed each other, with melancholy smiles and looks sufficiently allusive, such cupfuls of water as they had saved. Especially sharp in Strether meanwhile was the conviction that his (Strether) companion really knew, as we have hinted, where she (Mamie) had come out. It was at a very particular place--only THAT she (Mamie) would never tell him (Strether); it would be above all what he (Strether) should have to puzzle for himself. This was what he (Strether) hoped for, because his (Strether) interest in the girl wouldn't be complete without it. No more would the appreciation to which she (girl) was entitled--so assured was he (Strether) that the more he (Strether) saw of her (girl) process the more he (Strether) should see of her (girl) pride. She (girl) saw, herself, everything; but she (girl) knew what she (girl) didn't want, and that it was that had helped her (girl). What didn't she (girl) want?--there was a pleasure lost for her (girl) old friend in not yet knowing, as there would doubtless be a thrill in getting a glimpse. Gently and sociably she (girl) kept that dark to him (friend), and it was as if she (girl) soothed and beguiled him (friend) in other ways to make up for it. She (girl) came out with her (girl) impression of Madame de Vionnet--of whom she (girl) had

``heard so much'' (she)
; she (girl) came out with her (girl) impression of Jeanne, whom she (girl) had been
``dying to see'' (she)
: she (girl) brought it out with a blandness by which her (girl) auditor was really stirred that she (girl) had been with Sarah early that very afternoon, and after dreadful delays caused by all sorts of things, mainly, eternally, by the purchase of clothes--clothes that unfortunately wouldn't be themselves eternal--to call in the Rue de Bellechasse.

At the sound of these names Strether almost blushed to feel that he (Strether) couldn't have sounded them first--and yet couldn't either have justified his (Strether) squeamishness. Mamie made them easy as he (Strether) couldn't have begun to do, and yet it could only have cost her (Mamie) more than he (Strether) should ever have had to spend. It was as friends of Chad's, friends special, distinguished, desirable, enviable, that she (Mamie) spoke of them, and she (Mamie) beautifully carried it off that much as she (Mamie) had heard of them--though she (Mamie) didn't say how or where, which was a touch of her (Mamie) own--she (Mamie) had found them beyond her (Mamie) supposition. She (Mamie) abounded in praise of them, and after the manner of Woollett--which made the manner of Woollett a loveable thing again to Strether. He (Strether) had never so felt the true inwardness of it as when his (Strether) blooming companion pronounced the elder of the ladies of the Rue de Bellechasse too fascinating for words and declared of the younger that she (Mamie) was perfectly ideal, a real little monster of charm.

``Nothing,'' (she)
she (Mamie) said of Jeanne,
``ought ever to happen to her (Mamie)--she (Mamie)'s so awfully right as she (Mamie) is. Another touch will spoil her (Mamie)--so she (Mamie) oughtn't to BE touched.'' (Jeanne/Jeanne de Vionnet)

``Ah but things, here in Paris,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether observed,
``do happen to little girls.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
And then for the joke's and the occasion's sake:
``Haven't you found that yourself?'' (unknown)

``That things happen--? Oh I'm not a little girl. I'm a big battered blowsy one. I don't care,'' (Mamie/Mamie Pocock)
Mamie laughed,
``WHAT happens.'' (Mamie/Mamie Pocock)

Strether had a pause while he (Strether) wondered if it mightn't happen that he (Strether) should give her (Mamie) the pleasure of learning that he (Strether) found her (Mamie) nicer than he (Strether) had really dreamed--a pause that ended when he (Strether) had said to himself that, so far as it at all mattered for her (Mamie), she (Mamie) had in fact perhaps already made this out. He (Strether) risked accordingly a different question--though conscious, as soon as he (Strether) had spoken, that he (Strether) seemed to place it in relation to her (Mamie) last speech.

``But that Mademoiselle de Vionnet is to be married--I suppose you've heard of THAT.'' (he)
For all, he (Strether) then found, he (Strether) need fear!
``Dear, yes; the gentleman was there: Monsieur de Montbron, whom Madame de Vionnet presented to us.'' (unknown)

``And was he (Vionnet) nice?'' (Mamie/Mamie Pocock)

Mamie bloomed and bridled with her (Mamie) best reception manner.

``Any man's nice when he (Vionnet)'s in love.'' (Strether)

It made Strether laugh.

``But is Monsieur de Montbron in love--already--with YOU?'' (unknown)

``Oh that's not necessary--it's so much better he (Montbron) should be so with HER: which, thank goodness, I lost no time in discovering for myself. He (Montbron)'s perfectly gone--and I couldn't have borne it for her (myself) if he (Montbron) hadn't been. She (myself)'s just too sweet.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether hesitated.

``And through being in love too?'' (him)

On which with a smile that struck him (Strether) as wonderful Mamie had a wonderful answer.

``She (myself) doesn't know if she (myself) is or not.'' (him)

It made him (Strether) again laugh out.

``Oh but YOU do!'' (She)

She (Mamie) was willing to take it that way.

``Oh yes, I know everything.'' (she)
And as she (Mamie) sat there rubbing her (Mamie) polished hands and making the best of it--only holding her (Mamie) elbows perhaps a little too much out--the momentary effect for Strether was that every one else, in all their affair, seemed stupid.

``Know that poor little Jeanne doesn't know what's the matter with her (Jeanne)?'' (she)

It was as near as they came to saying that she (Mamie) was probably in love with Chad; but it was quite near enough for what Strether wanted; which was to be confirmed in his (Strether) certitude that, whether in love or not, she (Mamie) appealed to something large and easy in the girl before him (Strether). Mamie would be fat, too fat, at thirty; but she (Mamie) would always be the person who, at the present sharp hour, had been disinterestedly tender.

``If I see a little more of her (Jeanne), as I hope I shall, I think she (Jeanne)'ll like me enough--for she (Jeanne) seemed to like me to-day--to want me to tell her (Jeanne).'' (unknown)

``And SHALL you?'' (unknown)

``Perfectly. I shall tell her (Jeanne) the matter with her (Jeanne) is that she (Jeanne) wants only too much to do right. To do right for her (Jeanne), naturally,'' (Mamie/Mamie Pocock)
said Mamie,
``is to please.'' (Mamie/Mamie Pocock)

``Her (Jeanne) mother, do you mean?'' (unknown)

``Her (Jeanne) mother first.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether waited.

``And then?'' (unknown)

``Well, `then'--Mr. Newsome.'' (him)

There was something really grand for him (Strether) in the serenity of this reference.

``And last only Monsieur de Montbron?'' (unknown)

``Last only'' (she)
--she (Mamie) good-humouredly kept it up.

Strether considered.

``So that every one after all then will be suited?'' (She)

She (Mamie) had one of her (Mamie) few hesitations, but it was a question only of a moment; and it was her (Mamie) nearest approach to being explicit with him (Strether) about what was between them.

``I think I can speak for myself. I shall be.'' (him)

It said indeed so much, told such a story of her (Mamie) being ready to help him (Strether), so committed to him (Strether) that truth, in short, for such use as he (Strether) might make of it toward those ends of his (Strether) own with which, patiently and trustfully, she (Mamie) had nothing to do--it so fully achieved all this that he (Strether) appeared to himself simply to meet it in its own spirit by the last frankness of admiration. Admiration was of itself almost accusatory, but nothing less would serve to show her (Mamie) how nearly he (Strether) understood. He (Strether) put out his (Strether) hand for good-bye with a

``Splendid, splendid, splendid!'' (He)
And he (Strether) left her (Mamie), in her (Mamie) splendour, still waiting for little Bilham.

Book Tenth

I

Strether occupied beside little Bilham, three evenings after his (Bilham) interview with Mamie Pocock, the same deep divan they had enjoyed together on the first occasion of our friend's meeting Madame de Vionnet and her (Pocock) daughter in the apartment of the Boulevard Malesherbes, where his (Vionnet) position affirmed itself again as ministering to an easy exchange of impressions. The present evening had a different stamp; if the company was much more numerous, so, inevitably, were the ideas set in motion. It was on the other hand, however, now strongly marked that the talkers moved, in respect to such matters, round an inner, a protected circle. They knew at any rate what really concerned them to-night, and Strether had begun by keeping his (Strether) companion close to it. Only a few of Chad's guests had dined--that is fifteen or twenty, a few compared with the large concourse offered to sight by eleven o'clock; but number and mass, quantity and quality, light, fragrance, sound, the overflow of hospitality meeting the high tide of response, had all from the first pressed upon Strether's consciousness, and he (Strether) felt himself somehow part and parcel of the most festive scene, as the term was, in which he (Strether) had ever in his (Strether) life been engaged. He (Strether) had perhaps seen, on Fourths of July and on dear old domestic Commencements, more people assembled, but he (Strether) had never seen so many in proportion to the space, or had at all events never known so great a promiscuity to show so markedly as picked. Numerous as was the company, it had still been made so by selection, and what was above all rare for Strether was that, by no fault of his (Strether) own, he (Strether) was in the secret of the principle that had worked. He (Strether) hadn't enquired, he (Strether) had averted his (Strether) head, but Chad had put him (Chad) a pair of questions that themselves smoothed the ground. He (Chad) hadn't answered the questions, he (Chad) had replied that they were the young man's own affair; and he (Chad) had then seen perfectly that the latter's direction was already settled.

Chad had applied for counsel only by way of intimating that he (Chad) knew what to do; and he (Chad) had clearly never known it better than in now presenting to his (Chad) sister the whole circle of his (Chad) society. This was all in the sense and the spirit of the note struck by him (Chad) on that lady's arrival; he (Chad) had taken at the station itself a line that led him (Chad) without a break, and that enabled him (Chad) to lead the Pococks--though dazed a little, no doubt, breathless, no doubt, and bewildered--to the uttermost end of the passage accepted by them perforce as pleasant. He (Chad) had made it for them violently pleasant and mercilessly full; the upshot of which was, to Strether's vision, that they had come all the way without discovering it to be really no passage at all. It was a brave blind alley, where to pass was impossible and where, unless they stuck fast, they would have--which was always awkward--publicly to back out. They were touching bottom assuredly tonight; the whole scene represented the terminus of the cul-de-sac. So could things go when there was a hand to keep them consistent--a hand that pulled the wire with a skill at which the elder man more and more marvelled. The elder man felt responsible, but he (man) also felt successful, since what had taken place was simply the issue of his (man) own contention, six weeks before, that they properly should wait to see what their friends would have really to say. He (man) had determined Chad to wait, he (Chad) had determined him (Chad) to see; he (Chad) was therefore not to quarrel with the time given up to the business. As much as ever, accordingly, now that a fortnight had elapsed, the situation created for Sarah, and against which she (Sarah) had raised no protest, was that of her (Sarah) having accommodated herself to her (Sarah) adventure as to a pleasure-party surrendered perhaps even somewhat in excess to bustle and to

``pace.'' (she)
If her (Sarah) brother had been at any point the least bit open to criticism it might have been on the ground of his (brother) spicing the draught too highly and pouring the cup too full. Frankly treating the whole occasion of the presence of his (brother) relatives as an opportunity for amusement, he (brother) left it, no doubt, but scant margin as an opportunity for anything else. He (brother) suggested, invented, abounded--yet all the while with the loosest easiest rein. Strether, during his (Strether) own weeks, had gained a sense of knowing Paris; but he (Strether) saw it afresh, and with fresh emotion, in the form of the knowledge offered to his (Strether) colleague.

A thousand unuttered thoughts hummed for him (Strether) in the air of these observations; not the least frequent of which was that Sarah might well of a truth not quite know whither she (Sarah) was drifting. She (Sarah) was in no position not to appear to expect that Chad should treat her (Sarah) handsomely; yet she (Sarah) struck our friend as privately stiffening a little each time she (Sarah) missed the chance of marking the great nuance. The great nuance was in brief that of course her (Sarah) brother must treat her (Sarah) handsomely--she (Sarah) should like to see him (brother) not; but that treating her (Sarah) handsomely, none the less, wasn't all in all--treating her (Sarah) handsomely buttered no parsnips; and that in fine there were moments when she (Sarah) felt the fixed eyes of their admirable absent mother fairly screw into the flat of her (Sarah) back. Strether, watching, after his (Strether) habit, and overscoring with thought, positively had moments of his (Strether) own in which he (Strether) found himself sorry for her (Sarah)--occasions on which she (Sarah) affected him (Strether) as a person seated in a runaway vehicle and turning over the question of a possible jump. WOULD she (Sarah) jump, could she (Sarah), would THAT be a safe placed--this question, at such instants, sat for him (Strether) in her (Sarah) lapse into pallor, her (Sarah) tight lips, her (Sarah) conscious eyes. It came back to the main point at issue: would she (Sarah) be, after all, to be squared? He (Strether) believed on the whole she (Sarah) would jump; yet his (Strether) alternations on this subject were the more especial stuff of his (Strether) suspense. One thing remained well before him (Strether)--a conviction that was in fact to gain sharpness from the impressions of this evening: that if she (Sarah) SHOULD gather in her (Sarah) skirts, close her (Sarah) eyes and quit the carriage while in motion, he (Strether) would promptly enough become aware. She (Sarah) would alight from her (Sarah) headlong course more or less directly upon him (Strether); it would be appointed to him (Strether), unquestionably, to receive her (Sarah) entire weight. Signs and portents of the experience thus in reserve for him (Strether) had as it happened, multiplied even through the dazzle of Chad's party. It was partly under the nervous consciousness of such a prospect that, leaving almost every one in the two other rooms, leaving those of the guests already known to him (Chad) as well as a mass of brilliant strangers of both sexes and of several varieties of speech, he (Chad) had desired five quiet minutes with little Bilham, whom he (Bilham) always found soothing and even a little inspiring, and to whom he (Bilham) had actually moreover something distinct and important to say.

He (Bilham) had felt of old--for it already seemed long ago--rather humiliated at discovering he (Bilham) could learn in talk with a personage so much his (Bilham) junior the lesson of a certain moral ease; but he (Bilham) had now got used to that--whether or no the mixture of the fact with other humiliations had made it indistinct, whether or no directly from little Bilham's example, the example of his (Bilham) being contentedly just the obscure and acute little Bilham he (Bilham) was. It worked so for him (Bilham), Strether seemed to see; and our friend had at private hours a wan smile over the fact that he (Strether) himself, after so many more years, was still in search of something that would work. However, as we have said, it worked just now for them equally to have found a corner a little apart. What particularly kept it apart was the circumstance that the music in the salon was admirable, with two or three such singers as it was a privilege to hear in private. Their presence gave a distinction to Chad's entertainment, and the interest of calculating their effect on Sarah was actually so sharp as to be almost painful. Unmistakeably, in her (Sarah) single person, the motive of the composition and dressed in a splendour of crimson which affected Strether as the sound of a fall through a skylight, she (Sarah) would now be in the forefront of the listening circle and committed by it up to her (Sarah) eyes. Those eyes during the wonderful dinner itself he (Strether) hadn't once met; having confessedly--perhaps a little pusillanimously--arranged with Chad that he (Chad) should be on the same side of the table. But there was no use in having arrived now with little Bilham at an unprecedented point of intimacy unless he (Bilham) could pitch everything into the pot.

``You who sat where you could see her (Jeanne), what does she (Jeanne) make of it all? By which I mean on what terms does she (Jeanne) take it?'' (unknown)

``Oh she (Jeanne) takes it, I judge, as proving that the claim of his (Montbron) family is more than ever justified.'' (unknown)

``She (Jeanne) isn't then pleased with what he (Montbron) has to show?'' (unknown)

``On the contrary; she (Jeanne)'s pleased with it as with his (Montbron) capacity to do this kind of thing--more than she (Jeanne) has been pleased with anything for a long time. But she (Jeanne) wants him (Montbron) to show it THERE. He (Montbron) has no right to waste it on the likes of us.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether wondered.

``She (Jeanne) wants him (Montbron) to move the whole thing over?'' (unknown)

``The whole thing--with an important exception. Everything he (Montbron) has `picked up'--and the way he (Montbron) knows how. She (Jeanne) sees no difficulty in that. She (Jeanne)'d run the show herself, and she (Jeanne)'ll make the handsome concession that Woollett would be on the whole in some ways the better for it. Not that it wouldn't be also in some ways the better for Woollett. The people there are just as good.'' (unknown)

``Just as good as you and these others? Ah that may be. But such an occasion as this, whether or no,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether said,
``isn't the people. It's what has made the people possible.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

``Well then,'' (friend)
his (Strether) friend replied,
``there you are; I give you my impression for what it's worth. Mrs. Pocock has SEEN, and that's to-night how she (Pocock) sits there. If you were to have a glimpse of her (Pocock) face you'd understand me. She (Pocock) has made up her (Pocock) mind--to the sound of expensive music.'' (friend)

Strether took it freely in.

``Ah then I shall have news of her (Pocock).'' (unknown)

``I don't want to frighten you, but I think that likely. However,'' (Bilham/Mr. Bilham)
little Bilham continued,
``if I'm of the least use to you to hold on by--!'' (Bilham/Mr. Bilham)

``You're not of the least!'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
--and Strether laid an appreciative hand on him (Strether) to say it.
``No one's of the least.'' (he)
With which, to mark how gaily he (Strether) could take it, he (Strether) patted his (Strether) companion's knee.
``I must meet my fate alone, and I SHALL--oh you'll see! And yet,'' (he)
he (Strether) pursued the next moment,
``you CAN help me too. You once said to me'' (he)
--he (Strether) followed this further--
``that you held Chad should marry. I didn't see then so well as I know now that you meant he (Chad) should marry Miss Pocock. Do you still consider that he (Chad) should? Because if you do'' (he)
--he (Strether) kept it up--
``I want you immediately to change your mind. You can help me that way.'' (he)

``Help you by thinking he (Chad) should NOT marry?'' (unknown)

``Not marry at all events Mamie.'' (unknown)

``And who then?'' (unknown)

``Ah,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether returned,
``that I'm not obliged to say. But Madame de Vionnet--I suggest--when he (Chad) can.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

``Oh!'' (Bilham/Mr. Bilham)
said little Bilham with some sharpness.

``Oh precisely! But he (Chad) needn't marry at all--I'm at any rate not obliged to provide for it. Whereas in your case I rather feel that I AM.'' (Bilham/Mr. Bilham)

Little Bilham was amused.

``Obliged to provide for my marrying?'' (unknown)

``Yes--after all I've done to you!'' (The man)

The young man weighed it.

``Have you done as much as that?'' (unknown)

``Well,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
said Strether, thus challenged,
``of course I must remember what you've also done to ME. We may perhaps call it square. But all the same,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
he (Strether) went on,
``I wish awfully you'd marry Mamie Pocock yourself.'' (he)

Little Bilham laughed out.

``Why it was only the other night, in this very place, that you were proposing to me a different union altogether.'' (unknown)

``Mademoiselle de Vionnet?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Well, Strether easily confessed it.
``That, I admit, was a vain image. THIS is practical politics. I want to do something good for both of you--I wish you each so well; and you can see in a moment the trouble it will save me to polish you off by the same stroke. She (Pocock) likes you, you know. You console her (Pocock). And she (Pocock)'s splendid.'' (Bilham/Mr. Bilham)

Little Bilham stared as a delicate appetite stares at an overheaped plate.

``What do I console her (Pocock) for?'' (friend)

It just made his (Strether) friend impatient.

``Oh come, you knows'' (unknown)

``And what proves for you that she (Pocock) likes me?'' (unknown)

``Why the fact that I found her (Pocock) three days ago stopping at home alone all the golden afternoon on the mere chance that you'd come to her (Pocock), and hanging over her (Pocock) balcony on that of seeing your cab drive up. I don't know what you want more.'' (Bilham/Mr. Bilham)

Little Bilham after a moment found it.

``Only just to know what proves to you that I like HER.'' (unknown)

``Oh if what I've just mentioned isn't enough to make you do it, you're a stony-hearted little fiend. Besides'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
--Strether encouraged his (Strether) fancy's flight--
``you showed your inclination in the way you kept her (Pocock) waiting, kept her (Pocock) on purpose to see if she (Pocock) cared enough for you.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

His (Strether) companion paid his (Strether) ingenuity the deference of a pause.

``I didn't keep her (Pocock) waiting. I came at the hour. I wouldn't have kept her (Pocock) waiting for the world,'' (the man)
the young man honourably declared.

``Better still--then there you are!'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
And Strether, charmed, held him (Strether) the faster.
``Even if you didn't do her (Pocock) justice, moreover,'' (he)
he (Strether) continued,
``I should insist on your immediately coming round to it. I want awfully to have worked it. I want'' (he)
--and our friend spoke now with a yearning that was really earnest--
``at least to have done THAT.'' (friend)

``To have married me off--without a penny?'' (unknown)

``Well, I shan't live long; and I give you my word, now and here, that I'll leave you every penny of my own. I haven't many, unfortunately, but you shall have them all. And Miss Pocock, I think, has a few. I want,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether went on,
``to have been at least to that extent constructive even expiatory. I've been sacrificing so to strange gods that I feel I want to put on record, somehow, my fidelity--fundamentally unchanged after all--to our own. I feel as if my hands were embrued with the blood of monstrous alien altars--of another faith altogether. There it is--it's done.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
And then he (Strether) further explained.
``It took hold of me because the idea of getting her (Pocock) quite out of the way for Chad helps to clear my ground.'' (The man)

The young man, at this, bounced about, and it brought them face to face in admitted amusement.

``You want me to marry as a convenience to Chad?'' (unknown)

``No,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether debated--
``HE (Chad) doesn't care whether you marry or not. It's as a convenience simply to my own plan FOR him (Chad).'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

''`Simply'!'' (Bilham/Mr. Bilham)
--and little Bilham's concurrence was in itself a lively comment.
``Thank you. But I thought,'' (he)
he (Bilham) continued,
``you had exactly NO plan `for' him (Chad).'' (he)

``Well then call it my plan for myself--which may be well, as you say, to have none. His (Chad) situation, don't you see? is reduced now to the bare facts one has to recognise. Mamie doesn't want him (Chad), and he (Chad) doesn't want Mamie: so much as that these days have made clear. It's a thread we can wind up and tuck in.'' (Bilham/Mr. Bilham)

But little Bilham still questioned.

``YOU can--since you seem so much to want to. But why should I?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Poor Strether thought it over, but was obliged of course to admit that his (Strether) demonstration did superficially fail.

``Seriously, there is no reason. It's my affair--I must do it alone. I've only my fantastic need of making my dose stiff.'' (Bilham/Mr. Bilham)

Little Bilham wondered.

``What do you call your dose?'' (unknown)

``Why what I have to swallow. I want my conditions unmitigated.'' (He)

He (Bilham) had spoken in the tone of talk for talk's sake, and yet with an obscure truth lurking in the loose folds; a circumstance presently not without its effect on his (Bilham) young friend. Little Bilham's eyes rested on him (Bilham) a moment with some intensity; then suddenly, as if everything had cleared up, he (Bilham) gave a happy laugh. It seemed to say that if pretending, or even trying, or still even hoping, to be able to care for Mamie would be of use, he (Bilham) was all there for the job.

``I'll do anything in the world for you!'' (unknown)

``Well,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether smiled,
``anything in the world is all I want. I don't know anything that pleased me in her (my) more,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
he (Strether) went on,
``than the way that, on my finding her (my) up there all alone, coming on her (my) unawares and feeling greatly for her (my) being so out of it, she (my) knocked down my tall house of cards with her (my) instant and cheerful allusion to the next young man. It was somehow so the note I needed--her (my) staying at home to receive him (man).'' (he)

``It was Chad of course,'' (Bilham/Mr. Bilham)
said little Bilham,
``who asked the next young man--I like your name for me!--to call.'' (Bilham/Mr. Bilham)

``So I supposed--all of which, thank God, is in our innocent and natural manners. But do you know,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether asked,
``if Chad knows--?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
And then as this interlocutor seemed at a loss:
``Why where she (my) has come out.'' (this interlocutor)

Little Bilham, at this, met his (Strether) face with a conscious look--it was as if, more than anything yet, the allusion had penetrated.

``Do you know yourself?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether lightly shook his (Strether) head.
