``There I stop. Oh, odd as it may appear to you, there ARE things I don't know. I only got the sense from her (my) of something very sharp, and yet very deep down, that she (my) was keeping all to herself. That is I had begun with the belief that she (my) HAD kept it to herself; but face to face with her (my) there I soon made out that there was a person with whom she (my) would have shared it. I had thought she (my) possibly might with ME--but I saw then that I was only half in her (my) confidence. When, turning to me to greet me--for she (my) was on the balcony and I had come in without her (my) knowing it--she (my) showed me she (my) had been expecting YOU and was proportionately disappointed, I got hold of the tail of my conviction. Half an hour later I was in possession of all the rest of it. You know what has happened.'' (He)
He (Strether) looked at his (Strether) young friend hard--then he (Strether) felt sure.
``For all you say, you're up to your eyes. So there you are.'' (Bilham/Mr. Bilham)

Little Bilham after an instant pulled half round.

``I assure you she (my) hasn't told me anything.'' (unknown)

``Of course she (my) hasn't. For what do you suggest that I suppose her (my) to take you? But you've been with her (my) every day, you've seen her (my) freely, you've liked her (my) greatly--I stick to that--and you've made your profit of it. You know what she (my) has been through as well as you know that she (my) has dined here to-night--which must have put her (my), by the way, through a good deal more.'' (The man)

The young man faced this blast; after which he (man) pulled round the rest of the way.

``I haven't in the least said she (my) hasn't been nice to me. But she (my)'s proud.'' (unknown)

``And quite properly. But not too proud for that.'' (unknown)

``It's just her (my) pride that has made her (my). Chad,'' (Bilham/Mr. Bilham)
little Bilham loyally went on,
``has really been as kind to her (my) as possible. It's awkward for a man when a girl's in love with him (man).'' (Bilham/Mr. Bilham)

``Ah but she (my) isn't--now.'' (Bilham/Mr. Bilham)

Little Bilham sat staring before him (Bilham); then he (Bilham) sprang up as if his (Bilham) friend's penetration, recurrent and insistent, made him (Bilham) really after all too nervous.

``No--she (my) isn't now. It isn't in the least,'' (he)
he (Bilham) went on,
``Chad's fault. He (Chad)'s really all right. I mean he (Chad) would have been willing. But she (my) came over with ideas. Those she (my) had got at home. They had been her (my) motive and support in joining her (my) brother and his (brother) wife. She (my) was to SAVE our friend.'' (he)

``Ah like me, poor thing?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether also got to his (Strether) feet.

``Exactly--she (my) had a bad moment. It was very soon distinct to her (my), to pull her (my) up, to let her (my) down, that, alas, he (brother) was, he (brother) IS, saved. There's nothing left for her (my) to do.'' (unknown)

``Not even to love him (brother)?'' (unknown)

``She (my) would have loved him (brother) better as she (my) originally believed him (brother).'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether wondered

``Of course one asks one's self what notion a little girl forms, where a young man's in question, of such a history and such a state.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

``Well, this little girl saw them, no doubt, as obscure, but she (girl) saw them practically as wrong. The wrong for her (girl) WAS the obscure. Chad turns out at any rate right and good and disconcerting, while what she (girl) was all prepared for, primed and girded and wound up for, was to deal with him (Chad) as the general opposite.'' (unknown)

``Yet wasn't her (girl) whole point'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
--Strether weighed it--
``that he (Chad) was to be, that he (Chad) COULD be, made better, redeemed?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Little Bilham fixed it all a moment, and then with a small headshake that diffused a tenderness:

``She (girl)'s too late. Too late for the miracle.'' (Bilham/Mr. Bilham)

``Yes'' (companion)
--his (Strether) companion saw enough.
``Still, if the worst fault of his (Chad) condition is that it may be all there for her (girl) to profit by--?'' (unknown)

``Oh she (girl) doesn't want to ``profit,'' in that flat way. She (man) doesn't want to profit by another woman's work--she (man) wants the miracle to have been her (man) own miracle. THAT

``S what she (girl)'s too late for.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether quite felt how it all fitted, yet there seemed one loose piece.

``I'm bound to say, you know, that she (girl) strikes one, on these lines, as fastidious--what you call here difficile.'' (Bilham/Mr. Bilham)

Little Bilham tossed up his (Bilham) chin.

``Of course she (girl)'s difficile--on any lines! What else in the world ARE our Mamies--the real, the right ones?'' (unknown)

``I see, I see,'' (friend)
our friend repeated, charmed by the responsive wisdom he (Bilham) had ended by so richly extracting.
``Mamie is one of the real and the right.'' (unknown)

``The very thing itself.'' (unknown)

``And what it comes to then,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether went on,
``is that poor awful Chad is simply too good for her (Mamie).'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

``Ah too good was what he (Chad) was after all to be; but it was she (Mamie) herself, and she (Mamie) herself only, who was to have made him (Chad) so.'' (unknown)

It hung beautifully together, but with still a loose end.

``Wouldn't he (Chad) do for her (Mamie) even if he (Chad) should after all break--'' (unknown)

``With his (Chad) actual influence?'' (Bilham/Mr. Bilham)
Oh little Bilham had for this enquiry the sharpest of all his (Bilham) controls.
``How can he (Chad) `do'--on any terms whatever--when he (Chad)'s flagrantly spoiled?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether could only meet the question with his (Strether) passive, his (Strether) receptive pleasure. ``Well, thank goodness, YOU

``RE not! You remain for her (Mamie) to save, and I come back, on so beautiful and full a demonstration, to my contention of just now--that of your showing distinct signs of her (Mamie) having already begun.'' (he)

The most he (Strether) could further say to himself--as his (Strether) young friend turned away--was that the charge encountered for the moment no renewed denial. Little Bilham, taking his (Strether) course back to the music, only shook his (Strether) good-natured ears an instant, in the manner of a terrier who has got wet; while Strether relapsed into the sense--which had for him (Strether) in these days most of comfort--that he (Strether) was free to believe in anything that from hour to hour kept him (Strether) going. He (Strether) had positively motions and flutters of this conscious hour-to-hour kind, temporary surrenders to irony, to fancy, frequent instinctive snatches at the growing rose of observation, constantly stronger for him (Strether), as he (Strether) felt, in scent and colour, and in which he (Strether) could bury his (Strether) nose even to wantonness. This last resource was offered him (Strether), for that matter, in the very form of his (Strether) next clear perception--the vision of a prompt meeting, in the doorway of the room, between little Bilham and brilliant Miss Barrace, who was entering as Bilham withdrew. She (Bilham) had apparently put him (Bilham) a question, to which he (Bilham) had replied by turning to indicate his (Bilham) late interlocutor; toward whom, after an interrogation further aided by a resort to that optical machinery which seemed, like her (Bilham) other ornaments, curious and archaic, the genial lady, suggesting more than ever for her (lady) fellow guest the old French print, the historic portrait, directed herself with an intention that Strether instantly met. He (Strether) knew in advance the first note she (lady) would sound, and took in as she (lady) approached all her (lady) need of sounding it. Nothing yet had been so

``wonderful'' (she)
between them as the present occasion; and it was her (lady) special sense of this quality in occasions that she (lady) was there, as she (lady) was in most places, to feed. That sense had already been so well fed by the situation about them that she (lady) had quitted the other room, forsaken the music, dropped out of the play, abandoned, in a word, the stage itself, that she (lady) might stand a minute behind the scenes with Strether and so perhaps figure as one of the famous augurs replying, behind the oracle, to the wink of the other. Seated near him (Strether) presently where little Bilham had sat, she (lady) replied in truth to many things; beginning as soon as he (Bilham) had said to her (lady)--what he (Bilham) hoped he (Bilham) said without fatuity--
``All you ladies are extraordinarily kind to me.'' (he)

She (lady) played her (lady) long handle, which shifted her (lady) observation; she (lady) saw in an instant all the absences that left them free. ``How can we be anything else? But isn't that exactly your plight?

``We ladies'--oh we're nice, and you must be having enough of us! As one of us, you know, I don't pretend I'm crazy about us. But Miss Gostrey at least to-night has left you alone, hasn't she (Gostrey)?'' (unknown)
With which she (lady) again looked about as if Maria might still lurk.

``Oh yes,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
said Strether;
``she (Gostrey)'s only sitting up for me at home.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
And then as this elicited from his (Strether) companion her (Maria) gay
``Oh, oh, oh!'' (companion)
he (Strether) explained that he (Strether) meant sitting up in suspense and prayer.
``We thought it on the whole better she (Gostrey) shouldn't be present; and either way of course it's a terrible worry for her (Gostrey).'' (He)
He (Strether) abounded in the sense of his (Strether) appeal to the ladies, and they might take their choice of his (Strether) doing so from humility or from pride.
``Yet she (Gostrey) inclines to believe I shall come out.'' (unknown)

``Oh I incline to believe too you'll come out!'' (unknown)
--Miss Barrace, with her (Maria) laugh, was not to be behind.
``Only the question's about WHERE, isn't it? However,'' (she)
she (Maria) happily continued,
``if it's anywhere at all it must be very far on, mustn't it? To do us justice, I think, you know,'' (she)
she (Maria) laughed,
``we do, among us all, want you rather far on. Yes, yes,'' (she)
she (Maria) repeated in her (Maria) quick droll way;
``we want you very, VERY far on!'' (she)
After which she (Maria) wished to know why he (Strether) had thought it better Maria shouldn't be present.

``Oh,'' (he)
he (Strether) replied,
``it was really her (I) own idea. I should have wished it. But she (I) dreads responsibility.'' (he)

``And isn't that a new thing for her (I)?'' (unknown)

``To dread it? No doubt--no doubt. But her (I) nerve has given way.'' (him)

Miss Barrace looked at him (Strether) a moment.

``She (I) has too much at stake.'' (unknown)
Then less gravely:
``Mine, luckily for me, holds out.'' (unknown)

``Luckily for me too'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
--Strether came back to that.
``My own isn't so firm, MY appetite for responsibility isn't so sharp, as that I haven't felt the very principle of this occasion to be `the more the merrier.'' (Chad)
If we ARE so merry it's because Chad has understood so well.''

``He (me) has understood amazingly,'' (unknown)
said Miss Barrace.

``It's wonderful--Strether anticipated for her (MY).

``It's wonderful!'' (she)
she (Maria), to meet it, intensified; so that, face to face over it, they largely and recklessly laughed. But she (Maria) presently added:
``Oh I see the principle. If one didn't one would be lost. But when once one has got hold of it--'' (she)

``It's as simple as twice two! From the moment he (Strether) had to do something--'' (she)

``A crowd'' (she)
--she (Maria) took him (Chad) straight up--
``was the only thing? Rather, rather: a rumpus of sound,'' (him)
she (Maria) laughed,
``or nothing. Mrs. Pocock's built in, or built out--whichever you call it; she (Pocock)'s packed so tight she (Pocock) can't move. She (Pocock)'s in splendid isolation'' (she)
--Miss Barrace embroidered the theme.

Strether followed, but scrupulous of justice.

``Yet with every one in the place successively introduced to her (Pocock).'' (unknown)

``Wonderfully--but just so that it does build her (Pocock) out. She (Pocock)'s bricked up, she (Pocock)'s buried alive!'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether seemed for a moment to look at it; but it brought him (Strether) to a sigh.

``Oh but she (Pocock)'s not dead! It will take more than this to kill her (Pocock).'' (companion)

His (Strether) companion had a pause that might have been for pity.

``No, I can't pretend I think she (Pocock)'s finished--or that it's for more than to-night.'' (She)
She (Maria) remained pensive as if with the same compunction.
``It's only up to her (Pocock) chin.'' (unknown)
Then again for the fun of it:
``She (Pocock) can breathe.'' (unknown)

``She (Pocock) can breathe!'' (he)
--he (Strether) echoed it in the same spirit.
``And do you know,'' (he)
he (Strether) went on,
``what's really all this time happening to me?--through the beauty of music, the gaiety of voices, the uproar in short of our revel and the felicity of your wit? The sound of Mrs. Pocock's respiration drowns for me, I assure you, every other. It's literally all I hear.'' (he)

She (Maria) focussed him (Strether) with her (Maria) clink of chains.

``Well--!'' (she)
she (Maria) breathed ever so kindly.

``Well, what?'' (unknown)

``She (Pocock) IS free from her (Pocock) chin up,'' (she)
she (Maria) mused;
``and that WILL be enough for her (Pocock).'' (she)

``It will be enough for me!'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether ruefully laughed.
``Waymarsh has really,'' (he)
he (Strether) then asked,
``brought her (Pocock) to see you?'' (he)

``Yes--but that's the worst of it. I could do you no good. And yet I tried hard.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether wondered.

``And how did you try?'' (unknown)

``Why I didn't speak of you.'' (unknown)

``I see. That was better.'' (unknown)

``Then what would have been worse? For speaking or silent,'' (she)
she (Maria) lightly wailed, ``I somehow ``compromise.
'' And it has never been any one but you.'' (she)

``That shows'' (he)
--he (Strether) was magnanimous--
``that it's something not in you, but in one's self. It's MY fault.'' (he)

She (Maria) was silent a little.

``No, it's Mr. Waymarsh's. It's the fault of his (Waymarsh) having brought her (MY).'' (unknown)

``Ah then,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
said Strether good-naturedly,
``why DID he (Waymarsh) bring her (MY)?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

``He (Waymarsh) couldn't afford not to.'' (unknown)

``Oh you were a trophy--one of the spoils of conquest? But why in that case, since you do `compromise'--'' (unknown)

``Don't I compromise HIM as well? I do compromise him (Waymarsh) as well,'' (unknown)
Miss Barrace smiled.
``I compromise him (Waymarsh) as hard as I can. But for Mr. Waymarsh it isn't fatal. It's--so far as his (Waymarsh) wonderful relation with Mrs. Pocock is concerned--favourable.'' (he)
And then, as he (Strether) still seemed slightly at sea:
``The man who had succeeded with ME, don't you see? For her (Pocock) to get him (man) from me was such an added incentive.'' (he)

Strether saw, but as if his (Strether) path was still strewn with surprises.

``It's `from' you then that she (Pocock) has got him (man)?'' (She)

She (Maria) was amused at his (Strether) momentary muddle. ``You can fancy my fight! She (Pocock) believes in her (Pocock) triumph. I think it has been part of her (Pocock) joy.

``Oh her (Pocock) joy!'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether sceptically murmured.

``Well, she (Pocock) thinks she (Pocock) has had her (Pocock) own way. And what's to-night for her (Pocock) but a kind of apotheosis? Her (Pocock) frock's really good.'' (unknown)

``Good enough to go to heaven in? For after a real apotheosis,'' (Strether)
Strether went on,
``there's nothing BUT heaven. For Sarah there's only to-morrow.'' (Strether)

``And you mean that she (Sarah) won't find to-morrow heavenly?'' (unknown)

``Well, I mean that I somehow feel to-night--on her (Sarah) behalf--too good to be true. She (Sarah) has had her (Sarah) cake; that is she (Sarah)'s in the act now of having it, of swallowing the largest and sweetest piece. There won't be another left for her (Sarah). Certainly I haven't one. It can only, at the best, be Chad.'' (He)
He (Strether) continued to make it out as for their common entertainment.
``He (Chad) may have one, as it were, up his (Chad) sleeve; yet it's borne in upon me that if he (Chad) had--'' (she)

``He (Chad) wouldn't'' (she)
--she (Maria) quite understood--
``have taken all THIS trouble? I dare say not, and, if I may be quite free and dreadful, I very much hope he (Chad) won't take any more. Of course I won't pretend now,'' (she)
she (Maria) added,
``not to know what it's a question of.'' (she)

``Oh every one must know now,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
poor Strether thoughtfully admitted;
``and it's strange enough and funny enough that one should feel everybody here at this very moment to be knowing and watching and waiting.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

``Yes--isn't it indeed funny?'' (unknown)
Miss Barrace quite rose to it.
``That's the way we ARE in Paris.'' (She)
She (Maria) was always pleased with a new contribution to that queerness.
``It's wonderful! But, you know,'' (she)
she (Maria) declared,
``it all depends on you. I don't want to turn the knife in your vitals, but that's naturally what you just now meant by our all being on top of you. We know you as the hero of the drama, and we're gathered to see what you'll do.'' (she)

Strether looked at her (Maria) a moment with a light perhaps slightly obscured.

``I think that must be why the hero has taken refuge in this corner. He (hero)'s scared at his (hero) heroism--he (hero) shrinks from his (hero) part.'' (unknown)

``Ah but we nevertheless believe he (hero)'ll play it. That's why,'' (unknown)
Miss Barrace kindly went on,
``we take such an interest in you. We feel you'll come up to the scratch.'' (he)
And then as he (Strether) seemed perhaps not quite to take fire:
``Don't let him (hero) do it.'' (he)

``Don't let Chad go?'' (unknown)

``Yes, keep hold of him (Chad). With all this'' (she)
--and she (Maria) indicated the general tribute--
``he (Chad) has done enough. We love him (Chad) here--he (Chad)'s charming.'' (she)

``It's beautiful,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
said Strether,
``the way you all can simplify when you will.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

But she (Maria) gave it to him (Strether) back.

``It's nothing to the way you will when you must.'' (He)

He (Strether) winced at it as at the very voice of prophecy, and it kept him (Strether) a moment quiet. He (Strether) detained her (Maria), however, on her (Maria) appearing about to leave him (Strether) alone in the rather cold clearance their talk had made.

``There positively isn't a sign of a hero to-night; the hero's dodging and shirking, the hero's ashamed. Therefore, you know, I think, what you must all REALLY be occupied with is the heroine.'' (Miss Barrace)

Miss Barrace took a minute.

``The heroine?'' (unknown)

``The heroine. I've treated her (heroine),'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
said Strether,
``not a bit like a hero. Oh,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
he (Strether) sighed,
``I don't do it well!'' (he)

She (Barrace) eased him (Strether) off.

``You do it as you can.'' (unknown)
And then after another hesitation:
``I think she (heroine)'s satisfied.'' (he)

But he (Strether) remained compunctious.

``I haven't been near her (heroine). I haven't looked at her (heroine).'' (unknown)

``Ah then you've lost a good deal!'' (He)

He (Strether) showed he (Strether) knew it.

``She (heroine)'s more wonderful than ever?'' (unknown)

``Than ever. With Mr. Pocock.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether wondered.

``Madame de Vionnet--with Jim?'' (unknown)

``Madame de Vionnet--with `Jim.''' (unknown)
Miss Barrace was historic.

``And what's she (heroine) doing with him (Jim)?'' (unknown)

``Ah you must ask HIM!'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether's face lighted again at the prospect.

``It WILL be amusing to do so.'' (he)
Yet he (Strether) continued to wonder.
``But she (heroine) must have some idea.'' (unknown)

``Of course she (heroine) has--she (heroine) has twenty ideas. She (heroine) has in the first place,'' (unknown)
said Miss Barrace, swinging a little her (Barrace) tortoise-shell,
``that of doing her (heroine) part. Her (heroine) part is to help YOU.'' (unknown)

It came out as nothing had come yet; links were missing and connexions unnamed, but it was suddenly as if they were at the heart of their subject.

``Yes; how much more she (heroine) does it,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether gravely reflected,
``than I help HER!'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
It all came over him (Strether) as with the near presence of the beauty, the grace, the intense, dissimulated spirit with which he (Strether) had, as he (Strether) said, been putting off contact.
``SHE has courage.'' (unknown)

``Ah she (heroine) has courage!'' (unknown)
Miss Barrace quite agreed; and it was as if for a moment they saw the quantity in each other's face.

But indeed the whole thing was present.

``How much she (heroine) must care!'' (unknown)

``Ah there it is. She (heroine) does care. But it isn't, is it,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Miss Barrace considerately added,
``as if you had ever had any doubt of that?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether seemed suddenly to like to feel that he (Strether) really never had.

``Why of course it's the whole point.'' (unknown)

``Voila!'' (unknown)
Miss Barrace smiled.

``It's why one came out,'' (Strether)
Strether went on.
``And it's why one has stayed so long. And it's also'' (he)
--he (Strether) abounded--
``why one's going home. It's why, it's why--'' (he)

``It's why everything!'' (she)
she (Strether) concurred. ``It's why she (heroine) might be to-night--for all she (heroine) looks and shows, and for all your friend
``Jim' does--about twenty years old. That's another of her (heroine) ideas; to be for him (Jim), and to be quite easily and charmingly, as young as a little girl.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether assisted at his (Strether) distance.

''`For him (Strether)'? For Chad--?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

``For Chad, in a manner, naturally, always. But in particular to-night for Mr. Pocock.'' (friend)
And then as her (Strether) friend still stared:
``Yes, it IS of a bravery But that's what she (girl) has: her (girl) high sense of duty.'' (friend)
It was more than sufficiently before them.
``When Mr. Newsome has his (Newsome) hands so embarrassed with his (Newsome) sister--'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

``It's quite the least'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
--Strether filled it out--
``that she (sister) should take his (Newsome) sister's husband? Certainly--quite the least. So she (sister) has taken him (Newsome).'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

``She (sister) has taken him (Newsome).'' (unknown)
It was all Miss Barrace had meant.

Still it remained enough.

``It must be funny.'' (unknown)

``Oh it IS funny.'' (unknown)
That of course essentially went with it.

But it brought them back.

``How indeed then she (sister) must care!'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
In answer to which Strether's entertainer dropped a comprehensive
``Ah!'' (Strether entertainer)
expressive perhaps of some impatience for the time he (Strether) took to get used to it. She (Strether) herself had got used to it long before.

II

When one morning within the week he (Strether) perceived the whole thing to be really at last upon him (Strether) Strether's immediate feeling was all relief. He (Strether) had known this morning that something was about to happen--known it, in a moment, by Waymarsh's manner when Waymarsh appeared before him (Strether) during his (Strether) brief consumption of coffee and a roll in the small slippery salle-a-manger so associated with rich rumination. Strether had taken there of late various lonely and absent-minded meals; he (Strether) communed there, even at the end of June, with a suspected chill, the air of old shivers mixed with old savours, the air in which so many of his (Strether) impressions had perversely matured; the place meanwhile renewing its message to him (Strether) by the very circumstance of his (Strether) single state. He (Strether) now sat there, for the most part, to sigh softly, while he (Strether) vaguely tilted his (Strether) carafe, over the vision of how much better Waymarsh was occupied. That was really his (Strether) success by the common measure--to have led this companion so on and on. He (Strether) remembered how at first there had been scarce a squatting-place he (Strether) could beguile him (Strether) into passing; the actual outcome of which at last was that there was scarce one that could arrest him (Strether) in his (Strether) rush. His (Strether) rush--as Strether vividly and amusedly figured it--continued to be all with Sarah, and contained perhaps moreover the word of the whole enigma, whipping up in its fine full-flavoured froth the very principle, for good or for ill, of his (Strether) own, of Strether's destiny. It might after all, to the end, only be that they had united to save him (Strether), and indeed, so far as Waymarsh was concerned, that HAD to be the spring of action. Strether was glad at all events, in connexion with the case, that the saving he (Strether) required was not more scant; so constituted a luxury was it in certain lights just to lurk there out of the full glare. He (Strether) had moments of quite seriously wondering whether Waymarsh wouldn't in fact, thanks to old friendship and a conceivable indulgence, make about as good terms for him (Strether) as he (Strether) might make for himself. They wouldn't be the same terms of course; but they might have the advantage that he (Strether) himself probably should be able to make none at all.

He (Strether) was never in the morning very late, but Waymarsh had already been out, and, after a peep into the dim refectory, he (Strether) presented himself with much less than usual of his (Strether) large looseness. He (Strether) had made sure, through the expanse of glass exposed to the court, that they would be alone; and there was now in fact that about him (Strether) that pretty well took up the room. He (Strether) was dressed in the garments of summer; and save that his (Strether) white waistcoat was redundant and bulging these things favoured, they determined, his (Strether) expression. He (Strether) wore a straw hat such as his (Strether) friend hadn't yet seen in Paris, and he (Strether) showed a buttonhole freshly adorned with a magnificent rose. Strether read on the instant his (Strether) story--how, astir for the previous hour, the sprinkled newness of the day, so pleasant at that season in Paris, he (Strether) was fairly panting with the pulse of adventure and had been with Mrs. Pocock, unmistakeably, to the Marche aux Fleurs. Strether really knew in this vision of him (Strether) a joy that was akin to envy; so reversed as he (Strether) stood there did their old positions seem; so comparatively doleful now showed, by the sharp turn of the wheel, the posture of the pilgrim from Woollett. He (pilgrim) wondered, this pilgrim, if he (pilgrim) had originally looked to Waymarsh so brave and well, so remarkably launched, as it was at present the latter's privilege to appear. He (pilgrim) recalled that his (pilgrim) friend had remarked to him (pilgrim) even at Chester that his (pilgrim) aspect belied his (pilgrim) plea of prostration; but there certainly couldn't have been, for an issue, an aspect less concerned than Waymarsh's with the menace of decay. Strether had at any rate never resembled a Southern planter of the great days--which was the image picturesquely suggested by the happy relation between the fuliginous face and the wide panama of his (Strether) visitor. This type, it further amused him (Strether) to guess, had been, on Waymarsh's part, the object of Sarah's care; he (Strether) was convinced that her (Waymarsh) taste had not been a stranger to the conception and purchase of the hat, any more than her (Waymarsh) fine fingers had been guiltless of the bestowal of the rose. It came to him (Strether) in the current of thought, as things so oddly did come, that HE (Strether) had never risen with the lark to attend a brilliant woman to the Marche aux Fleurs; this could be fastened on him (Strether) in connexion neither with Miss Gostrey nor with Madame de Vionnet; the practice of getting up early for adventures could indeed in no manner be fastened on him (Vionnet). It came to him (Vionnet) in fact that just here was his (Vionnet) usual case: he (Vionnet) was for ever missing things through his (Vionnet) general genius for missing them, while others were for ever picking them up through a contrary bent. And it was others who looked abstemious and he (Vionnet) who looked greedy; it was he (Vionnet) somehow who finally paid, and it was others who mainly partook. Yes, he (Vionnet) should go to the scaffold yet for he (Vionnet) wouldn't know quite whom. He (Vionnet) almost, for that matter, felt on the scaffold now and really quite enjoying it. It worked out as BECAUSE he (Vionnet) was anxious there--it worked out as for this reason that Waymarsh was so blooming. It was HIS (Vionnet) trip for health, for a change, that proved the success--which was just what Strether, planning and exerting himself, had desired it should be. That truth already sat full-blown on his (Strether) companion's lips; benevolence breathed from them as with the warmth of active exercise, and also a little as with the bustle of haste.

``Mrs. Pocock, whom I left a quarter of an hour ago at her (Pocock) hotel, has asked me to mention to you that she (Pocock) would like to find you at home here in about another hour. She (Pocock) wants to see you; she (Pocock) has something to say--or considers, I believe, that you may have: so that I asked her (Pocock) myself why she (Pocock) shouldn't come right round. She (Pocock) hasn't BEEN round yet--to see our place; and I took upon myself to say that I was sure you'd be glad to have her (Pocock). The thing's therefore, you see, to keep right here till she (Pocock) comes.'' (Waymarsh/Mrs. Waymarsh)

The announcement was sociably, even though, after Waymarsh's wont, somewhat solemnly made; but Strether quickly felt other things in it than these light features. It was the first approach, from that quarter, to admitted consciousness; it quickened his (Strether) pulse; it simply meant at last that he (Strether) should have but himself to thank if he (Strether) didn't know where he (Strether) was. He (Strether) had finished his (Strether) breakfast; he (Strether) pushed it away and was on his (Strether) feet. There were plenty of elements of surprise, but only one of doubt.

``The thing's for YOU to keep here too?'' (Waymarsh/Mrs. Waymarsh)
Waymarsh had been slightly ambiguous.

He (Strether) wasn't ambiguous, however, after this enquiry; and Strether's understanding had probably never before opened so wide and effective a mouth as it was to open during the next five minutes. It was no part of his (Strether) friend's wish, as appeared, to help to receive Mrs. Pocock; he (Strether) quite understood the spirit in which she (Pocock) was to present herself, but his (Strether) connexion with her (Pocock) visit was limited to his (Strether) having--well, as he (Strether) might say--perhaps a little promoted it. He (Strether) had thought, and had let her (Pocock) know it, that Strether possibly would think she (Pocock) might have been round before. At any rate, as turned out, she (Pocock) had been wanting herself, quite a while, to come.

``I told her (Pocock),'' (Waymarsh/Mrs. Waymarsh)
said Waymarsh,
``that it would have been a bright idea if she (Pocock) had only carried it out before.'' (Waymarsh/Mrs. Waymarsh)

Strether pronounced it so bright as to be almost dazzling.

``But why HASn't she (Pocock) carried it out before? She (Pocock) has seen me every day--she (Pocock) had only to name her (Pocock) hour. I've been waiting and waiting.'' (unknown)

``Well, I told her (Pocock) you had. And she (Pocock) has been waiting too.'' (unknown)
It was, in the oddest way in the world, on the showing of this tone, a genial new pressing coaxing Waymarsh; a Waymarsh conscious with a different consciousness from any he (Strether) had yet betrayed, and actually rendered by it almost insinuating. He (Strether) lacked only time for full persuasion, and Strether was to see in a moment why. Meantime, however, our friend perceived, he (friend) was announcing a step of some magnanimity on Mrs. Pocock's part, so that he (friend) could deprecate a sharp question. It was his (friend) own high purpose in fact to have smoothed sharp questions to rest. He (friend) looked his (friend) old comrade very straight in the eyes, and he (friend) had never conveyed to him (friend) in so mute a manner so much kind confidence and so much good advice. Everything that was between them was again in his (friend) face, but matured and shelved and finally disposed of.
``At any rate,'' (he)
he (friend) added,
``she (Pocock)'s coming now.'' (he)

Considering how many pieces had to fit themselves, it all fell, in Strether's brain, into a close rapid order. He (Strether) saw on the spot what had happened, and what probably would yet; and it was all funny enough. It was perhaps just this freedom of appreciation that wound him (Strether) up to his (Strether) flare of high spirits.

``What is she (Pocock) coming FOR?--to kill me?'' (unknown)

``She (Pocock)'s coming to be very VERY kind to you, and you must let me say that I greatly hope you'll not be less so to herself.'' (Waymarsh/Mrs. Waymarsh)

This was spoken by Waymarsh with much gravity of admonition, and as Strether stood there he (Strether) knew he (Strether) had but to make a movement to take the attitude of a man gracefully receiving a present. The present was that of the opportunity dear old Waymarsh had flattered himself he (Strether) had divined in him (Strether) the slight soreness of not having yet thoroughly enjoyed; so he (Strether) had brought it to him (Strether) thus, as on a little silver breakfast-tray, familiarly though delicately--without oppressive pomp; and he (Strether) was to bend and smile and acknowledge, was to take and use and be grateful. He (Strether) was not--that was the beauty of it--to be asked to deflect too much from his (Strether) dignity. No wonder the old boy bloomed in this bland air of his (Strether) own distillation. Strether felt for a moment as if Sarah were actually walking up and down outside. Wasn't she (Sarah) hanging about the porte-cochere while her (Sarah) friend thus summarily opened a way? Strether would meet her (Sarah) but to take it, and everything would be for the best in the best of possible worlds. He (Strether) had never so much known what any one meant as, in the light of this demonstration, he (Strether) knew what Mrs. Newsome did. It had reached Waymarsh from Sarah, but it had reached Sarah from her (Sarah) mother, and there was no break in the chain by which it reached HIM.

``Has anything particular happened,'' (he)
he (Strether) asked after a minute--
``so suddenly to determine her (Pocock)? Has she (Pocock) heard anything unexpected from home?'' (he)

Waymarsh, on this, it seemed to him (Strether), looked at him (Strether) harder than ever.

''`Unexpected'?'' (him)
He (Strether) had a brief hesitation; then, however, he (Strether) was firm.
``We're leaving Paris.'' (unknown)

``Leaving? That IS sudden.'' (Waymarsh/Mrs. Waymarsh)

Waymarsh showed a different opinion.

``Less so than it may seem. The purpose of Mrs. Pocock's visit is to explain to you in fact that it's NOT.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether didn't at all know if he (Strether) had really an advantage--anything that would practically count as one; but he (Strether) enjoyed for the moment--as for the first time in his (Strether) life--the sense of so carrying it off. He (Strether) wondered--it was amusing--if he (Strether) felt as the impudent feel.

``I shall take great pleasure, I assure you, in any explanation. I shall be delighted to receive Sarah.'' (comrade)

The sombre glow just darkened in his (Strether) comrade's eyes; but he (Strether) was struck with the way it died out again. It was too mixed with another consciousness--it was too smothered, as might be said, in flowers. He (Strether) really for the time regretted it--poor dear old sombre glow! Something straight and simple, something heavy and empty, had been eclipsed in its company; something by which he (Strether) had best known his (Strether) friend. Waymarsh wouldn't BE his (Strether) friend, somehow, without the occasional ornament of the sacred rage, and the right to the sacred rage--inestimably precious for Strether's charity--he (Strether) also seemed in a manner, and at Mrs. Pocock's elbow, to have forfeited. Strether remembered the occasion early in their stay when on that very spot he (Strether) had come out with his (Strether) earnest, his (Strether) ominous

``Quit it!'' (he)
--and, so remembering, felt it hang by a hair that he (Strether) didn't himself now utter the same note. Waymarsh was having a good time--this was the truth that was embarrassing for him (Strether), and he (Strether) was having it then and there, he (Strether) was having it in Europe, he (Strether) was having it under the very protection of circumstances of which he (Strether) didn't in the least approve; all of which placed him (Strether) in a false position, with no issue possible--none at least by the grand manner. It was practically in the manner of any one--it was all but in poor Strether's own--that instead of taking anything up he (Strether) merely made the most of having to be himself explanatory.
``I'm not leaving for the United States direct. Mr. and Mrs. Pocock and Miss Mamie are thinking of a little trip before their own return, and we've been talking for some days past of our joining forces. We've settled it that we do join and that we sail together the end of next month. But we start to-morrow for Switzerland. Mrs. Pocock wants some scenery. She (Pocock) hasn't had much yet.'' (He)

He (Strether) was brave in his (Strether) way too, keeping nothing back, confessing all there was, and only leaving Strether to make certain connexions.

``Is what Mrs. Newsome had cabled her (Newsome) daughter an injunction to break off short?'' (unknown)

The grand manner indeed at this just raised its head a little.

``I know nothing about Mrs. Newsome's cables.'' (proportion)

Their eyes met on it with some intensity--during the few seconds of which something happened quite out of proportion to the time. It happened that Strether, looking thus at his (Strether) friend, didn't take his (Strether) answer for truth--and that something more again occurred in consequence of THAT. Yes--Waymarsh just DID know about Mrs. Newsome's cables: to what other end than that had they dined together at Bignon's? Strether almost felt for the instant that it was to Mrs. Newsome herself the dinner had been given; and, for that matter, quite felt how she (Newsome) must have known about it and, as he (Strether) might think, protected and consecrated it. He (Strether) had a quick blurred view of daily cables, questions, answers, signals: clear enough was his (Strether) vision of the expense that, when so wound up, the lady at home was prepared to incur. Vivid not less was his (Strether) memory of what, during his (Strether) long observation of her (lady), some of her (lady) attainments of that high pitch had cost her (lady). Distinctly she (lady) was at the highest now, and Waymarsh, who imagined himself an independent performer, was really, forcing his (performer) fine old natural voice, an overstrained accompanist. The whole reference of his (performer) errand seemed to mark her (Waymarsh) for Strether as by this time consentingly familiar to him (Strether), and nothing yet had so despoiled her (Waymarsh) of a special shade of consideration.

``You don't know,'' (he)
he (Strether) asked,
``whether Sarah has been directed from home to try me on the matter of my also going to Switzerland?'' (he)

``I know,'' (Waymarsh/Mrs. Waymarsh)
said Waymarsh as manfully as possible,
``nothing whatever about her (Sarah) private affairs; though I believe her (Sarah) to be acting in conformity with things that have my highest respect.'' (Waymarsh/Mrs. Waymarsh)
It was as manful as possible, but it was still the false note--as it had to be to convey so sorry a statement. He (Strether) knew everything, Strether more and more felt, that he (Strether) thus disclaimed, and his (Strether) little punishment was just in this doom to a second fib. What falser position--given the man--could the most vindictive mind impose? He (man) ended by squeezing through a passage in which three months before he (man) would certainly have stuck fast.
``Mrs Pocock will probably be ready herself to answer any enquiry you may put to her (Mrs). But,'' (he)
he (man) continued,
``BUT--!'' (he)
He (man) faltered on it.

``But what? Don't put her (Mrs) too many?'' (Waymarsh/Mrs. Waymarsh)

Waymarsh looked large, but the harm was done; he (man) couldn't, do what he (man) would, help looking rosy.

``Don't do anything you'll be sorry for.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

It was an attenuation, Strether guessed, of something else that had been on his (Strether) lips; it was a sudden drop to directness, and was thereby the voice of sincerity. He (Strether) had fallen to the supplicating note, and that immediately, for our friend, made a difference and reinstated him (friend). They were in communication as they had been, that first morning, in Sarah's salon and in her (Sarah) presence and Madame de Vionnet's; and the same recognition of a great good will was again, after all, possible. Only the amount of response Waymarsh had then taken for granted was doubled, decupled now. This came out when he (Vionnet) presently said:

``Of course I needn't assure you I hope you'll come with us.'' (he)
Then it was that his (Vionnet) implications and expectations loomed up for Strether as almost pathetically gross.

The latter patted his (Strether) shoulder while he (Strether) thanked him (Strether), giving the go-by to the question of joining the Pococks; he (Strether) expressed the joy he (Strether) felt at seeing him (Strether) go forth again so brave and free, and he (Strether) in fact almost took leave of him (Strether) on the spot.

``I shall see you again of course before you go; but I'm meanwhile much obliged to you for arranging so conveniently for what you've told me. I shall walk up and down in the court there--dear little old court which we've each bepaced so, this last couple of months, to the tune of our flights and our drops, our hesitations and our plunges: I shall hang about there, all impatience and excitement, please let Sarah know, till she (Sarah) graciously presents herself. Leave me with her (Sarah) without fear,'' (he)
he (Strether) laughed;
``I assure you I shan't hurt her (Sarah). I don't think either she (Sarah)'ll hurt ME: I'm in a situation in which damage was some time ago discounted. Besides, THAT isn't what worries you--but don't, don't explain! We're all right as we are: which was the degree of success our adventure was pledged to for each of us. We weren't, it seemed, all right as we were before; and we've got over the ground, all things considered, quickly. I hope you'll have a lovely time in the Alps.'' (he)

Waymarsh fairly looked up at him (Strether) as from the foot of them.

``I don't know as I OUGHT really to go.'' (unknown)

It was the conscience of Milrose in the very voice of Milrose, but, oh it was feeble and flat! Strether suddenly felt quite ashamed for him (Strether); he (Strether) breathed a greater boldness.

``LET yourself, on the contrary, go--in all agreeable directions. These are precious hours--at our age they mayn't recur. Don't have it to say to yourself at Milrose, next winter, that you hadn't courage for them.'' (comrade)
And then as his (Strether) comrade queerly stared:
``Live up to Mrs. Pocock.'' (comrade)

``Live up to her (Pocock)?'' (unknown)

``You're a great help to her (Pocock).'' (Waymarsh/Mrs. Waymarsh)

Waymarsh looked at it as at one of the uncomfortable things that were certainly true and that it was yet ironical to say.

``It's more then than you are.'' (unknown)

``That's exactly your own chance and advantage. Besides,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
said Strether,
``I do in my way contribute. I know what I'm about.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Waymarsh had kept on his (Strether) great panama, and, as he (Strether) now stood nearer the door, his (Strether) last look beneath the shade of it had turned again to darkness and warning.

``So do I! See here, Strether.'' (unknown)

``I know what you're going to say.

``Quit this'?'' (unknown)

``Quit this!'' (unknown)
But it lacked its old intensity; nothing of it remained; it went out of the room with him (Strether).

III

Almost the first thing, strangely enough, that, about an hour later, Strether found himself doing in Sarah's presence was to remark articulately on this failure, in their friend, of what had been superficially his (friend) great distinction. It was as if--he (friend) alluded of course to the grand manner--the dear man had sacrificed it to some other advantage; which would be of course only for himself to measure. It might be simply that he (man) was physically so much more sound than on his (man) first coming out; this was all prosaic, comparatively cheerful and vulgar. And fortunately, if one came to that, his (man) improvement in health was really itself grander than any manner it could be conceived as having cost him (man).

``You yourself alone, dear Sarah'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
--Strether took the plunge--
``have done him (you), it strikes me, in these three weeks, as much good as all the rest of his (you) time together.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

It was a plunge because somehow the range of reference was, in the conditions,

``funny,'' (Sarah/Sarah Pocock/Pocock)
and made funnier still by Sarah's attitude, by the turn the occasion had, with her (Sarah) appearance, so sensibly taken. Her (Sarah) appearance was really indeed funnier than anything else--the spirit in which he (Strether) felt her (Sarah) to be there as soon as she (Sarah) was there, the shade of obscurity that cleared up for him (Strether) as soon as he (Strether) was seated with her (Sarah) in the small salon de lecture that had, for the most part, in all the weeks, witnessed the wane of his (Strether) early vivacity of discussion with Waymarsh. It was an immense thing, quite a tremendous thing, for her (Waymarsh) to have come: this truth opened out to him (Strether) in spite of his (Strether) having already arrived for himself at a fairly vivid view of it. He (Strether) had done exactly what he (Strether) had given Waymarsh his (Strether) word for--had walked and re-walked the court while he (Strether) awaited her (Waymarsh) advent; acquiring in this exercise an amount of light that affected him (Strether) at the time as flooding the scene. She (Waymarsh) had decided upon the step in order to give him (Strether) the benefit of a doubt, in order to be able to say to her (Waymarsh) mother that she (Waymarsh) had, even to abjectness, smoothed the way for him (Strether). The doubt had been as to whether he (Strether) mightn't take her (Waymarsh) as not having smoothed it--and the admonition had possibly come from Waymarsh's more detached spirit. Waymarsh had at any rate, certainly, thrown his (Strether) weight into the scale--he (Strether) had pointed to the importance of depriving their friend of a grievance. She (Waymarsh) had done justice to the plea, and it was to set herself right with a high ideal that she (Waymarsh) actually sat there in her (Waymarsh) state. Her (Waymarsh) calculation was sharp in the immobility with which she (Waymarsh) held her (Waymarsh) tall parasol-stick upright and at arm's length, quite as if she (Waymarsh) had struck the place to plant her (Waymarsh) flag; in the separate precautions she (Waymarsh) took not to show as nervous; in the aggressive repose in which she (Waymarsh) did quite nothing but wait for him (Strether). Doubt ceased to be possible from the moment he (Strether) had taken in that she (Waymarsh) had arrived with no proposal whatever; that her (Waymarsh) concern was simply to show what she (Waymarsh) had come to receive. She (Waymarsh) had come to receive his (Strether) submission, and Waymarsh was to have made it plain to him (Strether) that she (Waymarsh) would expect nothing less. He (Strether) saw fifty things, her (Waymarsh) host, at this convenient stage; but one of those he (Strether) most saw was that their anxious friend hadn't quite had the hand required of him (friend). Waymarsh HAD, however, uttered the request that she (Waymarsh) might find him (friend) mild, and while hanging about the court before her (Waymarsh) arrival he (friend) had turned over with zeal the different ways in which he (friend) could be so. The difficulty was that if he (friend) was mild he (friend) wasn't, for her (Waymarsh) purpose, conscious. If she (Waymarsh) wished him (friend) conscious--as everything about her (Waymarsh) cried aloud that she (Waymarsh) did--she (Waymarsh) must accordingly be at costs to make him (friend) so. Conscious he (friend) was, for himself--but only of too many things; so she (Waymarsh) must choose the one she (Waymarsh) required.

Practically, however, it at last got itself named, and when once that had happened they were quite at the centre of their situation. One thing had really done as well as another; when Strether had spoken of Waymarsh's leaving him (Strether), and that had necessarily brought on a reference to Mrs. Pocock's similar intention, the jump was but short to supreme lucidity. Light became indeed after that so intense that Strether would doubtless have but half made out, in the prodigious glare, by which of the two the issue had been in fact precipitated. It was, in their contracted quarters, as much there between them as if it had been something suddenly spilled with a crash and a splash on the floor. The form of his (Strether) submission was to be an engagement to acquit himself within the twenty-four hours.

``He (you)'ll go in a moment if you give him (you) the word--he (you) assures me on his (you) honour he (you)'ll do that'' (Chad)
: this came in its order, out of its order, in respect to Chad, after the crash had occurred. It came repeatedly during the time taken by Strether to feel that he (Strether) was even more fixed in his (Strether) rigour than he (Strether) had supposed--the time he (Strether) was not above adding to a little by telling her (them) that such a way of putting it on her (them) brother's part left him (brother) sufficiently surprised. She (them) wasn't at all funny at last--she (them) was really fine; and he (brother) felt easily where she (them) was strong--strong for herself. It hadn't yet so come home to him (brother) that she (them) was nobly and appointedly officious. She (them) was acting in interests grander and clearer than that of her (them) poor little personal, poor little Parisian equilibrium, and all his (brother) consciousness of her (them) mother's moral pressure profited by this proof of its sustaining force. She (them) would be held up; she (them) would be strengthened; he (brother) needn't in the least be anxious for her (them). What would once more have been distinct to him (brother) had he (brother) tried to make it so was that, as Mrs. Newsome was essentially all moral pressure, the presence of this element was almost identical with her (Newsome) own presence. It wasn't perhaps that he (brother) felt he (brother) was dealing with her (Newsome) straight, but it was certainly as if she (Newsome) had been dealing straight with HIM. She (Newsome) was reaching him (brother) somehow by the lengthened arm of the spirit, and he (brother) was having to that extent to take her (Newsome) into account; but he (brother) wasn't reaching her (Newsome) in turn, not making her (Newsome) take HIM; he (brother) was only reaching Sarah, who appeared to take so little of him (brother).
``Something has clearly passed between you and Chad,'' (he)
he (brother) presently said,
``that I think I ought to know something more about. Does he (Chad) put it all,'' (he)
he (brother) smiled,
``on me?'' (he)

``Did you come out,'' (she)
she (Newsome) asked,
``to put it all on HIM?'' (she)

But he (brother) replied to this no further than, after an instant, by saying:

``Oh it's all right. Chad I mean's all right in having said to you--well anything he (Chad) may have said. I'll TAKE it all--what he (Chad) does put on me. Only I must see him (Chad) before I see you again.'' (he)

She (Newsome) hesitated, but she (Newsome) brought it out.

``Is it absolutely necessary you should see me again?'' (unknown)

``Certainly, if I'm to give you any definite word about anything.'' (unknown)

``Is it your idea then,'' (she)
she (Newsome) returned,
``that I shall keep on meeting you only to be exposed to fresh humiliation?'' (she)

He (brother) fixed her (Newsome) a longer time.

``Are your instructions from Mrs. Newsome that you shall, even at the worst, absolutely and irretrievably break with me?'' (unknown)

``My instructions from Mrs. Newsome are, if you please, my affair. You know perfectly what your own were, and you can judge for yourself of what it can do for you to have made what you have of them. You can perfectly see, at any rate, I'll go so far as to say, that if I wish not to expose myself I must wish still less to expose HER.'' (She)
She (Newsome) had already said more than she (Newsome) had quite expected; but, though she (Newsome) had also pulled up, the colour in her (Newsome) face showed him (brother) he (brother) should from one moment to the other have it all. He (brother) now indeed felt the high importance of his (brother) having it.
``What is your conduct,'' (she)
she (Newsome) broke out as if to explain--
``what is your conduct but an outrage to women like US? I mean your acting as if there can be a doubt--as between us and such another--of his (it) duty?'' (she)

He (brother) thought a moment. It was rather much to deal with at once; not only the question itself, but the sore abysses it revealed.

``Of course they're totally different kinds of duty.'' (unknown)

``And do you pretend that he (it) has any at all--to such another?'' (unknown)

``Do you mean to Madame de Vionnet?'' (He)
He (brother) uttered the name not to affront her (Newsome), but yet again to gain time--time that he (brother) needed for taking in something still other and larger than her (Newsome) demand of a moment before. It wasn't at once that he (brother) could see all that was in her (Newsome) actual challenge; but when he (brother) did he (brother) found himself just checking a low vague sound, a sound which was perhaps the nearest approach his (brother) vocal chords had ever known to a growl. Everything Mrs. Pocock had failed to give a sign of recognising in Chad as a particular part of a transformation--everything that had lent intention to this particular failure--affected him (Chad) as gathered into a large loose bundle and thrown, in her (Pocock) words, into his (Chad) face. The missile made him (Chad) to that extent catch his (Chad) breath; which however he (Chad) presently recovered.
``Why when a woman's at once so charming and so beneficent--'' (unknown)

``You can sacrifice mothers and sisters to her (woman) without a blush and can make them cross the ocean on purpose to feel the more and take from you the straighter, HOW you do it?'' (she)

Yes, she (Pocock) had taken him (Chad) up as short and as sharply as that, but he (Chad) tried not to flounder in her (Pocock) grasp.

``I don't think there's anything I've done in any such calculated way as you describe. Everything has come as a sort of indistinguishable part of everything else. Your coming out belonged closely to my having come before you, and my having come was a result of our general state of mind. Our general state of mind had proceeded, on its side, from our queer ignorance, our queer misconceptions and confusions--from which, since then, an inexorable tide of light seems to have floated us into our perhaps still queerer knowledge. Don't you LIKE your brother as he (brother) is,'' (he)
he (Chad) went on,
``and haven't you given your mother an intelligible account of all that that comes to?'' (he)

It put to her (Pocock) also, doubtless, his (Chad) own tone, too many things, this at least would have been the case hadn't his (Chad) final challenge directly helped her (Pocock). Everything, at the stage they had reached, directly helped her (Pocock), because everything betrayed in him (Chad) such a basis of intention. He (Chad) saw--the odd way things came out!--that he (Chad) would have been held less monstrous had he (Chad) only been a little wilder. What exposed him (Chad) was just his (Chad) poor old trick of quiet inwardness, what exposed him (Chad) was his (Chad) THINKING such offence. He (Chad) hadn't in the least however the desire to irritate that Sarah imputed to him (Chad), and he (Chad) could only at last temporise, for the moment, with her (Sarah) indignant view. She (Sarah) was altogether more inflamed than he (Chad) had expected, and he (Chad) would probably understand this better when he (Chad) should learn what had occurred for her (Sarah) with Chad. Till then her (Sarah) view of his (Chad) particular blackness, her (Sarah) clear surprise at his (Chad) not clutching the pole she (Sarah) held out, must pass as extravagant.

``I leave you to flatter yourself,'' (she)
she (Sarah) returned, ``that what you speak of is what YOU``VE beautifully done. When a thing has been already described in such a lovely way--!'' But she (Sarah) caught herself up, and her (Sarah) comment on his (Chad) description rang out sufficiently loud.
``Do you consider her (mother) even an apology for a decent woman?'' (unknown)

Ah there it was at last! She (Sarah) put the matter more crudely than, for his (Chad) own mixed purposes, he (Chad) had yet had to do; but essentially it was all one matter. It was so much--so much; and she (Sarah) treated it, poor lady, as so little. He (Chad) grew conscious, as he (Chad) was now apt to do, of a strange smile, and the next moment he (Chad) found himself talking like Miss Barrace.

``She (mother) has struck me from the first as wonderful. I've been thinking too moreover that, after all, she (mother) would probably have represented even for yourself something rather new and rather good.'' (He)

He (Chad) was to have given Mrs. Pocock with this, however, but her (Pocock) best opportunity for a sound of derision.

``Rather new? I hope so with all my heart!'' (unknown)

``I mean,'' (he)
he (Chad) explained,
``that she (mother) might have affected you by her (mother) exquisite amiability--a real revelation, it has seemed to myself; her (mother) high rarity, her (mother) distinction of every sort.'' (he)

He (Chad) had been, with these words, consciously a little

``precious'' (He)
; but he (Chad) had had to be--he (Chad) couldn't give her (Pocock) the truth of the case without them; and it seemed to him (Chad) moreover now that he (Chad) didn't care. He (Chad) had at all events not served his (Chad) cause, for she (Pocock) sprang at its exposed side.
``A `revelation'--to ME: I've come to such a woman for a revelation? You talk to me about `distinction'--YOU, you who've had your privilege?--when the most distinguished woman we shall either of us have seen in this world sits there insulted, in her (woman) loneliness, by your incredible comparison!'' (Strether)

Strether forbore, with an effort, from straying; but he (Chad) looked all about him (Chad).

``Does your mother herself make the point that she (woman) sits insulted?'' (Sarah/Sarah Pocock/Pocock)

Sarah's answer came so straight, so

``pat,'' (Sarah/Sarah Pocock/Pocock)
as might have been said, that he (Chad) felt on the instant its origin.
``She (woman) has confided to my judgement and my tenderness the expression of her (woman) personal sense of everything, and the assertion of her (woman) personal dignity.'' (the lady)

They were the very words of the lady of Woollett--he (Chad) would have known them in a thousand; her (lady) parting charge to her (lady) child. Mrs. Pocock accordingly spoke to this extent by book, and the fact immensely moved him (Chad).

``If she (woman) does really feel as you say it's of course very very dreadful. I've given sufficient proof, one would have thought,'' (he)
he (Chad) added,
``of my deep admiration for Mrs. Newsome.'' (he)

``And pray what proof would one have thought you'd CALL sufficient? That of thinking this person here so far superior to her (Newsome)?'' (He)

He (Chad) wondered again; he (Chad) waited.

``Ah dear Sarah, you must LEAVE me this person here!'' (he)

In his (Chad) desire to avoid all vulgar retorts, to show how, even perversely, he (Chad) clung to his (Chad) rag of reason, he (Chad) had softly almost wailed this plea. Yet he (Chad) knew it to be perhaps the most positive declaration he (Chad) had ever made in his (Chad) life, and his (Chad) visitor's reception of it virtually gave it that importance.

``That's exactly what I'm delighted to do. God knows WE don't want her (Sarah)! You take good care not to meet,'' (she)
she (Pocock) observed in a still higher key,
``my question about their life. If you do consider it a thing one can even SPEAK of, I congratulate you on your taste!'' (she)

The life she (Pocock) alluded to was of course Chad's and Madame de Vionnet's, which she (Pocock) thus bracketed together in a way that made him (Vionnet) wince a little; there being nothing for him (Vionnet) but to take home her (Pocock) full intention. It was none the less his (Vionnet) inconsequence that while he (Vionnet) had himself been enjoying for weeks the view of the brilliant woman's specific action, he (Vionnet) just suffered from any characterisation of it by other lips.

``I think tremendously well of her (Sarah), at the same time that I seem to feel her (Sarah) `life' to be really none of my business. It's my business, that is, only so far as Chad's own life is affected by it; and what has happened, don't you see? is that Chad's has been affected so beautifully. The proof of the pudding's in the eating'' (he)
--he (Vionnet) tried, with no great success, to help it out with a touch of pleasantry, while she (woman) let him (Vionnet) go on as if to sink and sink. He (Vionnet) went on however well enough, as well as he (Vionnet) could do without fresh counsel; he (Vionnet) indeed shouldn't stand quite firm, he (Vionnet) felt, till he (Vionnet) should have re-established his (Vionnet) communications with Chad. Still, he (Vionnet) could always speak for the woman he (Vionnet) had so definitely promised to
``save.'' (he)
This wasn't quite for her (woman) the air of salvation; but as that chill fairly deepened what did it become but a reminder that one might at the worst perish WITH her (woman)? And it was simple enough--it was rudimentary: not, not to give her (woman) away.
``I find in her (Sarah) more merits than you would probably have patience with my counting over. And do you know,'' (he)
he (Vionnet) enquired,
``the effect you produce on me by alluding to her (Sarah) in such terms? It's as if you had some motive in not recognising all she (Sarah) has done for your brother, and so shut your eyes to each side of the matter, in order, whichever side comes up, to get rid of the other. I don't, you must allow me to say, see how you can with any pretence to candour get rid of the side nearest you.'' (he)

``Near me--THAT sort of thing?'' (Sarah/Sarah Pocock/Pocock)
And Sarah gave a jerk back of her (Sarah) head that well might have nullified any active proximity.

It kept her (Sarah) friend himself at his (friend) distance, and he (friend) respected for a moment the interval. Then with a last persuasive effort he (friend) bridged it.

``You don't, on your honour, appreciate Chad's fortunate development?'' (unknown)

``Fortunate?'' (she)
she (Sarah) echoed again. And indeed she (Sarah) was prepared.
``I call it hideous.'' (she)

Her (Sarah) departure had been for some minutes marked as imminent, and she (Sarah) was already at the door that stood open to the court, from the threshold of which she (Sarah) delivered herself of this judgement. It rang out so loud as to produce for the time the hush of everything else. Strether quite, as an effect of it, breathed less bravely; he (friend) could acknowledge it, but simply enough.

``Oh if you think THAT--!'' (unknown)

``Then all's at an end? So much the better. I do think that!'' (She)
She (Sarah) passed out as she (Sarah) spoke and took her (Sarah) way straight across the court, beyond which, separated from them by the deep arch of the porte-cochere the low victoria that had conveyed her (Sarah) from her (Sarah) own hotel was drawn up. She (Sarah) made for it with decision, and the manner of her (Sarah) break, the sharp shaft of her (Sarah) rejoinder, had an intensity by which Strether was at first kept in arrest. She (Sarah) had let fly at him (Strether) as from a stretched cord, and it took him (Strether) a minute to recover from the sense of being pierced. It was not the penetration of surprise; it was that, much more, of certainty; his (Strether) case being put for him (Strether) as he (Strether) had as yet only put it to himself. She (Sarah) was away at any rate; she (Sarah) had distanced him (Strether)--with rather a grand spring, an effect of pride and ease, after all; she (Sarah) had got into her (Sarah) carriage before he (Strether) could overtake her (Sarah), and the vehicle was already in motion. He (Strether) stopped halfway; he (Strether) stood there in the court only seeing her (Sarah) go and noting that she (Sarah) gave him (Strether) no other look. The way he (Strether) had put it to himself was that all quite MIGHT be at an end. Each of her (Sarah) movements, in this resolute rupture, reaffirmed, re-enforced that idea. Sarah passed out of sight in the sunny street while, planted there in the centre of the comparatively grey court, he (Strether) continued merely to look before him (Strether). It probably WAS all at an end.

Book Eleventh

-LSB-Note: In the 1909 New York Edition the following two chapters were placed in the reverse of the order appearing below. Since 1950, most scholars have agreed, because of the internal evidence of the two chapters, that an editorial error caused them to be printed in reverse order. This Etext, like other editions of the past four decades, corrects the apparent error.--Richard D. Hathaway, preparer of this electronic text-RSB-

I

He (Strether) went late that evening to the Boulevard Malesherbes, having his (Strether) impression that it would be vain to go early, and having also, more than once in the course of the day, made enquiries of the concierge. Chad hadn't come in and had left no intimation; he (Chad) had affairs, apparently, at this juncture--as it occurred to Strether he (Strether) so well might have--that kept him (Strether) long abroad. Our friend asked once for him (friend) at the hotel in the Rue de Rivoli, but the only contribution offered there was the fact that every one was out. It was with the idea that he (friend) would have to come home to sleep that Strether went up to his (Strether) rooms, from which however he (Strether) was still absent, though, from the balcony, a few moments later, his (Strether) visitor heard eleven o'clock strike. Chad's servant had by this time answered for his (servant) reappearance; he (servant) HAD, the visitor learned, come quickly in to dress for dinner and vanish again. Strether spent an hour in waiting for him (Strether)--an hour full of strange suggestions, persuasions, recognitions; one of those that he (Strether) was to recall, at the end of his (Strether) adventure, as the particular handful that most had counted. The mellowest lamplight and the easiest chair had been placed at his (Strether) disposal by Baptiste, subtlest of servants; the novel half-uncut, the novel lemon-coloured and tender, with the ivory knife athwart it like the dagger in a contadina's hair, had been pushed within the soft circle--a circle which, for some reason, affected Strether as softer still after the same Baptiste had remarked that in the absence of a further need of anything by Monsieur he (Monsieur) would betake himself to bed. The night was hot and heavy and the single lamp sufficient; the great flare of the lighted city, rising high, spending itself afar, played up from the Boulevard and, through the vague vista of the successive rooms, brought objects into view and added to their dignity. Strether found himself in possession as he (Strether) never yet had been; he (Strether) had been there alone, had turned over books and prints, had invoked, in Chad's absence, the spirit of the place, but never at the witching hour and never with a relish quite so like a pang.

He (Chad) spent a long time on the balcony; he (Chad) hung over it as he (Chad) had seen little Bilham hang the day of his (Bilham) first approach, as he (Bilham) had seen Mamie hang over her (Mamie) own the day little Bilham himself might have seen her (Mamie) from below; he (Bilham) passed back into the rooms, the three that occupied the front and that communicated by wide doors; and, while he (Bilham) circulated and rested, tried to recover the impression that they had made on him (Bilham) three months before, to catch again the voice in which they had seemed then to speak to him (Bilham). That voice, he (Bilham) had to note, failed audibly to sound; which he (Bilham) took as the proof of all the change in himself. He (Bilham) had heard, of old, only what he (Bilham) COULD then hear; what he (Bilham) could do now was to think of three months ago as a point in the far past. All voices had grown thicker and meant more things; they crowded on him (Bilham) as he (Bilham) moved about--it was the way they sounded together that wouldn't let him (Bilham) be still. He (Bilham) felt, strangely, as sad as if he (Bilham) had come for some wrong, and yet as excited as if he (Bilham) had come for some freedom. But the freedom was what was most in the place and the hour, it was the freedom that most brought him (Bilham) round again to the youth of his (Bilham) own that he (Bilham) had long ago missed. He (Bilham) could have explained little enough to-day either why he (Bilham) had missed it or why, after years and years, he (Bilham) should care that he (Bilham) had; the main truth of the actual appeal of everything was none the less that everything represented the substance of his (Bilham) loss put it within reach, within touch, made it, to a degree it had never been, an affair of the senses. That was what it became for him (Bilham) at this singular time, the youth he (Bilham) had long ago missed--a queer concrete presence, full of mystery, yet full of reality, which he (Bilham) could handle, taste, smell, the deep breathing of which he (Bilham) could positively hear. It was in the outside air as well as within; it was in the long watch, from the balcony, in the summer night, of the wide late life of Paris, the unceasing soft quick rumble, below, of the little lighted carriages that, in the press, always suggested the gamblers he (Bilham) had seen of old at Monte Carlo pushing up to the tables. This image was before him (Carlo) when he (Carlo) at last became aware that Chad was behind.

``She (you) tells me you put it all on ME'' (he)
--he (Chad) had arrived after this promptly enough at that information; which expressed the case however quite as the young man appeared willing for the moment to leave it. Other things, with this advantage of their virtually having the night before them, came up for them, and had, as well, the odd effect of making the occasion, instead of hurried and feverish, one of the largest, loosest and easiest to which Strether's whole adventure was to have treated him (Strether). He (Strether) had been pursuing Chad from an early hour and had overtaken him (Strether) only now; but now the delay was repaired by their being so exceptionally confronted. They had foregathered enough of course in all the various times; they had again and again, since that first night at the theatre, been face to face over their question; but they had never been so alone together as they were actually alone--their talk hadn't yet been so supremely for themselves. And if many things moreover passed before them, none passed more distinctly for Strether than that striking truth about Chad of which he (Chad) had been so often moved to take note: the truth that everything came happily back with him (Chad) to his (Chad) knowing how to live. It had been seated in his (Chad) pleased smile--a smile that pleased exactly in the right degree--as his (Chad) visitor turned round, on the balcony, to greet his (Chad) advent; his (Chad) visitor in fact felt on the spot that there was nothing their meeting would so much do as bear witness to that facility. He (witness) surrendered himself accordingly to so approved a gift; for what was the meaning of the facility but that others DID surrender themselves? He (witness) didn't want, luckily, to prevent Chad from living; but he (Chad) was quite aware that even if he (Chad) had he (Chad) would himself have thoroughly gone to pieces. It was in truth essentially by bringing down his (Chad) personal life to a function all subsidiary to the young man's own that he (Chad) held together. And the great point, above all, the sign of how completely Chad possessed the knowledge in question, was that one thus became, not only with a proper cheerfulness, but with wild native impulses, the feeder of his (Chad) stream. Their talk had accordingly not lasted three minutes without Strether's feeling basis enough for the excitement in which he (Strether) had waited. This overflow fairly deepened, wastefully abounded, as he (Strether) observed the smallness of anything corresponding to it on the part of his (Strether) friend. That was exactly this friend's happy case; he (Strether)
``put out'' (he)
his (Strether) excitement, or whatever other emotion the matter involved, as he (Strether) put out his (Strether) washing; than which no arrangement could make more for domestic order. It was quite for Strether himself in short to feel a personal analogy with the laundress bringing home the triumphs of the mangle.

When he (Strether) had reported on Sarah's visit, which he (Strether) did very fully, Chad answered his (Chad) question with perfect candour.

``I positively referred her (you) to you--told her (you) she (you) must absolutely see you. This was last night, and it all took place in ten minutes. It was our first free talk--really the first time she (you) had tackled me. She (you) knew I also knew what her (you) line had been with yourself; knew moreover how little you had been doing to make anything difficult for her (you). So I spoke for you frankly--assured her (you) you were all at her (you) service. I assured her (you) I was too,'' (the man)
the young man continued;
``and I pointed out how she (you) could perfectly, at any time, have got at me. Her (you) difficulty has been simply her (you) not finding the moment she (you) fancied.'' (the man)

``Her (you) difficulty,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether returned,
``has been simply that she (you) finds she (you)'s afraid of you. She (you)'s not afraid of ME, Sarah, one little scrap; and it was just because she (Sarah) has seen how I can fidget when I give my mind to it that she (Sarah) has felt her (Sarah) best chance, rightly enough to be in making me as uneasy as possible. I think she (Sarah)'s at bottom as pleased to HAVE you put it on me as you yourself can possibly be to put it.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

``But what in the world, my dear man,'' (Chad)
Chad enquired in objection to this luminosity,
``have I done to make Sally afraid?'' (Chad)

``You've been `wonderful, wonderful,'' (people)
as we say--we poor people who watch the play from the pit; and that's what has, admirably, made her (Sarah). Made her (Sarah) all the more effectually that she (Sarah) could see you didn't set about it on purpose--I mean set about affecting her (Sarah) as with fear.''

Chad cast a pleasant backward glance over his (Chad) possibilities of motive.

``I've only wanted to be kind and friendly, to be decent and attentive--and I still only want to be.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether smiled at his (Strether) comfortable clearness.

``Well, there can certainly be no way for it better than by my taking the onus. It reduces your personal friction and your personal offence to almost nothing.'' (Chad)

Ah but Chad, with his (Chad) completer conception of the friendly, wouldn't quite have this! They had remained on the balcony, where, after their day of great and premature heat, the midnight air was delicious; and they leaned back in turn against the balustrade, all in harmony with the chairs and the flower-pots, the cigarettes and the starlight.

``The onus isn't REALLY yours--after our agreeing so to wait together and judge together. That was all my answer to Sally,'' (Chad/Chad Newsome/Newsome)
Chad pursued--
``that we have been, that we are, just judging together.'' (Chad/Chad Newsome/Newsome)

``I'm not afraid of the burden,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether explained;
``I haven't come in the least that you should take it off me. I've come very much, it seems to me, to double up my fore legs in the manner of the camel when he (yours) gets down on his (yours) knees to make his (yours) back convenient. But I've supposed you all this while to have been doing a lot of special and private judging--about which I haven't troubled you; and I've only wished to have your conclusion first from you. I don't ask more than that; I'm quite ready to take it as it has come.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Chad turned up his (Chad) face to the sky with a slow puff of his (Chad) smoke.

``Well, I've seen.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether waited a little.

``I've left you wholly alone; haven't, I think I may say, since the first hour or two--when I merely preached patience--so much as breathed on you.'' (unknown)

``Oh you've been awfully good!'' (unknown)

``We've both been good then--we've played the game. We've given them the most liberal conditions.'' (unknown)

``Ah,'' (Chad conditions)
said Chad,
``splendid conditions! It was open to them, open to them'' (Chad conditions)
--he (Chad) seemed to make it out, as he (Chad) smoked, with his (Chad) eyes still on the stars. He (Chad) might in quiet sport have been reading their horoscope. Strether wondered meanwhile what had been open to them, and he (Strether) finally let him (Strether) have it.
``It was open to them simply to let me alone; to have made up their minds, on really seeing me for themselves, that I could go on well enough as I was.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
