Strether met his (Strether) eyes with a sense of multiplying thoughts. What was it that made him (Strether) at present, late at night and after journeys, so renewedly, so substantially young? Strether saw in a moment what it was--it was that he (Strether) was younger again than Madame de Vionnet. He (Vionnet) himself said immediately none of the things that he (Vionnet) was thinking; he (Vionnet) said something quite different.

``You HAVE really been to a distance?'' (unknown)

``I've been to England.'' (Chad/Chad Newsome/Newsome)
Chad spoke cheerfully and promptly, but gave no further account of it than to say:
``One must sometimes get off.'' (Chad/Chad Newsome/Newsome)

Strether wanted no more facts--he (Strether) only wanted to justify, as it were, his (Strether) question.

``Of course you do as you're free to do. But I hope, this time, that you didn't go for ME.'' (unknown)

``For very shame at bothering you really too much? My dear man,'' (Chad)
Chad laughed,
``what WOULDn't I do for you?'' (Chad)

Strether's easy answer for this was that it was a disposition he (Chad) had exactly come to profit by.

``Even at the risk of being in your way I've waited on, you know, for a definite reason.'' (Chad/Chad Newsome/Newsome)

Chad took it in.

``Oh yes--for us to make if possible a still better impression.'' (he)
And he (Chad) stood there happily exhaling his (Chad) full general consciousness.
``I'm delighted to gather that you feel we've made it.'' (guest)

There was a pleasant irony in the words, which his (Chad) guest, preoccupied and keeping to the point, didn't take up.

``If I had my sense of wanting the rest of the time--the time of their being still on this side,'' (he)
he (Chad) continued to explain--
``I know now why I wanted it.'' (he)

He (Chad) was as grave, as distinct, as a demonstrator before a blackboard, and Chad continued to face him (Chad) like an intelligent pupil.

``You wanted to have been put through the whole thing.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether again, for a moment, said nothing; he (Strether) turned his (Strether) eyes away, and they lost themselves, through the open window, in the dusky outer air.

``I shall learn from the Bank here where they're now having their letters, and my last word, which I shall write in the morning and which they're expecting as my ultimatum, will so immediately reach them.'' (companion)
The light of his (Strether) plural pronoun was sufficiently reflected in his (Strether) companion's face as he (Strether) again met it; and he (Strether) completed his (Strether) demonstration. He (Strether) pursued indeed as if for himself.
``Of course I've first to justify what I shall do.'' (unknown)

``You're justifying it beautifully!'' (Chad/Chad Newsome/Newsome)
Chad declared.

``It's not a question of advising you not to go,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether said,
``but of absolutely preventing you, if possible, from so much as thinking of it. Let me accordingly appeal to you by all you hold sacred.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Chad showed a surprise.

``What makes you think me capable--?'' (unknown)

``You'd not only be, as I say, a brute; you'd be,'' (companion)
his (Chad) companion went on in the same way,
``a criminal of the deepest dye.'' (companion)

Chad gave a sharper look, as if to gauge a possible suspicion.

``I don't know what should make you think I'm tired of her (it).'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether didn't quite know either, and such impressions, for the imaginative mind, were always too fine, too floating, to produce on the spot their warrant. There was none the less for him (Strether), in the very manner of his (Strether) host's allusion to satiety as a thinkable motive, a slight breath of the ominous.

``I feel how much more she (it) can do for you. She (it) hasn't done it all yet. Stay with her (it) at least till she (it) has.'' (unknown)

``And leave her (it) THEN?'' (Chad/Chad Newsome/Newsome)

Chad had kept smiling, but its effect in Strether was a shade of dryness.

``Don't leave her (it) BEFORE. When you've got all that can be got--I don't say,'' (he)
he (Chad) added a trifle grimly.
``That will be the proper time. But as, for you, from such a woman, there will always be something to be got, my remark's not a wrong to her (woman).'' (Chad/Chad Newsome/Newsome)
Chad let him (Chad) go on, showing every decent deference, showing perhaps also a candid curiosity for this sharper accent.
``I remember you, you know, as you were.'' (unknown)

``An awful ass, wasn't I?'' (he)

The response was as prompt as if he (Chad) had pressed a spring; it had a ready abundance at which he (Chad) even winced; so that he (Chad) took a moment to meet it.

``You certainly then wouldn't have seemed worth all you've let me in for. You've defined yourself better. Your value has quintupled.'' (unknown)

``Well then, wouldn't that be enough--?'' (Chad/Chad Newsome/Newsome)

Chad had risked it jocosely, but Strether remained blank.

``Enough?'' (unknown)

``If one SHOULD wish to live on one's accumulations?'' (friend)
After which, however, as his (Strether) friend appeared cold to the joke, the young man as easily dropped it.
``Of course I really never forget, night or day, what I owe her (woman). I owe her (woman) everything. I give you my word of honour,'' (he)
he (Strether) frankly rang out,
``that I'm not a bit tired of her (woman).'' (he)
Strether at this only gave him (Strether) a stare: the way youth could express itself was again and again a wonder. He (Strether) meant no harm, though he (Strether) might after all be capable of much; yet he (Strether) spoke of being
``tired'' (he)
of her (Strether) almost as he (Strether) might have spoken of being tired of roast mutton for dinner.
``She (woman) has never for a moment yet bored me--never been wanting, as the cleverest women sometimes are, in tact. She (woman) has never talked about her (woman) tact--as even they too sometimes talk; but she (woman) has always had it. She (woman) has never had it more'' (he)
--he (Strether) handsomely made the point--
``than just lately.'' (he)
And he (Strether) scrupulously went further.
``She (woman) has never been anything I could call a burden.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether for a moment said nothing; then he (Strether) spoke gravely, with his (Strether) shade of dryness deepened.

``Oh if you didn't do her (woman) justice--!'' (unknown)

``I SHOULD be a beast, eh?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether devoted no time to saying what he (Strether) would be; THAT, visibly, would take them far. If there was nothing for it but to repeat, however, repetition was no mistake.

``You owe her (woman) everything--very much more than she (woman) can ever owe you. You've in other words duties to her (woman), of the most positive sort; and I don't see what other duties--as the others are presented to you--can be held to go before them.'' (Chad/Chad Newsome/Newsome)

Chad looked at him (Chad) with a smile.

``And you know of course about the others, eh?--since it's you yourself who have done the presenting.'' (unknown)

``Much of it--yes--and to the best of my ability. But not all--from the moment your sister took my place.'' (unknown)

``She (sister) didn't,'' (Chad/Chad Newsome/Newsome)
Chad returned.
``Sally took a place, certainly; but it was never, I saw from the first moment, to be yours. No one--with us--will ever take yours. It wouldn't be possible.'' (unknown)

``Ah of course,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
sighed Strether,
``I knew it. I believe you're right. No one in the world, I imagine, was ever so portentously solemn. There I am,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
he (Strether) added with another sigh, as if weary enough, on occasion, of this truth.
``I was made so.'' (Chad/Chad Newsome/Newsome)

Chad appeared for a little to consider the way he (Chad) was made; he (Chad) might for this purpose have measured him (Chad) up and down. His (Chad) conclusion favoured the fact.

``YOU have never needed any one to make you better. There has never been any one good enough. They couldn't,'' (the man)
the young man declared.

His (Chad) friend hesitated.

``I beg your pardon. They HAVE.'' (Chad/Chad Newsome/Newsome)

Chad showed, not without amusement, his (Chad) doubt.

``Who then?'' (Strether)

Strether--though a little dimly--smiled at him (Chad).

``Women--too.'' (unknown)

''`Two'?'' (Chad/Chad Newsome/Newsome)
--Chad stared and laughed.
``Oh I don't believe, for such work, in any more than one! So you're proving too much. And what IS beastly, at all events,'' (he)
he (Chad) added,
``is losing you.'' (he)

Strether had set himself in motion for departure, but at this he (Strether) paused.

``Are you afraid?'' (unknown)

``Afraid--?'' (unknown)

``Of doing wrong. I mean away from my eye.'' (Chad)
Before Chad could speak, however, he (Chad) had taken himself up.
``I AM, certainly,'' (he)
he (Chad) laughed,
``prodigious.'' (he)

``Yes, you spoil us for all the stupid--!'' (Chad)
This might have been, on Chad's part, in its extreme emphasis, almost too freely extravagant; but it was full, plainly enough, of the intention of comfort, it carried with it a protest against doubt and a promise, positively, of performance. Picking up a hat in the vestibule he (Chad) came out with his (Chad) friend, came downstairs, took his (Chad) arm, affectionately, as to help and guide him (Chad), treating him (Chad) if not exactly as aged and infirm, yet as a noble eccentric who appealed to tenderness, and keeping on with him (Chad), while they walked, to the next corner and the next.
``You needn't tell me, you needn't tell me!'' (he)
--this again as they proceeded, he (Chad) wished to make Strether feel. What he (Strether) needn't tell him (Strether) was now at last, in the geniality of separation, anything at all it concerned him (Strether) to know. He (Strether) knew, up to the hilt--that really came over Chad; he (Chad) understood, felt, recorded his (Chad) vow; and they lingered on it as they had lingered in their walk to Strether's hotel the night of their first meeting. The latter took, at this hour, all he (Strether) could get; he (Strether) had given all he (Strether) had had to give; he (Strether) was as depleted as if he (Strether) had spent his (Strether) last sou. But there was just one thing for which, before they broke off, Chad seemed disposed slightly to bargain. His (Chad) companion needn't, as he (Chad) said, tell him (Chad), but he (Chad) might himself mention that he (Chad) had been getting some news of the art of advertisement. He (Chad) came out quite suddenly with this announcement while Strether wondered if his (Strether) revived interest were what had taken him (Strether), with strange inconsequence, over to London. He (Strether) appeared at all events to have been looking into the question and had encountered a revelation. Advertising scientifically worked presented itself thus as the great new force.
``It really does the thing, you know.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

They were face to face under the street-lamp as they had been the first night, and Strether, no doubt, looked blank.

``Affects, you mean, the sale of the object advertised?'' (unknown)

``Yes--but affects it extraordinarily; really beyond what one had supposed. I mean of course when it's done as one makes out that in our roaring age, it CAN be done. I've been finding out a little, though it doubtless doesn't amount to much more than what you originally, so awfully vividly--and all, very nearly, that first night--put before me. It's an art like another, and infinite like all the arts.'' (He)
He (Strether) went on as if for the joke of it--almost as if his (Strether) friend's face amused him (Strether).
``In the hands, naturally, of a master. The right man must take hold. With the right man to work it c'est un monde.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether had watched him (Strether) quite as if, there on the pavement without a pretext, he (Strether) had begun to dance a fancy step.

``Is what you're thinking of that you yourself, in the case you have in mind, would be the right man?'' (Chad/Chad Newsome/Newsome)

Chad had thrown back his (Chad) light coat and thrust each of his (Chad) thumbs into an armhole of his (Chad) waistcoat; in which position his (Chad) fingers played up and down.

``Why, what is he (man) but what you yourself, as I say, took me for when you first came out?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether felt a little faint, but he (Strether) coerced his (Strether) attention.

``Oh yes, and there's no doubt that, with your natural parts, you'd have much in common with him (man). Advertising is clearly at this time of day the secret of trade. It's quite possible it will be open to you--giving the whole of your mind to it--to make the whole place hum with you. Your mother's appeal is to the whole of your mind, and that's exactly the strength of her (mother) case.'' (Chad/Chad Newsome/Newsome)

Chad's fingers continued to twiddle, but he (Strether) had something of a drop.

``Ah we've been through my mother's case!'' (unknown)

``So I thought. Why then do you speak of the matter?'' (unknown)

``Only because it was part of our original discussion. To wind up where we began, my interest's purely platonic. There at any rate the fact is--the fact of the possible. I mean the money in it.'' (unknown)

``Oh damn the money in it!'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
said Strether. And then as the young man's fixed smile seemed to shine out more strange:
``Shall you give your friend up for the money in it?'' (the man)

Chad preserved his (Chad) handsome grimace as well as the rest of his (Chad) attitude.

``You're not altogether--in your so great `solemnity'--kind. Haven't I been drinking you in--showing you all I feel you're worth to me? What have I done, what am I doing, but cleave to her (my) to the death? The only thing is,'' (he)
he (Chad) good-humouredly explained,
``that one can't but have it before one, in the cleaving--the point where the death comes in. Don't be afraid for THAT. It's pleasant to a fellow's feelings,'' (he)
he (Chad) developed,
``to `size-up' the bribe he (fellow) applies his (fellow) foot to.'' (he)

``Oh then if all you want's a kickable surface the bribe's enormous.'' (unknown)

``Good. Then there it goes!'' (Chad/Chad Newsome/Newsome)
Chad administered his (Chad) kick with fantastic force and sent an imaginary object flying. It was accordingly as if they were once more rid of the question and could come back to what really concerned him (Chad).
``Of course I shall see you tomorrow.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

But Strether scarce heeded the plan proposed for this; he (Strether) had still the impression--not the slighter for the simulated kick--of an irrelevant hornpipe or jig.

``You're restless.'' (unknown)

``Ah,'' (Chad)
returned Chad as they parted,
``you're exciting.'' (Chad)

V

He (Chad) had, however, within two days, another separation to face. He (Chad) had sent Maria Gostrey a word early, by hand, to ask if he (Chad) might come to breakfast; in consequence of which, at noon, she (Gostrey) awaited him (Chad) in the cool shade of her (Gostrey) little Dutch-looking dining-room. This retreat was at the back of the house, with a view of a scrap of old garden that had been saved from modern ravage; and though he (Chad) had on more than one other occasion had his (Chad) legs under its small and peculiarly polished table of hospitality, the place had never before struck him (Chad) as so sacred to pleasant knowledge, to intimate charm, to antique order, to a neatness that was almost august. To sit there was, as he (Chad) had told his (Chad) hostess before, to see life reflected for the time in ideally kept pewter; which was somehow becoming, improving to life, so that one's eyes were held and comforted. Strether's were comforted at all events now--and the more that it was the last time--with the charming effect, on the board bare of a cloth and proud of its perfect surface, of the small old crockery and old silver, matched by the more substantial pieces happily disposed about the room. The specimens of vivid Delf, in particular had the dignity of family portraits; and it was in the midst of them that our friend resignedly expressed himself. He (friend) spoke even with a certain philosophic humour. ``There's nothing more to wait for; I seem to have done a good day's work. I've let them have it all round. I've seen Chad, who has been to London and come back. He (Chad) tells me I'm ``exciting,

'' and I seem indeed pretty well to have upset every one. I've at any rate excited HIM. He (friend)'s distinctly restless.'' (unknown)

``You've excited ME,'' (Miss Gostrey)
Miss Gostrey smiled.
``I'M distinctly restless.'' (unknown)

``Oh you were that when I found you. It seems to me I've rather got you out of it. What's this,'' (he)
he (friend) asked as he (friend) looked about him (friend),
``but a haunt of ancient peace?'' (him)

``I wish with all my heart,'' (she)
she (Gostrey) presently replied,
``I could make you treat it as a haven of rest.'' (she)
On which they fronted each other, across the table, as if things unuttered were in the air.

Strether seemed, in his (Strether) way, when he (Strether) next spoke, to take some of them up.

``It wouldn't give me--that would be the trouble--what it will, no doubt, still give you. I'm not,'' (he)
he (Strether) explained, leaning back in his (Strether) chair, but with his (Strether) eyes on a small ripe round melon--``in real harmony with what surrounds me. You ARE. I take it too hard. You DON``T. It makes--that's what it comes to in the end--a fool of me.'' Then at a tangent,
``What has he (fool) been doing in London?'' (unknown)
he (Strether) demanded.

``Ah one may go to London,'' (Maria/Maria Gostrey)
Maria laughed.
``You know I did.'' (he)

Yes--he (Strether) took the reminder.

``And you brought ME back.'' (He)
He (Strether) brooded there opposite to her (Maria), but without gloom.
``Whom has Chad brought? He (Chad)'s full of ideas. And I wrote to Sarah,'' (he)
he (Strether) added,
``the first thing this morning. So I'm square. I'm ready for them.'' (he)

She (Maria) neglected certain parts of this speech in the interest of others.

``Marie said to me the other day that she (Marie) felt him (Chad) to have the makings of an immense man of business.'' (unknown)

``There it is. He (Chad)'s the son of his (Chad) father!'' (unknown)

``But SUCH a father!'' (unknown)

``Ah just the right one from that point of view! But it isn't his (Chad) father in him (Chad),'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether added,
``that troubles me.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

``What is it then?'' (He)
He (Strether) came back to his (Strether) breakfast; he (Strether) partook presently of the charming melon, which she (Maria) liberally cut for him (Strether); and it was only after this that he (Strether) met her (Maria) question. Then moreover it was but to remark that he (Strether)'d answer her (Maria) presently. She (Maria) waited, she (Maria) watched, she (Maria) served him (Strether) and amused him (Strether), and it was perhaps with this last idea that she (Maria) soon reminded him (Strether) of his (Strether) having never even yet named to her (Maria) the article produced at Woollett.
``Do you remember our talking of it in London--that night at the play?'' (he)
Before he (Strether) could say yes, however, she (Maria) had put it to him (Strether) for other matters. Did he (Strether) remember, did he (Strether) remember--this and that of their first days? He (Strether) remembered everything, bringing up with humour even things of which she (Maria) professed no recollection, things she (Maria) vehemently denied; and falling back above all on the great interest of their early time, the curiosity felt by both of them as to where he (Strether) would
``come out.'' (he)
They had so assumed it was to be in some wonderful place--they had thought of it as so very MUCH out. Well, that was doubtless what it had been--since he (Strether) had come out just there. He (Strether) was out, in truth, as far as it was possible to be, and must now rather bethink himself of getting in again. He (Strether) found on the spot the image of his (Strether) recent history; he (Strether) was like one of the figures of the old clock at Berne. THEY came out, on one side, at their hour, jigged along their little course in the public eye, and went in on the other side. He (Strether) too had jigged his (Strether) little course--him (Strether) too a modest retreat awaited. He (Strether) offered now, should she (Strether) really like to know, to name the great product of Woollett. It would be a great commentary on everything. At this she (Strether) stopped him (Strether) off; she (Strether) not only had no wish to know, but she (Strether) wouldn't know for the world. She (Strether) had done with the products of Woollett--for all the good she (Strether) had got from them. She (Strether) desired no further news of them, and she (Strether) mentioned that Madame de Vionnet herself had, to her (Strether) knowledge, lived exempt from the information he (Vionnet) was ready to supply. She (Strether) had never consented to receive it, though she (Strether) would have taken it, under stress, from Mrs. Pocock. But it was a matter about which Mrs. Pocock appeared to have had little to say--never sounding the word--and it didn't signify now. There was nothing clearly for Maria Gostrey that signified now--save one sharp point, that is, to which she (Gostrey) came in time.
``I don't know whether it's before you as a possibility that, left to himself, Mr. Chad may after all go back. I judge that it IS more or less so before you, from what you just now said of him (Chad).'' (guest)

Her (Gostrey) guest had his (guest) eyes on her (Gostrey), kindly but attentively, as if foreseeing what was to follow this.

``I don't think it will be for the money.'' (she)
And then as she (Gostrey) seemed uncertain:
``I mean I don't believe it will be for that he (Chad)'ll give her (I) up.'' (she)

``Then he (Chad) WILL give her (I) up?'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Strether waited a moment, rather slow and deliberate now, drawing out a little this last soft stage, pleading with her (Gostrey) in various suggestive and unspoken ways for patience and understanding.

``What were you just about to ask me?'' (unknown)

``Is there anything he (Chad) can do that would make you patch it up?'' (unknown)

``With Mrs. Newsome?'' (she)

Her (Gostrey) assent, as if she (Gostrey) had had a delicacy about sounding the name, was only in her (Gostrey) face; but she (Gostrey) added with it:

``Or is there anything he (Chad) can do that would make HER try it?'' (she)

``To patch it up with me?'' (unknown)
His (Strether) answer came at last in a conclusive headshake.
``There's nothing any one can do. It's over. Over for both of us.'' (Maria/Maria Gostrey)

Maria wondered, seemed a little to doubt.

``Are you so sure for her (Newsome)?'' (unknown)

``Oh yes--sure now. Too much has happened. I'm different for her (Newsome).'' (She)

She (Maria) took it in then, drawing a deeper breath.

``I see. So that as she (Newsome)'s different for YOU--'' (he)

``Ah but,'' (he)
he (Strether) interrupted,
``she (Newsome)'s not.'' (he)
And as Miss Gostrey wondered again:
``She (Newsome)'s the same. She (Newsome)'s more than ever the same. But I do what I didn't before--I SEE her (Newsome).'' (Miss Gostrey)

He (Strether) spoke gravely and as if responsibly--since he (Strether) had to pronounce; and the effect of it was slightly solemn, so that she (Gostrey) simply exclaimed

``Oh!'' (she)
Satisfied and grateful, however, she (Gostrey) showed in her (Gostrey) own next words an acceptance of his (Strether) statement.
``What then do you go home to?'' (He)

He (Strether) had pushed his (Strether) plate a little away, occupied with another side of the matter; taking refuge verily in that side and feeling so moved that he (Strether) soon found himself on his (Strether) feet. He (Strether) was affected in advance by what he (Strether) believed might come from her (Gostrey), and he (Strether) would have liked to forestall it and deal with it tenderly; yet in the presence of it he (Strether) wished still more to be--though as smoothly as possible--deterrent and conclusive. He (Strether) put her (Gostrey) question by for the moment; he (Strether) told her (Gostrey) more about Chad.

``It would have been impossible to meet me more than he (Newsome) did last night on the question of the infamy of not sticking to her (Newsome).'' (unknown)

``Is that what you called it for him (Newsome)--`infamy'?'' (unknown)

``Oh rather! I described to him (Newsome) in detail the base creature he (Newsome)'d be, and he (Newsome) quite agrees with me about it.'' (unknown)

``So that it's really as if you had nailed him (Newsome)?'' (unknown)

``Quite really as if--! I told him (Newsome) I should curse him (Newsome).'' (unknown)

``Oh,'' (she)
she (Gostrey) smiled,
``you HAVE done it.'' (she)
And then having thought again: ``You CAN
``T after that propose--!'' (unknown)
Yet she (Gostrey) scanned his (Strether) face.

``Propose again to Mrs. Newsome?'' (She)

She (Gostrey) hesitated afresh, but she (Gostrey) brought it out.

``I've never believed, you know, that you did propose. I always believed it was really she (Newsome)--and, so far as that goes, I can understand it. What I mean is,'' (she)
she (Gostrey) explained,
``that with such a spirit--the spirit of curses!--your breach is past mending. She (Newsome) has only to know what you've done to him (You) never again to raise a finger.'' (she)

``I've done,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
said Strether,
``what I could--one can't do more. He (You) protests his (You) devotion and his (You) horror. But I'm not sure I've saved him (You). He (You) protests too much. He (You) asks how one can dream of his (You) being tired. But he (You) has all life before him (You).'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

Maria saw what he (Strether) meant.

``He (You)'s formed to please.'' (unknown)

``And it's our friend who has formed him (friend).'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
Strether felt in it the strange irony.

``So it's scarcely his (friend) fault!'' (unknown)

``It's at any rate his (friend) danger. I mean,'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)
said Strether,
``it's hers. But she (it) knows it.'' (Strether/Lambert Strether)

``Yes, she (it) knows it. And is your idea,'' (Miss Gostrey)
Miss Gostrey asked,
``that there was some other woman in London?'' (Miss Gostrey)

``Yes. No. That is I HAVE no ideas. I'm afraid of them. I've done with them.'' (he)
And he (Strether) put out his (Strether) hand to her (Gostrey).
``Good-bye.'' (unknown)

It brought her (Gostrey) back to her (Gostrey) unanswered question.

``To what do you go home?'' (unknown)

``I don't know. There will always be something.'' (unknown)

``To a great difference,'' (she)
she (Gostrey) said as she (Gostrey) kept his (Strether) hand.

``A great difference--no doubt. Yet I shall see what I can make of it.'' (unknown)

``Shall you make anything so good--?'' (Mrs. Newsome)
But, as if remembering what Mrs. Newsome had done, it was as far as she (Newsome) went.

He (Strether) had sufficiently understood.

``So good as this place at this moment? So good as what YOU make of everything you touch?'' (He)
He (Strether) took a moment to say, for, really and truly, what stood about him (Strether) there in her (Newsome) offer--which was as the offer of exquisite service, of lightened care, for the rest of his (Strether) days--might well have tempted. It built him (Strether) softly round, it roofed him (Strether) warmly over, it rested, all so firm, on selection. And what ruled selection was beauty and knowledge. It was awkward, it was almost stupid, not to seem to prize such things; yet, none the less, so far as they made his (Strether) opportunity they made it only for a moment. She (Newsome)'d moreover understand--she (Newsome) always understood.

That indeed might be, but meanwhile she (Newsome) was going on.

``There's nothing, you know, I wouldn't do for you.'' (unknown)

``Oh yes--I know.'' (unknown)

``There's nothing,'' (she)
she (Newsome) repeated,
``in all the world.'' (she)

``I know. I know. But all the same I must go.'' (He)
He (Strether) had got it at last.
``To be right.'' (unknown)

``To be right?'' (She)

She (Newsome) had echoed it in vague deprecation, but he (Strether) felt it already clear for her (Newsome).

``That, you see, is my only logic. Not, out of the whole affair, to have got anything for myself.'' (She)

She (Newsome) thought.

``But with your wonderful impressions you'll have got a great deal.'' (unknown)

``A great deal'' (he)
--he (Strether) agreed.
``But nothing like YOU. It's you who would make me wrong!'' (she)

Honest and fine, she (Newsome) couldn't greatly pretend she (Newsome) didn't see it. Still she (Newsome) could pretend just a little.

``But why should you be so dreadfully right?'' (unknown)

``That's the way that--if I must go--you yourself would be the first to want me. And I can't do anything else.'' (she)

So then she (Newsome) had to take it, though still with her (Newsome) defeated protest.

``It isn't so much your BEING `right'--it's your horrible sharp eye for what makes you so.'' (unknown)

``Oh but you're just as bad yourself. You can't resist me when I point that out.'' (She)

She (Newsome) sighed it at last all comically, all tragically, away.

``I can't indeed resist you.'' (unknown)

``Then there we are!'' (unknown)
said Strether.

End of the Project Gutenberg EBook of The Ambassadors, by Henry James
